name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the basis of the Statements of the Council and the Commission on the preparation of the Euro Area Summit (2014/2838(RSP)). Before starting the debate, I give the floor to Mr Glezos, who wishes to speak on a point of order.

name: Emmanouil GLEZOS
text: Mr President, I would like to stress to colleagues that, in addition to what is happening in plenary, there is an agonizing question that is addressed both to Parliament and to all the citizens of Europe. What Europe do we want? Do we want a People's Europe or a Europe of monopolies and capital? Do we want a Europe of citizens and popular sovereignty, or do we want a German Europe or an Atlantic Europe? We want a Europe equal to equal members, we want a Europe that is autonomous, independent, self-government and not a sub-state in the United States of America, whether commercial or military NATO. I would like to stress that in my country Greece there are NATO military bases ... (The President interrupts the speaker.)

name: Benedetto DELLA VEDOVA
text: Mr President- in-Office of the Council. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, On behalf of the Presidency, I would like to thank you for this invitation to speak briefly on the preparations for the Euro Summit, which the August European Council, in its conclusions, considered appropriate to convene this autumn to examine the economic situation.  However, I would like to be clear from the outset that a debate on the euro summit is premature. While fully respecting Parliament's assessments and the considerations that honourable Members wish to make, I would like to make it clear that the euro summit has not been formally convened and no agenda has been drawn up. A more detailed discussion on this issue could take place in October, when preparations for the European Council will be considered at a broader level. I would like to add that the preparations for the euro summits are primarily the responsibility of the President of the Euro Summit, Mr Van Rompuy, in cooperation with the President of the Commission and on the basis of the work of the Eurogroup, rather than the Italian Presidency in this case. In the light of these considerations, and I do not wish to prejudge the content of a possible agenda, I will be extremely brief. In general terms, I believe that the euro area can usefully assess the causes of the recent loss of growth momentum in a low inflation environment. It is essential that this assessment takes place at the highest level.  We must be absolutely certain that our strategy to entrench the start of the eurozone's recovery remains perfectly calibrated in order to generate growth and employment in the whole area. This must remain our main priority at every level and that is what the citizens of Europe expect and deserve. In my opinion, this means making sure that the correct policy combination is implemented in all Member States that share the single currency. We must stimulate our structural reform programme to improve our competitiveness in the global market. We need to bring our public finances back to sustainable levels in a growth-conducive manner and we need to restore confidence in the financial sector, so that it can support the real economy and facilitate investment.  Measures in all these areas are well under way in all member states of the euro area. The Italian Presidency is working hard to ensure progress in legislative activity at EU level. Many initiatives have been taken by the Eurogroup and its President, and the European Central Bank has also recently announced a package of measures in response to the wider macroeconomic environment.  When many activities are under way, it is important to take stock of the progress made on a regular basis, it is essential if we are to be sure that the road map and the strategies established remain results-oriented and forward-looking, it is essential that they continue to be adapted to the challenges we face, in particular to combat the scourge of unemployment. I am convinced that the strategy adopted for the growth of the euro area is the right one, but I also believe that room for improvement is always possible. In this budget, honourable Members' views on how best to achieve our objectives of increasing growth and employment levels are and will be very important. I am ready to listen to all your views and to take advantage of the suggestions and competence that this Parliament will always be able to express.

name: Jyrki Katainen
text: Vice-President of the Commission. - Mr President, honourable Members, thank you for giving me the opportunity today to present to you the position of the Commission on the preparation of the euro area summit to take place on 24 October 2014 on the occasion of the European Council. The preparations for the summit are still at an early stage. As such, I very much look forward to hearing your views here today on how we can work together to deliver sustainable growth, create jobs and secure the welfare of our citizens. We are currently facing formidable challenges that only serve to underline that we have to do whatever it takes to deliver robust, sustainable growth and jobs in Europe. The Commission sees three main priorities for economic policy this autumn. At the informal Ecofin Council last weekend in Milan, we had a very fruitful discussion with finance ministers on a number of key issues. Going forward will, however, require a joint commitment from the Commission, the Member States, you in Parliament and other partners regarding our shared objectives. The first priority this autumn is supporting investment. Europe has a lot to offer in terms of innovation, a skilled labour force and entrepreneurship. In order for all of this to translate into new start-ups around Europe, we need to promote investments from both public and private sources and at both national and European level. We are working on a comprehensive plan that addresses both sides of the coin. This must be a joint effort. At national level, countries with large current account surpluses should commit to investing more. In addition, all countries should prioritise investment in research and development and key infrastructures within their public spending mix. At European level, European resources, such as the European budget and the EIB, should be used in particular to leverage private investment. We need a stable and robust banking sector and well-functioning capital markets to provide accessible credit to the real economy. The second priority is stepping up reforms that unlock growth potential. Without effectively-implemented reforms, we will not have sustainable growth and job creation. It is not about choosing between supply and demand-side measures: both are needed and are complementary. Reforms are also needed to secure the sustainability of our welfare societies and ability to protect the vulnerable. No country is immune from the need to reform, although some have more pressing needs. We should use the existing economic governance framework more effectively to support the adoption of the implementation of structural reforms. Our fiscal rules do not prevent countries from reforming – far from it. There are many examples of countries that have adopted important reforms in parallel with major fiscal adjustment. Nonetheless, there is scope to use our existing economic governance framework more effectively to support countries in their reform efforts. Thirdly, we need to continue ensuring sustainable fiscal policies for the sake of confidence and future generations. Interest rates will surely not stay at record lows forever. Once they rise, public debt will become more costly, again crowding out more valuable public spending and undermining the market confidence we have all worked so hard to regain. The more vulnerable countries would unfortunately be the hardest hit by any new financial market instability. Wise choices are therefore required. The pace of fiscal consolidation has slowed significantly since the peak of the sovereign debt crisis. Now it is essential to improve the quality of public spending. When money is tight, there is little choice but to make savings, but there is always a choice as to how to make those savings. Reducing expenditure rather than raising taxes and cutting inefficient current expenditure rather than future-oriented investments can ensure that consolidation is growth-friendly, fair and supportive of growth creation. A more efficient and citizen-oriented public administration can especially benefit those in need of social support but also promote job creation by enabling a better investment climate. As stated by the Euro Group last weekend, more efforts are needed to reduce the tax burden on labour. At the same time, we need to ask ourselves what is holding back private investment in Europe. We need to ensure that the business climate, our internal market and the regulatory environment are favourable to companies investing in the future: innovating, developing new markets and creating jobs. This ties in with my report on reforms. There is plenty of growth potential in Europe that is today held back by rigidities and vested interests. In some Member States, starting a business means weeks of cumbersome bureaucratic hurdles. Overly-complex tax systems in some Member States have contributed to a sizeable grey economy. Reforms are needed to deal with these obstacles. This inevitably means changes that require not only thinking outside the box but also stepping out of our comfort zone. Europe continues to face great challenges. While there is no silver bullet, I am confident that we can find new sources for growth and to enable us to work together in a spirit of mutual trust. Major joint efforts are needed to deliver sustainable economic growth. At the end of the day, we all share the same objective. Let us not lose sight of that objective.

name: Burkhard BALZ
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, I would like to thank the At the last summit, the Eurogroup made a clear statement on the Stability and Growth Pact. As the European People's Party, we naturally warmly welcome this commitment.  Some Member States are now calling for flexibility. I think that this is also possible, but it is limited to the existing rules. In other words, flexibility can only be granted in exceptional circumstances. Wherever flexibility is built into the Treaties, it is always conditional, namely structural reforms that need to be actively promoted, and not just promises of reform, the implementation of which is slow. This applies to both large and small Member States. The Member States cannot turn a blind eye to the need for further reform efforts. The country-specific recommendations of the Commission and the Council of Ministers build on a comprehensive analysis of what needs to be done urgently, and these recommendations need to be implemented. Reforms are the basis for investment falling on fertile ground and sustainable growth at the end of the day. The consistent application of the six-pack and the two-pack is an integral part of a policy that stands for accountability towards our citizens and, above all, towards future generations. Economic history has proven to us on several occasions that growth on the pump cannot be successful in the long term. The mistakes of the past must therefore not be repeated. Because growth is different.  As the European People's Party, we do not want a grip on the debt coffers. Rather, we are committed to an overall package of measures based on efficient use of funds, reducing investment hurdles, strengthening the competitiveness of our industry and our businesses in Europe and giving our citizens an economically viable future. As the European Parliament, we, as co-legislators, will certainly shape these European initiatives forcefully in the future. Europe has a role to play in maintaining stability and, above all, for greater growth and sustainability. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". These were fine words. That sounds wonderful to what you say. You are calling for flexibility for the debt countries, you are saying 'no grip on the debt fund', you are calling for reforms. I wonder a little bit which planet you live on. We can see that the measures that have been taken or are not being taken are grotesquely failing in all the countries in crisis. Contrary to what the Commissioner has just said, the debt crisis is, of course, not over at all. I would like to ask you: where do you see the success of the measures that are now being mentioned here? How long should we play this game?

name: Burkhard BALZ
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. If you had listened correctly, Mrs von Storch, you would have understood me correctly. That is a fundamental problem. (Interjections) We want to discuss this with each other. I believe that I have made it very clear that flexibility is possible, but only within the limits of what is set out. In this respect, I have no problem at all with us applying this here, but the existing rules must apply. Of course, we do not live on another planet, but we strive every day. I would be pleased if other parties, other groups in this House, were to go in a similar direction, to launch initiatives on a daily basis with which we can create more growth, with which we can generate investment in Europe. If you say that all this is not fruitful: yes, there are still major problems in Europe. But we must also acknowledge one thing, namely that in some areas – where it has been very difficult in recent years – we already have at least delicate plants that give cause for hope.

name: Maria João RODRIGUES
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, I believe, and my group believes, Mr Katainen, that Europe can become a continent with future-oriented prosperity and new growth as new competitive assets, and more and better jobs, together with social cohesion. We believe that we can have this continent. Nevertheless, the situation today is one of mediocrity, very low growth, stagnation and even the risk of deflation, as you know. We are losing a lot of good jobs, our unemployment is too high and our poverty rate is also too high. So there is a big problem here, and we should not hide from this. We were elected to ensure real change in Europe. We were elected to make sure that our top priority would be growth, investment and job creation. But we really want real solutions. So far the solutions proposed by the Commission are not working: this is very clear. You are putting your main focus on structural reforms, and particularly on the reform of the labour market. We believe that we need reforms, but not only in the labour market: also in the education system and in the innovation system. Many other changes need to be introduced; but much more than that, we need to have a monetary policy supporting growth and a coordinated economic policy supporting demand, and above all we need to have much more forward-looking investment. This means having an active EIB and also economic and monetary union which is completed with a banking union, fiscal capacity and a sensible fiscal discipline.

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take back from the ECR Group. Mr President, Commissioner Katainen, I would like to thank the commissioner for his excellent work and for the work she has I have to say that I was really shocked, shocked to hear you say here: how you read generalities from a paper, generalities that cannot be empty in terms of content. You want to have everything at the same time and you do not want to be bothered by the contradictions of what you are saying here. You want to have large investment programs, and at the same time you want fiscal consolidation. They want to reduce debt while lowering taxes. You want to have a supply policy, and at the same time you want to have a demand policy. You do not see any concept, but that at the same time you want everything is nothing more than an expression of the helplessness with which you have faced us here as a candidate for the most important economic policy commissioner. I would now like to comment briefly on the apparently growing pressure on the public authorities to use large investment programmes to combat the perceived weakness in investment in the euro area. I would like to remind you that the euro area has come into crisis because, as interest rates in the southern European countries have fallen after the introduction of the euro, the public authorities and private entrepreneurs have felt compelled to make investments on far too large scale, to make investments that were not profitable to make investments that did not yield any returns.  Today, interest rates are many times lower. If private investors are now shying away from investing, they do so because it seems that the earnings prospects for these investments are not there. If private entrepreneurs do not invest because they do not see the returns guaranteed, then we have to ask about the causes. And it was explicitly stated in the opening statement that these issues should be decided at the highest level. The highest level, I would like to say, should be set up professionally. I would like to remind you of the Lindauer Nobel Laureate meeting, where the highest capacities at the economic level have clearly stated that the eurozone will not emerge from its crisis as long as the euro exists.

name: Bill ETHERIDGE
text: blue-card question to Maria João Rodrigues. – I wanted to compliment you on your very fine words and aspirations. I actually share many of them myself, and I thought it was a very good and noble speech. What I am interested in is the way you intend to achieve it. Do you not agree that the best way to achieve these goals is to free people’s spirit and entrepreneurial skills, let people work freely, free of tax burdens and overregulation and too much state, and allow people to achieve these things for themselves through freedom? Then we can achieve our shared aims?

name: Maria João RODRIGUES
text: blue-card answer to Bill Etheridge. – I must say that of course we support entrepreneurship as a main trend which can bring more jobs and growth to Europe. We differ completely from your viewpoint because we think that markets should be regulated in order to ensure the best standards. But there is also another big difference, namely that, in our opinion, to go back to growth and jobs does not mean getting rid of the euro. On the contrary, we need to complete the Economic and Monetary Union in order to give all Member States the opportunity to go back to growth and to reduce these economic and social divergences we have. We need a proper banking union, more coordination in the euro area and a proper social dimension in the euro area. Finally we need to have a sensible fiscal discipline which can create room for manoeuvre for investments.  So I think we have quite different views about how to create the conditions for real growth and jobs in Europe.

name: Petr JEŽEK
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, I am not going to ask for a blue-card question. I would like instead to point out some areas that are crucial in this debate. On Monday you will have noticed that the OECD changed its forecast for the eurozone, cutting the growth forecast for this year to less than one percentage point – to just 0.8% – and we have seen countries in the eurozone having to implement incredibly difficult austerity measures, for example Ireland, Greece and Portugal. The effect of the measures on citizens in these countries is all too plain to see. There have been worrying developments lately in some larger eurozone economies, with France and Italy pushing for more flexibility in their fiscal rules and for their economies as their economies get into difficulty. Therefore, I would like to ask: is it the case that the EU fiscal rules are to be followed strictly by relatively small economies whereas they can suddenly be interpreted in a more flexible way when larger countries threaten to flout them, or will the Commission interpret the rules strictly no matter which countries are involved? To my mind, it is also crucial for the eurozone’s credibility among non-eurozone countries that the same clear rules apply to all eurozone Member States. It is clear too that eurozone decisions inevitably have an impact on non-eurozone countries. My question therefore is: how will you make sure that the eurozone does not act as an isolated bloc? How can you ensure that the eurozone Member States consider the consequences of their decisions on non-euro countries?

name: Marisa MATIAS
text: gue/NGL Group. " Mr President, everything must change so that everything is as it is. Tomasi di Lampedusa's phrase could be the motto of the European institutions. The obsession with austerity and what happens here as structural reforms is racking up defeats after defeats, causing economic catastrophe and leaving the Eurozone on the brink of disaggregation.  Here we talk about investment, job creation, growth, but what do they actually propose as an alternative? Alternatively, more austerity and structural reforms are proposed. But now they decide to give it a new name: it's growth-friendly fiscal consolidation or job-friendly fiscal consolidation. Really how does this employment-friendly fiscal consolidation differ from recession-friendly fiscal consolidation? Nothing at all! Nothing but the name.  Apparently, here in the European institutions, it is believed that changing the name to things changes policy, that no one will notice that the results are catastrophic and disastrous. But that's not the truth. That is not the truth and we are getting worse and with worse economic results.  I know that the fanatics of European eurocracy think that the labour market has to be completely deregulated and that public services have to be privatised to the last, and they think that people have patience for all this, but they are wrong. People are losing patience. There is no patience in European citizens. And if you keep this up, you're really going to have to find another continent to continue to do your experiments.

name: Philippe LAMBERTS
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Mr President, the first thing that strikes me, Gentlemen of the Council and the Commission, is a kind of lack of sense of urgency.  We have 27 or 28 million unemployed, we have a quarter of our population that is on or below poverty or social exclusion and it is not yet clear whether this summit will meet. It is not yet clear with which agenda... I sometimes wonder if we live in the same world. So there is an urgency and what I hear from you, Mr Katainen, is essentially a speech that I have been hearing for two, three, four years, namely structural reforms, structural reforms, structural reforms... And by that, you mean, essentially, reducing public spending and reducing the cost of labour.  I will not tell you anything by telling you that these structural reforms have the direct impact of reaching the most fragile in the population rather than the well-off. We Greens are in favour of fundamental structural reforms but not the same as yours! Not the same as yours because, for us, we share your desire to invest but, for us, we must invest to make Europe the most energy-efficient continent, the most resource-efficient and this is a complete transformation of our economy.  So you're going to ask me how do we mobilize investment? There are ways. There are simple ways but you have to give yourself the will to use them.  First way: these are rules, binding targets. You will have to debate in the Commission and the Council binding targets on climate, energy efficiency and resource efficiency. It is by setting binding targets that things move. It is not only the Greens who say that, it is the companies that work in that sector that say so. No binding targets, no investments. It's as simple as that. The second way is that if there is a structural reform to be done, it is to overhaul our tax systems. You will tell me that it is for the Member States. No, we have to do it together. Today, our tax systems are socially unjust, economically counterproductive and environmentally destructive. It is an overhaul of our taxation that needs to be done, and now I know there is the unanimity rule, but we cannot go on like this. If you want a tax system that encourages investment, you have to change it profoundly. Last thing I want to tell you is that as long as the "casino economy" business remains open, don't expect the liquidity that all the central banks in the world put into the financial system to end up in the economy. The Bank of England has been flooding the UK with liquidity for years, with the European Central Bank with a little less enthusiasm. Where is that cash today? They finance bubbles on the price of assets, whether it is real estate assets, whether they are personal assets. This liquidity is not invested in the economy. Because obviously as long as it is easy to make a profit without working, by speculating, you, as so-called financial investors, are not going to invest in the real economy because it is difficult, because it involves taking risks, risks that will not be carried by the taxpayer. These are the structural reforms we want. We are a proponent of structural reforms, but not the ones you are proposing. (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation))

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: question posed by raising the blue card. – Mr President, thank you for mr Lamberts' very fiery speech. Since I teach at university, I would like to ask him one question: whether he can explain to me how investing in energy will ensure the prosperity of the euro area. Briefly, clearly, on three points.

name: Philippe LAMBERTS
text: "blue card" answer. "Dear Sir, I am not your student and, if you may be in academia, I have spent twenty-two years in business, it is my only title of professional glory other than to have served a little in this Parliament.  It will not escape you, as Mr Katainen said, that an investment-based economy is one that creates more prosperity than an economy based on mere consumption. Quite simply, because when you invest, when you try to position yourself at the forefront of innovation, and here in particular in the energy field, well you put yourself in a position to create added value but also competitively you are ahead of other parts of the planet.  This means that, when inevitably we have to reduce our energy consumption or our consumption of resources, I would prefer that it be Europe that sells its solutions abroad rather than Europe having to buy the solutions and technology that goes with it to China, Brazil or the United States.  It is as you wish, but if you prefer to favour the economy through speculation and consumption, I am very concerned that Europe will plunge deeper into the doldrums. (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation))

name: Jean-Luc SCHAFFHAUSER
text: "blue card" question. Mr Lamberts, I obviously agree with what you said about the green economy and sustainable development. The only question I ask myself and I would like to ask you is: is this possible without changing the policy of the European Central Bank? Shouldn't quantitative easing or monetary creation be done for the real economy? Not so that it goes only to the banks, but so that, in fact, there is a major investment programme proposed by the Commission. The only question I have is how it will fund it.  So I think that without monetary creation, without quantitative easing at least 300-400 billion in sustainable development, that will not be possible.

name: Philippe LAMBERTS
text: "blue card" answer. Mr. Schaffhauser, the question you are asking is a well-founded question. To some extent, what we are seeing is already a more modest form of quantitative easing in continental Europe than we see in the United Kingdom. That cash must be made available, yes, but remember that these are loans that will have to be repaid. Of course, investments have to be profitable. What I am observing is that, in reality, Europe does not suffer from a lack of available capital. The problem is a problem of allocating that capital. This capital is not invested where it should be invested. In other words, it goes more into speculation, especially real estate - you see it in Paris, London, Brussels and elsewhere - and in equity markets.  In our view, therefore, it would be more a matter of redirecting available liquidity where it can be invested productively rather than always adding additional liquidity. So, obviously how much? That's to be examined. But let us ask ourselves the question of the allocation of resources before we always want to create additional resources.  Today, Europe is a rich continent, let us not forget, simply its capital is allocated in a completely suboptimal way.

name: Marco VALLI
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, what Commissioner Katainen said, namely that we need to consolidate our banking system, presents me with criticism, because it seems that we are giving a lot of liquidity to the banks. In recent years we have been doing the operation through the ECB of long-term refinancing, we have given a lot of billions, but no loan constraints from the real economy.  Now they have been announced by the ECB – I am sorry there is no Draghi here to talk about this – about possible transactions with a target on these long-term refinancing operations. What's the problem? It is that by going to read the modalities of these operations, there is no real constraint, because if you read the technical document well instead of making announcements there are no real loan constraints from the real economy.  We would therefore like, as Mrs Lambert said, a clearer and firmer position in regulating the financial sector, because if we lend money to the banks or give the banks the opportunity to obtain liquidity, but we do not give them loan constraints from the real economy, we will not be able to revive our economies and emerge from this crisis.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, you are here to prepare yet another summit at the request of France, but what is it for? In terms of economic results, experience shows us that this summit will end like the others, flat! Or if I dare say, hollow!  Indeed, since May 2010, the beginning of the eurozone crisis, you have tried to save the private banking system and your golden calf, the euro single currency, massive stimulus plans to stimulate economic activity, draconian austerity for the devaluation of wages, pensions and social insecurity - the troika has even gone so far as to commit a hold-up on Cypriot deposits in April 2013 , not to mention the re-establishment of capital controls at The borders of Cyprus, which proves that the currency area is not optimal.  How many eurozone summits and even the G20 will be needed to finally understand that the eurozone is the zero zone! Zero economic growth, zero employment, zero competitiveness except for Germany, zero increase in purchasing power. On the other hand, it is the dizzying increase in deficits and public debts. Despite all the gifts made by governments and the ECB to listed companies and private banks, economic growth is completely sluggish and competitiveness is still not there. Your ultra-liberal Europe is falling out. The other paradox is that Mr Juncker has appointed the least virtuous Eurogroup economic ministers, Mr Moscovici, as Commissioner in charge of the least virtuous deficits. When will you understand that the euro single currency is a monetary aberration that goes against the other 180 countries in the world that each have their own national currency, their central bank and their borders.  In France, the introduction of the euro coincided exactly with the reversal of the trade balance, which has become structurally in deficit; a French external deficit that beats its all-time high last July since we reached 85 billion euros at an annualized rate. With regard to debt, it has doubled since 2003, reaching more than 2 trillion euros at the end of 2014 in France.  You are so desperate for the crushing failure of the euro single currency and the breakdown of your economic system that you are asking Member States to falsify the calculation of GDP by integrating the criminal economy, i.e. prostitution, drug trafficking and smuggling. That's it, the euro will not lead to recovery but will lead to a re-crisis! (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation)

name: Marcus PRETZELL
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Mr Monot, I would like to thank Mr Monot for his You spoke of ultra-liberal Europe. I wonder in which Europe you live in. I see an ultra-socialist Europe, a Europe in which debts are communitised, in which we talk about communitising unemployment insurance and much more nonsense, which is still to be driven. Please explain to me: what is liberal about this Europe? If it were liberal, I would be the biggest fan of it!

name: Bernard MONOT
text: "blue card" answer. "Sir, Europe is not liberal, it is ultraliberal, as is the whole global economic model imposed on us by the Anglo-Saxon system. Obviously, we are for liberalism at the national level and we are in for protectionism at the international level. But where do you see today that people are happy to live in this Europe, the Europe of unemployment, the Europe of precariousness and the fall of purchasing power? Is that your business model?   (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation))

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: Question put in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure. – Sir, I have heard from you describing a Europe that you do not like. Europe's responsibility is ours, everyone's: the European Parliament, the Commission, the Council. My question is: what is the proposal? Because criticism is the simplest. I didn't hear a solution.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: "blue card" answer. To answer your question, Madam Member, indeed, what we want is a Europe of nations, a Europe that creates wealth for peoples and not wealth for multinationals and private banking systems. We want a Europe that makes people happy.  What we are proposing is quite simple, the same solution as the major economic powers of the world, the United States, England, Japan and China, which use their national currency, monetary and exchange rate policies, use their borders and have central banks.  We ask for the same advantages and the same solutions and therefore, the return and transition to the national currency with possibly a common euro currency.  These are the solutions to restore equality to citizens and restore prosperity to people.

name: Brian HAYES
text: Mr President, I do not have the same pessimistic and negative view as the previous speaker in terms of the future of the euro. I believe that the euro will succeed and that what is essential at this particular time is to do two things for the eurozone economy, and especially for the 28 Member States of the European Union. We must stick to the targets we have set in terms of stabilising the eurozone system, and it is crucially important that we continue to reduce deficits no matter where they are across the system. I come from a country that has seen enormous reductions in the amount of available expenditure and increases in tax because of the financial crisis, yet in Ireland the GDP growth is at one of the highest levels across the eurozone system. So even countries that go through enormous adjustments can actually have a much more competitive and productive model of economic growth into the future, if that is pursued.  We need to do three things. Firstly, I believe it is crucially important that we continue to reduce tax on work within the European Union. It is a madness policy. If you have 11% unemployment and you continue to tax people out of existence, that makes no sense. Secondly, we need to get business lending going again. It is crucially important – in a situation in which investment has been reduced by 20% in Europe in the last five years, according to Mario Draghi – that we get business investment going again. In Ireland in the last quarter, 50% of businesses were declined business lending opportunity from banks. That has to change. Thirdly, I very much agree with the Commission proposal in terms of capital market unity right the way across Europe. It is very important that we get on with that task, Commissioner, ensuring that new funding opportunities are provided in non-bank ways.  I shall leave with one more remark. 60% of the new jobs created in the USA since the start of this crisis came from businesses that had not even been created before 2008. The future for the eurozone system and the future for Europe is based on strong development and growth.

name: Udo BULLMANN
text: Mr. President, dear colleagues! The Commission tells us that it does not have a silver bullet. We know that, but you have told us many times. Commissioner, having no silver bullet does not explain why you are shooting in the wrong direction for more than five years. The Commission must tell us how it intends to deal with what is general economic expertise. In an internal market, in a monetary union, the more the Member States involved move in the same direction, the stronger the economic response. That is a general finding. Now you have explained to us for five years how to cut budgets together. When do you start explaining to us how to invest together? It is right to talk about investment today. Finally, the Commission has arrived that Europe has an investment gap. But when do you tell the Member States what a straight forward movement might look like so that we can achieve European added value in investment as a whole?  These are the important issues. Nobody understands us. The United States does not understand us, the Chinese do not understand us, the Latin Americans do not understand what we are doing, not even Frankfurt, the ECB, understands us. That is why Mr Draghi must give birth once again to a creative solution and be courageous in saving the eurozone. I would ask the Presidency of the Council to include this aspect of the same investment in the joint preparation of the relevant summit activities. It is high time that we did that. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: the blue card. " I represent a country where the euro will soon be introduced as early as 1 January. As we know, countries wishing to adopt the euro must meet the Maastricht criteria. However, there is no criterion such as ensuring a minimum income among those criteria. I think that perhaps it would be right to set a transitional period in order to make the state more concerned with the population, the people and the country more united. How do you think? (The language was interrupted.)

name: Udo BULLMANN
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Mr President, I would like to thank the Nevertheless, I am prepared to answer the honourable Member's question. If we allow so many blue cards here – one can consider whether this makes sense or not – then I would also like to include his very legitimate question. The honourable Member is, of course, right: it would be much better if we were to live in a Europe where we would have firm agreements on the fact that there is a decent minimum wage in every country, a reasonable minimum wage, which ensures that every worker can live on what he is working on and is not dependent on additional aid. My group, the S&D Group, is fighting for this. We can only pass on the appeal made by our colleague to the Commission and the Council to make a proposal to this end. This can be agreed tomorrow morning with a handshake. I am very much in favour of us moving forward with this development.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Commissioner, from what you have said, it seems that neither you nor the Commission have drawn any important conclusions as to why we have reached this situation. Why there is no growth in the European Union. Why there are millions unemployed. And you have to think about whether the model used by the European Union to get out of the economic crisis was the right thing to do. And it was not the right thing to do, because the model you used, namely austerity and deflation, had negative results: Europe was full of unemployed people. Secondly, the competitiveness model that you are promoting is a model based on the euro pact. In other words, the reduction in wages, i.e. competitiveness linked to the 'Chinese' wage in Europe. The opposite must be done! Investments need to be made! Investment must be made in technology, in the economy and, above all, in education.  But you cannot do that, because when you have a tough fiscal policy, it is essentially forbidden. And you are creating huge problems, especially in the countries of the South, such as Greece, where your policy is disastrous: 1.5 million unemployed, thousands of poor Greeks, thousands of closed shops, and all this as a result of your own policy, the Troika policy which has destroyed the Greek economy. So you have to draw the necessary conclusions and change policy, because as long as this situation continues we cannot really have a serious future. That is the reality, and you and the Troika should also take responsibility for your disastrous policy in Greece and the other countries of the Memorandum. [applause] (The speaker agrees to answer a question with a blue card (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Liisa JAAKONSAARI
text: blue card question. – The ECR is parliament's third largest group at the moment, so it would be great if, with this mandate from the citizens, you were to put forward something, but I just heard a rather dramatic description of the situation. I did not hear the first thought of how to move forward from this. So I ask you, what is the main proposal from your group? How can employment and growth be achieved?

name: Notis MARIAS
text: "blue card" answer. Mr President, the Group's proposal has been analysed by Both Mr Lucke and others. The basic concept is that with this policy of austerity that the European Central Bank and the European Union are currently pursuing, there can be no way out: we cannot have a Europe filled with the unemployed, we cannot have a Europe in which banks are profiting, we cannot have a Europe where liquidity does not go to the real economy. , we cannot have a Europe that oppresses the peoples of the South, a Europe which at the moment has broken up the whole economy in the South and is full of unemployed people. We need a different Europe, a Europe of nation-states, which can really give way to this situation, and not a Central Europe, a Europe that oppresses its own peoples.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: Mr Guerrero, do you wish to intervene on a point of order?

name: Enrique GUERRERO SALOM
text: Mr President, the use of the blue card is a right for the Member to ask a question to an earlier person. I therefore do not raise the absence of that right. What I raise is prudence in its use. Because, if blue cards accumulate, first, the distribution of time granted to political groups is being altered and, secondly, the capacity of Members who did not have time from their group and who came here at the beginning of the session and asked to intervene in the catch the eye is being reduced. I therefore ask the presidency to be extremely cautious and restrictive in the use of the blue card.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: Mr Guerrero, we are extreme prudence from this Presidency to such an extent that only two blue cards have been accepted in this debate on a single occasion. You will understand, therefore, that we are trying by all means to save time for your time to be yours and not anyone else's.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: Gentlemen of the Council and the Commission, you have come empty-handed! Gentlemen of the Italian Presidency, where is the shift to growth and the changes that Mr Renzi promised us here in June? Mr Katainen, where is the EUR 300 billion programme of private and public investment that Mr Juncker has told us? You have not been able to tell us when the development summit will take place and, at the same time, Mrs Merkel's economic orthodoxy is being questioned even by her own people. Mr Draghi is taking quantitative easing measures, timidly and belatedly, despite the obstacles put in place by Mr Schäuble. Even the OECD of the neoliberal Mr Guria tells you stop with this disastrous policy, take measures of quantitative easing and a shift in growth. France unilaterally announces that after two years it will comply with the requirements of the Stability Pact and you are telling us unbearable boring generalities, at a time when there is very high unemployment, 30% in my country, Greece – 60% youth unemployment – at a time when the euro area is facing a new recession and the risk of deflation. We expect answers from you and not generalities. Do not make fun of the European Parliament.

name: Sven GIEGOLD
text: Mr President, mr Katainen, mr Katainen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for his excellent work and for his excellent work. I must say that I was disappointed by the start of this discussion in that we have seen a marked deterioration in the economic situation over the summer and we see again that the euro is not well managed and functioning at the moment. This means that we have seen over the summer that the ECB has jumped back into the breach; it has taken measures to try to prevent further disintegration. But for the past two years we have had the proposals of the four Presidents for better governance of the euro area, for greater integration, for democratic legitimacy, and also for the coordination of the various policy areas. I have not heard of this here. Instead, we have a logic of shift on the agenda.  We had a summit immediately after the summer, when we talked about personnel and foreign policy. Now there should be this great summit in October. They could not even tell us when the next one would take place, in a situation where the economic measures are so bad. This won't do. Take your responsibilities and implement the long-drawn-out plans to really achieve the level of cooperation we need in the eurozone. Then the euro will work well. You did not present this today, but you repeated your old programmes.

name: Patrick O'FLYNN
text: Mr President, the euro may not have collapsed, but it certainly has failed. The basic test of any economic policy is whether it produces employment, growth and prosperity, and the euro has failed on all counts. For example, the economy of Italy – a country famous for the flair of its people in design, cuisine, fashion, automotive industry and much else besides – is barely any bigger now than it was when the euro was born. It has been not just a lost decade, but already a lost decade and a half. We know, and you know, Mr Katainen, why this is happening. The economies of southern Europe are on a lower long-term productivity path than is Germany. In order to protect economic activity levels, they need to have their own currencies to gently depreciate against Germany over time. They need to be able to set their own interest rates too. Either that, or they will need large and permanent transfer payments. However, you do not have the social solidarity across the eurozone to make that tenable. These countries need economic self-determination. You have locked them into deflation. Shame on you!

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I wanted to address Commissioner Katainen because from what he says... Perhaps he is used to talking to his countrymen, let me give you an example, a well-known Finnish Formula One driver, it seems to me that it is called – excuse the pronunciation – Raikkonen or something, which earns millions of euros. Because you're not coming with me, I'm the mayor of a town in Valsesia, Borgosesia. I get every Saturday morning, when there's the city market. In the square I put a table and two chairs and receive people. Out of a hundred people I see, ninety people ask me for work and money, because this Europe has slaughtered people. You talk... He's got all his own, let's say, hairstyle – I say a little jokingly, it looks like he licked a cow. Come to me on Saturday morning and you will see that your hair would come like the son of the Mayor of New York, Dante De Blasio, because you would have a head like this, because you do not put yourself before and do not talk to ordinary people, you only talk to the great bureaucrats, to the big banks that have massacred the country. The banks take the money to zero, practically, and resell it 10, 15% to entrepreneurs and families, that is the shame of this Europe, and you continue to go on this front. And instead of coming to Italy to give us lessons... (The President withdrew the speaker from the floor.)

name: Georgios KYRTSOS
text: Mr President, I think that reforms are necessary because without reforms the European Union will be economically defeated by the United States, China and other strong competitors. I also think that budgetary rigour is necessary, because otherwise we will fall into a debt black hole, and we in Greece are now paying not so much for the difficult policy of the memorandum as for the mistakes we made in the previous decade 2000-2009, which instead of preparing for additional competition within EMU - such as, for example, our German friends had 'Agenda 2010' - we made benefits and we missed financial management. But it takes an additional effort, a creative thought, to complement the core of the policy that is basically right. We need, first of all, to clarify exactly what we want. How strong do we want the euro? Do we want inflation close to 0% or inflation close to 2%? Do we want liquidity, do we want quantitative easing or do we want monetary orthodoxy? I think we're going to make it, but we have to try, there's no automation that solves the problem. Finally, I would like to protest against various Eurosceptics, particularly the Germans, who are criticising Greece and calling for the South to be abandoned. Don't they understand that if we fall into a black debt well, we're going to lure the German taxpayers, whom they're supposed to represent?

name: Elisa FERREIRA
text: Mr President, Commissioner, today there is no doubt that the European Union has followed a dogmatic and synchronised austerity policy, and this policy has caused a recession, and the recession has followed, and deflation and stagnation is following.  Six years after the 2008 crisis, the miracle did not occur. On the contrary, unemployment, recession and poverty have worsened, especially in some economies that are increasingly far from central economies. The crisis today is no longer global. The United States, which was the epicenter of the crisis, came out of it. The crisis today is European and is a consequence of the policy options we have been following. Today we are also in a situation of urgency, urgency in changing these policies. The European Central Bank has exhausted the instruments at its disposal, but liquidity cannot be turned into credit to companies if the recession kills business opportunities. The new President of the Commission was elected with the promise of this change, a new beginning, a hope that words will turn into acts, as has not happened so far, and we continue to repeat the same words.  Unfortunately, the new architecture proposed for the Commission and some of its interpreters do not allow us to trust that this promised change will materialise. We hope that clarification, before and during the hearings, will allow us to trust that the project is different again, and we also hope that the next Eurozone summit will not escape reality: reality is an emergency situation and action must be urgent and not be confused with always equal words...

name: Marco ZANNI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in Italy those who criticise the Renzi government for its lack of growth are referred to as 'owls'. Here in Europe you, Mr Katainen, are referred to as the 'hawk' of rigour. So politics likes to make these comparisons to the animal world. I would therefore like to make one myself, saying that you are treating the citizens of Europe as lambs for slaughter, sacrificed on the altar of your absurd economic approaches. When will you find that what has been done so far has been unsuccessful and disastrous? When will you realise that you are not coming out of the crisis by giving three thousand billion to the banks and doing nothing for businesses and citizens? When will you find that, in order to get this Europe out of the crisis, the watchword must not be fiscal rigour, but solidarity? I want to close with a tip. The next eurozone summit will do so in the suburbs of European cities, among the desperate who no longer own a job, more a home, to whom you have stolen hope. Talk to them, every week, face to face like I do every week. Go home, look in the mirror and ask yourself: are we doing the right thing?

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: Mr President, I would remind you that I have made a request to your Bureau for intervention on a serious point of order and I expect, in the course of the procedure, to take the floor. I return to the subject of the debate: Just before the eurozone summit, the Expectations of the European Union, even for anemic growth, turned into a fear of a new round of deeper capitalist crisis. The concerns of all parties bowing to the European Union and capitalist growth, about some relaxation of fiscal policy with an expansionary strategy, do not negate the statement of one of its rapporteurs, the President of the European Central Bank, Mr Draghi, who said that the relaxation would not affect the iron budgetary discipline, the European Union's memorandums of duration. Lower interest rates, the bond market, government subsidies and capital tax exemptions will not address unemployment, they will not benefit workers but only capitalist profits. Because this growth is based precisely on unemployment, poverty, the demolition of labour conquests, social security, health and education rights. The crumb measures on extreme poverty, which are being wiped out by wildly unpopular taxation, not only do not solve but, in fact, push the general level of wages and pensions into a general poverty line by abolishing collective labour agreements. Youth employment programmes generalise temporary, flexible employment without rights. No measure can save this system that has rots and only gives unemployment, poverty and wars. The only guarantee for workers to meet their real needs for development for their benefit is to overthrow this system and its policy.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: Mr President, I would like to greet the Representative of the Council. I would also like to greet the Commission. And I would first like to say that there is no doubt that we are always defending it, but that at this time it is necessary to give this start of the new Commission an absolute priority to growth and job creation policies. And that, of course, this must be taken into account by all the countries of the European Union, but in particular by those in the Eurozone, where the need to support growth and jobs and to make this priority a practical political reality is actually clearer in the Eurozone than in other countries of the European Union.  In any case, I think it is also essential, first of all, not to give in to the demagoguery that has just been done here in this Plenary, to say that everything behind it is wrong, to try to demonise, moreover, the new Commission itself, which results from the vote of the voters, whether at European level or at national level, and the vote of the voters must be respected , because it is essential to understand the following: without sound public finances and structural reforms in many of the eurozone countries, no more money we use for job creation or that we use for growth policies, it will eventually be thrown away because it will not be taken advantage of, and we have a responsibility to think that growth policies and employment policies also have to be , of course, be in line with structural reform policies and sound public finance policies.

name: Roberto GUALTIERI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, it seems to me that, under the blows of the crisis, what we might call a Jackson Hole Consensus is laboriously emerging, namely that we must overcome the one-dimensional approaches of the past and instead build a set of policies that must be structural, but also monetary and fiscal. In this respect, I welcome the fact that Commissioner Katainen has recognised that reforms are needed, but also investment, and that there is a deficit in competitiveness, but also in aggregate demand. But words are not enough, of course. In order to be credible, we must quickly define concrete responses that are consistent with this analysis, and that is why we will monitor and be particularly rigorous on investment. We need the details of Juncker's three hundred billion plan, and we need to be consistent with what you too, Mr Katainen, have said: private but also public investment, national but also European investment. So fresh money and effective leverage capacity in the markets. And then fiscal policies. The issue of flexibility. Flexibility is not an exception to the rule, flexibility is part of the rule. On the contrary, the rules require the use of flexibility to avoid pro-cyclical policies under conditions such as these. So the issue is that of correcting the fiscal position of the eurozone, not of some countries, which is consistent with the objective of growth and which favours those structural reforms that alone, without a coherent fiscal policy, are more difficult and less effective.

name: Steven WOOLFE
text: Mr President, as we prepare for the eurozone summit, I think it ought to be reminding this House of some of the statistics that the politicians and Commissioners and the senior people will be looking at on that day. GDP across Europe is 0.1 %; the share of world GDP is falling year on year. Unemployment sits around 11.5 % for the peoples of Europe. In countries like Croatia it is 17 %, 15 % in Portugal; in Spain it is 23 % and in Greece it is 25 %. That is very good news for those people, is it not, when they know people will be sitting in large cars drinking champagne and working out how they are going to make their jobs better? I hear one of their supporters over there now. We also look at labour costs rising; unemployment rising; private investment falling. I say to you, ladies and gentlemen and Members of this House: if it looks like a failure, it is a failure. If it smells like a failure, it is a failure. But all they will do at this summit is say: ah, the sweet smell of success!

name: Othmar KARAS
text: Mr. President, ladies and gentlemen! First of all, I am somewhat shocked by the poor preparation of this debate. We do not even know a date for the summit and are therefore discussing it very generally today. We need to be much more specific. We need to define projects and debate them. I would also ask you not to reduce the euro area to itself, but the euro area must become the engine for the internal market. What are our goals? Sustainable stabilisation of the banking sector, implementation of coordination decisions, increased competitiveness, growth, employment and investment. We are looking forward to proposals on how you will implement the decisions and how we will achieve these improvements. What are the necessary measures? Structures must be further reformed, in education, growth, research and the Energy Union is to invest, the internal market blockades must be eliminated, and the budgets are made fit for the future. We must first implement the banking union, we must first give teeth to the European Semester. We must implement this House's Troika report in the euro area in concrete terms of democratic legitimacy, control and respect for fundamental social rights. We must comply with Community law in every measure. And we should finally put an end to the mourning of the financial transaction tax by agreeing in the Council to implement the common objectives. Parliament's proposal is on the table.

name: Pervenche BERÈS
text: Mr President, Commissioner, the world is moving and Europe is sinking into deflation, in the absence of growth, and you are not moving! The central bank has moved. Mr Mario Draghi, whom we would have liked to have been with us this morning, in his speech in Jackson Hole, has in some way drawn up a record of the Commission to which you belong, questioning it on its ability to mobilise aggregate demand. What do you say to us? That more structural reforms are needed without ever understanding that well-understood structural reform is also one that sustains human capital.  We're calling on you, Mr. Katainen. How are you going to prepare for the much-needed eurozone summit to take account of the new situation, particularly illustrated by the OECD figures? When are you going to move in order to mobilise this capacity of strong domestic demand, of a global demand from the European Union? When are you going to move in order to implement this 300 billion euro plan that we are promised and which must spearhead a resumption of activity in our European Union, in the euro area, as a priority, to recreate jobs and re-create hope?

name: Enrique GUERRERO SALOM
text: Mr President, shortly before the summer the European Union experienced one of those 'outbreaks of complacency' that we have been seeing for quite a few years: the end of the crisis was practically decreed. But after the summer, it seems possible that we will enter a third depression: the OECD has reviewed growth, and growth is worse for the euro area and for the three major euro area economies. Why is this happening? Because we have turned the European economy into a chronically ill person. A chronic patient who has only been given immunosuppressants — austerity at all costs, social cuts, a brake on investment and wage devaluation — and what the European Union - the euro economy - needs right now is a vitamin shock, a vitamin shock with investment, with growth, with education and that recovers the level of wages whose loss, as they have pointed out , not the "friends of the deficit", but the International Monetary Fund, the OECD, the World Bank and different think tanks, is at the source of the devaluation of demand as well. Without demand there will be no economic recovery; without investment there will be no growth in the European Union. Without investment and without demand, poverty will continue to be created and a mass of workers will continue to be created who, despite receiving a salary, live below the poverty line.

name: Pablo ZALBA BIDEGAIN
text: Mr President, I think it is right to welcome the measures announced by Mr Draghi, President of the ECB, but let us not deceive ourselves: the European Central Bank is not going to solve the enormous problems we have.  The European Central Bank will give us time to solve the problems so that we can make the appropriate reforms and start creating jobs and economic growth. Spain is an example. An example of a reformist country. And it is an example because it is the country with the most growth in the euro area and it is the country that is creating the most jobs. It's not enough, we're convinced of that. But we have no doubt that it is an example. Commissioner, we don't just need reforms, we need reforms as well. We need to implement Juncker's plan. I hope that this time those plans that we have so often announced will not fall into a broken sack and we will soon see their implementation.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: Mr President, Gentlemen of the Council and the Commission, when we see that one year after its exit from the recession, the euro area is showing stalled growth, 0% in the second quarter, with the risk of falling into deflation, we understand that the economic recovery is seriously in the lead. I believe that sustainable growth and a resumption of economic activity require, among other things, massive and controlled public investment.  As you know, Mr Juncker promised us, in July, an investment plan of almost 300 billion euros and Mr Draghi confirms that we need to make better use of fiscal policy. Well, if you do not yet know what to put on the agenda for this next eurozone summit, I think that it is really these essential questions that the summit must answer, in particular the fate that will be reserved, in a global way, for the public investment of the States so that they can also continue to support growth. Indeed, when we look a little closer at all the standards that have been established by Eurostat and in particular the SEC standards, we understand that they do not fit at all with the reality on the ground and that they forget to account for bonuses, especially local entities, which does not allow us to continue to support growth. I think that is clearly a mistake.

name: Joachim STARBATTY
text: Mr. President! Commissioner, I am disappointed by what you have said. I have been hearing what you have said for five years, and I am sure I will hear it again in five years' time. We have no progress. I have the feeling that the Commission is blind to what is actually happening. Barroso has said here in this House that the situation is better than in 2010. The opposite is true. Unemployment is rising incessantly, total debt is constantly rising, competitiveness has not increased, and that is worse than in 2010. In Lindau, our Chancellor analysed her austerity policy and reform policy in front of Nobel laureates. The Nobel laureates have torn their speech swell. You said that, in a recession, making further austerity policies only leads to an increase in the recession and unemployment also to rise. However, you did not say that we need an investment programme. You said that we must have a fresh start in monetary union. Countries must finally be able to do what is in the interests of their countries. This means that as long as we have the euro, there will be difficulties within monetary union.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: Mr President, the measures we are taking at each Summit support two ideas: that only from a common position can we face global challenges and that we cannot continue to replace with patches the construction of economic and political governance. Either we are betting on a euro area with a growth model based on the real economy and social development or we will no longer be the benchmark for progress that we went for decades. We therefore need binding medium- and long-term measures that will pour europe, investments with European added value in infrastructure and transport that add competitiveness, and shared minimums in social policy.  These policies must be implemented in a coordinated manner in all States because all else is fires of artifice and lack of political honesty. Not doing so, Commissioner, answers your question as to why private investment is halted. Either we do that, or we won't get out of this economic crisis situation.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: Mr President, Mr Katainen, ladies and gentlemen of the Council, following this summer's disastrous economic data, with the three main euro area economies in technical unemployment, today you have come, once again, to transfer your blind faith in the combination of austerity and structural reforms. They are proposing to us, basically, to accelerate, Mr Katainen, faster and faster towards the precipice. Today he again insisted that the problem is that reforms are not moving fast enough. And now, after the imposition of the reforms you have made to the countries on the periphery — to Spain, Greece and Portugal — will do the same, or intend to do the same with France and Italy: lower wages further, make the labour market more flexible and continue to reduce, increasingly, expenditure on public services.  Meanwhile, the casino economy continues to ride with a European Central Bank whose liquidity is trapped in the hands of speculators, as my partner has said before. Mr. Katainen, how long is this going to continue to be like this? Please admit that you have made a mistake, apologize for the suffering caused, and at once relaunch that investment plan you have promised and which today, frankly, you have told us absolutely nothing about. And because we don't have one, we don't have a date for the euro area summit yet. So please take a hundred and eighty-degree turn, acknowledge the mistake, and change that economic policy that leads us to suicide.

name: João FERREIRA
text: Mr President, now that the elections have passed and that the swearing that the euro crisis was over is confronted with the harsh reality and in which everyone already recognises that the crisis is about to wash and last, the peoples of Europe are faced with two options: or more of the same, and it has become clear here today that this is the intention of the Commission and the majority of this Parliament , or the change that is required. This change involves a discussion on the role of the ECB, with a view to a profound change in its statutes and guidelines, its false autonomy, and the restitution to states of the decision-making power on central issues of the functioning of their economies, as well as the control of the currency instrument, on the establishment of a support programme for countries whose stay in the euro has proved unsustainable and which provides for proper compensation for the damage caused in the context of an exit negotiated from the single currency, by the beginning of the discussion process aimed at the dissolution of economic and monetary union, the extinction of the Stability Pact, and these instruments are replaced by intergovernmental agreements between states that in a sovereign and free way wish to pursue the objective of economic and monetary integration.

name: Bill ETHERIDGE
text: Mr President, all of us care about economic growth. It is crucial to all of us. Whether or not you believe that the EU and the euro are fine ideals or whether you believe – as I do – that they are grotesque constructs dragging the people down, all of us agree that we need growth and we need our economies to grow together. The greatest way that we can do this is to free the peoples of Europe from the chains that bind them and are holding all of them down – the over-oppressive state and too much taxation. There are too many things holding back their spirit. Free the entrepreneurial spirit of the people of Europe, allow them to work their way out of poverty; allow them, through their own drive, courage, determination and creativity, to make things great again. I call upon all of you, and particularly the Commission, to please think of these noble concepts. We all want to be better off, we all want to be wealthier, but let us use our individual creativity to achieve this.

name: Jyrki Katainen
text: Vice-President of the Commission. - Mr President, I would have liked to have had a comprehensive debate with Members but my flight to the Australia G20 meeting is leaving in a few minutes’ time so I have to rush. I would just like to make a couple of comments. Mr Balz recalled reforms in order to strengthen growth potential. This is a very important issue, because in many of our Member States the potential for growth is at a low level. This is why we need various reforms. It depends on the country. We do not need the same reforms in every country, but it depends on the local situation. It is very easy to agree with Ms Rodrigues, who said that we have to emphasise safeguarding the European social model. She also recalled the need for reforms to strengthen innovation, for instance. This is very important. There are various ways to organise innovation financing in different Member States, and we could perhaps copy the best practices from different countries. This is something which could renew Europe, and this kind of reform brings us forward. There are many strengths in Europe but also some shortages and weaknesses. I personally believe in research and development and innovation. Innovation usually means that there must be strong fundamental research and entrepreneurship. So it is not only a question of money but also of how to organise and use public resources better than we are doing at the moment. It is also very important to find a more efficient way to use the EIB. Mr Lucke – if I understood correctly – said that, if we want investment, it does not make sense to consolidate. For me this is not a black and white question, because investment means demand and that there must be a good level of confidence. That is why we have to combine healthy reforms. We need more demand and some consolidation in order to strengthen confidence, and we need European efforts. The Commissioners-designate are trying to define this at the moment. I hope that we can continue this debate later on, focusing more on investment and growth.

name: Benedetto DELLA VEDOVA
text: Mr President- in-Office of the Council. - (IT) Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, thank you for the opportunity you have given me and the Presidency to listen to the wide range of views expressed on this subject. The speeches also went far beyond the specific theme of next month's euro summit meeting. I cannot add much to what I said in my opening speech with regard to that particular meeting. I can repeat that we will be able to say more when the meeting is convened. We will certainly be able to have a more detailed debate in next month's plenary.  I would just like to reiterate, with regard to the broad issues of growth and investment, which have been raised, that the Italian Presidency is prioritising and as a matter of urgency the subject and the issues that have been discussed with different positions expressed by the groups and individual Members and, in conclusion, I would like to say that I have taken good note of all the points and indications that have emerged in this debate and I will ensure that these points and these indications are taken into account. be passed on to all those involved in the preparation of the next euro summit.

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: Madam President, a colleague was given the opportunity during the procedure on behalf of non-attached Members. Parliament's Rules of Procedure clearly state: unregistered Members are not a political group. Under no circumstances do they have a single political expression, so no one can represent unregistered Members. Everyone is placed accordingly on behalf of the national party with which he has been elected to this Parliament. Therefore, when giving the speech to an unregistered Member, it would be correct to state that the word is given to this non-attached Member.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: Mr Zarianopoulos , thank you for that point of order and we will take note of your comments. The debate is closed. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: in writing. – It is disappointing to see the extent to which the Commission continues to blind reality, not no longer from data, but from millions of people in Europe that after checking in its own flesh the failure of austerity recipes and structural reforms continue to face a scenario of lack of economic growth, long-term unemployment, job precariousness, wage devaluation and social unprotection that calls them to poverty and exclusion. We need facts. We demand a concrete timetable for the investment plan proposed by President Juncker, but also commitments from European leaders on the economic endowment they intend to commit to this plan at national level but above all at European level. We need expansive and supportive fiscal policies that stimulate a sclerotic demand that, coupled with the deflation that haunts us, condemns us to permanent stagnation. And we need to stop cutting wages, because even the OECD warns us that this has become a problem that can condemn us for many years to come. We need to put an end to the myth of expansive austerity because such expansion is impossible when everyone at once saves and no one spends or invests, and it only causes poverty and suffering.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: The next item is the debate on the Council and Commission statements on roll-out of the European Youth Initiative (2014/2846(RSP)). This is an important debate and I already see many who would like to catch the eye. We will take note of all of the requests and we would ask our blue-card speakers kindly to respect the rule of 30 seconds for a question, and indeed 30 seconds for the response.

name: Benedetto DELLA VEDOVA
text: Mr President- in-Office of the Council. - (IT) Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I am pleased to have the opportunity to take part in this important debate, which is in fact also very much linked to the debate we had at the previous point. The prospects for young people to enter the world of work are of particular concern and are one of our top priorities. We are all aware of the seriousness of the situation, the continuing context of slow growth will continue to hold back employment prospects.  The economic recovery in the first half of 2014 was fragile, uneven – we discussed it earlier, you discussed it earlier – and has not had a real effect on job creation so far. The youth unemployment rate in the European Union remains high, currently two and a half times higher than that of adults, affecting more than five million young people under the age of twenty-five in Europe. Youth unemployment rates are still uncceptably high in many Member States. We all know that unemployment and youth inactivity have high costs. These costs are not only a short-term social factor, there will be a considerable economic price to pay in the long term. EU leaders are well aware of the seriousness of the situation. Over the past two years, they have provided significant political impetus at numerous European Council meetings. Last year in particular, they agreed, firstly, to provide additional funding of EUR 6 billion for the youth employment initiative and to bring it forward over the next two years. This will be particularly important as it will make it possible to implement effectively the measures provided for in the Youth Guarantee and, secondly, to call on the Member States benefiting from the Youth Employment Initiative to commit themselves to adopting concrete plans for the implementation of the Youth Guarantee. Allow me to briefly outline some points in the youth guarantee system which, as you know, was adopted in April last year.
