In accordance with the Council recommendation, Member States should ensure that young people receive a qualitatively viable offer of work, continuation of studies, apprenticeship or traineeships within a period of four months of leaving the formal education system or starting unemployment. All Member States have submitted their plans for the implementation of the Youth Guarantee. They have been assisted by the Commission, which assesses the measures taken by the Member States and provides feedback on them.  We are pleased to say that the first evaluations indicate a high level of commitment on the part of national administrations and good progress in implementation. The efforts made by the Member States to devise and develop these plans are proof of their commitment. I would like to take this opportunity to highlight the work carried out by the Employment Committee, which has helped to promote a better understanding of the policies and programmes implemented by the Member States.  The Council has also followed closely the implementation of all these measures. In recent discussions, ministers have reported on the experience gained in implementing youth guarantees and youth employment initiatives. They stressed, however, that more needs to be done. The Council is closely following Parliament's important contributions to these debates. We fully share the view expressed in the resolution of 17 July this year that strong measures are needed to combat youth unemployment. There is a specific challenge to address the structural causes of youth unemployment.  We support your call for systematic and structured actions in the context of the reform of apprenticeship systems or vocational education and training, or in the context of vocational guidance and support, the development of skills and their correspondence, or early intervention to prevent early school leaving. There is no alternative, Europe must ensure that young people can find work or that they are reintroduced into education and training. We must continue to invest in the younger generation. It is essential that The Member States decide on concrete measures, which increase the employability of young people, improve their prospects of entering the labour market and facilitate the transition from education to work. We need to focus on adapting national education systems to the needs of the labour market. Similarly, on the demand side, more needs to be done to facilitate access for small and medium-sized enterprises to finance – we discussed this earlier, you discussed it earlier – so that they can create jobs. Vocational training and apprenticeship are of particular importance and the European Union has recently taken a number of initiatives in this field, such as the European Alliance for Apprenticeship and the Quality Framework for Traineeships.  Of course it is essential for young people to enter the labour market, but it is up to the individual Member States to choose the right policies and take effective measures. At EU level, Member States receive financial assistance and support, but a solution that applies to everyone is not adequate. Each Member State faces different challenges, and in this respect it should also be noted that the current economic situation does not facilitate the tasks that lie ahead. Today, many of the challenges are not necessarily structural but cyclical, depending on economic conditions. It is therefore essential to get our economies back on the path to employment-leading growth. To this end, it is necessary for all actors to unite their efforts towards achieving this common objective.  Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the Italian Presidency will continue to put improving the situation of our young people at the top of the list. The last European Council welcomed our intention to hold a summit on employment, especially youth employment. This high-level event will follow up on the conferences that were held last year in Berlin and Paris. However, we have been forced to postpone the event, which unfortunately will not take place on the scheduled date.  In conclusion, allow me to express our hope in the constant commitment with which the new European Commission will face with strength and conviction the challenges of high youth unemployment.

name: László Andor
text: Member of the Commission. - Madam President, I would like to thank the European Parliament for its support for the Commission’s efforts in developing and implementing the Youth Guarantee. The Youth Guarantee is one of the most important and ambitious reforms proposed by this Commission. As you know very well in this House, the Youth Guarantee is a fundamentally new approach based on the best existing models within the European Union, namely those of Austria and Finland. It is a key structural reform that requires in-depth changes to education, training and job search systems in order to facilitate and accelerate the transition from education to employment. The concept of the Youth Guarantee has been endorsed by the G20 employment Ministers meeting last week in Melbourne. We have been working very hard with the Member States to implement the Youth Guarantee. A few months ago, all Member States submitted comprehensive implementation plans to the Commission. Since then, they have passed new laws, established innovative working methods, and upgraded the support provided by the public employment services. Pilot projects are also running in a number of Member States. So implementation of the Youth Guarantee is well on track and is already bringing results. Compared to other structural reforms in Europe, the Youth Guarantee is probably the one being most rapidly implemented. As President Schulz highlighted a few day ago at the Cohesion Forum, significant EU funding dedicated to implementing the Youth Guarantee has been made available to the Member States, including through the frontloading of the EU budget.  Let me inform you of the state of play of the dedicated youth employment initiative resources with the latest data. The Commission has received all 34 operational programmes which include resources from the initiative. 26 out of 34 will be adopted in 2014, covering about 85% of the total amount of the youth employment initiative. As regards financial allocations, we can therefore ensure on the basis of the submitted operational programmes, that all the EUR 6.4 billion of the Youth Employment Initiative will be committed in 2014 and 2015. In addition, on the basis of the draft operational programmes submitted by the Member States, we can foresee that over EUR 4 billion of additional European Social Fund resources will be committed to supporting youth employment. In other words, the Member States have – at this stage – approximately EUR 10 billion to support young people. What about the actual action on the ground? Some Member States have already stated that they are making use of the early eligibility date, i.e. 1 September 2013, and they are funding measures on the ground that can be reimbursed from the initiative and ESF resources. I have asked national authorities to provide us with concrete information on the estimated number of young people who benefit from these measures and on the types of measures financed by the Member States in 2014. I expect to receive this information from the Member States by the end of this month. The level of unemployment has been decreasing in Europe in the last year, but it is still very high, and there are still more than 5 million young people among the unemployed. I believe the Youth Guarantee will help to make an economic recovery job-rich, and it will make a systematic and decisive improvement to school-to-work transitions. However, we should not forget that, in the absence of overall economic growth, it would be impossible for any labour market reform to solve and economic crisis of such a magnitude as we have experienced in Europe. In other words the Youth Guarantee will deliver much more when it will be accompanied by adequate and more supportive macroeconomic instruments, and I very much count on the Italian Presidency to keep all this high on the political agenda.

name: Jutta STEINRUCK
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her In fact, this is a European disaster when we see that, over the last five years, youth unemployment in Europe has risen dramatically. In order to be truly successful, we must also remove the obstacles for the Member States to develop, to work on the programmes. The crisis countries in particular have problems with co-financing, and this needs to be improved.  The procedure often seems to me to be far too complicated. Although the pilot projects presented by the Commission last week are showing initial progress, we must also look closely at how the money is used on the ground? Is it really being targeted at reducing youth unemployment?  We Social Democrats are calling for a comprehensive strategy to combat youth unemployment. This includes ensuring funding after 2016, investment in economic growth, creating good jobs and more European solidarity, especially with the crisis countries.

name: Anthea McINTYRE
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, I think we all recognise that youth unemployment is a very serious problem right across Europe and a subject of great concern. I think we also have to recognise that causes differ across the EU and there is no one-size-fits-all solution. I was very pleased that the Council recognised this. So, no one-size-fits-all EU blueprint. But the Commission has a great role to play in helping to share the ideas and best practice that it finds across the Member States. I am very pleased that in my own country – the UK – youth unemployment fell by 206 000 in the last year. That is the largest fall since records began over 30 years ago, so I am pleased that we are going in the right direction. I am also very pleased that, to use another example from the UK, the UK Government is abolishing employers’ national insurance contributions for the under-21s, thus encouraging businesses – and especially small businesses, where the burden falls heavily – to take on young people, because 80% of new jobs come from SMEs. So it is those companies that need to be helped and encouraged to take on young people. I think we also need to have programmes and encouragement for young people to become entrepreneurs, to use their great energy and enthusiasm, and to provide mentors to help them to create their own businesses, become entrepreneurs and, in turn, employ people themselves. There is still a lot to do, but I think that we are heading in the right direction. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Bill ETHERIDGE
text: blue-card question. – Hello to my West Midlands colleague. I wonder if she agrees with me that, when I hear these kind of debates, I am always reminded of what President Reagan said – that the most frightening words in the English language are: I am from the government and I am here to help. Also, would she agree with me that the best way to help West Midlands youngsters get jobs is to stop the flow of unskilled mass immigration into our area, allowing them to get a foothold on the employment ladder?

name: Anthea McINTYRE
text: blue-card answer. – I think my main concern is that we need to be developing skills. Within Europe we have a skills shortage. We have shortages in ICT skills of somewhere between 300 000 and 700 000; we have a great shortage in science, technology, engineering and maths. So we do not have floods of people coming to take jobs – I know the fear that some parties thrive on – but what we are seeing, and you must have seen it in the West Midlands, is youth unemployment coming down. We are pursuing the right policy.

name: Martina DLABAJOVÁ
text: on the alde group. – Madam President, as a member of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, I am very close to the subject of youth employment and consider improving the situation in this area to be a key priority of my work. The differences between the member countries with the lowest and, on the contrary, the highest youth unemployment remain extremely high, and it is good that the European Commission and the Italian Presidency are focusing their attention on regions with high unemployment.  In the Czech Republic, for example, youth unemployment for under-25s is almost three times the national unemployment rate, and this ranks the Czech Republic in the better average of the Countries of the European Union. Two things must not be neglected in solving the problem: firstly, it is the potential for European labour mobility, which, in my opinion, remains untapped. About 216 million people make up the European Union's workforce, but only 7.5 million of them work abroad within the European Union. At the same time, it is young people who are the ones who are most willing to move to work. The second problem to address is that European businesses are being forced to secure skilled forces directly, by recruiting in schools and retraining on their own, and at their own expense, because they cannot rely on a functioning system. I welcome the efforts of businesses and schools across Europe to restore prestige to crafts and technical education. Vocational training, in line with market needs, is a way to provide firms with a skilled workforce in the future, while at the same time providing young people with the knowledge that the labour market requires.  My intention is to help connect successful companies with young people who are interested in education and actively take care of their future careers. I will not support passive support schemes and the across-the-board payment of social benefits without incentives. Not only does it not systematically address the problem of unemployment, but it does not provide individuals or societies with a prospect of quality and full life. (The speaker agreed to answer the question posed by raising the Blue Card (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure).)

name: Laura AGEA
text: Blue card question. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, my question to my colleague is whether we can distinguish between mobility and precarious employment, because in Italy, for example, we live mobility as an obligation, a constraint, in a work situation that is at an all-time low.  Work is blackmail, the work of young people is simply precarious, as is that of millions of Italians. I would demand that the Commission, the Council, anyone who can and must do something give answers to the ... (The President withdrew the speaker)

name: Martina DLABAJOVÁ
text: Answer to a blue card question. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank my colleague for her question.  We must, of course, make a clear distinction between mobility and precarious employment. I have spoken of mobility, which is precisely the mobility of opportunities for young people to go to work abroad, to have the same conditions and to be able to find suitable employment in other Member States as well.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: gue/NGL Group. – Mr President, once again we are discussing the same problem here and in recent times, unfortunately, nothing has changed. Much propaganda has already been made about this programme to show the good intentions of the European Union. The same European Union that forces countries and peoples to destroy themselves by paying off debts that are priceless, rather than investing their wealth, the wealth of their work, in the growth of their economy, in their development and in job creation. But we must say that perspectives have been created in millions of young Europeans who have no prospect of carrying out a decent life project.  It is imperative that, in practice, the implementation of this initiative is a priority. Speed and urgency is needed, but it is also necessary that this programme is no more than what has existed in the masse in recent years and that most young people know so well: precariousness, emigration, temporary occupation programmes, low-paid internships and no social protection rights, part-time work. Thank you, we don't want that, we already know that, we don't want to. What is required is that those who benefit from this program, companies, give guarantees, not temporary, but effective and true, of stable, worthy and rights contracts. What is also necessary is that this programme does not under any circumstances serve as a pretext for cutting off existing national social and labour protection mechanisms which are acquired rights in those countries. There is a generation in entire countries that is desperate and is tired of being exploited and no longer needs words.

name: Karima DELLI
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, one figure is that more than 8 million young Europeans under the age of 25 are neither in employment, in training nor in an internship. There's an emergency. Urgency to finally include young Europeans in society. Otherwise, the very idea of Europe will disappear. Mr Renzi and Mr Juncker want to make youth unemployment their priority. Chick! "Welcome to the club," as Daniel Cohn-Bendit would say!  But let's be ambitious! Let the next Commission start by proposing that investments in young people should be leaving the calculations of public deficits. Let the youth guarantee finally become a reality. That the European Social Fund is really mobilised and that the famous 300 billion announced by Mr Juncker be invested where there is employment, including the energy transition. So put the package on training and learning. There is something that you did not say that is important: we need to lift young people out of poverty. When are you going to put in place a basic income directive? Colleagues, not including young people means forgetting to prepare for the future. While young people are with them, they are the ones who need to go faster, stronger and further. It is in this Chamber that we must prepare tomorrow. This is it... (The President withdraws the floor from the speaker)) (The speaker agreed to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation))

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: question posed by raising the blue card. – Madam President, thank you for your very emotional comments here. Colleague, would you ever be willing to have coffee with me to explain to you what a dual system works in Germany, Austria and Italy? Then maybe you'll trade the fiery conversations here or the statement for facts and a way of dealing with it.

name: Karima DELLI
text: "blue card" answer. I will not respond to your proposal for coffee in this Chamber, we will see this in a more discreet way, but I will answer you on the merits.  Why do you have to have an awakening and a conscience in this Chamber - you are talking about emotion? But because there's an emergency! Young people must make this Europe. Today, young people no longer vote or vote for parties that are against Europe. I want to give hope back. You say, "in systems that work." But these systems that work, why don't they work elsewhere?  I believe today that young people must be taken up here and ensure that they are the priority, especially of our European horizon.

name: Jane COLLINS
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Madam President, we sit here calling for more EU action, and it is the EU itself that is failing our youth of today. It is making it harder and harder for them to find jobs. Your flagship Youth Guarantee scheme is doomed to fail. The International Labour Organisation said that it needed EUR 21 billion to actually make it effective, but only EUR 6 billion is budgeted for the current period, although I have just heard that you have raised a little bit more. But it is not enough, so it is another ‘EU triumph’.  But the elephant in the room is immigration. We have a complete open door to 500 million people in the EU to compete for jobs, claim benefits and settle in the UK. How can we say to our young people that this is going to help them find work? We are forcing them to compete against a large workforce coming over from the EU and undercutting wages. The Labour Party and the Conservative Party, of course, support this open door immigration policy. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Amjad BASHIR
text: blue-card question. – Ms Collins, I would like to ask whether it is true that bureaucracy and high taxation within the EU are preventing further job growth in the UK? I would also like to ask whether vocational skills provision is preventing job growth in Yorkshire? Certain wards of ours in Yorkshire are experiencing 60-70% youth employment.

name: Jane COLLINS
text: blue-card answer. – I would say definitely that bureaucracy, red tape and high taxation are the main reasons that small to medium businesses are struggling and failing, and if they are failing they cannot employ younger workers. I would agree that we need to put something in place whereby we can actually activate more apprentice schemes in our own region where we seem to be falling behind with our younger unemployed.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: I am going to stop blue cards from this point on in the debate because we have 25 colleagues who wish to catch the eye at the end of the debate, so no more blue cards. We will continue to take names for catch the eye but realistically we are going to run out of time.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, fine words from the Commission today too. The EU that helps young people, the EU that allocates money to young people because young people are our future, our hope. In addition, there are the fine words of the Italian Presidency in perfect 'Renzi' style: promises. We need to invest in young people, young people are at the top of our priorities. But here we are experiencing a great contradiction, I wonder: are you there or are you doing it? Because you say there is no work for young people and you say at the same time that fifty million immigrants are needed because there is a lack of a workforce. Another all-European folly. The internal market is basically blocked. And what are you guys doing? Sanction Russia. So the many young farmers who had hoped for the Russian market find themselves risking their jobs. And then? And then think of new sanctions, for the fashion, furniture market, so those young people who had hoped for this find themselves without a chance. Here, six billion out of nowhere... (The President withdrew the speaker)

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: Madam President, the European Union must take advantage of all the potential that young people represent, and young people are a solution, they are not a problem. It should be recognised that the European Union has several youth support programmes and has allocated, for example, EUR 6 billion to be used this year and next for the Youth Employment Initiative.  In this regard, with regard to the Youth Employment Initiative, I ask the Commission: what amounts have been used already this year? What amounts do you plan to use next year? And I ask the Council: will it not make cuts as it has done in other initiatives, in payments for this initiative? And I ask again: and after 2015, from 2016 to 2020, will they end this Youth Employment Initiative programme or do they propose to provide it with money, with funds, funding for this programme to continue?  Programs that support youth employment are an investment, not a cost. The European Union must contribute to these capital gains programmes, such as the Youth Guarantee. In parallel, it is necessary to create an environment favourable to small and medium-sized enterprises. There needs to be no cuts to programmes for growth and jobs – cuts in Cosme, Horizon 2020, Erasmus+. These cuts must not be made so that jobs and growth are effectively a reality in the European Union.

name: Silvia COSTA
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner Andor and Mr Della Vedova, I very much appreciate the fact that the priorities of the Italian Presidency are above all to find the basis for greater youth employment and I think there is full awareness of the tragedy we are experiencing in Europe, and I would like to remind Mr Bizzotto that Italy was one of the first countries to adopt the youth guarantee in this case and also to raise it to twenty-nine years. , which other countries have not done. But I would like to say this on a more European level, and that is that we have demonstrated with this guarantee to young people – it is certainly not a total answer, it is the theme of macroeconomics that Andor said earlier, that is, a subject that concerns resilience – but it is a different method, a different approach that demonstrates two things: that we must work both on labour policies and on labour policies. , but also, and I think they have been somewhat forgotten, on policies against school drop-out, for a better quality of services, also of the dual system, of the services of school and professional and technical systems and on other competences, but also on tutoring.  In this context, the importance in the construction of European citizenship and the educational and work mobility of Erasmus+ must not be escaped... (The President withdrew the speaker from the floor.)

name: Ulrike TREBESIUS
text: Madam President, Commissioner Andor, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his work and for his As much as EU action to combat high youth unemployment may be welcome, it should be noted that out of 28 Member States, 20% of the countries in the EU now have regions where youth unemployment is more than 25%. Only countries such as Finland, Austria, the Netherlands and germany – and a few more – have no entitlements, although there are regions here too – in Germany, for example, North Rhine-Westphalia – that need support but which fail to meet the high 25% mark. I believe that there is a risk that the money allocated will be used to cover up the problems and to neglect the necessary structural reforms. As with other new EU programmes, such as the Banking Union or the European Unemployment Insurance Scheme promoted by Commissioner Andor, only funds are transferred here, pledging from north to south.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: Madam President, youth unemployment is a scandal, and we have been slow to react in the EU. But at least now we have a programme which is specifically designed to respond positively to youth unemployment. 6 billion plus for a Youth Guarantee over 28 Member States is not enough – not nearly enough; the ILO has said we need 21 billion. But at least we are encouraging Member States to frontload and to spend that money in 2014 and 2015. So I suppose the question is: are we making progress? We have a document from the Commission: a first-findings report which looks at a number of pilot projects that have the potential to make positive changes, particularly in the way school-to-work transition is managed and how youth employment services are delivered to young people. These programmes are providing short-term relief in many cases, and core to the approach is the partnership approach, where the schools, the NGOs, the employers, the government services and the young people themselves are included. Indeed, we have one of these pilot programmes in Ireland, in Ballymun in Dublin, where a local partnership has been set up under the umbrella of a national partnership. They are dealing with 316 young jobseekers, 80% of whom at this point have accepted an offer of work experience, employment or further education and training. It is a start: it is a small start by the EU, and Member States now have to step up to the plate. Finally, I want to wish Commissioner Andor well in his retirement. As we say in Ireland, his heart was in the right place.

name: Kostadinka KUNEVA
text: Mr President, I wonder, does it make any sense to discuss progress in implementing the Youth Employment Initiative? We all know that this initiative is a drop in the ocean. Why should the European Parliament be involved in this hypocrisy? Once the programmes are announced by the European Council, the next time by the Commission, the next by the governments of each country. What's the result? In most European countries, youth unemployment is steadily rising. In Greece, an entire generation of lies is lost. We have at least 700,000 unemployed people up to the age of 29. And what corresponds to them? EUR 220 each and these only once. We won't be complicit in this mockery. And the new leadership of the Commission knows that this is hypocrisy. Mr Juncker said that THE EUR 6 billion for Youth would increase it to EUR 300 billion. So let Mr Juncker bring the plan and the money for Youth and let us discuss how to create real jobs and proper training. Because at the moment the only guarantee for Youth that the Commission gives through the Troika to Greece is the occasional work with salaries of up to 480 euros, for a few months. It is shameful to claim that this is a pro-Youth policy.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen of the Italian Presidency, I have been here two months and I have the feeling that I am already listening to a bit of a scratched record. Some things: about the application of the youth guarantee; we have already discussed on some occasions that some countries are mis-implementing the youth guarantee, contradicting the Commission's own recommendations. In Spain it is only being used as a receptacle of funds to distribute it among companies. There are no training programmes, no accompaniment and advisory systems, no supplementary aid systems for those young people who do not have any income... does the Commission intend to do anything about it? And, by the way, in Spain, very constructive measures are also taken, such as the deletion of the Youth Council, which the Government has done in recent days. Second element: the question of resources. Will there be more resources? We know that the EUR 6 billion is insufficient. Thirdly, and this is a comment for the Italian Presidency: frankly, it seems like a bad joke that they come here to tell us that they have not been able to find a date for the Summit. It is not that we are genuine fans of summits—because we know that they are often made to speak and decide nothing, which is what young people have had to witness in recent years—but that they have not been able, on the Presidency's agenda, to find a deadline for a summit on an issue that is fundamentally , one of the most serious problems here right now, in the European Union, such as youth unemployment, seems, frankly, very uns serious.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, during the election campaign, the presidential candidates promised us to regain the voters' betrayed confidence in the institutions by means of innovative measures, particularly with the confidence of young people, to whom programmes were directed as a guarantee for young people who should and could raise the fortunes of an entire generation. However, the reality is very different. Today we are discussing a Commission which has nothing at all innovative. Its composition repeats the broad agreements as they were five years ago, with some Commissioners even being recycled into new positions. Young people will have no leading role in the executive. Why is it not present in any of the macro areas entrusted to the super vice-presidents? Why do you intend to entrust the fate of young Europeans, the future citizens of Europe, to a controversial figure such as that of the candidate Commissioner Navracsics?  In short, once again, by talking, you are deluding the citizens of Europe, especially those young people who are fighting unprecedented levels of unemployment and who will undermine their future and with it that of the whole of Europe.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Madam President! It is a misconception that the state or the Union can solve all economic problems, even with a lot of money, which is in any case scarce. It is therefore only partially sensible to set up more job placement jobs through EU funds. Europe's young people used to find work without the EU, but that also requires the jobs they need. Jobs are missing, especially in the recession situation, where, of course, these missing jobs are creating hiring freezes, and that, of course, unfortunately affects the young.  We must therefore ensure that our European companies are also equipped for international competition. This includes, of course, excellently trained staff, innovative staff, committed young employees, but also good framework conditions for our companies, no unnecessary bureaucracy, no distorting bureaucratic environmental regulations and burdens. We need smart incentives, smart temporary arrangements for the labour market. Then our companies will again employ more young workers.

name: Danuta JAZŁOWIECKA
text: Madam President, i voted in favour of this report. We have been quoting worrying figures on youth unemployment for years and nothing is changing. It is becoming increasingly clear that we are dealing with a lost generation in which people without sufficient work experience and without the chance of a decent retirement will dominate. Today's youth unemployment will put member states' budgetary problems in the future and will definitely prevent us from maintaining the new European social model. It is surprising that the government has resisted or neglected to use the instruments of the European Youth Initiative. Only 11 beneficiary countries have so far prepared the operational programmes necessary to make use of the available funds, and only two have benefited from them. It is therefore very clear that the problem is not the low budget, but the intuition of most countries. So, first of all, we should discuss the causes of the existing stagnation. We can criticise individual governments for their disrespectful attitude towards this programme, but this will not improve the situation of young people. It will be more effective to look for ways to remove existing blockades and to motivate countries to reach for available funds, especially as the current EUR 10 billion is available under the initiative as early as today in 2014 and 2015, rather than as is the case with other multiannual programmes.  Yesterday's debate on reducing funding for the best of the best Horizon 2020 programmes and today's debate on the complete ignorance of the Member States towards the European Youth Initiative programme, which already has 100% funding, shows how bad decisions we are making here in the European Parliament, often under pressure from Member States, which later disregard these decisions.  Commissioner, thank you very much to you and the team for their cooperation over the years.

name: Evelyn REGNER
text: Madam President! The Youth Guarantee is infinitely important. But it is no substitute for the adoption of macroeconomic instruments. The funds currently being made available for the fight against youth unemployment are, of course, far from sufficient. The Commission itself spoke of this in its press release yesterday, and I say it now in English: 'The Youth Guarantee scheme is an investment. For the Commission, this is crucial expenditure for the EU to preserve its future growth potential.' The cost of not acting is infinitely higher than taking money into the hands of young people. EUR 150 billion has been estimated for 2011. The wounds and scars left by young people and in our society as a whole cannot be quantified. That is why it is so important that these investments are exempted from the deficit criteria. These investments, and I repeat, really should be excluded. Because it is investment in the future.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: This Parliament has already warned in July this year that the Youth Employment Initiative should not be the only cure for youth employment problems, but that it is additional aid that must not substitute the role of Member States and their own responsibility in tackling young people's problems.  And now to the youth guarantee itself. The success of programmes and initiatives to help young people depends above all on the ability of Member States to fulfil these resolutions with real content, and this depends on the implementation capacity of the States. Unfortunately, the countries that need aid most often have the lowest and are improving only in a limited way.  Labour offices that have been given the task of helping young people are often unable to provide personalised and quality services. They thus tend to help where it is easiest, resigning to help the long-term unemployed and benefiting those who have the least problem with employment. For example, it is preferable to subsidise youth places, but the long-term sustainability of positions thus created is often secondary.  If we are to help young people find work, the Member States, and especially those that are most concerned about unemployment and youth inactivity, must know, above all, what they are doing and evaluate the quality of the services they provide to young people. In turn, the Commission must see to it that the Member States take the easiest path, but to keep an eye on them. (speaker aborted)

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: Madam President, the first thing: the Youth Guarantee sounds good; unfortunately it is probably not going to work, but it sounds nice. It sounds as though we could guarantee a job to everybody. We cannot. We need reforms, and I think the Commissioner should know that. We need very serious reforms in Europe. We do not need closed borders. Some of our British colleagues think it would help the UK and that if we just closed them and did not let in those Eastern Europeans, we would be protected. Some colleagues think that a big rise in the minimum wage would fix it. It will not. We need reforms. It needs to be easier to hire people, and there needs to be some ease in terms of letting them go when times are tough. That would give companies the confidence they need to hire people. It is all about confidence. Will we all create a confident Europe with a single market where people can travel from Lithuania to the UK and get a job (or vice versa)? Maybe if they are very talented and skilled and if we work with schools and universities to educate people for the future, for the digital economy, the digital single market – that is a big reform we need – and energy, another big reform we need. So I want you to open up, join and together create a Europe that is going to be efficient and competitive. Then we will all win. So reform, unfortunately, is the only way we are going to ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Lynn BOYLAN
text: Madam President, youth unemployment in Ireland and across the EU is having serious repercussions which are not only having impacts now but will have social ramifications for years to come. Those who do manage to find some work – the so-called lucky ones – are increasingly forced to accept unpaid internships or precarious work such as zero-hour contracts. Another supposed option offered to our youth in Ireland is emigration, which, of course, is not a choice. Those who did not cause the crisis – the young – are certainly having to pay for it. By failing to allocate the funds recommended by the ILO, the Youth Guarantee Scheme is a guarantee only on paper. Six months from its roll-out in January, even Angela Merkel had to admit that it had been a failure in truly tackling the problem. It has provided little more than nice sound bites for certain politicians who want to appear to be acting on the issue while in reality doing very little. I would like to see a full review of the Guarantee. Countries such as my own – Ireland – are using it merely as a box-ticking exercise instead of a genuine solution to a very real problem.

name: Elisabeth MORIN-CHARTIER
text: Madam President, my first words will be for Commissioner Andor, who has made a strong emphasis on distinguishing between the youth guarantee and the youth employment initiative. Our substantive policy is the youth guarantee, so that young people can return to employment. The Youth Employment Initiative is the tip of the iceberg. And so my second words will be for the representative of the Council. We are no longer hearing here "the Council is aware of the seriousness of the situation". We are no longer in the time to describe the situation. The policies have been passed, now you have to implement them and mobilize the Member States around you so that there is real implementation on the ground. The Youth Employment Initiative- make no mistake - is not a way to reduce the number of unemployed young people by putting them into an internship or training them. These are fundamental changes that we want, changes that affect the fight against out-of-school without qualifications, the articulation between academic training and the world of work, new skills and new jobs, learning and validation of experience. It's time to get to work. Thank you, I'm counting on you!

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, youth unemployment in Europe remains at unacceptable levels, just as a frightening European average of 23% is already unacceptable, let us not talk about countries where it exceeds 50%. Let us remember that without work there are no rights, there are no freedoms, there is no future, and without the support of young people there is no future for the Union. I am pleased that the Member States, as well as Italy – my own country – are taking action to implement the youth guarantee. I would like to thank Commissioner Andor for the work he has done in a difficult context, that of the Barroso Commission. At the same time, however, it must be stressed that the budget is not sufficient. In order to have a real impact, these initiatives must become structural measures to support the employment of young people. On 30 June, Angela Merkel made it clear at a press conference that she felt that the European Union's action to combat youth unemployment was not enough, but it was precisely the austerity policies of which she was the champion that prevented us from taking stronger action against youth unemployment. We look forward to the review of the multiannual financial framework and the Juncker plan to combat unemployment.

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: Madam President, Mr Andor, thank you very much for your work in this time in the Commission. Thank you for the courage to carry out an innovative and ambitious initiative, such as the Youth Guarantee, which we do not forget is based on a successful experience, that of Austria and Finland, and it is therefore even more important that there is a guarantee of success in the countries that are joining it and are implementing it. But this issue concerns me in particular - and that is why I ask the Commission and the Council to insist on monitoring the implementation of funds in countries such as Spain, which is, as you well know, a sad leader in youth unemployment with almost 54%— because Spain receives half of the funds from this programme. It is particularly important that we ensure that the implementation of the funds, especially for training, is not fraudulently used as we have had to do in Madrid and Andalusia — the Commissioner knows the issue and is very aware of this. It is important that we ask that countries that have to be exemplary in the implementation of a program like this, such as Spain, be not only well supervised, but are required to be a reference.

name: Jeroen LENAERS
text: I would like to join all the previous speakers who also believe that the 20% youth unemployment rate we have in Europe is unacceptable. We must give the fight against youth unemployment absolute priority over the next five years. However, the fight against youth unemployment must be conducted primarily in the Member States themselves. The situation in the different Member States is different. This also calls for different measures. I am surprised that when the resolution was adopted last July, several groups in the House immediately took the reflex of imposing a legal framework from Europe with minimum standards for the youth guarantee. We must set our goals in Europe, we must support Member States in their measures, but let us also allow the Member States to tailor their own measures for their own situation. If we really want to work seriously towards creating more jobs for young people in the long term, then we need to implement structural reforms. As far as I am concerned, one of these structural reforms of the economy and the labour market lies in the tax burden on labour. In Europe, we have a tax burden significantly higher than the OECD average. If we are serious about creating jobs, we must carry out structural, sustainable reforms and we must not continue to do so.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: For the second session in a row, we are discussing the employment problems of young people, which shows that this is indeed a priority in this parliamentary term. It is essential for everyone to concentrate their efforts on moving from youth employment guarantee planning and preparatory work as soon as possible to real implementation. I very much hope that the change in the Commission's term of office will certainly not prevent this work. I welcome the Commission's assessment of the implementation of pilot projects. This project was successfully carried out in my native Lithuania, where in eight districts attempted to unite the efforts of the social partners to better inform young people in their professional training and work. The Commission should ensure the dissemination of positive results for these projects in the European Union. I also propose that the Commission respond more quickly to labour market developments in the Member States and to help adjust the national youth guarantee implementation plans accordingly. Monitoring of the implementation of the plans is equally important. I believe that there should be no rush to introduce new indicators that can bring difficulties in the implementation of various projects.  In conclusion, I would like to thank László Andor for our five years of cooperation. I wish you the best of luck in your professional career in the future.

name: Heinz K. BECKER
text: Madam President, Commissioner Andor, commissioner, Commissioner Andor, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work he has done. In the final of your work, I would like to thank you, especially for many initiatives that have strengthened social Europe. Thank you very much. If we have growth and work as objective number one, then the issue of the European Youth Initiative should give us the opportunity, from the European Parliament, to urge the European Member States to tackle structural reforms immediately: the Youth Guarantee, dual training on employability, effective social partnership, efficient labour market management and the creation of broad small and medium-sized enterprises structures.  We must make benchlearning a binding instrument of European policy. We must learn from the models of success in other countries. Then we can achieve long-term success in the long term. This also applies to my own country, Austria, which is often presented as a model country. We also have some reforms ahead of us.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: Madam President, I would like to address the UKIP MEPs who came briefly in their little gang and did their carefully choreographed cynical performance and then left very quickly clapping each other on the back in self-congratulation. I would like to say to them that to come to this serious, considered debate about hundreds of thousands, indeed millions, of young people denied the dignity and decency of work at the beginning of their lives – to come here with their dog-whistle, xenophobic, lowest common denominator politics – is a national disgrace. As a British person I am ashamed. What they should have said was that the UK Government’s failure, with a programme that could have been implemented on 1 September, to have applied for funds is equally is a disgrace, letting down the young people of our country.

name: Alessandra MUSSOLINI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, it would have been an excellent opportunity to guarantee young people for Italy – we have 43% unemployment – but unfortunately that was not the case. Only six regions have had public-private accreditation. Very few applications, few job offers, especially 90% for a fixed-term period, and then something tragic happens for young people. You know that when you join the youth project, if you only work a few hours in one day, you lose your right of access, and that is very serious, because it means that only young people who are at home and who are supported by their parents can afford it. So let us give these funds not so much and not only for training and traineeships, but really for the integration of young people into the world of work. And then, unfortunately, there is membership, a kind of overlap between what is the youth guarantee project and the work of the Ministry of Labour. Why this? Because it hasn't updated. There are still too many things that don't work and that's very serious.

name: Guillaume BALAS
text: Madam President, there is a debate that I do not quite understand. We would like to make it seem that in Northern Europe there is no problem of precariousness among young people or access to the labour market, whereas in the South this is the case. Unfortunately, it is a question of degree, it is not a question of nature. The crisis is, of course, hitting the South head-on and it is extremely serious. But we also see in the countries of the North, which are said to be doing well in quotation marks, a youth that is not at all in the favourable situation that it might have had a few years ago. This is partly because young people today are in the minority and structurally we are struggling to act for them because many other age groups today are reluctant to make efforts.  Two considerations in this context. The first, on the youth guarantee, is that we have to see what is being done and the Commission must be serious in the assessment, that there are no drifts, as has been seen in some countries. The second element, then, is that the funds of the 6 billion that are now allocated must be mobilised in all countries.  And finally, we must look at what the ILO says about the 21 billion, even if we do not get to that amount right away, we can understand it. We need to increase in load fairly quickly, in short, there has to be a coherent and controlled strategy on this subject.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: Madam President, in Ireland we have introduced some structural changes, establishing education and training boards and offices – one-stop shops – where young people can go and be supported to ensure that they get relevant education and training. The success of the pilot scheme in Ballymun, referred to previously by Ms Harkin, is due to the fact that there has been a partnership and that we have engaged with employers and education providers. That is essential in ensuring the success of the Youth Guarantee scheme. Without employers’ input we are not providing young people with the skills that they need to gain meaningful employment. I think this is critical and I would ask the Commissioner, as I have asked him previously in such a debate, to focus on that aspect in order to ensure that the necessary reforms are in place. In 1995 in Europe, 21% of our youth were unemployed, and since then we have had pretty high youth unemployment of around 10-15%. So the problem is not just related to the recent financial crisis: it is also related to the fact that our education provision does not sufficiently match the needs of industry or provide young people with the skills that they need to gain employment. That is a critical issue right across Europe, and in my own country especially. We can speak to employers and, you know yourself, Commissioner, the criticism that these employers are not getting the skills they need and that they have to look outside Europe. So this is also about competitiveness. I wish you well in moving on to your next venture but I would ask you to ensure that the needs of young people, in particular, are addressed and that work to give them the skills they require to gain meaningful employment continues.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: Madam President, we have 5.2 million young people unemployed, a figure that is said to be fast, but which is hugely painful for this continent: 23%. More than half of young people in some countries, such as Spain, Croatia or Greece. And this is not just data, it has enormous economic consequences, for wasting talent and huge investments in public training; enormous social consequences, for condemning an entire generation to poverty, emigration or precariousness; and also huge institutional consequences, because we are disconnecting it from its institutions. We have given some answers — it is always positive to give answers — but these responses — the Youth Guarantee, a youth employment initiative — have been slow, uns ambitious, timid, are being wasted by some States — very important: the case of Spain is flagrant with the Youth Guarantee — and we are also conditioning States and State budgets by counting these budgets. What we have to do is give an ambitious response, proportional to the scar that is causing this problem for the future of this continent. Ambitious, fast and urgent, because the future knocks on our door.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: Colleagues, we now have a list of speakers for catch the eye. We have over 25 colleagues who want to take the floor and clearly I cannot accommodate everyone because time is running out for our debate. I would ask for your patience. I will now take speakers from each of the groups in order. Catch-the-eye procedure

name: Gabriel MATO
text: Madam President, the initiative to promote youth employment that we approved a few months ago was a very important step in addressing one of the great and fundamental challenges ahead in Europe, and we must be careful, that is precisely why the expectations and objectives we set ourselves that young people can be better shaped and have decent work are met. The youth unemployment rate is a problem of concern to all, but mainly in certain countries and regions. Let me refer today specifically to the outermost regions of the European Union, which always have the most difficult thing in all areas and also when it comes to their young people being able to find job opportunities. We are talking about whether unemployment in Europe was 10%, in the Canary Islands it reached 33.7% or in Meeting 29%. In the case of youth unemployment, in the Canary Islands we had, at the end of 2013, a rate of 62%, a chilling fact. We're getting better, yes, but there's a lot to do.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: Madam President, one of the greatest challenges that the European Union has is precisely to open the doors of the labour market to young people. In the case of Spain, 40% are unemployed under the age of thirty: one and a half million. If it is one of the biggest problems facing the European Union, we must have ambition in the response. The Youth Guarantee is an answer, but it's not ambitious. It doesn't give satisfaction, it's not effective, it's not enough. Therefore, we must consider what policies must be implemented to respond and not frustrate generations who have a very dark present, but who also have no hopes or expectations for the future. You have to have more ambition. We have to break that policy of austerity. Investment policy, growth policy must be increased. We need to talk about the industrialisation of Europe. We must speak, in short, of employment, to give horizon and perspectives to a generation that can be lost.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Madam President, this debate is indeed a continuation of the previous one, because the problem of the huge unemployment that exists in the European Union is directly related to the model used to get out of the crisis. A model based on deflation, on austerity, a model based on reducing labour costs but thus not giving competitiveness to the European economy. At the same time, it relied on the rescue of the banks. More than EUR 1.5 trillion of the European Union was given to support the banks themselves, to rescue the bankers, to socialize the losses. What amounts are we now giving to support unemployment? EUR 6 billion, at a time when the banks had been given EUR 1.5 trillion. See what has happened in Greece: the country has borrowed 214 billion euros and yet it has 1.5 million unemployed. This policy has failed!

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: Madam President, the problem of youth unemployment requires, in addition to resolving the economic imbalances we are talking about this morning, more funding, more proximity between training and demand for new skills and professions, improving the conditions of first jobs and promoting self-priming. We have a deficit in some technical-scientific specialties on which the innovation that needs to be resolved depends. But I also miss a discourse on values and attitudes. It's not comfortable to talk about this, but there's a responsibility of authorities, individuals and families. Other reference models must be promoted, educated in responsibility, taught to fail and regain the prestige of personal effort. Knowledge yields more with values. Soulless talent, as we have seen with unscrupulous financiers, generates this crisis, and this is the best example of what I say and why we need to change.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: Madam President, the deterioration of the labour market cannot be solved by initiatives like this, which argue that the problem is the lack of employability of our young people. Ladies and gentlemen, I have been a vocational and job-oriented teacher and I will tell you what the problem is for our young people: when we have to help our young people look for jobs, the problem is not that they are not sufficiently trained or that they are not flexible enough. The problem is, there's no job. And we know this well in the countries of southern Europe, because our labour market has been destroyed to obey the dictates of large financial institutions and large multinationals. And when they argue that the alternative is self-employment, it is laughable, because most of our young people are experiencing dramatic situations and have no initial capital to cope with the costs of setting up a new company, when, moreover, most small businesses are suffering the consequences of the economic situation. The reality is that young people, today, are forced into unemployment, precariousness or exile, and that the deterioration of the labour market is resolved by developing a model... (The Chair withdrew the floor to the speaker)

name: Terry REINTKE
text: Madam President, we have heard a lot about the financial implementation of the Youth Guarantee. The numbers that Mr Andor has given us show once again that there is a dire need for more money, a demand that my group has already pushed for in the past. In my view, what has been neglected in this debate is the question of youth participation in implementing all these programmes. I think that we need youth organisations and other representatives of young people to be heavily involved in the drafting of the implementation programmes because, otherwise, implementation will not meet the needs of young people. But what do we see happening in many EU Member States? The exact opposite. The financial and organisational capacities of precisely these stakeholders are being limited and are being silenced in discussions on the implementation of the Youth Guarantee.  I would like to appeal to Mr Andor and the new Commission to ensure that the voices of young people are heard in the discussion and youth organisations are ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Giulia MOI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Mr Della Vedova, you said earlier that Italy is very keen to use European funds for young people and, above all, you are very concerned about the quality of these European funds, as they are used.  Was he referring to the 'Genovese case', where in Sicily for years these European funds instead of training were used for his private ends and now he is accused of abuse of office, fraud, criminal association and has been protected by you by putting him in parliament and is now an MP? Or was it referring to the system where in Sardinia training courses, financed from European funds, were used by putting cartoons? Is this the quality you want to give to young Italians and Europeans?

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: Madam President, the European Union has given billions of euros to the capital for growth and employment. However, unemployment has soared. Only yesterday, a delegation of 500 laid-off cleaners in Greece visited the European Parliament to raise their issue. For a year now, Coca-Cola workers in Greece have been on strike because they have closed all factories and, at the same time, the Troika and the Greek Government are calling for the release of collective redundancies. How does everything the Commission supposedly says about employment go hand in hand? Another is its objective, not unemployment and employment, but to strengthen its capital, profits and competitiveness.

name: Milan ZVER
text: In Slovenia, research shows that the lack of jobs for young people is the biggest factor of poverty. As many as 75% of young people are even willing to move abroad. Secondly, when we offered a guarantee scheme at European level, many complained that six, seven billion euros were too little. Today, we find that it is only two countries that are already successfully pumping this money. This is further proof that administrative measures do not help if officialism is ineffective. More than that, I believe that the European Commission should take action against governments that do not stick to the agreements. Thirdly, youth unemployment is only the result of a real problem, which lies mainly in our economies. Small and medium-sized enterprises and micro-enterprises contribute 85% of jobs, so we need to create conditions, favourable conditions, and introduce incentives to create their own businesses for more young people. This is better than giving money to national bureaucracies.

name: László Andor
text: Member of the Commission. - Madam President, first of all I would like to thank Parliament for this very important debate and I also want to thank those who expressed some personal messages about my work and the Commission’s work in this area. It is the duty of the Commission to inform Parliament about every step which is taken in the area of youth employment. I will be brief because of the shortage of time but I would like to respond to some of the key points of today’s discussion. First of all I would like to clarify very clearly that the Youth Guarantee is a reform. It is about a reform agenda; it is about reforming vocational training; it is about reforming, if necessary, how the public employment services work in various EU Member States because it is public action that is needed to help young people who might be looking for a job or who might not even be registered as unemployed in many cases. Obviously the purpose is that young people gain skills that are relevant to the labour market and information and experience which will help them in their future careers. Let me also clarify that the Youth Guarantee is not a one-size-fits-all project. It allows for a lot of flexibility – for example integrating measures to boost entrepreneurship; it allows for demand-side measures but also supply-side investment; and it calls for an innovative approach at Member State level and also within regions. Concerning current trends, I think it is clear – and clear too from the discussion – that recently unemployment, including youth unemployment, has been falling faster outside the euro area than inside the euro area. That just highlights how important the macroeconomic background is in making progress. Nevertheless in those countries where there has been progress in reducing the youth unemployment rate, I would like to underline three important criteria which also need to be observed at the same time. One of them is the quality of the new jobs and the new employment. The second one is outreach to their needs because it is not enough just to reduce the number of registered unemployed; the Youth Guarantee is also about reaching out to those who are not in education, employment or educational training. And the third, to monitor something very important in our scheme – and it is actually uniform – namely the four-month deadline, the actual guarantee that young people can count on this safety net. Another observation concerning current trends is that there is indeed no conflict between labour mobility and reducing youth unemployment. Countries that have either been performing well or making progress in the recent period, like Germany or the United Kingdom, have experienced a relatively significant inward mobility but, at the same time, falling or low unemployment. Why? Because they have been on the better side of the EU in terms of economic growth and this has allowed new jobs to be created in this period. So the contradiction or the trade-off which some people assume to exist cannot be observed in reality.  Fourthly, regarding money: more money is of course always better than less money but the important thing is that we take advantage of the existing budget. The EU budget is not the only source. It was never meant to be the only source for the Youth Guarantee, especially in countries and regions that are not eligible because their performance has already been relatively better. So it is also important to rely on national resources and combine the European Social Fund plus the top-up fund – the famous EUR 6 billion – in regions where the youth unemployment rate has been extremely high in the past period. It is also important – if Members are concerned with the flow of EU funds – to take the lead in Council in order to refill the EU budget with the payment credits needed to enable the Commission to pay the bills in time under the European Social Fund and other financial instruments. A very good starting point for this would be to agree on the third amending budget for 2014 and the draft budget for 2015 without any cuts to the Commission proposal. We need to reduce the accumulated backlog of payment claims and not to increase it further. Finally, my fifth point is about the evaluation. I agree with those who stress the importance of a serious fact-based evaluation of progress – or, in some cases, the lack of it – and this evaluation has to be inclusive. It has to include the social partners, the parliaments – the European Parliament as well as the national parliaments – and, most importantly, the youth organisations themselves. This is what I have been doing in my capacity – meeting as much as possible representatives of the Youth Forum and various youth organisations. This is what we are acknowledging also at Member State level.

name: Benedetto DELLA VEDOVA
text: Mr President- in-Office of the Council. - (IT) Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, a few words in conclusion. First of all, i would like to thank you for today's debate. The debate was extremely stimulating, frank and highlighted the urgent need to act to tackle one of the most alarming problems facing many Member States today. There is only one point on which I would like to say a few words. Since some speakers have strongly criticised the guarantee mechanism for young people, there has been talk of hypocrisy. We have never claimed that the measures we have discussed today can provide a solution on their own. The youth employment initiative is the seed capital for stimulating national initiatives and the scope for action at EU level is relatively limited and the main focus of initiatives is on coordination, promotion of new initiatives and support for funding mechanisms.  The Council provides guidance to the Member States and strongly encourages them to take action to tackle the problem of youth unemployment and, on behalf of the Council, I can assure them that the Italian Presidency will do all it can to help create the conditions for the worrying situation of youth unemployment in Europe to be alleviated. Let me express my sincere hope that the excellent cooperation we have had so far on this issue will continue with the new Parliament and the new European Commission. I am convinced that our joint efforts to combat youth unemployment in Europe will soon bear fruit.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: The debate is closed. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. This European Youth Initiative, which integrates the "Youth Guarantee" provides EUR 6 billion in loans, of which EUR 620 million is provided by the YEI and the ESF for France. Of this envelope, only 13 French regions are eligible for this programme. Economically affected regions such as Lorraine will not benefit from these European credits, as the youth unemployment rate is considered "satisfactory".  This program for NEETs (young people without education, training and without employment) will not simplify the situation since it will build on existing devices without really pooling them (platforms, missions and others). On the other hand, the proposed objectives will not allow young people to enter the labour market in a sustainable way and will only be palliatives to the crisis (jobs of the future, civic service, etc.).  A proactive employment policy should be pursued, breaking with the ultra-liberal dogmas of Brussels, allowing intelligent border protections, massive support for SMEs rather than multinationals and removing the detachment directive, which contributes to social dumping.

name: Cristian-Silviu BUŞOI
text: in writing. – With a youth unemployment rate in the EU of 23.6%, twice the adult rate, with 7.5 million Non-professional Europeans and non-professional stresses, with a budget of EUR 6 billion , it's an excellent tool.  Unfortunately, there are Member States that have not yet approved the programmes submitted by the Governments to the Commission. These countries include Romania. According to a study by the Academy of Economic Studies in Romania, although last year the youth unemployment rate was below the European average, in the first quarter of 2014 this rate reached 25.7%, after a continuous increase in the last three quarters.  In this context, and given that the employment rate among young people has declined considerably, I call on the European Commission to assist Member States and actively engage in finding solutions for programmes already submitted for approval. I also call on Member States that have not yet started implementing this programme to make efforts in this regard.

name: Tamás DEUTSCH
text: in writing – The European Youth Initiative is primarily aimed at supporting young people under the age of 25 who are not in employment, education or training in regions where the youth unemployment rate exceeded 25% in 2012. Under this criterion, regions in 20 Member States (Hungary) are eligible under the Youth Employment Initiative. The ambition fits well with the EU's Europe 2020 Strategy employment target of 75% employment for 20-64 year olds by 2020. This is a very important issue, as the youth unemployment rate is twice that of adults and their chances in the labour market are much more modest. Even if they find a job, they often only manage to find a temporary job.  A huge problem is the lack of harmony between qualifications and the needs of the labour market, which contributes to the fact that there are more than two million vacancies in the EU today. In the light of the foregoing, I consider the European Youth Initiative and its effective implementation to be extremely important.

name: Adam GIEREK
text: in writing. In its resolution adopted at the time (2014/2713(RSP)), Parliament shared this view, stating that it was necessary to reindustrialize Europe, which would favour policies aimed at growth and thus job creation. Companies will employ more young people when the economic situation is conducive to growth. I believe that these threads must take a sufficiently important place in the current debate on the progress made by the Member States of the European Union, which are implementing the European Youth Initiative, launched in January this year.  When criticising individual national governments for their slow action in implementing this initiative, the question must be asked of the extent to which this is the result of inedibility or even bad will, and to what extent the result of the European economic bad situation. In order to improve it, emphasis should be placed on progress on the reindustrialisation of Europe and the climate and energy package reviewed. It is based on erroneous scientific reasons, negatively affects the EU's economic situation and stimulates the job losses, especially in countries with high energy and heavy industry potential.

name: Michela GIUFFRIDA
text: for iscritt. I welcome Commissioner Andor's announcement on the increase in funds but, as Mr Della Vedova pointed out, the budget is still insufficient, more needs to be done.  In Sicily, the figures are not worrying, but literally tragic. Youth unemployment is well over twice the European average: in 2013, 53%, in 2014 the Diste estimates it at 60%. Other than falling, our indices are constantly rising! We must focus, with structural measures and reforms, on the countries that also suffer most from school drop-out, which causes social exclusion and unemployment.  A particular understanding of growing inequalities within and between Member States is required. In southern Italy "youth guarantee" does not take off, memberships are growing but not work, questions are not answered because companies are in meltdown. This must be affected, even with a different distribution of funds, and the non-inclusion in the deficit criteria, in short with a different approach, so as not to repeat some obvious mistakes of the 'guarantee' that we already know.

name: Krzysztof HETMAN
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The Youth Guarantees were conceived as a structural reform that requires changes in member states' employment policies. Commissioner Andor has recently emphasised this. I agree with that statement. However, the review of pilot projects for guarantees has shown that Member States approach the implementation of the system in different ways. Among the 18 projects, there are fortunately good and exemplary projects whose positive results are already visible - those that are trying to make such a deeper and lasting change. I believe that the next steps should focus on such in-depth reforms and improvements to existing instruments. Instead of creating new cooperation platforms or online portals, Member States should transform their public employment services. The example of the Ireland pilot project shows that this can produce very good results. Furthermore, I consider it important to be adequately involved in the implementation of employers' guarantees. Incentives should be introduced for them, both financially and in the form of simplified regulation, to create new jobs.

name: Agnieszka KOZŁOWSKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Youth unemployment is one of the Union's most serious social and economic problems. Lack of work results in the poverty of many families, poorer educational prospects for this and the next generation, low pensions in the future. In order to prevent the effects of mass youth unemployment, it is necessary to make efficient and efficient use of the tools and funds that the EU has secured for this purpose. Unfortunately, very few Member States make use of the instruments set up under the European Youth Employment Initiative; the Youth Guarantee is being implemented very slowly. It would be urgent to check what the causes of this inertion are. There may be formal barriers that can be lifted by Parliament or the European Commission. This is a very urgent task, as the financial resources allocated to combating unemployment are counted in EUR 1 billion, and every day of delay in taking the necessary measures worsens the situation and increases the risk of cumulation of the dramatic effects of high unemployment among young Europeans. Among the necessary measures, it is necessary to indicate not only the creation of new jobs, but also , perhaps in the first place, the adaptation of the qualifications of the unemployed to vacancies that are already on the market. Employers are unsuccessfully looking for thousands of workers, and at the same time an army of unemployed people are unsuccessfully looking for work. Achieving compatibility between the needs of employers and the qualifications of potential employees is the most urgent objective of educational activities undertaken under the young unemployed programmes.

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: Writing. - Dear Colleagues, Quite rightly, the European Commission places particular emphasis on the Youth Initiative, which the European Parliament has discussed and advocated many times. I have had the pleasure of reporting on the issue of the Youth Initiative in the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, and in the light of the expectations we have seen there, I must say that something has finally moved. At the same time, this is not enough at all, work must be continued jointly and efforts must be made by both the Commission and the Member States. I can repeat my speech in July: I am convinced that by increasing competitiveness, including quality training and quality training for young people, we will be able to really improve these measures. Once again, warn everyone: we are at the last minute. In fact, in the next 10 years, practically, if we do not deal deeply with this issue, we will recreate the problem, and in the next time 30 million unskreated young people will reappear in the labour market in the world. So we have to stop this.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. - I am pleased that all Member States have submitted operational programmes and that all funding from the YeI, totalling €10 billion at EU level, will be contracted by the end of 2015. This is encouraging in relation to the data we have had so far, as implementation does not appear successful in practice.  It would be good if these funds were also disbursed by the end of 2015, as young people need urgent support. Last year I visited more than 20 faculties and held conferences on the possibilities of using EU funds and Union programmes. I spoke to young people and came across numerous examples of young people who: through Erasmus one semester ended up in one of the Member States, then after completing their studies they received additional education funded by the state, were on professional training with the employer - therefore they passed measures that can now be financed from the Youth Employment Initiative - and after all that they are now unemployed again.
