The economy is falling, there are no new jobs, which is why these measures of additional education and temporary employment do not give the desired, longer-term results. We need to help young people get into employment for long periods of time and set aside more measures and resources for entrepreneurial centres, incubators for young people and for self-employment.

name: Marian-Jean MARINESCU
text: in writing. – Youth unemployment has increased alarmingly in the last period at European level. Statistics show that in most Member States the lack of jobs is the main problem facing the population. Basically, today one in four young people do not work, although they should be the main active workforce. At The level of the Member States there are still very large discrepancies between youth unemployment rates: from almost 8% in Germany to over 50% in Greece, Spain, Croatia. There is a need for a number of common measures taken at European level to incentivise employers to employ young graduates and unemployed people up to the age of 29. I also propose the establishment of committees to monitor very carefully the use of European funds allocated to solve the problem of youth unemployment. They are countries, such as Romania where there is absolutely no result in this.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. – Youth unemployment is twice as high as the other categories. Today, unemployment is over 23%, compared to 9% in 2012. More than 70% of young employees have fixed-term or part-time contracts. 13% of young Europeans are not registered as unemployed or in some form of education. I come from a country, Romania, where the government has done a lot for young people, being even the fourth European country to implement the European Youth Guarantee. However, I believe that neither the Council nor the Commission understand the gravity of the situation. 6 billion euros for 6 million unemployed under 25 is not enough! What about young people between the ages of 25 and 40? I repeat the information in such a way as to understand the gravity of the situation: - 6 million unemployed young people in Europe - 6 million young people with no future in Europe - 6 million young people who have nothing to live in Europe. These aren't just numbers, we're talking about people!

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: in writing.–  As one of the youngest MEPs, I want to underline that young people must be not only the subject, but also the driver of the European Youth Initiative. The role of the EU in this process is to create a fruitful enabling environment for developing the potential and realising the ideas of the new generation. An important step in this direction is reforming old rigid structures and promoting new, more flexible systems in every Member State. If young people have their say, they will stand up for an education that is no longer focused on memorising and reproducing information, but on fostering practical skills and analytical thinking. This is what the current labour market needs. We must therefore be more proactive with bottom-up initiatives, where young people decide on the design and content of educational and work programmes.  If we empower young people, we will have a new generation with the capacity and motivation to build their own professional life. And these will be the problem-solvers, the creators, the entrepreneurs, who can create jobs and move the economy forward. This is the best guarantee for the youth; the only way to tackle youth unemployment.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. - I support the Council and Commission report as well as the support they show to young people as a group particularly hard hit by the recession. Statistics from July 2014 show that we currently have 5 million unemployed young people up to the age of 25 in the EU28. Statistically at EU level, there is a positive trend in youth employment, as the number of unemployed young people decreased by 563 000 compared to July last year. That's certainly cause for optimism. However, a detailed look at the data by Member State and especially by region tells us that there are regions that have a very negative perspective on youth employment.  For this reason, I support the European Youth Employment Initiative for 2014-2015 and define a threshold of over 30% growth in the youth unemployment rate in 2012 in the Member States and a threshold of over 25% youth unemployment at regional NUTS 2 level as the basis for entry into the aid package. The Council's proposal for a European Youth Initiative speaks of allocating a total of €6 billion between 2014-2020, of which €3 billion would be allocated from the European budget and another 3 from the European Social Fund.  I welcome this strong signal to young people, but also to the European Parliament resolution of July this year, and hope to introduce minimum standards for traineeships, as well as the appropriate payment of youth work.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. Ladies and gentlemen, it is essential to create the conditions for youth employment, taking into account the specificities of the labour markets of the various Member States. The Europe of tomorrow is in their hands! To avoid having a generation sacrificed, we must fight against the structural causes of youth unemployment. Let us take the evil at the root: by investing in learning, by strengthening training, and in particular technical, professional and technological studies, so that they better correspond to the realities experienced by young people and by companies. In a coordinated approach and partnership between Training and Employment, let us use dedicated means to create jobs for young people in promising sectors, to develop internships and tutoring and to promote mobility. To do this, Europe must give itself the means of its ambitions by supplementing the budget of 6 billion euros for the hardest-hit regions. The policies have been passed, it is now a question of implementing them and controlling their implementation! It goes without saying that these measures will be all the more relevant if they are linked to the 300 billion investment plan proposed by the Commission.

name: Anne SANDER
text: In writing. Commissioner, we are going through an unprecedented crisis and our young people are the first victims of it. Precarity, unemployment, resignation: our younger generation is in trouble. The European Youth Initiative must be acted upon and implemented quickly. Unfortunately, the Commission's low level of advance is worrying. Do we want to discourage our local missions and associations because of cash flow problems? If Europe is to act effectively, it must do so in line with the economic reality of its territories. I come from a region, Alsace, which is not eligible for the Youth Initiative. Yet it suffers from high youth unemployment. At the same time, the other projects of the European Social Fund must be pursued. I am thinking in particular of Erasmus for young entrepreneurs.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. – I have repeatedly welcomed the European Council's decision on the Youth Employment Initiative, which lives in regions with unemployment rates above 25 percent, unfortunately croatia is among those regions. The harsh fact is that in 2014 the year is at an end, many EU member states, as well as Croatia, are not withdrawing the available funds, and unemployment is not decreasing. It is inadmissible for those least to blame for the economic crisis to pay the most, and these are the young. The youth guarantee is good, but it must not be the only instrument of employment, but should be complemented by good macroeconomic policies and an additional impulse of youth employment. We need reforms, we need an effective and competitive Europe, and that means new jobs. How to justify employment policies when 5.2 young people in the Union are not working - what we can freely call the 29th EU member state. I believe that the education and competence of young people is not in doubt, and the real problem is that we do not have strong and competitive enough economies. The policies have been voted and that is why I am now urging member states to mobilise and activate themselves, and here I unfortunately have to mention Croatia, which is at the very top in terms of youth unemployment, and at the same time has not launched the Youth Guarantee instrument.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. – It is a shame for Europe that, in recent times, neither the majority of Member States nor the Union as a whole have been able to effectively reduce youth unemployment. The Social Democratic Youth Guarantee Programme is a good initiative, but it can only be really effective if we increase the allocated funds and raise the age limit to 30. In several Member States, even the use of resources has not started. However, the problem exists and the steps cannot wait. Two months ago, I also drew attention to the need to monitor the use of funds in the Member States at EU level. Only in this way can we guarantee that resources are used for the right purposes and effectively everywhere. The question now is whether any steps have been made by the Commission to implement the EU audit that has been called for and how does the Commission intend to encourage the development of appropriate programmes in the Member States and thus accelerate the use of resources?

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. – When the Juncker Commission takes office, a new period and a new time will begin in the political direction of the European Parliament, the European community. Firstly, I would like to thank THE EU Commissioner for Employment László Andor for his dedicated work in recent years: he has a number of important initiatives and achievements to his name. However, there is still plenty of work to be done. Last year, 26.6 million people were out of work in Europe, and the consequences of the economic crisis hit young people hardest: in 2013, the number of unemployed people under the age of 25 in the European Union reached almost six million. The Youth Employment Initiative and the Youth Guarantee Programme are important handrails, but far from sufficient.  Hundreds of thousands of people are leaving their home countries, mainly from Eastern and Central Europe, to find prosperity in more developed countries due to austerity economic constraints. There are hundreds of thousands of people who migrate not out of 'adventurousness', not for learning purposes or taking advantage of labour mobility in Europe, but from a simple, painful need to make ends meet. The European Union must respond and help the hundreds of thousands who, if they were able to do so, would be repatriation from their economic emigration. This is why, as a Hungarian MEMBER, I launched the Hungarian Home Waiting Programme, providing targeted assistance and seeking social refugees in my own country. I will take the initiative, week after week, to launch a comprehensive EU programme to support young people who wish to return to their home countries and want to build a new existential system there. Europe must not leave its citizens in forced exile.

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent report and for his excellent work. I would ask you to take a seat. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent report, which In the early morning of 1 September 75 years ago, the Second World War began with the invasion of neighbouring Poland by Nazi Germany. A world fire was unleashed, driven by an insane ideology, which, in its rage of destruction, in the madness of manor, sought to destroy other countries on the grounds of a habitat policy. Other countries should be exploited, enslaved, entire peoples should be wiped out. This was followed by radicalization, which led to what was called the "total war". This was preceded by a cynical pact between Hitler and Stalin, which led to two armies invading Poland, Germany raiding Russia and bringing immense suffering to the country, with the result that six years later Germany was also completely destroyed. 60 million dead, fallen on battlefields, starved in captivity, civilians, men, women, old people, children, arbitrarily murdered, systematically wiped out, driven out of their homes, died miserably on the streets, fallen on the battlefields, devastated and devastated by incendiary bombs, fallen in the rifle salvos, executed at the gallows or driven into the gas chambers – the civilisational low point of human history, the genocide of the Jews. Ladies and gentlemen! This breach of civilization casts its shadows to this day. We remember thousands of years back to atrocities that took place at that time. How can we believe that almost 70 years after this breach of civilization, something could be forgotten? We are all today, every day, under the impression of this devastating war and its effects. One result of this war was the will of the generations who had experienced the First and Second World Wars to create an order in Europe that would make it impossible for this to happen again. Transnational cooperation between peoples across borders – and not just across physical borders, but across economic borders, across cultural borders, across religious borders – has created the Europe we have today. And this multinational assembly of parliamentarians is a result of this will. Here, Members of the European nations sit together in free self-determination. In our Parliament there are different religions, different races, different political beliefs, representatives of different cultures and nations, but united with one will: that this must not be repeated on our continent. It is a miracle that reconciliation has succeeded on this continent after everything that has happened in our Europe. For me, it is always a fascinating moment that captivates me when I come to this Chamber and see that, in free self-determination, we are creating a Europe that has managed to overcome war and hunger, to tear down borders and walls, which has succeeded in overcoming its artificial division according to the Yalta order and living together today in a united Europe. The miracle of European unification can help us ensure that such a human catastrophe does not happen again. Ladies and gentlemen! We have no guarantee of this. We did not conjure up the war. It exists. We have created institutions and structures that make it likely that war will not return to our peoples. But that is because we have these transnational structures. If we smash them, there is also the danger that ultranationalism, hatred, racial hatred, the madness of men's manbeing can return to Europe. We have created an immune system against war, but we have not eliminated the war. And there are people in Europe who are afraid of war. Borders on our continent are once again being shifted unilaterally. We must be attentive. Peace and freedom are the great privilege of the post-war generation to which I belong. As a German, I am one of those who have not taken on individual guilt – I was born after the war – but who have an individual responsibility that I want to live up to – just as all those who know that peace, tolerance and respect only have an effect if they are not written on paper, but are implemented in daily practice. The great strength of this Parliament is that we are doing just that. That is why the European Parliament has a special responsibility to recognise that peace, tolerance and solidarity must be defended every day, because they threaten every day anew. Be. That is why the work of this multinational assembly of parliamentarians is a good instrument – not the only instrument, but a good one – to defend our Europe of respect and peace. In memory of the victims of the Second World War, our common task should be to consider peace in Europe, tolerance and respect as our primary task. (Applause) (The President gives members technical advice for the 360-degree photograph taken afterwards.)

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: Before we get to the votes, I have a request for you, ladies and gentlemen. At the end of the votes, when we have completed all the votes, I would ask you to sit for a short moment, because I will then have to make an important communication to you. The next item on the agenda is voting time. (For results and other details of the vote: see Minutes).

name: Liadh NÍ RIADA
text: Rapóirtéir. - A Uachtaráin, de bharr an chúlaithe eacnamaíochta agus an strus atá ar oibrithe i láthair na huaire is coiste thar a bheith tábhachtach é an Coigeartú don Domhandú.  Ciste Eorpach um Choigeartú don Domhandú sna Ballstáit atá ag déileáil le srianta tromchúiseacha sóisialta, eacnamaíochta agus airgeadais a chur i ngluaiseacht.  Taispeánann sé chomh maith go bhfuil géarghá ann cabhair a spreagadh chun féinriail agus sorochtaineacht ag leibhéal réigiúnach a chur i bhfeidhm chun réiteach áitiúil a chumasú ag leibhéal réigiúnach maidir le haon chás a thagann faoi raon an Chiste Eorpaigh um Choigeartú don Domhandú. Fáiltím go mbeidh níos mó comhordú agus comhoibriú ann, agus scagadh eolais, ionas go gcruthóidh sé an comhoibriú seo idir na Ballstáit agus na réigiúin. Mar sin, a chomhghleacaithe, impím oraibh tacaíocht a thabhairt don leasú seo agus glacadh leis.

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: That concludes the vote.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this report which introduces amendments to the legal framework of the European Globalisation Adjustment Funds. In particular, the minimum number of unemployed persons to apply for the Fund is reduced from 500 to 200, and funding is provided for the state side of those states with social, economic or financial constrictions; the leading role of the regions in their implementation is increased and finally the heading for the EGF is increased, which will become part of the regular EU budget. That's why I voted for it.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: Writing. I welcome the reports on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. The European Globalisation Fund helps workers who have fallen victim to the closure of a large company or the relocation of a large production plant outside the EU to reintegrate into the labour market through targeted measures. The annual budget of the Fund is set at a maximum annual amount of €150 million in the 2014-2020 budget phase. The Globalisation Fund complements the ESF and is an important instrument for reintegration into the European labour market, which is undergoing rapid change as a a force arising from globalisation. The measures financed include vocational guidance, vocational training and traineeships, assistance in taking up self-employed activities, renting the production site and paying the rent for the duration of the project, travel allowance, application grant, flat-rate residence allowance and traineeship allowance, and support after taking up a new job. The aim of these measures is to promote workers as specifically as possible. The fund is deliberately individual is designed and does not serve to restructure companies or sectors.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. - This technical assistance from the European Commission should provide a better understanding of the measures proposed and implemented under the EGF, which will promote the sharing of information and the strengthening of the effectiveness of the measures. In addition, this assistance will facilitate the application process and analyse the extension of the scope of the EGF.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. The current economic and social situation in Europe obliges us to rescue those who, victims of globalisation and ultraliberalism, lose their jobs. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EMF) is there to train and retrain workers who are victims of relocation and the financial crisis.  The technical assistance funds to this fund correspond to the maximum of 0.5% of its budget, here it is 330,000 euros.  On this vote, I abstained not out of a desire not to rescue workers in difficulty but to mean that this fund would not have been if Brussels had not pursued ultra-liberal policies and opened our borders wide to unfair competition from all over the world.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. - (IT) I agree with the positions expressed in Mr De Clercq's report. I therefore voted in favour of mobilising 0.5% of the EGF to cover the costs of technical assistance on the Commission's initiative.

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: Written. I have voted in favour of these reports today. I therefore do so to provide workers in the cases in question with financial support for retraining and/or other measures to find new jobs. However, I would like to stress that the high level of unemployment in europe could be effectively combated if the austerity policies of the European Commission and the governments of the Member States have long been pursued could be stopped. Creating new jobs in Europe requires a new economic policy with massive public and environmentally friendly investments. Public investment is needed in schools, health and social care, but also in infrastructure, rail, public transport, energy-efficient housing and sustainable energy systems.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. - (IT) Technical vote, I voted in favour of the allocation of the fund.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. I voted in favour of mobilising the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EMF) for the measures proposed by the Commission, under technical assistance. This fund was established in 2006 by Regulation (EC) No. 1927/2006 to help workers who have lost their jobs as a result of major structural changes brought about by globalization. In the face of the global economic and financial crisis, it must therefore provide effective and appropriate assistance. But it is still little known to the general public and its mobilization by the Member States is little known.  The Commission will be able to fund the WEF Contact Expert Group, which facilitates the networking and exchange of information on the EGF. The Commission will also be able to ease the administrative burden on Member States by working on an electronic application form for the EGF mobilization.  To vote for this mobilization is to enable a simplified and effective mobilization of the EGF, necessary in this time of crisis.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. - Between 2007 and 2013, more than EUR 400 million was allocated to tens of thousands of workers made redundant as a result of globalisation and the economic crisis. The goal? He retrains it to find a new job or launch a new company. This aid was made available by the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF), which was set up to provide additional support to workers who have lost their jobs, for example in the event of the closure of a business or relocation of a production to a non-EU country, or as a result of the global economic and financial crisis. I voted in favour of this report today because I agree with the proposed measures, which will help to simplify the application procedure and provide better access to the EGF. In particular, I support the extension of the Fund's scope for eligible beneficiaries, i.e. the self-employed, and the provision of tailor-made services co-financed by the EGF for a certain number of young unemployed people who are not enrolled in a course of education or training. I also very much welcome the extension of the objectives and criteria of the EGF in order to integrate and facilitate applications from regions and countries with lower population densities.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in favour of mobilising an amount of EUR 330 000 from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) to cover technical assistance on the Commission's initiative. The Fund was set up to provide additional support to workers affected by the consequences of major structural changes in world trade. The objective of technical assistance is to finance monitoring and information, to create a knowledge/interface base and to advise Member States on the use, continuity and evaluation of the EGF, and I believe that these are all necessary measures for the effective use of the EGF.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. - The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) was set up to provide additional support to workers affected by the effects of major structural changes in world trade patterns and to assist in their reintegration into the labour market. Regulation (EC) No 1927/2006 provides that 0.5 % of the maximum annual amount of the EGF may be made available annually for technical assistance at the initiative of the European Commission (EC).  I agree with the European Commission's proposal to mobilise EUR 330 000 to cover technical assistance expenditure to the Commission, with the aim of monitoring the applications received and financed and the measures proposed and implemented, expanding the website and translating new elements into all the languages of the Union, increasing the visibility of the EGF, drawing up publications and audiovisual media, providing administrative and technical support to the Member States. With this funding we will contribute to the simplification of the application processes that will allow better access to relevant data, the sharing of knowledge and information through the website, leading to a more efficient future implementation of this Fund.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. - (IT) In view of the usefulness that the Globalisation Adjustment Fund has shown in recent years in support of all those companies in difficulty, I can only agree with the allocation of EUR 330 thousand for technical assistance. The amount will be used to finance preparation, monitoring, data collection, administrative and technical support, training and communication activities, the creation of a database, as well as audits, control and evaluation, factors necessary for the application of the EGF Regulation. I also support what the rapporteur, Ni Riada, has said in her report, namely to encourage the Commission to increase the visibility of the EGF in the context of further actions and to urge those Member States that have benefited from this instrument to publicise the actions financed by the EGF.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. – I voted in favour to support the provision of additional assistance to workers suffering from the consequences of major structural changes in world trade partners.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. - (IT) I am convinced that technical assistance in order to make the best use of European funds is very important. I also think it is important to start providing, on the part of the European institutions, a standard and proven mechanism of technical assistance that will give the likely recipients of European funds active help in the design, demand and management of European resources. Today, in many Italian regions, the resources allocated to technical assistance are the subject of investigations and condemnations by the competent authorities. For the above reasons, I have chosen to abstain.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this report which introduces amendments to the legal framework of the European Globalisation Adjustment Funds. In particular, the minimum number of unemployed persons to apply for the Fund is reduced from 500 to 200, and funding is provided for the state side of those states with social, economic or financial constrictions; the leading role of the regions in their implementation is increased and finally the heading for the EGF is increased, which will become part of the regular EU budget. That's why I voted for it.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. – I have voted in favour of this proposal, as I believe that the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) is an important tool that needs to be supported and developed further. This tool was established to provide support for workers made redundant and self-employed persons whose activities have ceased as a result of major structural changes in world trade patterns due to globalisation. I believe that the mobilisation of EUR 330 000 from the Fund, covering technical assistance for the Commission, is important in that it provides funds and support for further analysis of this tool. The objective of the technical assistance is to finance monitoring and information with the aim of creating a knowledge-based interface and to advise Member States on using, following up and evaluating the EGF. Furthermore, the provision of this technical assistance is already stipulated in the EGF Regulation itself.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. This text provides for a number of measures aimed at improving knowledge of the various situations for which the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EMF) is being sought. It also aims to make application processing more efficient. It is, in fact, essential to help employees who have lost their jobs quickly. My support for this text also extends to the reflection on the possibility of mobilising the EGF for young people in great difficulty.

name: Tamás DEUTSCH
text: Writing. - The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was set up to provide additional support to workers affected by the consequences of major structural changes in world trade. The Commission proposal includes the use of EUR 330 000 from the Fund for technical support. The purpose of technical assistance is to finance supervision, information and the establishment of a knowledge base interface, as well as to advise Member States on the use, monitoring and evaluation of the EGF. Pursuant to Article 11(1) of the EGF Regulation, 0.5% of the EGF maximum annual amount may be used for technical assistance each year on the initiative of the Commission. I supported the report in the plenary vote.

name: Pablo ECHENIQUE
text: in writing. - EGF is a tool that seeks the relocation of laid-off workers in sectors particularly hit by "globalization". To this end, it allocates most of the funds to training, mentoring, accompaniment and development of "personal skills", while only a small portion of them goes directly into the pocket of the workers and only if they follow obediently the proposed itinerary or in the unlikely event that they get a job as a result of the program. The positive vote is explained by the recognition that any aid directed at those individuals and families who are suffering is welcome. Under no circumstances does it imply acceptance of the paternalistic and unfair logic underlying the design of this fund. People who have lost their jobs have not lost it because of lack of training and certainly do not need "incentives" to learn computer science or seek employment. They have lost it because the economy and the productive fabric have been severely undermined by powers that never consulted them and seek only the private benefit of a tiny minority.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Writing. - I voted against this project because the sums are proposed to be given to training and retraining companies for the unemployed and not directly to those who have lost their jobs and need them. Consequently, the majority of the appropriations will result in entrepreneurs who have not suffered the consequences of the economic crisis.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. - The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund aims to express the reintegration of redundant workers who have suffered the consequences of liberalisation and deregulation of world trade. These are unacceptable costs, determined and taken advantage of by those who have brought us to the profound economic crisis in which we find ourselves and by those who make it the case for deepening the precariousness and exploitation of workers. In December 2013, negotiations to amend the EGF Regulation brought negative results, with the maximum annual ceiling from €500 million to €150 million being lowered, while extending the scope of the fund.  This report agrees with the measures proposed by the European Commission to finance technical assistance, in particular as to mobilising EUR 330 000 for monitoring, information, establishing a knowledge base/interface and advising Member States on the use and evaluation of the EGF, although the Regulation points to up to 0.5 % of the maximum annual amount of the EGF (EUR 750 000). The report in question considers that the Fund would be more effective and of much greater impact if the allocation criterion went from 500 to 200 workers, also insisting on increasing total resources to at least EUR 500 million. Support.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. - The Reg. (EU) No 1309/2013 states that 0.5% of the maximum annual amount of the EGF may be used annually for technical assistance (data update, simplification) on the initiative of the Commission, which is in favour of mobilising an amount of € 330,000.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. – I am voting against the report because two thirds of the disbursement of funds from the Fund, which covers the Commission's technical assistance, will go to companies and institutes whose usefulness has so far not provided what is expected in the main problem, namely the creation of new jobs especially for young people, but remains at theoretical levels. I believe that some benefit financially at the expense of European taxpayers.

name: Ashley FOX
text: in writing. – The ECR Group is opposed in principle to the use of this fund and I have voted against as a result.  The use of the EGF as a remedy for long-term structural imbalances is both unnecessary and ineffective. The EGF is too often being used to supplement the income support already provided by national governments, and I do not believe this to be an appropriate use of EU resources. There is very little evidence that the EGF even helps those workers for whom it was designed, and its implementation is a hindrance to the natural functioning of the single market.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. - EGF is a tool that seeks the relocation of laid-off workers in sectors particularly hit by "globalization". To this end, it allocates most of the funds to training, mentoring, accompaniment and development of "personal skills", while only a small portion of them goes directly into the pocket of the workers and only if they follow obediently the proposed itinerary or in the unlikely event that they get a job as a result of the program. The positive vote is explained by the recognition that any aid directed at those individuals and families who are suffering is welcome. Under no circumstances does it imply acceptance of the paternalistic and unfair logic underlying the design of this fund. People who have lost their jobs have not lost it because of lack of training and certainly do not need "incentives" to learn computer science or seek employment. They have lost it because the economy and the productive fabric have been severely undermined by powers that never consulted them and seek only the private benefit of a tiny minority.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. – I support this report and the need to have a European instrument to assist redundant workers. I am glad that Parliament fully supported the setting up of the EGF as part of the MFF for 2014 to 2020.  It is important to ease the administrative burden for Member States by simplifying the application process and to monitor the implementation of the fund to ensure maximum value is obtained for current and future applications.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report by my colleague Liadh N-Riada on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. This fund allows people who have lost their jobs as a result of the crisis to receive financial assistance to set up projects or to find a job. The report was adopted by a large majority. I welcome the result of this vote.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. - (IT) I am voting in favour of Mr De Clercq's report. Liadh Nì Riada as I consider the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to be a fundamental support for those who have lost their jobs, as a result of major structural changes in world trade due to globalisation. In times of crisis such as the present one, the creation of new jobs and the protection of existing jobs are absolute priorities of our political action.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. - The Globalisation Adjustment Fund plays an important role as an instrument of Community support for countries and regions which, by using these funds, meet their own important needs. I am pleased that there has been no problem obtaining a qualified majority, which demonstrates the advisability of creating and using this fund. I share the views and assessments expressed by rapporteur Ní Riada. At the same time, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her good work, as this technical assistance report makes it possible to approve the remaining five reports on specific applications.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this report which introduces amendments to the legal framework of the European Globalisation Adjustment Funds. In particular, the minimum number of unemployed persons to apply for the Fund is reduced from 500 to 200, and funding is provided for the state side of those states with social, economic or financial constrictions; the leading role of the regions in their implementation is increased and finally the heading for the EGF is increased, which will become part of the regular EU budget. That's why I voted for it.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: in writing. - We announce the vote in favour of the proposal for a Resolution for the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF), on the proposed implementation to meet technical assistance needs at the initiative of the Commission. I would like to express my full agreement with the Commission on the need to improve the means to better inform potential beneficiaries and extend the mobilisation of these funds, and we are particularly in line with the proposed new measures, such as special care for unemployed young people under the age of 25 who are not currently pursuing any education or training programmes (NEET). It is also right for us to strengthen assistance at the regional and local levels, broadering the scope spectrum of the EGF, as it is allowed to be accessed from regions and municipalities with lower population density. Finally, we would like to support the motion for a Resolution on the requirement of greater economic endowment and less conditionality to access it.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. - As the Commission uses technical assistance to support and improve the use of the European Globalisation Fund to Member States, the Commission has thus accelerated the transfer of financial assistance to redundant workers and since technical assistance costs have been reduced in 2014 compared to the previous year, I supported the Report on the Mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for Technical Assistance.  The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was set up with the aim of further assisting redundary workers and the self-employed who had to cease their activities as a result of globalisation. This report aims to provide an amount of EUR 330 000 for the preparation, monitoring and exchange of information, knowledge base creation, administrative and technical support, which is extremely important for faster and better implementation of the Fund.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, the EGF, is part of the funds allocated by the European Union to economically support certain sectors in difficulty in the Member States and all those workers who are suffering the consequences of the economic crisis. The Commission's proposal concerns the mobilisation of an amount of EUR 330 000 from the Fund to cover the assistance needed to simplify the application procedure and provide better access to data. In practice, some experts from outside the European Commission will be needed to improve and ensure the functionality of the database and for the assessment of individual cases.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. - The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is a symbol of the hypocrisy of the current European Union. On the one hand, free and undistorted competition and relocations are encouraged, and on the other hand a miserable remedy is created with the "potential negative consequences" of this policy. According to the regulation relating to this fund, a maximum of 0.5% of its annual amount can be allocated each year, on the initiative of the Commission, to finance administrative and technical support activities as well as audit, monitoring and evaluation activities.  The Commission proposes to allocate EUR 330,000 for this technical assistance. The rapporteur of the GUE/NGL group has made concrete proposals to improve this European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. Thus it is proposed to lower the threshold for the mobilization of this fund to 200 workers, instead of 500. Without illusions about this fund, I abstain on this report which allows to improve its functioning at the margin.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. - The EU is an area of solidarity and is part of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. This support is essential to help the unemployed and the victims of relocations in a globalised context. More and more companies are relocating, taking advantage of the low labour prices, which are practised in several countries, notably China, India and Pakistan, with harmful effects on countries that respect workers' rights. The EGF is intended to help workers who are victims of business relocation and is key to facilitating access to new employment. In this case, the Commission requested the mobilisation of the EGF to cover expenditure on technical assistance in order to monitor the applications received and financed and the measures proposed and implemented, to expand the website and translate new elements into all union languages, increase the visibility of the EGF, develop publications and audiovisual media, create a knowledge base , provide administrative and technical support to Member States and regional authorities and do not require funds for evaluations in 2014.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. – Up to 0.5% of the annual European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) amount can be made available each year for technical assistance at the initiative of the European Commission, in order to provide financing for the preparation, monitoring, data-gathering and creation of a knowledge base, administrative and technical support, information and communication activities as well as audit, control and evaluation activities necessary to implement the EGF Regulation, as stipulated in Article 11(1) of that Regulation. This report confirms that the EUR 330 000 that have been proposed to be mobilised by the European Commission for technical assistance in 2014 is below the maximum of 0.5% of the annual maximum amount of the EGF. Moreover, this same report confirms that the measures proposed by the European Commission to be financed as technical assistance are in accordance with the EGF Regulation. I have therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. The modern world brings its share of opportunities and challenges. Thus European companies are not immune to the perverse effects of uncontrolled globalisation. The European Union has set itself the goal of combining solidarity and economic growth. Economic growth makes sense if it serves all European citizens. The Union understands this and is seen by some as an example of successful regional globalisation.  As representatives elected by citizens, we have an obligation to help the most disadvantaged. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EMF) is an indispensable tool to achieve this. It is now a matter of increasing its effectiveness. To achieve this, the agreement provides for allocating 0.5% of the maximum EGF budget to improve technology assistance. By allocating this amount of money, the fund would be more efficient and visible to the citizens who need it most.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. – I fully support this report because the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund provides support to people losing their jobs as a result of major structural changes or a result of the global economic and financial crisis.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is used for training and retraining workers who are victims of relocation or/or the financial and economic crisis. This economic and social damage is generated directly by the ultraliberal dogma defended by the EU.  However, given the economic situation and the massive deindustrialization in the euro area, this fund is necessary. However, it would not be if the submissive governments of the Member States had not politically encouraged the savage globalisation and ultraliberalism that are destroying our industries, our businesses and our jobs. We have to decide here on technical assistance to this fund. According to Article 11, paragraph 1 of the WEF regulation, 0.5% of its budget can be spent on these appropriations, totalling 750,000 euros, and we are being asked here to budget for 330,000 euros. These credits are used for assistance to states, even if we pay these subsidies mainly to support the countries of Eastern Europe which also participate in the unfair competition that France is experiencing. On the other hand, the cost of the 2 expert meetings (70,000 euros), 2 seminars (120,000 euros) or the website (20,000 euros) contributes to the waste of public money. For these reasons, I abstained.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. - The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund helps people who have lost their jobs as a result of globalisation, the economic crisis or a disruption of international trade. This vote concerns a request from the European Commission to finance the technical part of this financial aid. I voted in favour because the European Commission wants, among other things, to change the procedure for submitting applications for aid to simplify the process and allow for faster mobilization of funds.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. - (IT) We welcome the adoption of this report because we believe that the measures proposed by the Commission can provide better technical assistance and help simplify the procedure for submitting applications for the activation of the EGF.   In particular, we intend to support the measures identified for the sharing of knowledge and information through a specific website, through the networking of groups and networks of experts at local, regional and national level; we also support the extension of its scope with regard to eligible beneficiaries, i.e. the self-employed, as well as the provision of personalized services to those unemployed young people who are not enrolled in a cycle of education or training under the age of 25 or, if the Member States so decide, under the age of 30. All these new circumstances require us to increase the resources available to the Fund, at least to return to the previous level of appropriations, amounting to EUR 500 million, taking into account in particular the extension of its scope in line with the strategic priorities set by the EU.  Finally, we agree with the rapporteur that, for reasons of transparency and accountability, we need to promote the inclusion of the EGF in the European Union budget.

name: Dan NICA
text: in writing. - I voted for the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) - application for EGF/2014/000 TA 2014 - Technical assistance at the initiative of the Commission. The Commission requested that the EGF be mobilised to cover expenditure related to technical assistance for monitoring applications received and paid and measures proposed and implemented, to expand the website and translate new elements into all Union languages, in order to increase the visibility of the EGF and in particular to provide administrative and technical support to Member States and regional authorities. We stress the importance of establishing better links between all those involved in the formulation of EGF requests for assistance, in particular between the social partners and local and regional stakeholders, in order to create as many synergies as possible. We call on the Member States and all the institutions involved to make the necessary efforts to improve procedural and budgetary mechanisms in order to accelerate the mobilisation of the EGF. Last but not least, I stress that the Union's financial assistance to redundant workers should be adequate and made available as quickly and efficiently as possible.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this globalisation adjustment fund because the Commission's action requires enough flexibility to adapt to the needs of workers made redundant in the European Union. In this sense, I would like to see the activation of such a fund, the purpose of which is to provide additional support to this policy of the European Commission.

name: Laurenţiu REBEGA
text: in writing. - I believe that the development of these legislative and budgetary instruments is an important step on the part of the European Union, with the aim of providing additional support to workers affected by the major changes and crises that occur in the structure of global trade. I strongly support Parliament's cooperation with the European Commission and that it must invite Parliament's representatives to the meetings and seminars of the expert group, in accordance with the applicable provisions of the Framework Agreement on relations between the European Parliament and the European Commission.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. I welcome today's vote and will always support these reports on the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. Because in a crisis situation, it is necessary to intervene for the affected workers but also because it is important to rethink the Fund so that it is more proactive, faster and can concern companies with less than 500 people. It should be noted that the September plenary session will have seen this Fund apply to new cases in Spain, Romania and the Netherlands.

name: Matteo SALVINI
text: in writing. — (IT) I have chosen to vote in favour of Mr De Clercq's report. Ní Riada as the Reg. (EU) No 1309/2013 states that 0.5% of the maximum annual amount of the EGF may be used annually for technical assistance on the Commission's initiative. The Commission therefore proposes to mobilise an amount of € 330,000

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. – Since 2007 the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund has supported workers who lost their jobs as a result of major structural changes in world trade patterns caused by globalisation. In the period 2014-2020 the scheme will be available for additional categories of beneficiaries. Not only employed workers made redundant can benefit from EGF projects but also the self-employed, temporary workers and fixed-term workers. If redundancies occur in a region eligible under the Youth Employment Initiative, such as the West Midlands, a temporary derogation (until end-2017) will enable Member States to offer services to an equal number of young people not in employment, education or training (NEETs). The UK has never made an application under this fund. UK workers therefore receive none of this support.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. - The resolution agrees with the Commission's proposed measures to be financed by the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, which are a necessary tool for better and easier use of funds to help Member States. Parliament also supports the Commission in working to standardise procedures for easier application, speed up the application processing process and better reporting in order to reduce the administration's burden on Member States. It also underlines the importance of increasing general awareness of the role of the EGF.  The resolution calls on member states to take advantage of and exchange positive experiences of those countries, regional and local authorities, which have assistance programmes ready for situations falling under the AUTHORITY of the EGF. It welcomes the decision to extend criteria that would seek to further assist sparsely populated countries and regions, although this can still be worked on.  A particularly significant point of the resolution relates to the expansion of the offer of assistance to the self-employed, but also to persons who are not employed or in the process of education or vocational training, under the age of 25 or if the member state decides to put the limit at 30 years. This is a significant measure in the fight against rising youth unemployment. Although, Parliament considers that even more effective measures would be increased if the limit of the unemployed was set at 200 instead of 500 people.

name: Kay SWINBURNE
text: in writing. – I voted against this report today. I am opposed in principle to the use of this European Globalisation Adjustment Fund and as a result I cannot support this proposal to mobilise it.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. - I am voting against because most of the funds will be given to technical support companies, to Commission services which supposedly aim to increase the employment of young people, rather than to youth employment programmes.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. - I voted in favour of the text. I agree that the measures proposed by the Commission should be funded as technical assistance, which should simplify the application process and ensure better access to useful data.  The proposed measures on the sharing of knowledge and information are highlighted through the WEF website and expert groups and networks at the local, regional and national levels, which, together with a better overview of the functioning of the EGF, could allow for perspective in the future. I also recommend facilitating, for a better Europe, access at the regional level, in order to enable local solutions at the regional or local level in the event that a situation within the scope of the EGF arises.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this report which introduces amendments to the legal framework of the European Globalisation Adjustment Funds. In particular, the minimum number of unemployed persons to apply for the Fund is reduced from 500 to 200, and funding is provided for the state side of those states with social, economic or financial constrictions; the leading role of the regions in their implementation is increased and finally the heading for the EGF is increased, which will become part of the regular EU budget. That's why I voted for it.

name: Derek VAUGHAN
text: in writing. – I support today’s report to provide technical assistance to the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. The EGF provides support to people losing their jobs as a result of major structural changes in world trade due to globalisation. This support includes help with looking for a new job, careers advice, education and other areas of support and guidance, and I am pleased that young people not in employment, education or training in regions with high youth unemployment can also benefit from EGF support.  The EGF is a vital tool to be utilised by the European Union in order to assist those who have lost their jobs due to unforeseen circumstances resulting from the globalisation of the world’s economy.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. - We regret that in December 2013 the negotiations for the EGF have brought negative results, and the maximum annual ceiling from EUR 500 million has been reduced, while increasing the scope of the fund.  This report agrees with the measures proposed by the Commission for the financing of technical assistance, in particular as to the mobilisation of EUR 330 000 for monitoring, information, establishing a knowledge base/interface and advising Member States on the use and evaluation of the EGF.  The Regulation, however, points to up to 0.5 % of the maximum annual amount of the EGF (EUR 750 000), also stressing the need to strengthen the link between all those working on EGF applications, including, inter alia, the social partners and stakeholders at regional/local level, and considers that the fund would be more effective and of much greater impact if the allocation criterion went from 500 to 200 workers, also insisting on increasing the fund to at least EUR 500 million.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. - The official objective of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is to express the reintegration of redundant workers who have suffered the consequences of the unacceptable socio-economic costs of the liberalisation of world trade, exploited by those who make the economic, financial and social crisis the irreprehensible argument for deepening the precariousness and insecurity of workers. In December 2013, negotiations for the EGF brought negative results, and the maximum annual ceiling from €500 million to €150 million was reduced, while the fund's scope increased.  This report agrees with the measures proposed by the European Commission to finance technical assistance, in particular as to mobilising EUR 330 000 for monitoring, information, establishing a knowledge base/interface and advising Member States on the use and evaluation of the EGF, although the Regulation points to up to 0.5 % of the maximum annual amount of the EGF (EUR 750 000). The report in question considers that the Fund would be more effective and of much greater impact if the allocation criterion went from 500 to 200 workers, also insisting on increasing total resources to at least EUR 500 million. Support.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report as it allows the mobilization of resources for redundancies in Nutriart S.A. and twenty-five suppliers and transformers of its own products, as well as twenty-four self-employed workers who ceased their activity and who depended on the Greek main undertaking, with 508 workers targeting the measures co-financed by the EAGF from 16 July 2013 to 16 November 2013. This mobilisation of funds is due to the disastrous consequences of the internationalisation of productive sectors in the EU.  These funds are not able to solve the problems of these workers in the context of high unemployment in Greece, but at least give the possibility of alleviating a small part of human drama. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. - The recession has hit Greece hard since 2008 and has resulted in a significant decline in GDP and household consumption as well as an increase in poverty. Nutriart is one of the companies affected by this recession, exacerbated by the austerity measures imposed by the Union. The EGF's intervention to support personalised training and job search assistance to more than 500 unemployed people and the support of 508 young people without training in a country already hard hit by austerity can only be supported.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. On this report of mobilization of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, we are asked to release more than 6 million euros for 508 employees laid off by Nutriart SA and its suppliers as well as 25 self-employed workers who are out of work.  This is a request put forward by Greece, which is in an unprecedented social and economic crisis and is suffering the full force of the austerity policy imposed by the European Union.  Indeed, the country has seen a 5% fall in its GDP since 2008 and unemployment reaches 27% nationally, of which 28% in Attica and 30% in Central Macedonia, regions affected by this aid.  In light of these elements, I have spoken out in favour of this assistance, as has been the case with all the other cases.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. - (IT) I support Mr McDerman's report. Kyrtsos which is concerned with the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for 508 Greek workers in the pastry and bakery sector. The text provides for the allocation of € 6,096,000, the purpose of which is the reintegration of workers who have lost their jobs due to the process of globalisation taking place in world markets.

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: Written. I have voted in favour of these reports today. I therefore do so to provide workers in the cases in question with financial support for retraining and/or other measures to find new jobs. However, I would like to stress that the high level of unemployment in europe could be effectively combated if the austerity policies of the European Commission and the governments of the Member States have long been pursued could be stopped. Creating new jobs in Europe requires a new economic policy with massive public and environmentally friendly investments. Public investment is needed in schools, health and social care, but also in infrastructure, rail, public transport, energy-efficient housing and sustainable energy systems.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in favour of the support of 508 workers in the bakery and bakery sector.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. - I voted in favour of this request for a financial contribution from Greece for one of its companies, Nutriart S.A., which was hit hard by layoffs in 2013. The application was serious and submitted in time, this is the first request for financial contribution from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund applicable to the 2014-2020 multi-year financial period. Faced with businesses hit hard by the global economic and financial crisis, the WEF must support those most severely affected.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. - (IT) Today I voted in favour of this report in order to provide additional support to the 508 Nutriart workers who lost their jobs in Greece as a result of the global economic and financial crisis.  Following the bankruptcy of several companies, such as Nutriart, the Greek economy is undergoing a divestment process in the secondary economic sector. According to the OECD, gross fixed capital formation fell by 20% between 2008 and 2013. According to official statistics, most people without a job are longterm unemployed, unemployment affects both younger generations and people in their fifties who find it difficult to find a new job.  The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF), which provides support to those who have lost their jobs as a result of major structural changes in world trade due to globalisation, is becoming essential, given that more and more European companies are being forced to close down.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in favour of the application, the sixth in the framework of the 2014 budget, for the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) for a total amount of EUR 6 096 000 for Greece. The application in question was submitted by the Greek authorities following redundancies made by Nutriart S.A., operating in the food industry.   The Greek authorities stated that the redundancy was mainly due to the decrease in disposable household income, the delay in payments of most of Nutriart's customers and the drastic reduction in loans to businesses and individuals due to the lack of liquidity of Greek banks.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. - The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was established in 2006 to provide additional assistance to workers affected by the consequences of major changes in the structure of international trade and to help them reintegrate into the labour market.  From 1 May 2009, the scope of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund has been extended to include support for workers made redundant as a direct result of the economic, financial and social crisis.  At a time when Europe is in the face of a financial, economic and social crisis, with unemployment being one of the main consequences, the European Union should use all means at its service to react, in particular, to the support to be provided to people who have been left without a job.  I therefore supported this report on mobilising EUR 6096 000 for Greece, with the aim of supporting the 508 workers, potential beneficiaries, made redundant following the redundancies at Nutriart SA.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in favour of mobilising the Globalisation Adjustment Fund following redundancies carried out by Nutriat S:A and 25 suppliers and producers downstream, as well as 24 self-employed workers whose activities ceased because they depended on the main company in Greece. In this particular case, I believe that the mobilisation of the Fund can really give practical help to workers, firstly because a coordinated package of personalised services has been created aimed at vocational guidance, training, retraining and advisory services towards entrepreneurship. Furthermore, because for the first time the self-employed will also be included in the cofinancing of the EGF and also because the idea has been launched, which I hope will be successful, of launching an incubator for new innovative companies.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. – I voted in favour to support workers (including providers, downstream producers and self-employed people) made redundant, whose activity ceased and was dependent on the primary enterprise in Greece.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. - (IT) I am convinced that technical assistance in order to make the best use of European funds is very important. I also think it is important to start providing, on the part of the European institutions, a standard and proven mechanism of technical assistance that will give the likely recipients of European funds active help in the design, demand and management of European resources.  Today, in many Italian regions, the resources allocated to technical assistance are being investigated and condemned by the competent authorities. For the above reasons, I have chosen to abstain.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report as it allows the mobilization of resources for redundancies in Nutriart S.A. and twenty-five suppliers and transformers of its own products, as well as twenty-four self-employed workers who ceased their activity and who depended on the Greek main undertaking, with 508 workers targeting the measures co-financed by the EAGF from 16 July 2013 to 16 November 2013. This mobilisation of funds is due to the disastrous consequences of the internationalisation of productive sectors in the EU.  These funds are not able to solve the problems of these workers in the context of high unemployment in Greece, but at least give the possibility of alleviating a small part of human drama. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. – I note that this particular application from Greece submitted in respect of redundancies at the enterprise Nutriart S.A and 25 providers and downstream producers – AR.ZIGAS & SIA and 24 self-employed people whose activity ceased and were dependent on the primary enterprise – complies with the requirements for determining financial contribution. I therefore agree that the EGF should be mobilised in order to provide a financial contribution for the application submitted by Greece. This is the reason for my vote in favour of this proposal.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. In the general context of a sharp slowdown in the Greek economy, the food sector is experiencing particular difficulties. Mass layoffs occur. The company in question here has been forced to part with 508 employees. In this context, I support this text because it will enable, through the mobilization of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, to help sacked employees to find a job.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: In writing. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EMF) was established in 2006 to help reintegrate workers who have lost their jobs as a result of changes in world trade. In 2009, its scope was expanded to include victims of the financial crisis.  This request, submitted by Greece, is for redundancies within the food industry. The aim is to help 508 employees laid off by Nutriart S.A. and its suppliers and downstream producers: AR. ZIGAS and SIA, as well as 24 self-employed workers who have been out of work. The aid provided will amount to about 6,096,000 euros and will help to co-finance active measures in the labour market such as career guidance, training, contribution to the creation of a business... I also welcome the fact that for the first time independents are benefiting from the co-financing of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund.  This aid is essential for Greece, whose economy is in deep recession for the sixth consecutive year (2008-2013). This request has received my support and the support of the European Parliament.

name: Tamás DEUTSCH
text: Writing. - The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was set up to provide additional support to workers affected by the consequences of major structural changes in world trade. Greece has requested assistance from the Globalisation Adjustment Fund because Nutriart S.A., located in the central Macedonian and Attica regions, has laid off around 500 people. According to the Commission, the measures described above constitute an active labour market measure within the scope of the eligible activities under Article 7 of the EGF Regulation. Personalised services for redundant workers, self-employed persons terminating their activities and NEETs are the following measures which together constitute a coordinated package of personalised services: career guidance, training, retraining and vocational training, advice on becoming an entrepreneur, contribution to setting up a business, financial support for job search and mobility support. I supported the report in the plenary vote.

name: Pablo ECHENIQUE
text: in writing. - EGF is a tool that seeks the relocation of laid-off workers in sectors particularly hit by "globalization". To this end, it allocates most of the funds to training, mentoring, accompaniment and development of "personal skills", while only a small portion of them goes directly into the pocket of the workers and only if they follow obediently the proposed itinerary or in the unlikely event that they get a job as a result of the program. The positive vote is explained by the recognition that any aid directed at those individuals and families who are suffering is welcome. Under no circumstances does it imply acceptance of the paternalistic and unfair logic underlying the design of this fund. People who have lost their jobs have not lost it because of lack of training and certainly do not need "incentives" to learn computer science or seek employment. They have lost it because the economy and the productive fabric have been severely undermined by powers that never consulted them and seek only the private benefit of a tiny minority.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Writing. - I voted in favour of this project, despite the fact that the funds are proposed to be made available to training and retraining companies for the unemployed and not directly to those who have lost their jobs and need them, because this limited money will be given to Greek companies even if most of the credit ends up in entrepreneurs who have not suffered the consequences of the economic crisis.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. - The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was set up to provide additional support to workers made redundant following major structural changes in world trade patterns due to globalisation or financial crisis and help them find new jobs. Between 2014 and 2020, the fund's annual ceiling is EUR 150 million. Redundant workers are offered measures such as support for business creation, job search assistance, vocational guidance and various types of training. In most cases, national authorities have already begun to take steps to reimburse their costs by the EU when their applications are approved. This mobilisation of the EGF in favour of Greece serves to support the reintegration into the labour market of workers made redundant by Nutriart, its suppliers/producers and cessation of activity of 24 self-employed workers for a total of 508 people and refers to the mobilisation of a total amount of EUR 6 096 000 from the EGF. I voted in favour.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. - Following redundancies at Nutriart S.A., the Greek authorities submitted the application for the financial contribution of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund on 5 February 2014. These are redundancies in 25 downstream suppliers and producers and the cessation of activity of 24 self-employed workers, whose activity depended on the main undertaking in Greece, with 508 of the potential workers benefiting from the measures co-financed by the EGF. Of the workers targeted, the vast majority are between 30 and 54 years old, in a country whose unemployment rate remains at historic highs of around 27 % of the working population, and in the affected regions of Attica and Central Macedonia they are already up to 28 % and 30 %, respectively. This is one of the most bitter and painful facets of the policy of the European Union and the governments that submissively apply it. Once again, we have agreed to mobilise this aid swiftly because it is important to support these workers. However, we reaffirm our fundamental criticism of this instrument, as it would be necessary to ensure measures to prevent unemployment, including the reversal of the neoliberal course of EU policies leading to outcomes such as this.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. - The measure affects 508 workers in the pastry and bakery sector for an amount of € 6,096,000. I voted in favour of helping these workers, families and businesses in great difficulty.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. - We support the report with the logic that it concerns Greek workers although we disagree with the way funding is managed. The winners will be some companies offering theories for solutions that have not reduced the unemployment rate in the areas concerned by the action to a minimum. The sum of EUR 6,096,000 should be allocated to the creation of new jobs and not simply to train stakeholders in skills they will never be able to apply when they do not have a job.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. – I support the need to have a European instrument to assist redundant workers. I am glad that Parliament fully supported the setting up of the EGF as part of the MFF for 2014 to 2020.  I voted in favour of the Nutriart application and support the use of the fund for the 508 people made redundant due to the global economic crisis. In particular I fully support the Greek government’s decision to co-finance personalised services for 505 youths under 30 also living in the regions that were impacted by these redundancies.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report by my colleague Geogios Kyrtsos on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. This fund allows people who have lost their jobs as a result of the crisis to receive financial assistance to set up projects or to find a job. The report was adopted by a large majority. I welcome the result of this vote.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. - (IT) I am voting in favour of Mr De Clercq's report. Liadh Ní Riada. As in the other cases put to the vote today, it is a question of allocating resources to ensure that some redundant workers are reintegrated into the labour market. In this case, these are the workers of Nutriart S.A. and the 25 downstream suppliers and producers who lost their jobs in Greece as a result of the global economic and financial crisis. Unfortunately, the bankruptcy of several Greek companies is leading to a process of loss of production capacity and social distress. In this respect, the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund will be able to make a positive and concrete contribution.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report as it allows the mobilization of resources for redundancies in Nutriart S.A. and twenty-five suppliers and transformers of its own products, as well as twenty-four self-employed workers who ceased their activity and who depended on the Greek main undertaking, with 508 workers targeting the measures co-financed by the EAGF from 16 July 2013 to 16 November 2013.
