That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. - I supported a report on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to help recruit workers laid off from Nutriart S.A. and other affiliated companies and self-employed people from Greece. The European Globalisation Fund was set up to provide additional support to workers made redundant as a result of the global financial and economic crisis to help re-enter the labour market. This Report aims to mobilise €6,096,000 to advise on job creation, job search assistance, education and training and financial support during the job search period, all for the purpose of restoring to the labour market and getting Greece out of the crisis more quickly.

name: Michał MARUSIK
text: I would like to write to the Commission. - (C) Mr President, I would like to begin by thank Socialism is a system that heroly fights the problems it creates. The fight against the effects of globalisation is a clinical example of this. The nature of the economy is that efficient ventures thrive by giving an abundance of good and cheap products, and inefficient ones go bankrupt without giving anyone losses. Taking money away from those who can produce a lot, well and cheaply is already hampering development and prosperity. Allocating this money to cover losses to those who should go bankrupt is the cause of further losses. Europe's greatest misfortune is to believe that it is right. Let us abandon this naïve faith.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. – Greece has submitted an application (EGF/2014/001 EL/Nutriart) for a financial contribution from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) due to numerous redundancies at Nutriart S.A. and 25 service providers and downstream producers. The total of 508 redundancies exacerbate unemployment in the Attica and Central Macedonia regions, with Attica accounting for 43% of Greece's GDP, which means that the closure of businesses in the region is having a massive impact on the Greek economy as a whole. The rise in unemployment in Greece's two largest agglomerations threatens social cohesion and exacerbates the tense situation in society. I therefore voted in favour of mobilising the EGF in the Nutriart/Greece case.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. - The globalization aid fund fulfils its role well. Instead of helping workers, it encourages shareholders and states to submit to forced liberalism. The application concerns the 508 workers and suppliers of the food company Nutriat SA who have been made redundant or bankrupt. The Greek government justifies this situation by the decline in household disposable income, which has undermined the consumption of a whole range of products (here baked goods). Also at issue are the late payment of the majority of the customers of this company and the asphyxiation of credit by the banks. Without proposing to break with the austerity policy that led to this situation, both the Greek government and the EU treat the symptoms without ever addressing the causes of the evil. I abstain so as not to deprive The Greek workers of this fund.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. - The EU is an area of solidarity and is part of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. This support is essential to help the unemployed and the victims of relocations in a globalised context. There is an increasing number of companies relocating, taking advantage of the low labour prices, which are practised in several countries, notably China and India, with harmful effects on countries that respect workers' rights. The EGF is intended to help workers who are victims of business relocation and is key to facilitating access to new employment. The EGF has already been used in the past by other EU countries and it is now up to greece, which has submitted the EGF/2014/001 EL/Nutriart application to a financial contribution from the EGF, following redundancies at Nutriart S.A., 25 downstream suppliers and producers and the cessation of activity of 24 self-employed workers, whose activity depended on the main undertaking in Greece (508 of which were potential workers receiving the measures co-financed by the EGF) during the reference period from 16 July 2013 to 16 November 2013.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. – The European Union has set up legislative and budgetary instruments in order to provide additional support to workers who have been affected by the consequences of major structural shifts in world trade patterns and to assist the re-integration of the same workers back into the labour market. This report confirms that the proposed financial contribution will cater for 25 providers and downstream producers and 24 self-employed people whose activity ceased. Moreover, 508 workers will be targeted for EGF co-funded measures. I have therefore voted in favour of this report which will give additional opportunities for the workers and families affected by these redundancies.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. – I fully support this report because the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund provides support to people losing their jobs as a result of major structural changes or a result of the global economic and financial crisis.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. - I voted in favour of this issue to allow the release of financial aid for the retraining of Nutriart workers of 6,096,000 euros. This assistance will benefit the company's 508 former employees, the laid-off workers who worked for the suppliers and the 24 self-employed affected by the closure.

name: Elisabeth MORIN-CHARTIER
text: In writing. - Today, the European Parliament adopted six reports of mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. I have spoken in favour of each of these reports. The aim of this fund is to enable employees who have been made redundant to have personalised training so that they can retrain professionally. On this issue, the European Parliament has agreed to release EUR 6 million from this Fund to 503 beneficiaries in Greece.  In these difficult times, the mobilization of this Fund is essential. It is imperative that personalised training be provided to those made redundant so that they can return to the job market as soon as possible. The European Parliament once again shows its commitment to one of the founding values of the European Union: solidarity.

name: Dan NICA
text: in writing. - I voted for the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) - egf/2014/001 EL/Nutriart – Greece. Greece submitted the application for a financial contribution from the EGF as a result of the redundancies at Nutriart S.A. and 25 downstream suppliers and producers. The measures co-financed by the EGF target 508 workers in the reference period July to November 2013. The 508 redundancies will worsen the unemployment situation in the regions of Attica and Central Macedonia, given that in the fourth quarter of 2013 the unemployment rate in Attica was 28.2% and in Central Macedonia 30.3%. Attica accounts for 43% of Greece's GDP and therefore the impact of the closure of companies based in this region extends to the entire Greek economy. We find that 150 workers and young people who are not in employment and do not follow any educational or training programme sit will be selected to receive the maximum eligible amount of EUR 15 000 as a contribution to start their own business. The aim of this measure is to promote entrepreneurship by providing funding, which should lead to the creation of new jobs in the medium term.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. – Greece has submitted an application (EGF/2014/001 EL/Nutriart) for a financial contribution from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) due to numerous redundancies at Nutriart S.A. and 25 service providers and downstream producers. I therefore voted in favour of mobilising the EGF in the Nutriart/Greece case.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. - I voted in favour of the resolution on the Globalisation Adjustment Fund aimed at re-creating new jobs for laid-off workers at Nutriart in Greece. Given the particularly difficult economic situation experienced by Greece, it is the role of the European Union to help sectors in difficulty by encouraging the creation of businesses.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. – I welcome that today the European Parliament overwhelmingly approved EU aid to help 508 Greeks workers made redundant. The EUR 6 096 000 in EGF aid approved by Parliament will pay for training to help these 508 people and another 505 young people without jobs to boost their employment chances. The UK has never made an application under this fund. UK workers therefore receive none of this support.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. - With this Resolution, Parliament takes into account that the surplus of nutriart employees S.A. and 25 of its suppliers and downstream producers, as well as twenty-four self-employed persons whose business has been discontinued, and directly depending on the operations of Nutriart S.A. are consequences of the global financial crisis that is felt especially in Greece, where the unemployment rate is at a record high. The causes of the redundancies are considered primarily a decrease in revenues, then non-payment of claims, as well as the inability to borrow further as a result of measures of the Greek banking system. These are circumstances that are present in a significant number of Member States.  Parliament welcomes the efforts of the Greek authorities to prepare and assist the unemployed through this programme, in particular the fact that the individual approach to EGF co-financed assistance will be extended from 508 people to another 505 people under 30 who are unemployed or not in the process of education or training. This represents a direct way of helping young people and the unemployed. The maximum available amount of EUR 15 000 for 150 selected workers is granted in order to start their business. Parliament underlines the importance of recognising the knowledge gained in working life when seeking employment.  In addition, the policy of gender equality and the principle of non-discrimination when applying egf provisions is also welcomed. The specific case is an example of how EGF assistance is possible for a number of cases.

name: Kay SWINBURNE
text: in writing. – I voted against this report today. I am opposed in principle to the use of this European Globalisation Adjustment Fund and as a result I cannot support this proposal to mobilise it.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. - I support it because it concerns Greek unemployed people, arguing that the funds should be given to employment programmes for the unemployed and/or dismissed and not to some companies that will be rewarded for training them. In Greece we have an unemployment problem and not a lack of knowledge, skills and degrees for the unemployed.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. - I voted in favour of the application. It was the sixth to be considered in the 2014 budget and aims to mobilise a total of EUR 6,096,000 from the EGF for Greece.  It concerns 508 workers laid off by Nutriart S.A. (the "main company") and 25 downstream suppliers and producers: AR. ZIGAS and SIA, as well as 24 self-employed workers who were out of business because their activity depended on the main company. The Greek authorities will provide personalised services co-financed by the EGF to up to 505 unemployed, out-of-school and untrained young people under the age of 30 at the time of the application, as all the redundancies covered in point 8 occurred in the NUTS 2 regions of Central Macedonia (EL12) and Attica (EL30) , eligible for the Youth Employment Initiative. The estimated total number of beneficiaries who should be covered by the measures, including unemployed, out-of-school and untrained youth, is therefore 1,013. The application met the requirements for a financial contribution from the Fund.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report as it allows the mobilization of resources for redundancies in Nutriart S.A. and twenty-five suppliers and transformers of its own products, as well as twenty-four self-employed workers who ceased their activity and who depended on the Greek main undertaking, with 508 workers targeting the measures co-financed by the EAGF from 16 July 2013 to 16 November 2013. name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. - The Greek authorities submitted an application for the financial contribution of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund on 5 February 2014, following redundancies at Nutriart S.A., which led to hundreds of workers being unemployed. The majority of targeted workers are between 30 and 54 years old, in a country whose unemployment rate remains at historic highs of around 27 % of the working population. We agree that this aid is rapidly mobilising because it is important to support these workers. However, we reaffirm our criticism of the fund, as it would be necessary to ensure measures to prevent unemployment, in particular the reversal of the neoliberal course of EU policies, in particular those leading to outcomes such as this, such as the insistence on the deregulation and liberalisation of international trade.

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: Writing. – Funds from the so-called "Globalisation Fund" to finance programmes for laid-off workers, whose monopolies fly into unemployment to invest in other countries and sectors with cheaper labour force for greater profitability, as in the case of the laid-off NUTRIART Group, are propagandized as a supposed response to unemployment. In reality, however, they cannot and are not intended to deal with the enormous problems of unemployment and the unemployed. They are minimal, totally inadequate to meet the needs of the unemployed and are evaporating with the end of the programmes and the overall unpopular policy. The real objective of the Fund is to manage extreme poverty with crumbs, to curb workers' indignation, to cover up and embellish capitalist barbarism, the unpopular policy of the EU and the urban governments that serve by all means the profits of monopolies. The programmes it funds recycle unemployment, strengthen various false training mechanisms to gnaw funds. The only way to permanently eliminate unemployment - inherent in the capitalist system - is to ensure permanent and stable work with rights for all and with salaries that meet modern popular needs, is to organize the fight to overthrow the unpopular policy, to free it from the EU and the People's Power.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. - Following redundancies at Nutriart S.A., the Greek authorities submitted the application for the financial contribution of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund on 5 February 2014. These are redundancies in 25 downstream suppliers and producers and the cessation of activity of 24 self-employed workers, whose activity depended on the main undertaking in Greece, of which 508 of the potential workers benefiting from the measures co-financed by the EGF during the reference period from 16 July 2013 to 16 November 2013. Of the workers targeted, the vast majority are between 30 and 54 years old, in a country whose unemployment rate remains at historic highs of around 27 % of the working population, and in the affected regions of Attica and Central Macedonia they are already up to 28 % and 30 %, respectively. We agree that this aid is rapidly mobilising because it is important to support these workers. However, we reaffirm our criticism of the fund, as it would be necessary to ensure measures to prevent unemployment, including the reversal of the neoliberal course of EU policies leading to outcomes such as this.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report as it allows the mobilization of resources following 1 513 dismissals of workers, namely 1 441 during and after the reference period in Mechel Campia Turzii and 72 in Mechel Reparatii Targoviste, with 1 000 workers who could benefit from the measures co-financed by the EGF during the period from 20 June 2012 to 20 October 2012. This mobilisation of funds is due to the disastrous consequences of the internationalisation of productive sectors in the EU.  These funds are not able to solve the problems of these workers in the context of high unemployment in Romania, but at least give the possibility of alleviating a small part of human drama. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. - The decline in exports of finished and semi-finished steel products, the increase in imports of these same products and the purely financial logic of some private groups have led in recent years to a number of business closures across the Union. The dismissal of the workers of the Mechel company therefore justifies the intervention of the EGF to promote training and career guidance, especially in a region characterized by a low level of income and a very limited diversification of economic activities.

name: Heinz K. BECKER
text: Writing. – The rapid decline in the EU market share and the increase in the market share of countries such as China in steel products have led to a serious disruption to the economic development of the production of finished products and semi-finished products made of steel, the sector in which Mechel C'mpia Turzii and Mechel Repara ii Térgovicewere were active. The EGF's request is therefore intended to support those who have lost their jobs as a result of major structural changes in world trade patterns as a result of globalisation. The redundancies therefore had a significant impact on the local labour market, given the few jobs in the Region of The Turzii area (an average of 30 vacancies per month) and the small number of potential employers. All the following measures together form a coordinated package of personalised services for the reintegration of the labour force into the labour market, registration of the workforce, information, advice and vocational guidance, vocational training and traineeships, support for the taking up of self-employment, rental of the production site and payment of the rent for the duration of the project, travel allowance, application grant, traineeship allowance, flat-rate residence allowance, participation grant, support after taking up a new job. The request must therefore be fully supported.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. — The report by Mr De Clercq on beazley is a good one. Muresan is unclear and lacks information on the effects of the use of the funds required in the competitive dynamics of the sector at the level of the internal market, which is why I abstained in this vote.

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: Written. I have voted in favour of these reports today. I therefore do so to provide workers in the cases in question with financial support for retraining and/or other measures to find new jobs. However, I would like to stress that the high level of unemployment in europe could be effectively combated if the austerity policies of the European Commission and the governments of the Member States have long been pursued could be stopped. Creating new jobs in Europe requires a new economic policy with massive public and environmentally friendly investments. Public investment is needed in schools, health and social care, but also in infrastructure, rail, public transport, energy-efficient housing and sustainable energy systems.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the resolution on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in the redundancies sector of Romania's steel industry not only because one of the two companies referred to operated in the N-V Region of Transylvania itself, where I ran, but also because the Russian Mechel group was done a great injustice there. In February 2013, more than a thousand employees were laid off after the Russian group Mechel sold this combination for the symbolic price of 55 Euros. I have witnessed the massive redundancies that have created imbalances, with more than 1,800 employees accounting for about a third of the total number of employees in the area. Significant financial support for redundant employees is an indispensable measure for retraining. The EU mechanisms demonstrate that this structure, through its support programmes for people who lose their jobs due to major changes in globalisation or the economic crisis, is becoming stronger and closer to its citizens.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. I abstained. In the Commission's decision there is no information on the effects of this manoeuvre on the competitive dynamics of the sector at the level of the entire internal market.

name: Cristian-Silviu BUŞOI
text: in writing. - I support the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in favour of Romania, in order to support the reintegration into the labour market of workers made redundant by SC Mechel Plain Turzii SA and the manufacturer SC Mechel Repairs Targoviste SRL. The redundancies had serious repercussions for the local labour market, as Mechel Plain Turzii was the largest employer in the area. The package of services adopted includes measures to reintegrate 1 000 of the laid-off workers into the labour market, such as vocational guidance and advice, vocational training and training courses or assistance for the initiation of self-employment.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. - (IT) Today I voted in favour of this report in order to provide additional support to 1 513 workers of the company Mechel Campia Turzii who lost their jobs in Romania as a result of the global economic and financial crisis. The aim is to facilitate the rapid reintegration into working life of these redundant workers through tailor-made accompanying actions, such as assistance in finding employment, vocational guidance, training and retraining, promotion of self-employment and entrepreneurship.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the fourth application under the 2014 budget for the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) for a total amount of EUR 3 571 150 in favour of Romania. The request by the Romanian authorities for mobilisation of the EGF refers to 825 redundancies in Mechel Campia Turzii and a downstream producer during a reference period of four months, as well as to a further 688 redundancies outside the reference period but attributable to the same collective redundancy procedure. The Romanian authorities reported that the manufacturing sector of finished and semi-finished steel products, in which the companies in question operated, suffered a serious economic disturbance as a result of the rapid decline in the EU market share in the steel products sector and the increase in the market share of some countries, such as China.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. - The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was established in 2006 to provide additional assistance to workers affected by the consequences of major changes in the structure of international trade and to help them reintegrate into the labour market.  From 1 May 2009, the scope of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund has been extended to include support for workers made redundant as a direct result of the economic, financial and social crisis.  At a time when Europe is in the face of a financial, economic and social crisis, with unemployment being one of the main consequences, the European Union should use all means at its service to react, in particular, to the support to be provided to people who have been left without a job.  I therefore supported this report on the mobilisation of EUR 3571 150 for Romania with the aim of supporting 1000 workers, potential beneficiaries, of the 1513 workers made redundant, in the company SC Mechel Campia Turzii SA and in a downstream production company (SC Mechel Reparatii Targoviste SRL).

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. - Unfortunately, the affair related to the 1,513 redundancies concerning the companies Mechel Campia Turzii and Mechel Reparatii Targoviste is part of this scenario of employment crisis, mainly due to aggressive competition from companies in emerging countries, in particular from China. I welcome the European Commission's decision to allocate an appropriation under the EGF to the Romanian authorities, in order to take concrete measures to promote the reintegration of workers, the start-up of independent activities and the creation of a package of tailor-made services. In addition to economic aid, we should not forget that there are local situations where local work is very limited and where it is precisely companies, such as those in question, that give a whole population a living. It is also necessary to draw up a European strategy for the steel products sector in order to remain competitive.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. – The 1 513 redundancies are linked to major structural changes in world trade patterns due to globalisation. I voted in favour to support measures that integrate workers into employment through various ways and means including training courses and internships.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. - In view of Romania's request for assistance from Mechel Campia Turzi SA, and given that the European Adjustment Fund was set up to provide additional support to workers affected by the consequences of major structural changes in world trade, I can only vote in favour of this resolution also in order to support the reintegration of redundancies into the labour market.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report as it allows the mobilization of resources following 1 513 dismissals of workers, namely 1 441 during and after the reference period in Mechel Campia Turzii and 72 in Mechel Reparatii Targoviste, with 1 000 workers who could benefit from the measures co-financed by the EGF during the period from 20 June 2012 to 20 October 2012. This mobilisation of funds is due to the disastrous consequences of the internationalisation of productive sectors in the EU.  These funds are not able to solve the problems of these workers in the context of high unemployment in Romania, but at least give the possibility of alleviating a small part of human drama. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Andi CRISTEA
text: in writing. - In recent years there has been a considerable increase in imports into the EU of finished and semi-finished steel products, as well as a relative decrease in exports of such products, both of which add to a loss of EU market share in the finished and semi-finished steel products sector in which Mechel operates. These events have adversely affected the performance of the sector, leading to job losses due to restructuring in the steel sector in Europe.  Romania turned to the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) to help implement reintegration measures for 1,000 people who were left without jobs after the Russian mechel group decided to stop working in Romania in 2012. The total contribution requested from the EGF is EUR 3 571 150. It is a novel initiative, no longer being implemented through EU funds, because it will be owned by employees themselves.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. – I note that in this particular application from Romania only one fourth of the workers dismissed in the enterprise SC Mechel Campia Turzii SA, and one downstream producer SC Mechel Reparatii Targoviste SRL, are eligible for this help. The amount of EUR 15 000 will be granted to 250 selected workers as assistance in initiating independent activities, alongside another EUR 70 000 for information and publicity which should result in a better awareness of the EGF contribution and more visibility of the role of the Community in it. Hence, I voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. The European steel industry is experiencing a serious crisis. The case of these Romanian companies forced to lay off 825 employees is a new example of this. Across Europe, we face competition from foreign steel, sometimes leading to life-saving restructurings but especially to social disasters resulting in large-scale layoffs. To deal with this, we must take the appropriate measures that the financial contribution of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund makes possible. That is why I support this text.

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: in writing. - I welcome the importance of improving the employability of all workers through tailored training and recognition of the capacities and skills acquired during their professional careers, and I believe that the offer of training in the coordinated package must be adapted not only to the needs of redundant workers, but also to the real needs of the business environment.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: In writing. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EMF) was established in 2006 to help reintegrate workers who have lost their jobs as a result of changes in world trade. In 2009, its scope was expanded to include victims of the financial crisis.  This application, submitted by Romania, is for redundancies in the steel industry. Indeed, this sector has been severely disrupted by a sharp decline in the EU's steel market and the growing importance of countries such as China.  The aim is to help 825 employees made redundant by Mechel Câmpia Turzii and one of its downstream producers: SC Mechel Reparatii Targoviste SRL. The assistance provided will amount to approximately EUR 3,571,150 and will enable the co-financing of active measures in the labour market such as career guidance and counselling, vocational training and internships, assistance in starting an independent activity.  This request has received my support and the support of the European Parliament.

name: Tamás DEUTSCH
text: Writing. - The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was set up to provide additional support to workers affected by the consequences of major structural changes in world trade. Romania requested assistance from the Globalisation Adjustment Fund because SC Mechel Câmpia Turzii SA, a company producing finished and semi-finished steel products in the municipality of Aranyosgyéres in Cluj-Napoca, laid off 1513 people. The Commission has established that the application fulfils the requirements for the use of the EGF laid down in Article 2(a) of Regulation (EC) No 1927/2006. With the help of the Community budget, measures will be taken to help around 1 000 redundant workers to re-find employment on the labour market. I supported the report in the plenary vote.

name: Pablo ECHENIQUE
text: in writing. - EGF is a tool that seeks the relocation of laid-off workers in sectors particularly hit by "globalization". To this end, it allocates most of the funds to training, mentoring, accompaniment and development of "personal skills", while only a small portion of them goes directly into the pocket of the workers and only if they follow obediently the proposed itinerary or in the unlikely event that they get a job as a result of the program. The positive vote is explained by the recognition that any aid directed at those individuals and families who are suffering is welcome. Under no circumstances does it imply acceptance of the paternalistic and unfair logic underlying the design of this fund. People who have lost their jobs have not lost it because of lack of training and certainly do not need "incentives" to learn computer science or seek employment. They have lost it because the economy and the productive fabric have been severely undermined by powers that never consulted them and seek only the private benefit of a tiny minority.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Writing. - I voted against this project because the sums are proposed to be given to training and retraining companies for the unemployed and not directly to those who have lost their jobs and need them. Consequently, the majority of the appropriations will result in entrepreneurs who have not suffered the consequences of the economic crisis.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. - The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was set up to provide additional support for workers made redundant following major structural changes in world trade patterns due to globalisation or the financial crisis and help them find new jobs. Between 2014 and 2020, the fund's annual ceiling is EUR 150 million. Redundant workers are offered measures such as support for business creation, job search assistance, vocational guidance and various types of training. In most cases, national authorities have already begun to take steps to reimburse their costs by the EU when their applications are approved. This mobilisation of the EGF in favour of Romania is to support the reintegration into the labour market of 1523 workers made redundant from the steel company Mechel Campia Turzii and suppliers due to a sharp drop in orders for their products, and buyers of their products have chosen to buy from companies in China. This mobilisation is a total amount of EUR 3 571 150 from the EGF. I voted in favour.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. - Much has been said in the last elections to the European Parliament on the need to combat unemployment. A few months have passed since then, here we are evaluating five requests for support for the dismissal of hundreds of workers.  This application concerns 1513 redundancies at Mechel Campia Turzii and Mechell Reparatti Targoviste, manufacturers of finished and semi-finished steel products. These companies were based in the municipality of Campoia Turzii in Romania and were the largest employer in the region – employing about a third of the region's total workers.  Once again, the so-called structural changes in world trade patterns – read capitalist globalisation, promoted from the outset by EU policies – and the decrease in the EU's market share in the steel sector and the increase in the share of countries such as China are the justification for this social crime. We know that what is behind these massive redundancies is the need for capitalism to have a cheaper and more docile army of labour, which will reduce the cost of the labour force, thereby increasing exploitation and profit. There is an increasing need for these policies to be overresuming the dignity of all those who live from their work.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. - We disagree with the way funding is managed. The winners will be some companies offering theories for solutions that have not reduced the unemployment rate in the areas concerned by the action to a minimum. The sum of EUR 3,571,150 should be allocated to the creation of new jobs and not simply to train stakeholders in skills they will never be able to apply when they do not have a job.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. - EGF is a tool that seeks the relocation of laid-off workers in sectors particularly hit by "globalization". To this end, it allocates most of the funds to training, mentoring, accompaniment and development of "personal skills", while only a small portion of them goes directly into the pocket of the workers and only if they follow obediently the proposed itinerary or in the unlikely event that they get a job as a result of the program. The positive vote is explained by the recognition that any aid directed at those individuals and families who are suffering is welcome. Under no circumstances does it imply acceptance of the paternalistic and unfair logic underlying the design of this fund. People who have lost their jobs have not lost it because of lack of training and certainly do not need "incentives" to learn computer science or seek employment. They have lost it because the economy and the productive fabric have been severely undermined by powers that never consulted them and seek only the private benefit of a tiny minority.

name: Eduard-Raul HELLVIG
text: in writing. - I welcome the report by Colleague Siegfrid Mureşan with a view to granting aid from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) to the more than a thousand workers made redundant from SC Mechel Plain Turzii SA, for retraining and support in finding new jobs. It is an eloquent situation for the social and economic implications of the crisis affecting European industry, which is why the conclusions that can be drawn from the Mechel case have a broader significance. I note that Romania has submitted a request to mobilise the EGF as early as December 2012 with regard to the redundancies made by SC Mechel Plain Turzii SA. I therefore call on the European Commission to apply as soon as possible the agreement agreed by Parliament and the Council on increasing the EU's financial contribution and making procedures for approving applications more efficient. Secondly, there is a need for a wider debate on the fate of European steel, as the recovery of economic growth in the European Union is inextricably linked to the reindustrialisation of the Member States. The EU is in a position to have to allocate money to its own citizens made redundant due to the decline in European competitiveness and increased imports from China. It is not at all a sustainable situation, neither economically nor socially.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Siegfried Murean's report on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. This fund allows people who have lost their jobs as a result of the crisis to receive financial assistance to set up projects or to find a job. The report was adopted by a large majority. I welcome the result of this vote.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. - (IT) I am voting in favour of Mr De Clercq's report. Siegfried Mureşan which provides support to some Romanian companies active in the manufacture of finished and semi-finished steel products. Specifically, the report provides for the allocation of resources necessary for the reintegration into the labour market of redundancies at Mechel Campia Turzii SA and its downstream producer (SC Mechel Reparatii Targoviste SRL), due to the significant changes in the structure of world trade due to globalisation.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report as it allows the mobilization of resources following 1 513 dismissals of workers, namely 1 441 during and after the reference period in Mechel Campia Turzii and 72 in Mechel Reparatii Targoviste, with 1 000 workers who could benefit from the measures co-financed by the EGF during the period from 20 June 2012 to 20 October 2012. These funds are not able to solve the problems of these workers in the context of high unemployment in Romania, but at least give the possibility of alleviating a small part of human drama. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. - Due to the structural changes that are taking place due to the growing trend of globalization, I supported the Report on the Mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund with the aim of ensuring a financial contribution to Romania in order to lay off workers at Mechel Camptia Turzii SA. The European Globalisation Fund was set up to provide additional support to workers made redundant as a result of structural changes in globalisation-induced globalisation trade flows and to help them enter the labour market. This report aims to mobilise 3,571,150 euros for career guidance and counselling, education and assistance in starting independent business.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this resolution because the European Globalisation Adjustment fund is a very important tool by which we can support countries of the EU when they need it most. For example, this vote was for workers who had been made redundant. This redundancy was due to the forces of globalisation and the fund will not be a hand-out to them, but a means by which they can be reintegrated into the labour market of their country.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. – The redundancies at SC Mechel Compia Turzii and a downstream producer (SC Mechel Repara ii T'rgovice SRL) are linked to far-reaching structural changes in world trade patterns as a result of globalisation. The losses in the sector in which Mechel C'mpia Turzii and Mechel Repara ii Torgovicte were active, namely the production of finished products and semi-finished products made of steel, illustrates the rapid decline in the European market share in steel production and the simultaneous increase in the market share of countries such as China. This makes it all the more important to adopt an effective Union strategy for the steel-producing industry in order to maintain competitiveness. The redundancies at issue in the present case 1 513 have a serious impact on the local labour market in Romania, since Mechel Was the largest employer, with 1 837 employees (June 2012) and about one third of the total number of employees in the region. For these reasons, I voted in favour of mobilising the EGF in this case.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. - The globalization aid fund fulfils its role well. Instead of helping workers, it encourages shareholders and states to submit to forced liberalism. The application concerns 1000 of the 1513 workers laid off by the steel company SC Mechel Câmpia Turzii SA and its supplier SC Mechel Reparatii Targoviste SRL. It should be noted that 250 of these workers will receive specific assistance in order to set up a cooperative company. The Romanian authorities denounce the increase in imports of finished and semi-finished steel products into the European Union as the root cause of this situation. But not for a moment is solidarity protectionism, the only tool that can stop europe's industrial hemorrhage, is mentioned. I abstain so as not to deprive workers of this fund.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. - The EU is an area of solidarity and is part of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. This support is essential to help the unemployed and the victims of relocations in a globalised context. There is an increasing number of companies relocating, taking advantage of the low labour prices, which are practised in several countries, notably China and India, with harmful effects on countries that respect workers' rights. The EGF is intended to help workers who are victims of business relocation and is key to facilitating access to new employment. The EGF has already been used in the past by other EU countries, and it is now up to Romania, which has submitted the EGF/2012/010 RO/Mechel application to a financial contribution from the EGF, following 1513 redundancies: 1 441 during and after the reference period at Mechel Campia Turzii and 72 at Mechel Reparatii Targoviste (1000 of which were potential workers beneficiary of the measures co-financed by the EGF) during the reference period from 20 June 2012 to 20 October 2012.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. – The European Union has set up legislative and budgetary instruments in order to provide additional support to workers who have been affected by the consequences of major structural shifts in world trade patterns and to assist the re-integration of the same workers back into the labour market. This report confirms that the proposed financial contribution will cater for 1 000 workers who have been made redundant in Romania. I have therefore voted in favour of this report which will give additional opportunities for the workers and families affected by these redundancies.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. – I fully support this report because the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund provides support to people losing their jobs as a result of major structural changes or a result of the global economic and financial crisis.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. - I voted in favour of this issue to allow the release of financial aid of 3,571,150 euros which will benefit 1513 former employees of the steel sector in Romania. As an elected official from a region marked by the steel crisis, I know the situation in the sector and the suffering caused by plant closures. Even as Europe produces less and less steel, it is importing more and more. To cope with the decline, the Union must take concrete steps to restore competitiveness to our businesses, support innovation and ensure security of supply.

name: Elisabeth MORIN-CHARTIER
text: In writing. - Today, the European Parliament adopted six reports of mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. I have spoken in favour of each of these reports. The aim of this fund is to enable employees who have been made redundant to have personalised training so that they can retrain professionally. On this issue, the European Parliament has agreed to release EUR 3.5 million from this Fund to 1,000 beneficiaries in Romania.  In these difficult times, the mobilization of this Fund is essential. It is imperative that personalised training be provided to those made redundant so that they can return to the job market as soon as possible. The European Parliament once again shows its commitment to one of the founding values of the European Union: solidarity.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. - As shadow rapporteur from the S&D Group in the European Parliament and as a member of the Social Democratic Party, I voted for the adoption of this report. I note that this project was initiated by the PSD Government led by Prime Minister Victor Ponta and was unlocked at European Commission level through the joint efforts of the Executive and Social Democrat MEPs. Furthermore, the amendments tabled on a personal behalf and approved have drawn the Commission's attention to the long delay in approving the project and call for a future reporting of amounts at the rate of inflation.

name: Dan NICA
text: in writing. - I voted for the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund: request EGF/2012/010 RO/MECHEL – Romania. Romania submitted the application for a financial contribution from the EGF following 1,513 redundancies at Mechel Plain Turzii and 72 at Mechel Targoviste Repairs. In the reference period June to October 2012 1 000 workers are targeted by the measures co-financed by the EGF. The Romanian authorities submitted their application for the financial contribution from the EGF on 21 December 2012 and the Commission made the assessment of the application available on 7 May 2014. We regret the long 17-month valuation period and the decrease in purchasing power between 2012 and 2014 as a result of inflation. We call on the Commission to propose measures to remedy this problem in similar situations in the future. Unfortunately, redundancies are linked to major structural changes in international trade practices as a result of globalisation and, in particular, due to the rapid decline in the Union's market share in the steel sector and the increase in market share of countries such as China. As S&D Coordinator for the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy, I stress that this case demonstrates the need for a Union strategy on the steel industry to maintain competitiveness.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. - The redundancies at SC Mechel Compia Turzii and a downstream producer (SC Mechel Repara ii T'rgovice SRL) are linked to far-reaching structural changes in world trade patterns as a result of globalisation. For these reasons, I voted in favour of mobilising the EGF in this case.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: in writing. – I supported the use of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for one of the Romanian businesses. I welcome the fact that the funds of this fund are now being used more frequently for entities from the new Member States. At the same time, it should be noted that the funds from the Fund must be under permanent control, as this is European taxpayers' money.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. - I voted in favour of the European Parliament's resolution on the globalisation adjustment fund to compensate and re-create new jobs for the sacked employees of Mechel Câmpia Turzii SA, because the end of their activity came under conditions of unfair international competition. The steel sector is particularly affected by the lack of industrial policy of the Member States. It is up to these workers to diversify and noved their activities while investing at European level in a common industrial policy.

name: Teresa RODRIGUEZ-RUBIO
text: in writing. - EGF is a tool that seeks the relocation of laid-off workers in sectors particularly hit by "globalization". To this end, it allocates most of the funds to training, mentoring, accompaniment and development of "personal skills", while only a small portion of them goes directly into the pocket of the workers and only if they follow obediently the proposed itinerary or in the unlikely event that they get a job as a result of the program.
