People who have lost their jobs have not lost it because of lack of training and certainly do not need "incentives" to learn computer science or seek employment. They have lost it because the economy and the productive fabric have been severely undermined by powers that never consulted them and seek only the private benefit of a tiny minority.

name: Matteo SALVINI
text: in writing. - I have decided to abstain because through this vote 250 Romanian workers from a company operating in the steel sector will receive € 15,000 each to create a cooperative society that will produce sporting goods for a Romanian company that in turn works as a subcontractor for a multinational company in the sector. Both in the EMPL Commission's letter and in the Commission's decision there is no information on the effects this manoeuvre will have on the competitive dynamics of the sector throughout the internal market.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. - The positive vote is explained by the recognition that any aid directed at those individuals and families who are suffering is welcome. Under no circumstances does it imply acceptance of the paternalistic and unfair logic underlying the design of this fund. People who have lost their jobs have not lost it because of lack of training and certainly do not need "incentives" to learn computer science or seek employment. They have lost it because the economy and the productive fabric have been severely undermined by powers that never consulted them and seek only the private benefit of a tiny minority. EGF is a tool that seeks the relocation of laid-off workers in sectors particularly hit by "globalization". To this end, it allocates most of the funds to training, mentoring, accompaniment and development of "personal skills", while only a small portion of them goes directly into the pocket of the workers and only if they follow obediently the proposed itinerary or in the unlikely event that they get a job as a result of the program.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report as it allows the mobilization of resources following 1 513 dismissals of workers, namely 1 441 during and after the reference period in Mechel Campia Turzii and 72 in Mechel Reparatii Targoviste, with 1 000 workers who could benefit from the measures co-financed by the EGF during the period from 20 June 2012 to 20 October 2012. This mobilisation of funds is due to the disastrous consequences of the internationalisation of productive sectors in the EU.  These funds are not able to solve the problems of these workers in the context of high unemployment in Romania, but at least give the possibility of alleviating a small part of human drama. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. – Together with other 613 other MEPs I voted today to help to help 1000 Romanian workers made redundant by steel product maker Mechel Câmpia Turzii. The EUR 3 571 150 EGF aid will help pay inter alia for vocational guidance, starting up new firms and providing mentoring after landing a job. The UK has never made an application under this fund. UK workers therefore receive none of this support.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: in writing. – I voted for the decision on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for SC Mechel Campia Turzii SA, as the EUR 7 million project could greatly benefit a former industrial city from my constituency. We are talking about 1 500 people who lost their jobs in recent years, most of whom will be able to benefit from vocational guidance and training, as well as assistance in initiating independent activities. Such measures are most beneficial and a clear example of European solidarity at work. However, I would like to draw Parliamentʼs attention once again to the fact that factory closures such as this are a result of a longer-term process of industrial decline in Europe. Therefore, I believe that besides supporting regions in difficulty, we should intensify our efforts to re-industrialise Europe and create new and stable jobs.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. - I voted for a resolution in which the European Union set up legislative and budgetary instruments to support workers who have been laid off or made redundant as a result of the financial and economic crisis.  I agree with the Commission that the conditions set out in the EGF Regulation have been met and that Romania is therefore entitled to a financial contribution under that Regulation. Sc Mechel Campia Turzii's redundancies are linked to changes due to globalisation, given the fact that the finished products and semi-finished steel products sector has suffered economic distortions as a result of the rapid decline in the EU market share. It is clear from this example that a Union strategy for steel products is needed to maintain competitiveness; It is noted that the local labour market is limited because the unemployment rate in Câmpia Turzia is about 5%, and vacancies are very few.  That is why I support the fact that romania's national employment agency, as well as other local and regional authorities, will be linked to the cooperative to be set up to support laid-off workers. This is organised as part of the 'Help in Starting Independent Business' measure and will apply a policy of equality between women and men and the principle of non-discrimination during the different stages of the EGF approach and its implementation.

name: Kay SWINBURNE
text: in writing. – I voted against this report today. I am opposed in principle to the use of this European Globalisation Adjustment Fund and as a result I cannot support this proposal to mobilise it.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. - I am voting against the idea that funds should be given for the creation of new jobs, not for education in areas where unemployment is already high.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. – In December 2012 the Romanian authorities applied for a financial contribution under the EFG following the redundancies of 1 513 workers in Mechel Campia Turzii and in Mechel Reparatii Targoviste between June and October 2012. On May 2014 the Commission concluded that the application met the conditions under the EGF and approved the mobilisation of EUR 3 571 150 for Romania. The approved package also includes measures to assist the reintegration of workers into employment by providing them with vocational guidance, counselling, training courses, internships, etc. While welcoming the deployment of EGF funds in favour of Romania, I regret the lengthy evaluation period of 17 months and I believe this delay contradicts the aim of the EGF to provide a quick aid to workers. This region in Romania relays principally on the finished and semi-finished steel products sector, therefore it is not surprising that the redundancies in Mechel affected the local labour market in the region as whole. In order to find a sustainable solution to the problem, I urge the Commission to present a proposal on the steel products industry with measures to improve the employability of workers in this particular sector in Romania, and elsewhere in Europe.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. I have spoken in favour of this text. Moreover, we can only welcome the adoption of the new FEM regulation, which incorporates the agreement between the European Parliament and the Council to reintroduce the crisis mobilization criterion, increase the EU's financial contribution to 60% of the estimated total cost of the proposed measures, increase the efficiency of the processing of EGF requests in the Commission and the European Parliament and the Council by reducing the evaluation deadlines and approval, to extend eligible shares and potential beneficiaries to the self-employed and young people and to fund incentives for beneficiaries to set up their own businesses.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. – I support the motion on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, on cooperation in budgetary matters and on sound financial management in order to give additional help to workers who are suffering from the consequences of major structural changes in Romania. It is important that we make this financial assistance available as quickly and efficiently as possible, so that these workers have the opportunity to their reintegration into the labour market.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report as it allows the mobilization of resources following 1 513 dismissals of workers, namely 1 441 during and after the reference period in Mechel Campia Turzii and 72 in Mechel Reparatii Targoviste, with 1 000 workers who could benefit from the measures co-financed by the EGF during the period from 20 June 2012 to 20 October 2012. This mobilisation of funds is due to the disastrous consequences of the internationalisation of productive sectors in the EU.  These funds are not able to solve the problems of these workers in the context of high unemployment in Romania, but at least give the possibility of alleviating a small part of human drama. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. - This application aims to support 1513 workers made redundant by Mechel Campia Turzii and Mechell Reparatti Targoviste, manufacturers of finished and semi-finished steel products. These companies were the largest employer in the region – they employed about a third of the region's total workers.  Structural changes in world trade patterns, the decrease in the EU's market share in the steel sector and the increase in the share of countries such as China are the justification for this social crime. Once again it is the workers and their families who have paid for a crisis that they have not provoked, and to see their rights trampled and withdrawn. There is an increasing need for these policies and the reposition of dignity for the men and women who live from their work.

name: Iuliu WINKLER
text: Writing. - The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund has also proved to be a successful tool in Romania, with more than 1,000 laid-off employees from the Nokia factory in Cluj-Napoca being able to return to the labour market with the support of the fund. Today, I voted in favour of the report on the use of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in order to allocate EUR 3.5 million to support the return to the labour market of 1 000 employees made redundant from the Mechel Reparaţii factories in Aranyosgyéres and Târgoviște. In the case of NOKIA, the Cluj-Napoca Employment Agency is active in an effective activity with a view to the reintegration of the unemployed, and the data so far show that even for those made redundant in Aranyosgygys, the Cluj County Agency is presenting an innovative socially collaborative solution. I hope that, despite the delay, this money, which will be given to support workers, can indeed be used in the most efficient way.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. - In the new Parliament that came out of the May 2014 elections, elections where there was talk of the need to put an end to unemployment, rampant poverty, here we are evaluating five requests for support for the dismissal of hundreds of workers.  This application relates to 1513 redundancies made by Mechel Campia Turzii and Mechell Reparatti Targoviste, manufacturers of finished and semi-finished steel products. These companies had their headquarters in the municipality of Campoia Turzii, Romania, and were the largest employer in the region - they employed about a third of the region's total workers.  Once again, structural changes in world trade patterns and the decrease in the EU's market share in the steel sector and the increased share of countries such as China are the justification for this social crime. But we all know that what is behind these massive redundancies is capitalism's need to have a cheaper and more docile labour army that will reduce the cost of labour, thereby increasing its profit. There is an increasing need for these policies and the reposition of dignity for the men and women who live from their work.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report as it allows the mobilization of resources following the dismissal of 904 workers in 661 companies whose activity corresponds to division 56 of NACE Review 2 (food and beverages) in the NUTS 2 region Aragon (ES24), with 280 workers targeting measures co-financed by the EGF during the period from 1 March 2013 to 1 December 2013. This mobilisation of funds is due to the disastrous consequences of the internationalisation of productive sectors in the EU.  These funds are not able to solve the problems of these workers in the context of high unemployment in Spain, but at least give the possibility of alleviating a small part of human drama. That's why I've decided to vote for it.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. - The Horeca sector has been severely affected by the Spanish economic crisis and the drastic fall in internal purchasing power due to the austerity measures initiated to meet European requirements. The WEF's intervention will support 280 people out of the 904 workers laid off in 661 companies in the sector in Aragon. This necessary solidarity will enable the development of training, orientation and job search mechanisms.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted to support the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in favour of the 280 workers made redundant in the catering sector in the Aragon region of Spain.

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: Written. I have voted in favour of these reports today. I therefore do so to provide workers in the cases in question with financial support for retraining and/or other measures to find new jobs. However, I would like to stress that the high level of unemployment in europe could be effectively combated if the austerity policies of the European Commission and the governments of the Member States have long been pursued could be stopped. Creating new jobs in Europe requires a new economic policy with massive public and environmentally friendly investments. Public investment is needed in schools, health and social care, but also in infrastructure, rail, public transport, energy-efficient housing and sustainable energy systems.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in favour. Yes to the support of 280 workers in the wood construction sector.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. - (IT) Today I voted in favour of this report in order to provide additional support to workers in the catering sector in the Aragon region of Spain who have lost their jobs in Spain as a result of the global economic and financial crisis. The catering sector has always been seen as a safety net in times of job shortages: finding a job in this sector was easy. The fact that the catering sector is now also suffering from the financial and economic crisis, resulting in redundancies, has a more serious negative effect on the regional economy than the figures alone seem to show. The objective of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) is to facilitate the rapid reintegration into working life of these redundant workers through personalized accompanying actions, such as assistance in finding employment, vocational guidance, training and retraining, promoting self-employment and entrepreneurship.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in favour of the application, the eighth under the 2014 budget, for the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) for a total amount of EUR 960 000 for Spain. The application was submitted by the Spanish authorities following redundancies and terminations of activity in 661 companies operating in the catering sector in the Region of Aragon and concerns 904 workers made redundant. In submitting the application, the Spanish authorities argued that the economic and financial crisis led to a fall in household consumption in Spain, resulting in a reduction in demand for food and drink, given the close relationship between the level of household expenditure and the consumption of food and drink outside the home.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. - The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was established in 2006 to provide additional assistance to workers affected by the consequences of major changes in the structure of international trade and to help them reintegrate into the labour market.  From 1 May 2009, the scope of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund has been extended to include support for workers made redundant as a direct result of the economic, financial and social crisis.  At a time when Europe is in the face of a financial, economic and social crisis, with unemployment being one of the main consequences, the European Union should use all means at its service to react, in particular, to the support to be provided to people who have been left without a job.  I therefore supported this report on mobilising EUR 960 000 in favour of Spain with the aim of supporting the 208 workers, beneficiary powers, of the 904 workers made redundant in 661 companies in the Region of Aragon.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. - Unfortunately, at this time of credit crunch due to the economic and financial crisis, many businesses in Europe are collapsing. The economy is slowing down, taxes are rising, vat in particular, wages are falling and redundancies are increasing. In Europe, unemployment has reached a rate of 10.3% with Spain having one of the highest rates, 25.1% not to mention the youth rate of around 54%. It is true that European solidarity is important in these difficult situations, but it is not enough. It is also necessary to reflect on the adequacy of national and European economic policies in a context of continuous change in the global market.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. – The redundancies in the said 661 enterprises are linked to global financial and economic crisis. Support provided will improve the employability of workers and assist workers to reintegrate into employment and hence I voted in favour.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. - (IT) I fully support and support the mobilisation of the EGF in order to provide a financial contribution of EUR 960 000 in relation to spain's request for redundancies in hundreds of companies operating in catering services activities which are particularly affected at this time of economic crisis.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report as it allows the mobilization of resources following the dismissal of 904 workers in 661 companies whose activity corresponds to division 56 of NACE Review 2 (food and beverages) in the NUTS 2 region Aragon (ES24), with 280 workers targeting measures co-financed by the EGF during the period from 1 March 2013 to 1 December 2013. This mobilisation of funds is due to the disastrous consequences of the internationalisation of productive sectors in the EU.  These funds are not able to solve the problems of these workers in the context of high unemployment in Spain, but at least give the possibility of alleviating a small part of human drama. That's why I've decided to vote for it.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. – I note that this particular application from Spain relates to 904 workers in 661 enterprises in the food and beverage service industry in the region of Aragon, who were made redundant or whose activities ceased over the period of six years as unemployment increased by 14 %. This complies with the requirements for determining a financial contribution and that is why I voted in favour of this proposal.

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: in writing. - I welcome the improved procedure put in place by the Commission following Parliament's call to speed up the release of these subsidies, and I believe that the Spanish authorities and the Commission must take all necessary action to verify the implementation of the measures financed in accordance with the principles of sound and effective financial management.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. It is right that the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is mobilised in this country. In the face of layoffs in Spain's restaurant sector, these funds will enable employees to be effectively supported in their efforts to reintegrate into the labour market through measures on orientation, counselling and job search.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: In writing. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EMF) was established in 2006 to help reintegrate workers who have lost their jobs as a result of changes in world trade. In 2009, its scope was expanded to include victims of the financial crisis. This application, submitted by Spain, is for redundancies in the catering services; layoffs related to the global economic and financial crisis, knowing that the decline in average wages and the decline in household consumption in Spain have led to an overall contraction in demand in this sector. The aim is to help 904 sacked employees in 661 companies located in the Aragon region. The assistance will amount to approximately EUR 960,000 and will help to co-finance active labour market measures focused on orientation, counselling, job search, training, reintegration into the workforce,... This aid is essential for Spain. Indeed, the fact that the restaurant sector is suffering from the consequences of the financial and economic crisis, with the resulting layoffs, has really negative consequences for the regional economy. This request has received my support and the support of the European Parliament.

name: Tamás DEUTSCH
text: Writing. - The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was set up to provide additional support to workers affected by the consequences of major structural changes in world trade. Spain has requested assistance from the Globalisation Adjustment Fund because workers were laid off from a huge number of companies during the economic crisis and measures to help them reintegrate into the labour market are supported by the Commission from the Fund. According to the Commission, the measures described above constitute an active labour market measure within the scope of the eligible activities under Article 7 of the EGF Regulation. I supported the report in the plenary vote.

name: Pablo ECHENIQUE
text: in writing. - EGF is a tool that seeks the relocation of laid-off workers in sectors particularly hit by "globalization". To this end, it allocates most of the funds to training, mentoring, accompaniment and development of "personal skills", while only a small portion of them goes directly into the pocket of the workers and only if they follow obediently the proposed itinerary or in the unlikely event that they get a job as a result of the program. The positive vote is explained by the recognition that any aid directed at those individuals and families who are suffering is welcome. Under no circumstances does it imply acceptance of the paternalistic and unfair logic underlying the design of this fund. People who have lost their jobs have not lost it because of lack of training and certainly do not need "incentives" to learn computer science or seek employment. They have lost it because the economy and the productive fabric have been severely undermined by powers that never consulted them and seek only the private benefit of a tiny minority.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Writing. - I voted against this project because the sums are proposed to be given to training and retraining companies for the unemployed and not directly to those who have lost their jobs and need them. Consequently, the majority of the appropriations will result in entrepreneurs who have not suffered the consequences of the economic crisis.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. - The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was set up to provide additional support for workers made redundant following major structural changes in world trade patterns due to globalisation or the financial crisis and help them find new jobs. Between 2014 and 2020, the fund's annual ceiling is EUR 150 million. Redundant workers are offered measures such as support for business creation, job search assistance, vocational guidance and various types of training. In most cases, national authorities have already begun to take steps to reimburse their costs by the EU when their applications are approved. In this mobilisation of the EGF, Spain submitted a request following the dismissal of 904 workers in 661 companies in the catering sector, with the factor responsible for redundancies the significant decrease in food and drink consumption due to the economic downturn, the increase in tax revenues, especially VAT, and the reduction in wages. In this mobilisation of the EGF in favour of Spain, EUR 960,000 was granted for aid in the reintegration into the labour market of workers who have lost their jobs in the Region of Aragon. I voted in favour.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. - This application stems from the dismissal of 904 workers in 661 companies in the Region of Aragon, Spain. These are companies in the restaurant sector. According to the Spanish authorities, the main factor responsible for the redundancies was the significant decrease in the consumption of food and beverages, particularly outside the home, due to the economic downturn, increased VAT revenues and lower wages. We are therefore not faced with any natural cataclysm, but rather the results of concrete policies which have brought us to the economic and social crisis we are experiencing; that promoted the processes of concentration and centralization of the current capital, the search for easy profit, the reduction of wages and pensions, the withdrawal of hard-won rights by workers over more than a century of struggles.  Policies that also go through the deregulation of world trade – the reason for the procession of relocations and redundancies that we have seen. As in the past, misery and injustice spread. But there is also an awareness that it is only through struggle that it is possible to break with the neoliberal policies that are leading us to the bottom of the abyss.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. - The measure affects as many as 280 workers in the construction and wood sector for an amount of € 960,000. My vote will be in favour of helping these workers, families and businesses in great difficulty.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. - We disagree with the way funding is managed. The winners will be some companies offering theories for solutions that have not reduced the unemployment rate in the areas concerned by this action to a minimum. The sum of EUR 960 000 should be allocated to the creation of new jobs and not simply to train stakeholders in skills they will never be able to apply when they do not have a job.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. - EGF is a tool that seeks the relocation of laid-off workers in sectors particularly hit by "globalization". To this end, it allocates most of the funds to training, mentoring, accompaniment and development of "personal skills", while only a small portion of them goes directly into the pocket of the workers and only if they follow obediently the proposed itinerary or in the unlikely event that they get a job as a result of the program. The positive vote is explained by the recognition that any aid directed at those individuals and families who are suffering is welcome. Under no circumstances does it imply acceptance of the paternalistic and unfair logic underlying the design of this fund. People who have lost their jobs have not lost it because of lack of training and certainly do not need "incentives" to learn computer science or seek employment. They have lost it because the economy and the productive fabric have been severely undermined by powers that never consulted them and seek only the private benefit of a tiny minority.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. – I support the need to have a European instrument to assist redundant workers. I am glad that the Parliament fully supported the setting up of the EGF as part of the MFF for 2014 to 2020.  I supported this report to grant EUR 960 000 for 280 workers made redundant from the food and drink services industry in the Aragón region. According to the Spanish authorities the sectoral index of business activity declined by 8.26 % during the period 2010-2012 so the use of the EGF will be essential in retraining and reintegration into employment for these workers.

name: Pablo IGLESIAS
text: in writing. - EGF is a tool that seeks the relocation of laid-off workers in sectors particularly hit by "globalization". To this end, it allocates most of the funds to training, mentoring, accompaniment and development of "personal skills", while only a small portion of them goes directly into the pocket of the workers and only if they follow obediently the proposed itinerary or in the unlikely event that they get a job as a result of the program. The positive vote is explained by the recognition that any aid directed at those individuals and families who are suffering is welcome. Under no circumstances does it imply acceptance of the paternalistic and unfair logic underlying the design of this fund. People who have lost their jobs have not lost it because of lack of training and certainly do not need "incentives" to learn computer science or seek employment. They have lost it because the economy and the productive fabric have been severely undermined by powers that never consulted them and seek only the private benefit of a tiny minority.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report by my colleague Anneli Jàtteenmaki on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. This fund allows people who have lost their jobs as a result of the crisis to receive financial assistance to set up projects or to find a job. The report was adopted by a large majority. I welcome the result of this vote.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. - (IT) I am voting in favour of Mr De Clercq's report. Anneli Jäätteenmäki. It provides for the reintegration into the labour market of workers made redundant in 661 companies operating in NACE Rev. 2 Division 56 (Catering Services) in Aragon, Spain. With today's vote, we are trying to guarantee a system of reintegration into the labour market for employees affected by the economic crisis, highlighting, once again, the role that Europe has and must continue to play in this time of crisis: a driving force for supporting growth and development.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report as it allows the mobilization of resources following the dismissal of 904 workers in 661 companies whose activity corresponds to division 56 of NACE Review 2 (food and beverages) in the NUTS 2 region Aragon (ES24), with 280 workers targeting measures co-financed by the EGF during the period from 1 March 2013 to 1 December 2013. This mobilisation of funds is due to the disastrous consequences of the internationalisation of productive sectors in the EU.  These funds are not able to solve the problems of these workers in the context of high unemployment in Spain, but at least give the possibility of alleviating a small part of human drama. That's why I've decided to vote for it.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: in writing. - We announced a favourable vote on the motion for a Resolution on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF), in relation to the proposed application for the accommodation, food and beverage services sector in Aragon. This sector has suffered a great break in recent years, superior even to the fall supported by the sector throughout the Spanish territory. The sharp reduction in production has had negative consequences in the form of layoffs and closures of companies that has dragged other sectors of activity in Aragon. Given the situation, the implementation of the Fund is entirely necessary and appropriate to assist in the recycling of laid-off workers in other sectors of activity, as well as to complement subsistence and encourage self-employment of dismissed persons.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: in writing. - The European Union has established this instrument to provide additional assistance to workers suffering the consequences of major structural changes in global trade models or who are dismissed as a result of the global economic and financial crisis, as well as to assist them in their reintegration into the labour market. The Spanish Government, attentive to the difficult situation in certain sectors, requested a financial contribution from feAG following the dismissal of 904 workers in 661 companies whose activity corresponds to division 56 of NACE Revision 2 (food and beverages) in the Autonomous Community of Aragon. These include 960,000 euros of training and new training aids, job search assistance, tutoring on reintegration into work and contribution to careers for dependents. For these reasons I voted in favour of granting this important aid.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. - Due to the global economic and financial crisis, I supported the Report on the Mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to assist the region of Aragon on the application submitted by Spain.  The European Globalisation Fund was set up to support workers made redundant as a result of the global financial and economic crisis to help re-enter the labour market. This Report allocates EUR 960,000 for counselling, job search assistance, education and training and support for redundance workers, all for the purpose of re-employment.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. - The globalization aid fund fulfils its role well. Instead of helping workers, it encourages shareholders and states to submit to forced liberalism. The application concerns 904 Spanish workers laid off in 661 catering companies.  The causes of this situation have been identified by the Spanish authorities as the "replica of the economy, the increase in taxes, including VAT, and the fall in wages". However, they do not call into question the policy of rigour at work in Spain. I abstain so as not to deprive workers of this fund.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. - The EU is an area of solidarity and is part of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. This support is essential to help the unemployed and the victims of relocations in a globalised context. There is an increasing number of companies relocating, taking advantage of the low labour prices, which are practised in several countries, notably China and India, with harmful effects on countries that respect workers' rights. The EGF is intended to help workers who are victims of business relocation and is key to facilitating access to new employment. The EGF has already been used in the past by other EU countries, and it is now up to Spain to give this aid to the EGF/2014/003 ES/Aragon - Restoration to a financial contribution from the EGF, following the dismissal of 904 workers in 661 companies of NACE Division 56 (Restoration)(4) in the NUTS II level Aragon region (ES24) (280 potential workers receiving the measures co-financed by the EGF) during the reference period from 1 March 2013 to 1 December 2013.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. – The European Union has set up legislative and budgetary instruments in order to provide additional support to workers who have been affected by the consequences of major structural shifts in world trade patterns and to assist the re-integration of the same workers back into the labour market. This report confirms that the proposed financial contribution will cater for 280 workers who have been made redundant by enterprises operating in the region of Aragón. I therefore voted in favour of this report to give an opportunity for the workers and families affected by these redundancies to be reintegrated into Spain’s labour market.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. – I fully support this report because the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund provides support to people losing their jobs as a result of major structural changes or a result of the global economic and financial crisis.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. - The region of Aragon in Spain has been hit hard by the economic crisis. The restaurant sector was among the first to be impacted by the difficulties. The drop in tourist traffic has hurt employment. I therefore voted to mobilise financial aid for the conversion of 960,000 euros, which will benefit 904 laid-off workers in 661 different companies in the restaurant sector.

name: Elisabeth MORIN-CHARTIER
text: In writing. - Today, the European Parliament adopted six reports of mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. I have spoken in favour of each of these reports. The aim of this fund is to enable employees who have been made redundant to have personalised training so that they can retrain professionally. On this issue, the European Parliament has agreed to release EUR 960,000 from this Fund to 208 beneficiaries in Spain.  In these difficult times, the mobilization of this Fund is essential. It is imperative that personalised training be provided to those made redundant so that they can return to the job market as soon as possible. The European Parliament once again shows its commitment to one of the founding values of the European Union: solidarity.

name: Dan NICA
text: in writing. - I voted for the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund: request EGF/2014/003 ES/Aragón - Restaurants – Spain. Spain submitted an application for a financial contribution from the EGF following 904 redundancies between March and December 2013 in 661 undertakings falling within division 56 of NACE Rev. 2 ('Restaurants') in the Aragón region. 65.36% of the workers targeted by the measures are women and 34.64% are men, and the vast majority (82.86%) workers are between the ages of 25 and 54. The 904 redundancies will further worsen the situation in the Aragón region with regard to unemployment, given that its rate has increased rapidly in the region, from 4,2 % in December 2007 to 18,4 % in December 2013. We recall the importance of improving the employability of all workers through tailored training and recognition of the capacities and skills acquired during their professional careers. We call on the Spanish authorities to ensure that the selection of beneficiaries of allowances and incentives fully complies with the principles of non-discrimination and equal opportunities between women and men.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the European Parliament's resolution on the globalisation adjustment fund for laid-off workers in the restaurant sector in Aragon, because in view of the squeeze on demand this sector was particularly affected.  I believe that the Spanish State has rightly requested this aid, the aim of which should enable the creation of businesses and new jobs.

name: Teresa RODRIGUEZ-RUBIO
text: in writing. - EGF is a tool that seeks the relocation of laid-off workers in sectors particularly hit by "globalization". To this end, it allocates most of the funds to training, mentoring, accompaniment and development of "personal skills", while only a small portion of them goes directly into the pocket of the workers and only if they follow obediently the proposed itinerary or in the unlikely event that they get a job as a result of the program. The positive vote is explained by the recognition that any aid directed at those individuals and families who are suffering is welcome. Under no circumstances does it imply acceptance of the paternalistic and unfair logic underlying the design of this fund. People who have lost their jobs have not lost it because of lack of training and certainly do not need "incentives" to learn computer science or seek employment. They have lost it because the economy and the productive fabric have been severely undermined by powers that never consulted them and seek only the private benefit of a tiny minority.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. - The positive vote is explained by the recognition that any aid directed at those individuals and families who are suffering is welcome. name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report as it allows the mobilization of resources following the dismissal of 904 workers in 661 companies whose activity corresponds to division 56 of NACE Review 2 (food and beverages) in the NUTS 2 region Aragon (ES24), with 280 workers targeting measures co-financed by the EGF during the period from 1 March 2013 to 1 December 2013. This mobilisation of funds is due to the disastrous consequences of the internationalisation of productive sectors in the EU.  These funds are not able to solve the problems of these workers in the context of high unemployment in Spain, but at least give the possibility of alleviating a small part of human drama. That's why I've decided to vote for it.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. – Spain was granted EUR 960 000 to help 280 workers who lost their jobs in the food and beverages services industry in the Aragón region. The redundancies were due to declining demand during the financial and economic crisis. With 597 votes the European Parliament has shown its solidarity for these Spanish workers. The UK has never made an application under this fund. UK workers therefore receive none of this support.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. - I voted for a resolution in which the European Union established legislative and budgetary instruments to provide additional support to workers who have been laid off or made redundant by the global financial and economic crisis.  I agree with the Commission that the conditions set out in the EGF Regulation have been met and that Spain is therefore entitled to a financial contribution under that Regulation. The Spanish authorities argue that the main factor in increasing the number of redundancies is a significant reduction in the consumption of food and beverages, primarily food that is not consumed at home, which is due to negative developments in the economy, increased tax revenues, primarily VAT and wage cuts. Additional redundancies in the number of 904 people will adversely affect unemployment in Aragon, where the rate rose sharply from 4.2% in December 2007 to 18.4% in December 2013.  I would therefore like to stress the importance of increasing the employment opportunities of all workers through tailored training programmes and recognising the abilities and skills acquired by the worker throughout his or her career. Measures to assist workers such as guidance, counselling and job search and training and retraining are expected to adapt not only to their needs but also to the real business environment.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: in writing - I voted against. The EU will give 1.66 million euros, 475 Dutch €1.6 million, 508 Greeks over €6 million and 1,000 Romanians €3.6 million. However, these contributions are levied arbitrarily, from the taxes of others, and do not solve the cause of the problem, only moderate consequences. The cause of the problem is the lack of competitiveness of European economies, which continues to be reduced by exaggerated climate objectives and unnecessarily high social protection and other standards. As long as the EU has conflicting objectives, such as climate targets versus an increase in industrial production, jobs will disappear by then.

name: Kay SWINBURNE
text: in writing. – I voted against this report today, I am opposed in principle to the use of this European Globalisation Adjustment Fund and as a result I cannot support this proposal to mobilise it.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. - I am voting against it because I disagree with the allocation of funds when they do not concern the creation of new jobs.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. - Eighth considered in the 2014 budget, this request was aimed at mobilising a total of EUR 960,000 from the EGF for Spain. It affected 280 beneficiaries out of 904 workers who had been laid off in 661 companies. The Spanish authorities have indicated that, according to the annual report of the Federacion Espa'ola de Hostelera y Restauracion on accommodation and catering activities for 2012(4), the sector index of business activity fell by 8.26% over the period 2010-2012. Furthermore, the Spanish authorities argue that, as a result of the decline in out-of-home catering spending, the number of businesses operating in the restaurant sector fell by 3.5% nationally in 2011 compared to 2009, while the decline was 11% in Aragon. The decline in commercial activity in the restaurant sector and the closure of many businesses operating in this sector have led to a significant number of layoffs. So we decided to accede to this request

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. – In the face of the turmoil that is affecting some EU countries and the unacceptably high level of unemployment among the EU population, any initiative that improves the employment of all workers by means of adapted training and the recognition of skills and competences gained throughout a worker's professional career is of vital importance. Hence, it is necessary to provide solidarity and this programme on a coordinated package of personalised services goes in the right direction.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report as it allows the mobilization of resources following the dismissal of 904 workers in 661 companies whose activity corresponds to division 56 of NACE Review 2 (food and beverages) in the NUTS 2 region Aragon (ES24), with 280 workers targeting measures co-financed by the EGF during the period from 1 March 2013 to 1 December 2013. This mobilisation of funds is due to the disastrous consequences of the internationalisation of productive sectors in the EU.  These funds are not able to solve the problems of these workers in the context of high unemployment in Spain, but at least give the possibility of alleviating a small part of human drama. That's why I've decided to vote for it.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. - 904 workers were made redundant in the region of Aragon, Spain, in 661 companies in the catering sector, mainly because of the decrease in food and drink consumption due to the economic downturn, increased VAT revenues and lower wages.  Today, several generations are faced with misery. Despair grows. Discredit and discouragement flourish. This fund is only palliative, but it can serve to relieve a little of the suffering of these people.

name: Marco ZANNI
text: in writing. - (IT) I supported this and the other reports that we have voted on today for the mobilisation of the EGF, the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. It is an instrument that can help the workers of these companies affected by the crisis, even if the causes of this whole situation would be to be analysed in depth. Today we have approved requests for support from Greece, Spain, Romania and the Netherlands, which shows that the difficulties are not confined to a single country, but it is the whole of Europe that is suffering terribly. Steel, construction, food and catering: the companies affected were operating in these areas, and it is clear that these are sectors that are also in enormous difficulty in Italy. I do not always want to have to ask for the approval of these support instruments, but I would rather see the European Union and the Member States trying to prevent or at least limit this. It is undeniable that there is a lack of an effective industrial policy strategy, and the actions decided on in Brussels often have disastrous consequences, such as the free trade agreements in which our productive realities usually lose out. We need an immediate change of course and strategy, not least because with TTIP things could even get worse.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. - The application we are considering stems from the dismissal of 904 workers in 661 companies in the region of Aragon, Spain, companies in the restaurant sector. According to the Spanish authorities, the main factor responsible for the redundancies was the significant decrease in the consumption of food and beverages, particularly outside the home, due to the economic downturn, increased VAT revenues and lower wages. As a fact, these have not appeared unannounced and are rather the result of the economic and financial crisis and the processes of concentration and centralisation of the current capital, the search for easier profits, which involves reducing wages and pensions, the withdrawal of hard-won rights by workers over more than a century of struggles and enormous sacrifices of workers and their families.  Today, several generations are faced with misery. Despair grows. Discredit and discouragement flourish. But, as in the past, there is also an awareness that it is only through struggle that it is possible to break with the neoliberal policies that are leading us to the bottom of the abyss.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report as it allows the mobilization of resources following redundancies in 89 companies operating in DIVISION 41 ('Building Buildings') of NACE Rev. 2 in the adjoining NUTS 2 regions of the Goeldres and Overijssel level in the Netherlands, where 475 workers could benefit from the measures co-financed by the EGF during the period from 1 March 2013 to 1 March December 2013. This mobilisation of funds is due to the disastrous consequences of the internationalisation of productive sectors in the EU.  These funds are not able to solve the problems of these unemployed, but at least give the possibility of alleviating a small part of human drama. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. - The intervention of the EGF is justified here because the dismissals of more than 500 workers in the construction sector are the result, on the one hand, of the global financial and economic crisis which leads to a more restrictive credit policy on the part of the banks, and, on the other hand, of austerity measures which have strongly affected the purchasing power of citizens.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. The European Parliament has adopted 6 mobilisation reports from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund.  This application by the Netherlands is mainly for the construction sector. This sector is going through a crisis throughout Europe due to lower demand, not least because of the budgetary restrictions of the states but also because of the difficulty for individuals to be granted bank loans.  The aid provided here amounts to 1.6 million euros to help 475 sacked employees in 89 companies and to enable them to train and reorient themselves. That is why I voted in favour of this request.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in favour of the report by Mr Beazley on behalf of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs and Industrial Policy. Mr Tang, the text identifies in a relevant and precise way the actions on which it is appropriate to invest urgently in order to retrain workers who are currently unemployed as a result of the crisis in the construction sector in the Netherlands. I therefore support the mobilisation of the EGF and the allocation of EUR 1 625 781 to workers in difficulty.

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: Written. - (1) (1) Whereas I have voted in favour of these reports today; I therefore do so to provide workers in the cases in question with financial support for retraining and/or other measures to find new jobs. However, I would like to stress that the high level of unemployment in europe could be effectively combated if the austerity policies of the European Commission and the governments of the Member States have long been pursued could be stopped. Creating new jobs in Europe requires a new economic policy with massive public and environmentally friendly investments. Public investment is needed in schools, health and social care, but also in infrastructure, rail, public transport, energy-efficient housing and sustainable energy systems.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in favour of the EGF's support for 475 construction workers.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. - I voted in favour of this request for a financial contribution from the Netherlands, which was dealt with very effectively within 5 months. This assistance will affect 475 laid-off workers in 89 companies. The assistance provided by the EMF is adapted and is not a substitute for actions under the responsibility of companies.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. - (IT) Today I voted in favour of this report in order to provide additional support to construction workers in the Gelderland and Overijssel regions of the Netherlands, who have lost their jobs as a result of the global economic and financial crisis. The possibilities for Dutch banks to attract savings capital from the Dutch market are limited, so they cannot finance Dutch mortgage loans with Dutch capital alone. Some 98% of Dutch construction companies are small and medium-sized enterprises and suffer from the lack of access to credit, which results in numerous cases of bankruptcy resulting in redundancies. Employment in the construction sector is the one most affected by the crisis, and the recovery is expected to be very slow. The objective of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) is to facilitate the rapid reintegration into working life of these redundant workers through tailor-made accompanying actions, such as assistance in job search, vocational guidance, training and retraining, promotion of self-employment and entrepreneurship.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in favour of the application, the seventh in the framework of the 2014 budget, aimed at mobilising the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) for a total amount of EUR 1 625 781 for the Netherlands. The Dutch authorities requested this financial contribution following the redundancies of 89 companies operating in the construction sector. They stated that there are a number of reasons for the negative production and employment performance in the construction sector, and in particular in the construction sector (public utility and housing buildings), all of which are linked to the financial and economic crisis, including the more restrictive measures taken by banks in the mortgage and credit sectors, government austerity measures and the sharp fall in prices and values on the housing market.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. - The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was established in 2006 to provide additional assistance to workers affected by the consequences of major changes in the structure of international trade and to help them reintegrate into the labour market.  From 1 May 2009, the scope of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund has been extended to include support for workers made redundant as a direct result of the economic, financial and social crisis.  At a time when Europe is in the face of a financial, economic and social crisis, with unemployment being one of the main consequences, the European Union should use all means at its service to react, in particular, to the support to be provided to people who have been left without a job.  I therefore supported this report on mobilising EUR 1625 781 for the Netherlands to support the 475 potential beneficiaries following the redundancies in 89 companies in the Gelderland and Overijssel regions.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. - (IT) Concrete help has now arrived from the Strasbourg Chamber to the Authorities of the Netherlands and in particular to the regions of Gelderland and Overijssel and to all those companies operating in the construction sector. Since last January, other categories of workers, such as self-employed and fixed-term workers, temporary workers and young people who are outside any training and work circuit, the so-called NEETs, have also benefited from the Globalisation Adjustment Fund.  In addition, this instrument has been improved by services and actions aimed at offering the reintegration of workers. In this case, specific training in the demolition of asbestos has been set up among the measures financed by the EGF for the benefit of health and safety for those who habitually work in contact with this type of material. I can therefore only vote in favour of the allocation of this instrument, which allows, through appropriate training, to acquire further training knowledge and to find a new job.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. – I voted in favour as the redundancies in 89 enterprises are linked to global financial and economic crisis. Such redundancies aggravate the unemployment situation in the relevant provinces. The support being provided will improve the employment prospects of the redundant workers.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. - I am voting in favour of mobilising the EGF requested by the Netherlands to make a financial contribution following redundancies in 89 building companies, given the banks' policy of adopting more restrictive mortgage and credit measures, which has significantly reduced access to loans and loans, making it difficult to buy and sell real estate.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report as it allows the mobilization of resources following redundancies in 89 companies operating in DIVISION 41 ('Building Buildings') of NACE Rev. 2 in the adjoining NUTS 2 regions of the Goeldres and Overijssel level in the Netherlands, where 475 workers could benefit from the measures co-financed by the EGF during the period from 1 March 2013 to 1 March December 2013. This mobilisation of funds is due to the disastrous consequences of the internationalisation of productive sectors in the EU.  These funds are not able to solve the problems of these unemployed, but at least give the possibility of alleviating a small part of human drama. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. – I note that this particular request by Holland deals with 562 workers in 89 enterprises in the construction industry in the regions of Gelderland and Overijssel in the Netherlands, as a result of negative trends in the construction sector. This complies with the requirements for determining a financial contribution and that is why I voted in favour of this proposal.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. With this funding from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, the European Union is helping to promote and accelerate the reintegration into the labour market of Dutch employees who have been made redundant in the building construction sector. This text will have concrete consequences for these employees by allowing them to be better supported in their job search, to be trained and to give them the ability to be more mobile. So I voted for him.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: In writing. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EMF) aims to help reintegrate workers who have lost their jobs as a result of changes in world trade and the victims of the financial crisis.  The current application, submitted by the Netherlands, is for redundancies in the building construction sector. Indeed, the sale and purchase of real estate is now made difficult not only because of the banks' policy of applying stricter rules on mortgages and loans, but also because of the austerity measures taken by governments to reduce public debt and the budget deficit.  Added to this is the sharp decline in prices and values in the real estate market. The aim is to help 562 sacked employees in 89 companies located in the Gelderland and Overijssel regions. The aid provided will amount to 1,625,781 euros and will help to co-finance active measures in the labour market focused on job search assistance, training, career reorientation... This request has received my support and the support of the European Parliament.

name: Tamás DEUTSCH
text: Writing. - The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was set up to provide additional support to workers affected by the consequences of major structural changes in world trade. On 10 July 2014, the Commission adopted a proposal for a decision on the use of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for the Netherlands to support the reintegration into the labour market of workers made redundant from 89 companies as a result of the global financial and economic crisis in the bordering regions of Gelderland and Overijssel as a result of the construction downturn. I supported the report in the plenary vote.

name: Pablo ECHENIQUE
text: in writing. - EGF is a tool that seeks the relocation of laid-off workers in sectors particularly hit by "globalization". To this end, it allocates most of the funds to training, mentoring, accompaniment and development of "personal skills", while only a small portion of them goes directly into the pocket of the workers and only if they follow obediently the proposed itinerary or in the unlikely event that they get a job as a result of the program. The positive vote is explained by the recognition that any aid directed at those individuals and families who are suffering is welcome. Under no circumstances does it imply acceptance of the paternalistic and unfair logic underlying the design of this fund. People who have lost their jobs have not lost it because of lack of training and certainly do not need "incentives" to learn computer science or seek employment. They have lost it because the economy and the productive fabric have been severely undermined by powers that never consulted them and seek only the private benefit of a tiny minority.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Writing. - I voted against this project because the sums are proposed to be given to training and retraining companies for the unemployed and not directly to those who have lost their jobs and need them. Consequently, the majority of the appropriations will result in entrepreneurs who have not suffered the consequences of the economic crisis.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. - The EGF was created to provide additional support for workers made redundant following major structural changes in world trade patterns due to globalisation or the financial crisis and help them find new jobs. Between 2014 and 2020, the fund's annual ceiling is EUR 150 million. Redundant workers are offered measures such as support for business creation, job search assistance, vocational guidance and various types of training. In most cases, national authorities have already begun to take steps to reimburse their costs by the EU when their applications are approved. The Netherlands has submitted an application for a financial contribution from the EGF following redundancies in 89 companies operating in building construction in the contiguous regions of Gelderland and Overijssel, with 475 targeted workers and are related to the global financial and economic crisis, highlighting the fact that the bank's policy is to apply stricter rules for the granting of mortgage loans and credits , have significantly reduced the granting of these, while the government's austerity measures to reduce government debt and the budget deficit have resulted in a decrease in public spending and a sharp fall in prices and values in the housing market, making it difficult to buy and sell homes. Eur 1625781 was granted in this mobilisation of the EGF in favour of the Netherlands. I voted in favour

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. - Another mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF). A few hundred more workers who are victims of capitalist globalization. This time, it was the Netherlands to apply for a financial contribution from the EGF, following redundancies in 89 companies operating in nace's Building Building Division Revision 2 in the contiguous regions of Gelderland and Overijssel, with 475 of potential workers benefiting from the measures co-financed by the EGF. The Fund aims to reverse the consequences of deepening the liberalisation of world trade and its continued deregulation which are contained in the general orientation of EU policies, which ruin many businesses, pushing work into pre-charity and unemployment. The EGF, although it represents in the immediate right to represent important support for workers, is not a solution and does not excuse, much less makes the neoliberal policies in force acceptable. The Netherlands was one of the most critical countries with regard to the extension of the scope of the Fund which initially applied only in cases linked to the consequences of globalisation, and even against (in the Council) enlargement to cases the consequences of which resulted from the global financial and economic crisis. However, it was one of the countries that most appealed to the EGF by invoking the reason it rejected earlier.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. - The measure affects as many as 470 workers in the construction sector for an amount of € 1,625,781. My vote will be in favour of helping these workers, families and businesses in great difficulty.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. - We disagree with the way funding is managed. The winners will be some companies offering theories for solutions that have not reduced the unemployment rate in the areas concerned by this action to a minimum. The amount of EUR 1,625,781 should be allocated to the creation of new jobs and not simply to train those concerned in skills they will never be able to apply when they do not have a job.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. - EGF is a tool that seeks the relocation of laid-off workers in sectors particularly hit by "globalization". To this end, it allocates most of the funds to training, mentoring, accompaniment and development of "personal skills", while only a small portion of them goes directly into the pocket of the workers and only if they follow obediently the proposed itinerary or in the unlikely event that they get a job as a result of the program. The positive vote is explained by the recognition that any aid directed at those individuals and families who are suffering is welcome. Under no circumstances does it imply acceptance of the paternalistic and unfair logic underlying the design of this fund. People who have lost their jobs have not lost it because of lack of training and certainly do not need "incentives" to learn computer science or seek employment. They have lost it because the economy and the productive fabric have been severely undermined by powers that never consulted them and seek only the private benefit of a tiny minority.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Paul Tang's report on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. This fund allows people who have lost their jobs as a result of the crisis to receive financial assistance to set up projects or to find a job. The report was adopted by a large majority. I welcome the result of this vote.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in favour of Mr De Clercq's report. Paul Tang because I regard the decision on the mobilisation of the EGF in favour of the Netherlands as an undisputed opportunity for the reintegration into the labour market of workers made redundant in 89 companies operating in NACE Rev.2 Division 41 (Building Construction). In a context of economic crisis such as the one we are experiencing, we have repeatedly stressed the importance and effectiveness of an instrument such as the EGF. By using the most appropriate destination criteria, Europe is once again demonstrating its mission of solidarity and its concreteness in helping the people most affected by a devastating economic crisis.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report as it allows the mobilization of resources following redundancies in 89 companies operating in DIVISION 41 ('Building Buildings') of NACE Rev. 2 in the adjoining NUTS 2 regions of the Goeldres and Overijssel level in the Netherlands, where 475 workers could benefit from the measures co-financed by the EGF during the period from 1 March 2013 to 1 March December 2013. This mobilisation of funds is due to the disastrous consequences of the internationalisation of productive sectors in the EU.  These funds are not able to solve the problems of these unemployed, but at least give the possibility of alleviating a small part of human drama. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. - Due to the global and economic crisis and the change in bank policy, which tightened the conditions for granting mortgage loans and loans and significantly reduced their supply, I supported the Report on the Mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to assist the Dutch regions of Gelderland and Overijssel on the application submitted by the Netherlands.    The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was set up with the aim of further assisting redundary workers and the self-employed who had to cease their activities as a result of globalisation. This Report aims to provide 1,625,781 euros to help laid-off workers look for work and additional education.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this report because it will help the re-integration of the workers of the 89 enterprises that were made redundant. These redundancies had to be made because of the negative impact of the global financial and economic crisis. This is the seventh application to be examined under the 2014 budget and will come out of the Netherlands’ allocation of funds in this pot.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. - The globalization aid fund fulfils its role well. Instead of helping workers, it encourages shareholders and states to submit to forced liberalism. The application concerns 562 Dutch construction employees operating in 89 different companies. The crisis in the construction sector is explained by the Dutch authorities by the heavy dependence of their financial sector on the global financial sector. This has led to a contraction in credit, particularly real estate, as well as a sharp decline in prices and values in the real estate market. But the report does not propose binding measures on the banking sector and calls on laid-off workers to have more mobility and flexibility. I abstain so as not to deprive workers of this fund.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. - The EU is an area of solidarity and is part of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. This support is essential to help the unemployed and the victims of relocations in a globalised context. There is an increasing number of companies relocating, taking advantage of the low labour prices, which are practised in several countries, notably China and India, with harmful effects on countries that respect workers' rights. The EGF is intended to help workers who are victims of business relocation and is key to facilitating access to new employment. The EGF has already been used in the past by other EU countries, and it is now up to the Netherlands that submitted the EGF/2014/002 NL/Gelderland-Overijssel construction application to a financial contribution from the EGF, following redundancies in 89 companies operating in NACE Revision 2 Division 41 (Building Construction)(4) in the contiguous NUTS-2 regions of Gelderland and Overijssel, with 475 workers targeted for measures co-financed by the EGF during the reference period from 1 March 2013 to 1 December 2013.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. – The European Union has set up legislative and budgetary instruments in order to provide additional support to workers who have been affected by the consequences of major structural shifts in world trade patterns and to assist the re-integration of the same workers back into the labour market. This report confirms that the proposed financial contribution will cater for 475 workers who have been made redundant in the regions of Gelderland and Overijssel. This report also confirms that the redundancies are linked to the global financial and economic crisis, mainly related to the policy of banks to implement more stringent rules for the provision of mortgages and credits. This was augmented by the austerity measures of the government to reduce national debt and budget deficit, which led to the reduction of public spending, thus having a considerable effect on the construction industry. I therefore voted in favour of this report which will give additional opportunities for the workers and families affected by these redundancies.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. – I fully support this report because the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund provides support to people losing their jobs as a result of major structural changes or a result of the global economic and financial crisis.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. - I voted in favour of this issue to allow the release of financial aid of EUR 1,625,781 for 562 former construction workers in the Gelderland region. The construction sector in this region has suffered enormously from the economic crisis. The decline in investment has led to a decrease in housing starts and renovations. Beyond the retraining aid that we have just approved, it is essential that Member States take responsibility by implementing public housing policies aimed at boosting investment in the sector.

name: Elisabeth MORIN-CHARTIER
text: In writing. - Today, the European Parliament adopted six reports of mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. I have spoken in favour of each of these reports. The aim of this fund is to enable employees who have been made redundant to have personalised training so that they can retrain professionally. On this issue, the European Parliament has agreed to release EUR 1.6 million from this Fund to 475 beneficiaries in the Netherlands.  In these difficult times, the mobilization of this Fund is essential. It is imperative that personalised training be provided to those made redundant so that they can return to the job market as soon as possible. The European Parliament once again shows its commitment to one of the founding values of the European Union: solidarity.

name: Dan NICA
text: in writing. - I voted for the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund: application for EGF/2014/002 NL/Gelderland-Overijssel construction – The Netherlands. 475 workers out of a total of 562 eligible workers are targeted for measures co-financed by the EGF during the march-December 2013 reference period. The redundancies are associated with the global economic and financial crisis, recalling in this context that the policy of banks to implement more stringent rules on the granting of loans and mortgages has considerably reduced the granting of such loans. The government's austerity measures to reduce public debt and the budget deficit have led to cuts in public spending, as well as a sharp fall in prices and values in the housing market, making it difficult to sell and buy homes.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the European Parliament's resolution on the globalisation adjustment fund for laid-off workers in the construction sector in the Netherlands. The credit crunch during the financial crisis had a serious impact on real estate construction, which the European Union must respond to in order to encourage the creation of new businesses and new jobs.

name: Teresa RODRIGUEZ-RUBIO
text: in writing. - EGF is a tool that seeks the relocation of laid-off workers in sectors particularly hit by "globalization". To this end, it allocates most of the funds to training, mentoring, accompaniment and development of "personal skills", while only a small portion of them goes directly into the pocket of the workers and only if they follow obediently the proposed itinerary or in the unlikely event that they get a job as a result of the program. The positive vote is explained by the recognition that any aid directed at those individuals and families who are suffering is welcome. Under no circumstances does it imply acceptance of the paternalistic and unfair logic underlying the design of this fund. People who have lost their jobs have not lost it because of lack of training and certainly do not need "incentives" to learn computer science or seek employment. They have lost it because the economy and the productive fabric have been severely undermined by powers that never consulted them and seek only the private benefit of a tiny minority.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
