name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report as it allows the mobilization of resources following redundancies in 89 companies operating in DIVISION 41 ('Building Buildings') of NACE Rev. 2 in the adjoining NUTS 2 regions of the Goeldres and Overijssel level in the Netherlands, where 475 workers could benefit from the measures co-financed by the EGF during the period from 1 March 2013 to 1 March December 2013. This mobilisation of funds is due to the disastrous consequences of the internationalisation of productive sectors in the EU.  These funds are not able to solve the problems of these unemployed, but at least give the possibility of alleviating a small part of human drama. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. - Thanks to today´s vote Dutch redundant workers are offered support after a lack of orders due to the financial crisis forced 89 building firms in the Gelderland and Overijssel provinces to make workers redundant. The €1,625,781 in EGF aid will pay for training and other measures to help to 475 redundant workers back into jobs. The UK has never made an application under this fund. UK workers therefore receive none of this support.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. - I support a resolution in which the European Union has set up legislative and budgetary instruments to provide additional support to workers who have been laid off or made redundant as a result of the global financial and economic crisis.  I agree with the Commission that the conditions set out in the EGF Regulation have been met and that the Netherlands is therefore entitled to a financial contribution under that Regulation. The redundancies of workers at 89 NACE companies concerning the construction of buildings in the neighbouring Dutch regions of Gelderland and Overijssel are linked to the financial and economic crisis. It refers to the fact that banks' policy has introduced stricter criteria regarding mortgage lending and thus significantly reduced the supply of mortgages and loans. Government austerity measures to reduce the national debt and budget deficit have reduced public spending and resulted in a drop in the price and value of properties, making it difficult to buy and sell houses. The number of unemployed in these both provinces accounts for 39% of the total number of redundant employees in 2012.  In my view, the implementation decided by the Dutch authorities is a good step to combat unemployment. It refers to help workers look for work, education measures and other factors that would facilitate the difficult position of people who have unexpectedly lost their jobs.

name: Kay SWINBURNE
text: in writing. – I voted against this report today, I am opposed in principle to the use of this European Globalisation Adjustment Fund and as a result I cannot support this proposal to mobilise it.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. - I am voting against because I disagree with the return of money except in cases where new jobs are created.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. - On 10 July 2014, the Commission adopted a proposal for a decision on the mobilization of the EGF in favour of the Netherlands in order to support the reintegration into the labour market of workers laid off in 89 companies under the 41 division of the NACE Rev. 2 ("Building construction")(4) located in the adjoining NUTS 2 regions of Gelderland and Overijssel due to the global economic and financial crisis. In this context, the European Parliament has decided to grant these aid funds. I therefore voted in favour of this text.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. – I welcome the initiative of future cross-border initiatives such as border desks or alignment of rules in order to enhance the exchange of information and to stimulate the cross-border mobility of workers. Representing a country with boundaries, it should be a priority to use all the tools available to enhance best practices. In this case, as well, it is important to train participants for occupations outside the construction sector.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report as it allows the mobilization of resources following redundancies in 89 companies operating in DIVISION 41 ('Building Buildings') of NACE Rev. 2 in the adjoining NUTS 2 regions of the Goeldres and Overijssel level in the Netherlands, where 475 workers could benefit from the measures co-financed by the EGF during the period from 1 March 2013 to 1 March December 2013. These funds are not able to solve the problems of these unemployed, but at least give the possibility of alleviating a small part of human drama. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. - The proposal is intended to alleviate the situation caused by the dismissal of 475 workers in 89 companies operating in the Building Building Division of NACE Revision 2 in the contiguous regions of Gelderland and Overijssel. The consequences of deepening the liberalisation of world trade and its continued deregulation are contained in the general orientation of EU policies that ruin the survival capacity of businesses, pushing work towards precariousness until it is extinguished. We note that the Netherlands was one of the most critical countries with regard to the extension of the scope of the Fund, which initially applied only in cases linked to the consequences of globalisation, and it was even against (in the Council) enlargement to cases whose consequences resulted from the global financial and economic crisis.  However, and interestingly enough, it was one of the countries that most appealed to the EGF, invoking the reason it rejected earlier.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. - This time, it was the Netherlands to submit an application for a financial contribution from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF), following redundancies in 89 companies operating in the NACE Building Building Division Revision 2 in the contiguous regions of Gelderland and Overijssel, with 475 of potential workers benefiting from the measures co-financed by the EGF. The Fund aims to reverse the consequences of deepening the liberalisation of world trade and its continued deregulation which are contained in the general orientation of EU policies that ruin the survival capacity of businesses, pushing work towards precariousness until it is extinguished. The Fund, despite immediately representing important support for workers, is still the mercy that allows large capital to continue to disseminate neoliberal policies that have led to recession and the historic rise in unemployment. The Netherlands was one of the most critical countries with regard to the extension of the scope of the Fund which initially applied only in cases linked to the consequences of globalisation, and even against (in the Council) enlargement to cases the consequences of which resulted from the global financial and economic crisis. However, it was one of the countries that most appealed to the EGF by invoking the reason it rejected earlier.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report as it allows the mobilisation of the 587 redundancies, with 400 workers who are expected to participate in the measures, in three companies that manufacture wood and wood and cork products in the NUTS II region of Castilla y León (ES41), in Spain, during the reference period from 28 December 2012 to 28 September 2013. This mobilisation of funds is due to the disastrous consequences of the internationalisation of productive sectors in the EU.  These funds are not able to solve the problems of these unemployed, but at least give the possibility of alleviating a small part of human drama. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. - The figures show that the carpentry and structural parts sector for business construction in Castile e Leon has suffered particularly from the economic crisis and the contraction of the EU 27 export market share. The 587 jobs lost also concern a region where the unemployment rate rose from 8.2% in 2008 to 22.7% in 2013! Assistance in the reorientation of the workers concerned is therefore essential.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in favour of mobilising the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in favour of 587 workers made redundant in the construction sector in Spain.

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: Written. I have voted in favour of these reports today. I therefore do so to provide workers in the cases in question with financial support for retraining and/or other measures to find new jobs. However, I would like to stress that the high level of unemployment in europe could be effectively combated if the austerity policies of the European Commission and the governments of the Member States have long been pursued could be stopped. Creating new jobs in Europe requires a new economic policy with massive public and environmentally friendly investments. Public investment is needed in schools, health and social care, but also in infrastructure, rail, public transport, energy-efficient housing and sustainable energy systems.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in favour of supporting 587 construction workers.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. - (IT) Today I voted in favour of this report in order to provide additional support to the 587 workers in the wood sector who have lost their jobs in Spain as a result of the global economic and financial crisis.  The objective of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) is to facilitate the rapid reintegration into working life of these redundant workers through tailor-made accompanying actions, such as assistance in job search, vocational guidance, training and retraining, promotion of self-employment and entrepreneurship.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in favour of the application, the 9th in the framework of the 2014 budget, for the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) for a total amount of EUR 700 000 for Spain. The application in question was submitted by Spain following the redundancy of the staff of three wood companies in the Castilla y Leon region. This redundancy may be linked to significant changes in the structure of world trade in carpentry and wood carpentry work for construction.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. - The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was established in 2006 to provide additional assistance to workers affected by the consequences of major changes in the structure of international trade and to help them reintegrate into the labour market.  From 1 May 2009, the scope of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund has been extended to include support for workers made redundant as a direct result of the economic, financial and social crisis.  At a time when Europe is in the face of a financial, economic and social crisis, with unemployment being one of the main consequences, the European Union should use all means at its service to react, in particular, to the support to be provided to people who have been left without a job.  I therefore supported this report on mobilising EUR 700 000 in favour of Spain to support the 587 workers made redundant in three companies in the wood and cork industry and their works in the Castilla y Leon region.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. - (IT) I strongly support the mobilisation of the Globalisation Adjustment Fund in favour of certain Spanish companies operating in the wood and wood and cork industries, and I welcome the Commission's proposal to allocate EUR 700 000 to them. Unfortunately, it is not at all pleasant to note that 587 workers have lost their jobs as a result of the serious decline in the volume of exports of carpentry and wooden carpentry for construction in Europe. Of course, it is now necessary to provide timely assistance to workers and also to companies, but in the next period we will also have to think about how to raise the wood market and the employment rate in Spain, as well as in Europe.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. – I voted in favour as this measure will promote entrepreneurship and support reintegration of workers into the labour market.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. - (IT) I can only vote in favour of intervention by the EGF following the redundancy of 587 workers among the companies operating in the wood and cork industry in the NUTS II region of Castilla y León in Spain.  In the same area there is an unemployment rate rising from 8.2% in the first quarter of 2008 to 22.70% in the first quarter of 2013 and the employment situation in the region concerned is particularly fragile given the extremely low population density, as in the province of Soria and given the heavy dependence on the wood sector, which due to such a population density causes redundancies to have serious effects on the local economy as well.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report as it allows the mobilisation of the 587 redundancies, with 400 workers who are expected to participate in the measures, in three companies that manufacture wood and wood and cork products in the NUTS II region of Castilla y León (ES41), in Spain, during the reference period from 28 December 2012 to 28 September 2013. This mobilisation of funds is due to the disastrous consequences of the internationalisation of productive sectors in the EU.  These funds are not able to solve the problems of these unemployed, but at least give the possibility of alleviating a small part of human drama. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. – Spain submitted this application following 587 redundancies in the manufacture of wood and of products of wood and cork in the NUTS II region of Castilla y León (ES41) which were linked to major structural changes in world trade patterns as a result of globalisation. This complies with the requirements for determining a financial contribution and that is why I voted in favour of this proposal.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. In a country that already has one of the highest unemployment rates in Europe, it is necessary to provide a full range of services in order to restore the ability of unemployed Spanish workers to find a job quickly. Funded by the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, support for career guidance and intensive job search, vocational training and the enhancement of entrepreneurship will be assets to promote their reintegration into the labour market.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: In writing. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EMF) aims to help workers who have lost their jobs as a result of changes in world trade as well as the victims of the financial crisis. This application, submitted by Spain, is for redundancies in the timber sector. While the share of exports of carpentry and construction parts in the EU27 fell by 10.33 per cent over the 2008-2011 period; it is important to note that during the same period, the decline of this sector was even greater in Spain, where the number of enterprises fell by 28.8%. The aim is to help 587 sacked employees in three companies located in the Castile-et-Leon region. The aid will amount to EUR 700,000 and will enable active labour market measures to be co-financed, focusing on job search and training. This assistance is all the more essential since these layoffs have hit the local labour market hard, with the unemployment rate rising from 8.2% in the first quarter of 2008 to 22.70% in the first quarter of 2013. This request has my support as well as that of the European Parliament.

name: Tamás DEUTSCH
text: Writing. - The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was set up to provide additional support to workers affected by the consequences of major structural changes in world trade. Spain has turned to the European Commission for aid because a total of 587 people were laid off between 28 December 2012 and 28 September 2013 at three companies processing wood and timber and cork products in the Regions of Castile and Leon. Of these people, 400 can be helped by the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to find work again through retraining. I supported the report in the plenary vote.

text: in writing. - EGF is a tool that seeks the relocation of laid-off workers in sectors particularly hit by "globalization". name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Writing. - I voted against this project because the sums are proposed to be given to training and retraining companies for the unemployed and not directly to those who have lost their jobs and need them. Consequently, the majority of the appropriations will result in entrepreneurs who have not suffered the consequences of the economic crisis.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. - The EGF was created to provide additional support to redundant workers following major structural changes in world trade patterns due to globalisation or the financial crisis and help them find new jobs. Between 2014 and 2020, the fund's annual ceiling is EUR 150 million. Redundant workers are offered measures such as support for business creation, job search assistance, vocational guidance and various types of training. In most cases, national authorities have already begun to take steps to reimburse their costs by the EU when their applications are approved. Spain submitted its application to the EGF following the dismissal of 587 workers in three companies in the timber and cork industry and their works in the Castile and León region of Spain during the reference period from 28 December 2012 to 28 September 2013, related to major changes in the structure of world trade resulting from globalisation , referring to the fact that the volume of exports of carpentry and carpentry for construction from the EU-27 decreased by 10.33 % in the period 2008-2011. In this mobilization of the EGF for the region of Castile and León in Spain, EUR 700,000 was granted. I voted in favour.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. - The application under consideration stems from the dismissal of 587 workers in three companies in the wood and cork industry in the Region of Castile and León in Spain. This redundancy severely affected the labour market in that region, with the unemployment rate rising from 8.2 % to 22.70 %. Once again, the changes in the structure of world trade resulting from globalisation – in the self-justifying jargon of this European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, whose existence is still a living libel accusing capitalist globalization, even if what it wants is to excuse and make acceptable – are pointed out as responsible for throwing these workers and their families into the world of uncertainty.  We are approving palliatives which, if necessary, are not the solution. There is a new direction for Europe, a course that has social justice and the well-being of peoples at the heart of its policies and the right to work with decent rights, wages and pensions. The way is the struggle of workers and peoples.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. - The measure affects as many as 587 workers in the construction sector for an amount of € 700,000. My vote will be in favour of helping these workers, families and businesses in great difficulty.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. - We disagree with the way funding is managed. The winners will be some companies offering theories for solutions that have not reduced the unemployment rate to a minimum in the areas concerned by the action. The sum of EUR 700 000 should be allocated to the creation of new jobs and not simply to train stakeholders in skills they will never be able to apply when they do not have a job.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report by my colleague Esteban Gonzalez Pons on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. This fund allows people who have lost their jobs as a result of the crisis to receive financial assistance to set up projects or to find a job. The report was adopted by a large majority. I welcome the result of this vote.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. - (IT) Today we have voted on a further 5 requests for the mobilisation of the Globalisation Adjustment Fund. Mr President, I would like to make it very important that we get the commission to Esteban González Pons, in particular, concerns the reintegration into the labour market of workers made redundant by three companies operating in Nace Rev. 2 Division 16 (Wood and wood and cork products industry, excluding furniture; manufacture of straw and weaving materials) in the Castilla y León region. These are concrete signals that the European Parliament is sending to workers and companies in difficulty, because of the economic crisis.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report as it allows the mobilisation of the 587 redundancies, with 400 workers who are expected to participate in the measures, in three companies that manufacture wood and wood and cork products in the NUTS II region of Castilla y León (ES41), in Spain, during the reference period from 28 December 2012 to 28 September 2013. This mobilisation of funds is due to the disastrous consequences of the internationalisation of productive sectors in the EU.  These funds are not able to solve the problems of these unemployed, but at least give the possibility of alleviating a small part of human drama. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: in writing. - We announce the vote in favour of the proposal for a Resolution for the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (FEAG), in relation to the proposed application for the carpentry and furniture sector of Castilla y León. Since 2008, this sector has lost 40% of its exports, almost three times more than the average European decline. This snout in sales has had dire consequences on production, which has led to layoffs and closures of factories in a region which, due to its low population density and low weight of the industrial sector, suffers in a special way from the problem of industrial unemployment. Measures for job reintegration, vocational guidance and employment-intensive support are not only welcome but are essential to alleviate the crisis situation in the region in recent years.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: in writing. - On 22 July 2014, the Commission adopted a proposal for a decision on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in favour of Spain to support the reintegration into the labour market of dismissed workers in three companies operating in division 16 of NACE (Wood and Cork Industry, except Furniture; Manufacture of Basketry and Spartan Goods) in the Castilla y León region , following significant structural changes in the patterns of world trade as a result of globalization. This is an aid of EUR 700 000 for reception and information sessions, professional guidance and advice, aid to the intensive search for employment, training, promotion of entrepreneurship and incentives. I greet my colleague Esteban González Pons for this report which I voted in favour of.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. - Due to major structural changes in global trade flows occurring as a result of increasing globalisation, I supported the Report on the Mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to help the Castilla y Leon region on the application submitted by Spain.  The European Globalisation Fund was created to provide additional support to workers affected by the effects of structural changes due to globalisation. This Report allocates 700,000 euros to help redundate workers, which will enable faster reintegration of workers through consultations, education and incentives for entrepreneurial ventures.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this report because I believe it is an appropriate use of the Global Adjustment fund and will help the workers of that region re-integrate into the labour market.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. - The Globalization Assistance Fund fulfils its role well. Instead of helping workers, it encourages shareholders and states to submit to forced liberalism. The application concerns 400 Spanish workers laid off in three companies working in the woodworking business. This is due to the sharp decline in exports of carpentry and structural parts from outside and within the EU. The wood sector is a European asset to be valued. In order to effectively help these workers, solidarity protectionism should be put in place to reduce the share of "exotic" woods that are often illegal in favour of European woods. Nevertheless, I abstain so as not to deprive Spanish workers of this fund.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. - The EU is an area of solidarity and is part of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. This support is essential to help the unemployed and the victims of relocations in a globalised context. There is an increasing number of companies relocating, taking advantage of the low labour prices, which are practised in several countries, notably China and India, with harmful effects on countries that respect workers' rights. The EGF is intended to help workers who are victims of business relocation and is key to facilitating access to new employment. The EGF has already been used in the past by other EU countries, and it is now up to Spain, which has submitted the EGF/2013/010 ES/Castilla y León application to a financial contribution from the EGF, following the dismissal of 587 workers in three companies in the timber and cork industry and their works (4) in the NUTS II (ES41) region of Castile and León in Spain during the reference period from 28 December 2012 to 28 September 2013, with 400 workers made redundant participating in the measures.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. – The European Union has set up legislative and budgetary instruments in order to provide additional support to workers who have been affected by the consequences of major structural shifts in world trade patterns and to assist the re-integration of the same workers back into the labour market. This report confirms that the proposed financial contribution will cater for 400 workers who have been made redundant in the region of Castilla y León. I therefore voted in favour of this report which will give additional opportunities for the workers and families affected by these redundancies.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. I am pleased that the European Parliament has decided to provide financial support to Spain through the European Adjustment Fund. It would be inconceivable if the European Union did not have an instrument to help the poorest when they are victims of globalisation.  The crisis has hit Spain hard and many Spanish workers have suffered unfair dismissals, caused by a decline in consumption as well as by major changes in the structure of international trade. It was therefore essential that the Globalization Adjustment Fund help these workers. Since its accession to the Union, Spain has been a real part of the European project. The difficulties of the crisis must not be forgotten, but we must move forward in order to offer the Spanish people the future they deserve. In any case, it is positive to see that the Union does not forget this.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. – I fully support this report because the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund provides support to people losing their jobs as a result of major structural changes or a result of the global economic and financial crisis.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. - I voted in favour of this issue to allow the release of financial aid of 700,000 euros which will benefit 587 laid-off workers from three timber companies in the Castilla y Leon region of Spain. The closure of the wood industry plants in Europe is a huge waste. Europe's forests form one of the world's leading wood reservoirs. Too often, this timber is exported to countries with low labour costs to be re-imported into Europe with processed products.  Here too, priority must be given to the competitiveness of our companies to protect and develop employment.

name: Elisabeth MORIN-CHARTIER
text: In writing. - Today, the European Parliament adopted six reports of mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. I have spoken in favour of each of these reports. The aim of this fund is to enable employees who have been made redundant to have personalised training so that they can retrain professionally. On this issue, the European Parliament has agreed to release EUR 7,000,000 from this Fund to 400 beneficiaries in Spain.  In these difficult times, the mobilization of this Fund is essential. It is imperative that personalised training be provided to those made redundant so that they can return to the job market as soon as possible. The European Parliament once again shows its commitment to one of the founding values of the European Union: solidarity.

name: Dan NICA
text: in writing. - I voted for the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund: the request of EGF/2013/010 ES/Castilla y Léon - Spain. Spain applied for the financial contribution from the EGF following the dismissal of 587 workers from three companies in the wood processing and cork manufacturing sector in the Castilla y León region. For the reference period December 2012 to September 2013, 400 of the workers made redundant are to participate in the measures envisaged. The redundancies that took place in the three companies are linked to the occurrence of major changes in international trade practices generated by globalisation, as the volume of exports from the EU 27 timber products for carpentry and carpentry in construction work decreased by 10.33% between 2008 and 2011. In Spain, the decline over the same period was even stronger, with the number of enterprises reduced by 28.8%. It is estimated that a limited number of participants could receive up to EUR 5 200 under the measure to promote entrepreneurship. We welcome the fact that, in order to provide rapid assistance to workers, the Spanish authorities decided to start providing personalised services to affected workers in February 2014, well before the final decision to provide support from the EGF.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the European Parliament's resolution on the globalisation adjustment fund for workers made redundant in the wood and cork manufacturing sector in Castile because there have been major changes in the structure of this sector in international trade. A fortiori, this activity was one of the largest sources of employment in the region. Aid funds should therefore be provided to alleviate the vagaries of globalization and to promote job creation.

name: Teresa RODRIGUEZ-RUBIO
text: in writing. - EGF is a tool that seeks the relocation of laid-off workers in sectors particularly hit by "globalization". To this end, it allocates most of the funds to training, mentoring, accompaniment and development of "personal skills", while only a small portion of them goes directly into the pocket of the workers and only if they follow obediently the proposed itinerary or in the unlikely event that they get a job as a result of the program. The positive vote is explained by the recognition that any aid directed at those individuals and families who are suffering is welcome. Under no circumstances does it imply acceptance of the paternalistic and unfair logic underlying the design of this fund. People who have lost their jobs have not lost it because of lack of training and certainly do not need "incentives" to learn computer science or seek employment. They have lost it because the economy and the productive fabric have been severely undermined by powers that never consulted them and seek only the private benefit of a tiny minority.
