name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report as it allows the mobilisation of the 587 redundancies, with 400 workers who are expected to participate in the measures, in three companies that manufacture wood and wood and cork products in the NUTS II region of Castilla y León (ES41), in Spain, during the reference period from 28 December 2012 to 28 September 2013. This mobilisation of funds is due to the disastrous consequences of the internationalisation of productive sectors in the EU.  These funds are not able to solve the problems of these unemployed, but at least give the possibility of alleviating a small part of human drama. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. - I support a resolution authorising the mobilisation of funds to help redundast workers in Spain, a country with a high unemployment rate. Redundancies at three NUTS II Castilla y Leon companies operating in the wood and wood and cork processing sectors are thought to be linked to changes caused by globalisation. The redundancy of this size has significantly affected the overall labour market in the region, and given the rare population of the region and its dependence on the wood industry, the impact is even greater than only the number of 587 workers laid off.  With the resolution, Parliament reiterates, in addition to direct financial assistance, the importance of improving employment opportunities through tailor-made training programmes and recognising the competences and knowledge gained in working life. It also calls on all institutions to further involve and further accelerate the possibility of mobilising funds to help those affected and to achieve greater efficiency, transparency and visibility of the EGF, as there are unfortunately such and similar cases in many Member States. It is emphasised, however, that EGF assistance measures do not serve short-term objectives, but are only used to finance active labour market measures leading to permanent, long-term employment.

name: Kay SWINBURNE
text: in writing. – I voted against this report today, I am opposed in principle to the use of this European Globalisation Adjustment Fund and as a result I cannot support this proposal to mobilise it.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. - I am voting against because I disagree with the return of money except in cases where new jobs are created.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. - On 22 July 2014, the Commission adopted a proposal for a decision on the mobilization of the EGF in favour of Spain in order to support the reintegration into the labour market of laid-off workers in three companies located in the NUTS 2 region of Castile and Leon, due to major changes in the structure of international trade resulting from globalisation. Ninth considered in the 2014 budget, this request is aimed at mobilising a total of EUR 700,000 from the EGF for Spain. It concerns 587 redundancies in three companies. So we decided to accede to that request.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report as it allows the mobilisation of the 587 redundancies, with 400 workers who are expected to participate in the measures, in three companies that manufacture wood and wood and cork products in the NUTS II region of Castilla y León (ES41), in Spain, during the reference period from 28 December 2012 to 28 September 2013. This mobilisation of funds is due to the disastrous consequences of the internationalisation of productive sectors in the EU.  These funds are not able to solve the problems of these unemployed, but at least give the possibility of alleviating a small part of human drama. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. - 587 workers were recently laid off in three companies in the wood and cork industry in the Castilla y Léon region of Spain, triggering the unemployment rate from 8.2 % to 22.70 %. The changes in the structure of world trade resulting from globalization are pointed out as responsible for throwing these workers and their families into the world of uncertainty.  We are approving palliatives which, if necessary, are not the solution, but another direction is needed for Europe, a course that has social justice and the well-being of peoples at the heart of its policies. For this, peoples must continue to transform hopelessness and discouragement into a river of wills, capable of building a more just and fraternal world, where people and not money prevail.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. - The application under consideration stems from the dismissal of 587 workers in three companies in the wood and cork industry in the Region of Castile and León in Spain. This redundancy severely affected the labour market in that region, with the unemployment rate rising from 8.2 % to 22.70 %. Once again, the changes in the structure of world trade resulting from globalization are pointed out as responsible for throwing these workers and their families into the world of uncertainty.  We are approving palliatives which, if necessary, are not the solution. There is a need for another direction for Europe, a course that has social justice and the well-being of peoples at the heart of its policies and the right to work with rights to decent wages and pensions, among other rights won by workers for more than a century. For this, peoples must continue to transform hopelessness and discouragement into a river of wills, capable of building a more just and fraternal world, where people prevail and not profit.

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: Ladies and gentlemen! I ask for a small moment of attention. As you know, in the plenary session of 16 July, Mr Korwin-Mikke made statements which are incompatible with the Rules of Procedure of the European Parliament. These were racist remarks. I have checked the minutes of this sitting and have asked Mr Korwin-Mikke for his opinion on what he has said. I have asked him to correct what has been said or to apologise. He refused to do so in a personal interview with me on 9 September. He insists on his point of view. Members of the European Parliament are particularly obliged to refrain from making racist or discriminatory statements of a racist or discriminatory nature, which are discriminatory or infringing human dignity. Under Rule 166 of the Rules of Procedure, I have therefore decided to impose a penalty of ten days on Mr Korwin-Mikke, which I am depifiing him. (Applause) The honourable Member may appeal against this decision within fourteen days of this announcement. I will then have to decide on the contradiction.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: The sitting is resumed. The Minutes of yesterday's sitting and the texts adopted have been distributed. Are there any comments?

name: Bruno GOLLNISCH
text: Mr President, my speech will focus on item 6 of this report, namely the conditions under which we have been led to ratify the relations with Ukraine. I believe, as the record partially indicates, that there has been an unheard-of fact, which is the intervention of a foreign politician, a foreign parliament, in a very direct way. This is a considerable pressure which has been exerted on this House and I believe that this has tainted the consent that Parliament has given to the adoption of these reports.  That is why I would ask you to put this record to a vote to find out whether a number of my colleagues, as appeared to be the case, shares this opinion or not and rejects the adoption of the minutes in these circumstances in view of the defects that have marred the procedure.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: We will take your comments into account. Thank you so much.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: Mr President, to complete what mr Gollnisch said, there has been interference by a foreign force in Parliament's deliberation. In other words, there was a desire to influence the vote of European parliamentarians in the context of the economic agreement with Ukraine. Therefore, we dispute the veracity of the vote and ask that the minutes be put to a vote today as to whether we do accept this foreign interference.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Members, there has been no external intervention. I have listened to your speeches, and I ask you to listen to what I am saying. No one has forced members to vote in any way. The result showed that there were Members who were in favour - the majority - and Members who were against - a minority. It's democracy. No one could influence. I think that MEPs are free and have no problem listening to other people. It is not another parliament that can influence the freedom of all MEPs.

name: Anna FOTYGA
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking Before the members of the European Parliament voted in plenary, the Association Agreement was voted on during the meeting of the European Parliament's Committee on Foreign Affairs and was decided by an overwhelming majority. There was no communication with other parliaments at the time, so it was the decision of the committee in committee.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: Mr President, in order to complete what The Lady has just said, what we are denouncing is this live connection which has not been put to a vote. That is to say, there was a fait accompli, we were forced to have the presence of the Ukrainian Parliament during a deliberation of the European Parliament. This connection should have been subject to acceptance beforehand.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Mr. Member, I do not think there has been a breach of the rules of Parliament. What happened was a decision that will strengthen the ties between the two parliaments and I think that the vote of the Parliament of Ukraine did not impose anything on MEPs.

name: James CARVER
text: Mr President, I am a member of the Committee on Foreign Affairs – my colleague over there spoke about the Foreign Affairs Committee – and the meeting was called extremely quickly. As I pointed out in my speech yesterday in the Chamber, the Committee on International Trade did not even have the opportunity to come back with a proper economic argument with regard to the trade implications of this treaty. It may well be that parliamentary procedure was followed correctly yesterday – I would say it possibly was not – but it certainly was not as far as the committee stage was concerned, and that is what really arouses my concern. If this truly is a democratic institution I would think that the powers that be here should go away and learn seriously from this flawed message. But then again, you carry on doing as you wish anyway, do you not?

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: I think this was a free vote yesterday and I think it is impossible to change our decision today. I understand that you take a different position but it is impossible to change the European Parliament decision. Alors, on peut voter le procès-verbal. Quelle est votre proposition, Monsieur, s'il vous plaît?

name: Bruno GOLLNISCH
text: Mr. President, at your discretion. Voting by show of hands if the vote is guaranteed, or by roll call.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Yes, I understood that. But I was just asking if you want to change a few words in the minutes.

name: Bruno GOLLNISCH
text: Mr President, I would like to see a vote on the minutes on whether we adopt it or if we do not adopt it, given that there is an extremely worrying precedent, which could put us in communication with the parliaments of potential partners in each association agreement, which is obviously a psychological pressure on our Parliament.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: J'ai bien compris. Alors qui est contre la proposition de M. Gollnisch? Well, then I shall put to the vote: who is in favour of approving the Minutes?

name: Anna FOTYGA
text: Mr President, it is an extremely important moment normally when it comes to adopting international and even multilateral agreements. Minutes are very important proof. When they are voted on in an almost empty Chamber, this may be seen as an additional point for getting rid of this agreement later. Contrary to what my colleague said, I think that this procedure may spoil our legislative procedure.

name: António MARINHO E PINTO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, yesterday there was a vote here which was the expression of a substantive will of this Parliament. I voted against signing that trade treaty with Ukraine, but I was not coerced by anyone and no Member who voted against or for obviously not felt coerced. The political act embodied in this vote is irreversible. The vote on the minutes is a mere formal and administrative act which can be refused only if the minutes do not contain the elements or does not accurately report what happened here. We are trying to mix two totally different things: the substantive political act, which was the vote with the result it had, and the adoption of the minutes, which reflects that act. I think there's been a dangerous mess right now.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: The result of the vote is out of the question, and that is very clear. It is only the drafting of the text that was called into question, not the substantive content. There were some formal aspects that could have been added, but the result of the vote is not in question, the result of the vote cannot be changed, so the one that was approved yesterday remains approved. This is very clear, it is only a question of content, possibly to be added in the Minutes, but it has nothing to do with the result of the vote and the legitimacy of the vote.  The connection with the Parliament in Kiev, which has not affected parliament's freedom, was perfectly legitimate, and no Member of the European Parliament, I believe, can feel influenced by anyone but their conscience. This is clear and incontrovertible, so it absolutely does not change what has been said. However, we are making further legal findings. I will postpone this point until later and proceed with the debate because we must also respect the other institutions, so we will also give clarification at a technical level. J'ai dit que nous allions reporter ce point, parce que nous allons procéder à des contrôles. Nous poursuivons. Le résultat du vote d'hier est clair. Il faut aller de l'avant. Let us move on to the next point.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: The next item is the debate on the Council and Commission statements on the EU response to the Ebola virus epidemic (2014/2842(SDR)).

name: Benedetto DELLA VEDOVA
text: Mr President- in-Office of the Council. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, the recent Ebola epidemic in West Africa is the most important of its kind. This is a public health emergency which is causing considerable international concern.  The Ebola epidemic is having an unprecedented impact on public and humanitarian health on the affected countries and the region as a whole. The Council is gravely concerned about the consequences for the socio-economic and security situation of the West African countries affected. At the same time, we would point out that, according to the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control, the risk of being infected with the Ebola virus for EU residents and those travelling to the affected countries is low, provided that the recommended precautions are taken.  The European Union has taken a leading role within the international community in responding to the epidemic. At their meeting on 15 August, the Foreign Ministers called for careful follow-up and a coordinated international response.  The extraordinary European Council of 30 August 2014 also stressed the importance of providing coordinated international support as quickly and effectively as possible. It called for greater coordination at EU level and called on the Council to adopt a comprehensive EU response framework to address the situation. What have been our follow-up measures in this case? As far as humanitarian aid is concerned, the European Union and its Member States have reacted to the Ebola crisis from the outset. This includes financial support for health and humanitarian actors and UN organisations. We pay tribute to the extraordinary commitment of these operators on the ground, a commitment that some of them have paid with their lives. In close coordination with the Commission, Member States have regularly carried out joint analyses and assessments of the need for humanitarian assistance. The civil protection mechanism was activated at the request of the WHO and the United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs. The emergency response coordination centre, which is operational seven days a week and round the clock, helps coordinate assistance.  Since the crisis escalated, Member States have stepped up their support and expressed their willingness to provide further assistance and mobilise experts and medical staff. Let me give you a few brief examples. The UK has started to set up a treatment centre near Freetown in Sierra Leone, the first phase of which is expected to be operational within eight weeks. Austria and France have offered assistance in kind in the form of medical equipment. Germany has welcomed a WHO staff member who contracted the virus. Italy has supported the World Health Organisation since the onset of the crisis, making an initial contribution of EUR 200 000 to WHO activities in Guinea in April. A further EUR 240 000 has recently been allocated. In addition, we have just approved an intervention totalling EUR 1.2 million for the prevention and treatment of the virus. The Council is currently working on a framework for the European Union's global response to the crisis. This framework will also include the coordination of air transport, which is currently a critical shortcoming and restricts access for medical and humanitarian personnel and resources. The Presidency is well aware of the need for more to be done. The EU must help rebuild health systems that collapsed as a result of the Ebola crisis. If we do not do so, there is a real risk that the humanitarian crisis caused by the Ebola epidemic will spread to other countries on the African continent. The Presidency, in cooperation with the Commission and the EEAS, will help coordinate the European Union's collective response in partnership with the WHO and the UN.  On the public health front, the EU response framework is active, sufficient to protect human health in the Union. EU Member States have national preparedness plans to respond to possible health threats. At European level, Member States, in cooperation with the Commission, coordinate their responses to serious cross-border health threats in the Health Safety Committee. A network of competent national authorities, the Commission and the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control, managed and coordinated by ECDC, are responsible for epidemiological surveillance of communicable diseases and related special health problems.  A high-level meeting was held in Brussels on 15 September to coordinate the further stages of the EU's response to the Ebola epidemic in West Africa. In addition to the relevant Commissioners and several Ministers for Health and Development of the Member States, the meeting was attended by the high-level coordinator of the UN System for the Response to Ebola Virus Disease as well as representatives of the World Health Organisation and the NGO Médecins sans Frontières. The meeting paved the way for greater coordination of the international effort needed to combat the epidemic. Eu ropean Union health ministers will discuss the issue at the informal ministerial meeting in Milan on 22 and 23 September, in particular with regard to the following actions: medium and long-term follow-up measures; information to travellers and citizens; the health eviction; the need to share resources in complex emergency situations; interventions to improve the availability of Ebola treatments and vaccines; the need for further support for the affected countries, the WHO and non-governmental organisations active in this area and the need for the EU to support the strengthening of global leadership and operational coordination of the WHO and the UN in crisis response. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, I thought it important to take a long time to give you an account of the commitment of the Presidency and the Council to coordinate the EU's efforts to help the affected countries and international organisations in the fight against this serious epidemic.

name: Kristalina Georgieva
text: Member of the Commission. - Mr President, we have heard a very comprehensive presentation from the Council. I would like to contribute to the discussion by elaborating further on three points: first, the character of this epidemic; second, what we are doing at the Commission to advance a coordinated response; and finally a few words about the approach we are taking to protect our own population, the citizens of Europe. On the epidemic itself: it is unprecedented in two ways. Firstly, this is a pandemic which is taking place in countries that had very weak health systems to begin with. In the past, if pandemics occurred they were mostly in middle-income or high-income countries where the health systems could be mobilised to respond. This is not the case now. Secondly, at no time before has an Ebola epidemic lasted so long, and it is not yet contained. So we are in a very unusual and very dramatic situation. As was mentioned, the UN Senior Coordinator for the fight against Ebola, Dr David Nabarro, who is extremely competent, told us that not only do we have 4 963 cases and 2 453 deaths today (that is actually as of yesterday) but that the most important and troubling fact is that figures for the number of cases are nearly doubling every three weeks.  If we do not act decisively now, there are three major risks stemming from this. One is that in the three countries which are the most affected, Guinea, Liberia and Sierra Leone, the spread would be such that containing it would become extremely difficult. It is already difficult but it would be extremely difficult. Secondly, we may not be able to protect other countries in the region from the spread of the epidemic. The worry then, of course, is that it may go further. And the third and most dangerous risk, I believe, is that the longer we fail to get on top of the epidemic the greater is the risk that the virus may mutate. What its impact would then be is hard to predict but it could be quite dramatic. We are not talking anymore just about a health emergency in the three countries; we are talking about an impact on their economies and their societies that is quite dramatic. Growth rates have dropped significantly. We are worried about the political and security implications, and let us remember that these are countries that experienced civil wars in the 1990s and 2000s. They have just emerged from this, rebuilding their societies, and now they are being tremendously badly hit. We talk about fighting Ebola on the front lines but this is not your usual humanitarian emergency where we can mobilise humanitarian staff, send them into the field and then they deal with the problem. This epidemic requires highly competent professionals in the health field who know how to deal with it. We are very constrained in terms of personnel, equipment and transport.  Going on to my second point: what are we in Europe doing in terms of being on the front line in fighting Ebola? Of course we are mobilising money. I am proud to say that the Commission, with EUR 150 million, is leading in the financial response to this crisis. We have just received a figure from the United Nations revised upwards: close to a billion dollars is now necessary, but we are putting our funding together and we will do more. On Monday our Member States had pledged up to EUR 78 million. Many of them, however, are working on raising their financial contributions so we can be more and more effective. Much more important than money is mobilising assistance in kind and deploying teams. We have laboratories in the affected countries and, as we have heard, our Member States are providing new hospitals and new treatment centres to provide beds. But let me tell you what the reaction of Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) was to our numbers, which are in the high hundreds. They said high hundreds is good, but what we need is in the thousands if we want to stop the epidemic, because they are still sending people who are coming to treatment centres back to their communities, with all the risks that this creates.  We are very focused on the critical issue of medical evacuation. For many health workers, one concern about going to the affected countries is ‘What would I do if I am impacted, would there be any help?’ We are working in Europe to create a medical evacuation capacity so that that concern, and the health of medical workers, are addressed.  Last but not least, we understand how critical it is to invest in research, in vaccines and in treatment, and also to build a wall against any future Ebola outbreaks. There was a discussion here in Parliament on this topic with Tonio Borg in early September in the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety.  The third point is: what do we do about the safety of our own citizens? Here we have received the message very loud and clear, and I want to split this into two points. One, we are saying let us stop the virus, isolate it and fight it back, but let us not isolate the countries. I want to pay tribute to Brussels Airlines and to Air France, European companies that continue to fly back and forth to the region – absolutely essential. Secondly, we have taken measures collectively to make sure that this is not going to bring the virus into Europe. I can stand here in front of you and say we are doing this. A huge amount of work is going on at the moment to make sure that our laboratory system is ready to carry out testing in all Member States and that those with fewer capabilities can count on the support of others; that we have suitable treatment facilities; that we coordinate our preventive measures; and also that we communicate with one voice so that we do not confuse people. I want to end by saying that I was very encouraged at the meeting on Monday to see Europe coming together as one. I heard a Member State that would not normally say such a thing asking ‘please, coordinate usʼ. We want to act together and together we will act.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: on behalf of the PPE Club. – Mr. President, as we have heard from the Commissioner, the virus is spreading at a truly exponential rate, and at such a rate, according to world health organization data, we could have as many as 20,000 cases by the end of the year. So colleagues and colleagues, today we need a serious and responsible discussion, of course we do not need any sensationalism or unnecessary intimidation of our citizens. But we must say, loud and clear, that the international community underestimated the danger of the Ebola epidemic. We need to make it clear from here that the Ebola crisis is not only a West African problem, it is a global threat and it is looking for a decisive response from the European Union.  I welcome the efforts of a Member State and what the European Commission has done with around €150 million, these are good moves, but it is clear that this is not enough. Partner organizations in the field point out to us the fact that besides money we need most organizational capacities to isolate and treat patients. All this includes, and what you commissioners have said, hence human resources and logistical material and technological capacities, health equipment. In West Africa we have a really big shortage of qualified staff, adequate training for healthcare professionals and what may be badly needed, we don't have wider information for the local population. That is why we are also calling on the European Commission to continue its stepped-up efforts.  We also heard that we will have a meeting of health ministers in Milan. We also ask them for an urgent plan of action by the Member States coordinated by the European Commission, of course under the auspices of the work of the United Nations. The European Union must show leadership in this matter, we are not only indebted to this for the solidarity towards West Africa, but also for our own security, for the safety of our citizens. There is no time, a decisive response from the European Union is needed immediately.

name: Linda McAVAN
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, I would like to thank the Commission and the Council for coming here today and telling us about the steps being taken this week. It is a critical week now for tackling this problem. Mr Stier mentioned the World Health Organisation figures of 20 000 dying before the end of the year. But that is if we do something. They are saying it will be much higher if we do not do something. So we really have to step up our act. There was the meeting on Monday; I very much welcome what happened on Monday in Brussels and the announcement by the US President that the United States is going to take part in this global effort to combat Ebola. But I think we need to reflect: we need short-term measures. We have to get the emergency under control but, once that is done, we need to reflect on the long term. It is pretty clear that we have all been slow off the mark, and we need to be asking ourselves: why is it that this epidemic is far more serious than ever before? Why have more people died in this epidemic than have died since the disease was first identified about forty years ago? Why is it that vaccines and treatments have been looked at for many years but we have not had the results we need? How do we make sure that this time we do the research and continue it when the headlines disappear, when hopefully we get the disease under control? A trial started today in the United Kingdom, and we hope that clinical trial will lead to a vaccine. Finally, I want to pay tribute, as the Council did, to the health workers and professionals on the ground from our Member States in particular who are going in, but also health workers from across Africa and across the globe. They are very brave people; they have gone in under very difficult conditions. As the Commissioner said, we need to strengthen the health systems in those countries and, if we make that commitment to strengthen them, it is a good investment for European citizens, because ultimately it will protect us at home as well. So the short term is under control, but we need long-term reflection.

name: Nirj DEVA
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, I am very encouraged by what Commissioner Georgieva has said about what we are doing. We also have to start an educational programme, as I understand that this virus is spread through bushmeat and other consumption of contaminated meat. I think we need to do that: we need to contain the problem and get the European and African Unions involved in that containment programme. We need to get the bigger states, which can help the fragile states in Africa, to become engaged. It is their problem, but it is our problem too. I would like to say a great thank you to all the health workers who have been putting their lives at risk to save other lives. They are sometimes forgotten. I also want to ask the Commissioner if there is a vaccine or if there is something going on in the United States. Should we not accelerate the process and not test it to death – so to speak – until it is not a crisis anymore?

name: Charles GOERENS
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. Mr President, the international community's underestimation of the crisis and the lack of a well-coordinated strategy explain the more than worrying spread of the virus. Are we up to the challenge? The answer, alas, is no until we can contain the pandemic. The number of Ebola infections doubles every three weeks. The longer the response is, the more difficult it will become to stop proliferation. In the case of Ebola, you have to be faster than the virus. What do we need? Vigilance, of course. It is important, in the immediate future, to ensure a capacity of some 2,000 beds to receive the necessary care but also to prevent further contamination outside isolated areas. Not the day after tomorrow, not tomorrow, but now, right now.  This is a serious time. We need resolute action. The great humanitarians have indicated all that needs to be done. If any of them appeal to the international community to mobilize all means, including military ones, and deploy them under the leadership of the United Nations, that is to say that the time is no longer for academic discussion. We have to do something.  It is by creating treatment centres that we can provide care to those who are infected. Treatment capacity is insufficient and very often non-existent. Too often, patients are turned away at the door of saturated centres and have no choice but to return home at the risk of contaminating others.  In Liberia, the situation is changing in a particularly dramatic way. Indeed, in this country, the health system is, so to speak, down. If the international community's response to the current tragedy before our eyes were to prove insufficient, other health facilities in the region could also collapse. We should also note the disastrous impact of the current crisis on economic activity. In many companies, the production tool is at a standstill. This makes the countries concerned even more dependent on foreign aid.  A final word to pay tribute to the teams of doctors, nurses and all those who are concerned about helping to save human beings at the risk of their own lives.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, we do not know how many dead Ebola has already left. West Africa's health systems are very weak and now completely collapsed, with a ratio of two doctors per hundred thousand people to deal with an unprecedented epidemic, as the Commissioner has rightly said. And the European Union and its states can think of nothing but to cut the development aid budget. My country, Spain, for example, has cut it by 74% since 2011. Development aid is not charity, gentlemen, it is justice. And European countries have a huge debt to African countries. And I'm not going to talk about the resources we continue to commit on that continent. But it seems that the people of the South are not a priority even in situations of extreme need. We need to make it a global threat for us to get going. But moreover, this Europe, which is a champion in the defence of human rights, does not prioritize the real needs of this situation. Doctors, technicians, laboratories, isolation units, training of the population and overflowing health bodies are lacking. They don't need military support. Let us follow the example of Cuba, which will command one hundred and sixty-five highly specialized doctors, and not that of the United States, who propose to send three thousand soldiers on the excuse of supporting the development of a health structure. More soldiers than toilets. Many conflicts are already suffering from these people to further militarize the region. A European plan is needed to mobilisation the resources needed to provide effective health aid now. We can't wait any longer.

name: Michèle RIVASI
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Mr President, I would like to go back a little bit to the question of how we have managed and mismanaged this epidemic. It started on 22 March in Guinea and quickly spread to Sierra Leone, Liberia, now Senegal and Nigeria. As you said, there are more than four thousand nine hundred people, but that is an assessment because we do not really know how many people are infected, and more than two thousand four hundred dead. The international community has not reacted quickly enough, even WHO. They thought, we're going to do what we used to do, we're going to be able to contain the epidemic. And then it went at a high speed V and we realized that the countries could not respond, we are in a state of war. When we see the situation in Liberia, even the Prime Minister says "my country is going to collapse", there is no health system, there is no business and even there is a food crisis that threatens.   I was quite pleased when I saw that the Commission said that it was releasing EUR 150 million, but that is not enough! There has been a lack of international coordination and we would have liked the United Nations, through OCHA for humanitarian crises, to address this problem, because we need real coordination.  When I heard President Obama say, "We are going to put three thousand military personnel in," and I would like to respond to my colleague, it is not three thousand military personnel, three thousand people are going to set up hospitals to meet the demand. And that's a good thing. But beware, this will not be enough, the Commission must say 'we too will put hospitals, we too will put staff'. I have my children who are at MSF there and the situation is catastrophic. I have heard Commissioner Borg say that the risk is low in Europe. But he didn't understand anything! If this virus ever mutates, it could be a global epidemic. So you really have to be aware of the magnitude of the problem. Last thing: it is very good to say we need repatriation, we need planes, but do you know that at the moment there is no plane that is capable of repatriating a volunteer and in particular all these humanitarians working there?

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the Ebola epidemic in North Africa is having a very strong health impact and a very high cost in terms of human lives. There are more than two thousand five hundred deaths and about five thousand infected, but in the African countries most affected by the virus, attention and concrete action have not so far been adequately concentrated. The Western world, easily suggestive, has been enormously alarmed and rightly mobilised whenever the contagion of a Westerner has occurred, but the same emotions, the same pathos, the same apprehension have not manifested themselves in the face of the hundreds of victims in Africa, which generally returns to interest when it comes to going to exploit resources.  I've often heard of blending. What better opportunity than an emergency such as the one caused by the Ebola virus to actively begin to make those multinationals that make huge profits from the resources of the countries most affected actively? Ebola is not only a health and humanitarian emergency, it is not only death and fear of contagion, it is also a social and political problem and it generates a disastrous economic effect. The FAO recently announced the huge risk to crops in West Africa. The secondary effects of this crisis are becoming increasingly apparent. Food insecurity is worsening the already fragile economies of these countries, which are now facing the rapid collapse of exports.  The challenges for Europe are immense. Local institutions are very weak, public health systems ineffective, inconsistent, even in some cases non-existent. There is a lack of basic infrastructure, roads and facilities to deal with the emergency. There is a distorted view of the disease by local communities for the very low level of literacy that favors the spread of the virus. There are endless ethnic, political and religious divisions that bloodied the territories and make only merchants smile at death. My question, ladies and gentlemen, is this: is Europe ready to take up this enormous challenge, and if so, how?

name: Matteo SALVINI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we are talking about thousands of deaths, and here too Europe is waking up as a good last, and with a half-empty Chamber. We are talking about a virus that has an incubation time of two to twenty-one days and we are talking about a time when, with a demented operation called Mare Nostrum, thousands of people land daily in Italy even from countries where the virus is killing – I am thinking of Nigeria, I am thinking of Senegal and I am thinking of Liberia. Therefore, over and above the fact that, of course, the more you spend, the sooner you intervene in those countries, the better for everyone, especially for them, who have no place in italian and European news. However, I wonder and ask you: if some countries in the world such as South Korea or Saudi Arabia are even thinking of closing their borders to immigrants from areas at risk of contagion, what are we doing other than going to save those lives there, which is right and for which we are already behind schedule, to avoid problems here?  And I wonder and wonder whether Europe can still turn a blind ear to the landing of thousands of people who, over and above the Ebola virus, can, indeed are carriers – these are data from Italian hospitals – of tuberculosis and scabies, but which do not stop in Italy, I say this to our European colleagues who care. The problem is not just Italian, the problem is European, so I ask you whether it makes sense to continue to pick up these people in the middle of the sea without any kind of control, guarantee or even if the money we are banging away for Mare Nostrum would not be better spent in Africa, in North Africa to prevent these people from traveling to death and to prevent us and our children from any possible infection.

name: Bogdan Brunon WENTA
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking West Africa is the largest Ebola outbreak. By September 7, about 4,500 cases of infection had been reported, including 2,300 deaths. Many organizations have provided financial and medical support to prevent the spread of the epidemic. Also, 160 medical personnel lost their lives in the fight against this epidemic. Ebola control is hampered by outbreaks of infection in various countries, insufficient precautions, dangerous cultural and funeral habits, lack of knowledge, diagnosis and handling of the disease.  The Director-General of the World Health Organization has announced that the epidemic is international in scope. Let us note that this epidemic can affect us all. It is the specific responsibility and responsibility of the European Union to support the African side and strengthen humanitarian aid and to monitor and plan actions to prevent further epidemics. The European Parliament resolution is very important. I support the transfer of an additional EUR 140 million from the European Union and the Member States.  Between 2000 and 2003, Ebola outbreaks with an 85% mortality rate occurred in Central Africa, but the further development of the epidemic was finally managed. This indicates that only coordinated action by the European Commission, the UN and the African side is crucial in the fight against the epidemic.

name: Enrique GUERRERO SALOM
text: Mr President, the African continent is typically and topically rated as the 'continent of pain' but, in this case, the topic corresponds to reality. The combination of famine and genocide has ended the lives of millions of people on that continent. Poverty, lack of access to water, remote education and child mortality affect hundreds of thousands of people. On that continent, on the other hand, there is armed violence, there is terrorism, there are civil conflicts everywhere. A continent that a few decades ago abandoned the situation of colonialism, but is now being colonized in its resources and structures. On that continent, the Ebola crisis has now broken out. The Ebola crisis, which, as Commissioner Georgieva pointed out, has three characteristics: exponential growth of those affected; a very high death toll of around 60%; and, on the other hand, also the lack of health structures with which these countries can deal with the problem. And that is our challenge: to offer, of course, structures; provide sanitary equipment; and allow humanitarian access. I therefore believe that it is time for us to support the Milan Council, to support the United Nations meeting and to finally support, on 24 September, the donors' decision on this matter. One last word: the sooner European countries ratify the eleventh European Development Fund, the more funds we will have to respond structurally to this problem.

name: Vicky FORD
text: Mr President, earlier this year I led Parliament’s work on the European and Developing Countries’ Clinical Trials Partnership, which budgets more than EUR 600 million over seven years towards finding new cures and treatments for infectious diseases – diseases which, unless tackled at their source, pose an extreme risk to European citizens. I understand that the Commission is looking to fast-track some of this money into researching anti-viral drugs and vaccines for Ebola, and I hope that colleagues will support this. No one can find cures to Ebola by themselves but this programme enables African partners to work with our own national researchers, both charitably funded researchers and private companies like Glaxo-Smith-Kline which, I understand, may have the most advanced potential vaccine for Ebola. Ebola is a real and growing danger. We have researchers, who are experts, who are already out there and in our own countries researching new means of prevention and treatments. This programme has already looked at the ethical and other issues. We have the money in our budgets. Let us put it to good use and get it to the scientists right now. (The speaker agreed to take two blue-card questions under Rule 162(8))

name: James CARVER
text: blue-card question. – Does my colleague share the opinions of her colleague Mr Deva, who raised the issue with regard to the contamination of bushmeat coming into the UK? Could I ask her to take it back to her own party and perhaps ask her to review the situation? It was indeed her government that instigated the merging of Her Majesty’s Customs and Excise into a new border force (which in some quarters is jokingly referred to as a border farce). What we are now seeing is entrance points in some parts of the United Kingdom where the priority seems to be dealing with people at the primary customs points. At the same time resources are being taken away from Customs and Excise and searching people returning from the African continent who, unfortunately in some quarters, do carry bushmeat.

name: Giulia MOI
text: Blue card question. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, my colleague said that these funds must go to researchers.  I would like to ask you whether you have considered whether there is or if a system has been put in place to control how this money would be used by researchers, because in Italy, for example, there is a great deal of corruption on this point too and researchers are often subjugated by university barons and there is an incredible system of nepotism, so that if money goes to Italy in research you have to control it well and demand effectiveness and results.

name: Vicky FORD
text: blue-card answer. – As regards the first question, we have a very clear principle in this Parliament that if you want to ask a question of another Member you ask the Member concerned, so I am afraid I cannot answer the question that you are putting to Mr Deva because, whilst he is an enormously esteemed colleague, I am not him. However, I will answer on the issue of the British role in the research programmes that I am describing. In answer to the second question about Italian researchers, again I cannot speak for Italian researchers. The UK research community is one of the leaders in trying to solve and help find solutions for infectious diseases that unless cured at source are putting increased risks back on our own communities at home, for example drug-resistant TB, which is back in parts of Europe. That is why our researchers put their efforts in; our national governments put their efforts in. In this particular programme funding goes to match fund national governments. Not all countries have decided to commit. It is not only EU-28, but it is a very significant part for the UK, and I think we should support our science and research community and get the money out to where it can make a difference.

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: Mr President, all my colleagues have said this and I will repeat it, we obviously need urgent international mobilization against this terrible scourge with the many consequences that have been described, whether they are health, economic, or obviously social tomorrow.  When we come out of this crisis, we will have to ask ourselves why the extremely slow international response will be. What has been dysfunctional for months that has made us take too long to take this issue head-on? That's the first question. Second, I want to acknowledge President Obama's commitment. I think it is good that there is a strong voice that has come up with this issue. And I know what you are doing, Commissioner, but I regret that there is not a strong voice - I do not know where the President of the Commission or the President of the Italian Council is - who spoke on behalf of the Union, on behalf of Europe in this battle that we must all fight against Ebola. It has not been done and I want it done. Third, we give money and that is fine. But we know very well that it is not just money that is needed on the ground. When you talk to the medical staff , and it happened to me , who are in place on the ground, they are devastated, they can no longer cope, they are not enough. It is concrete help that they need. It is logistical assistance that they need. It's additional medical and health personnel, it's mobile laboratories, it's air transport assistance for themselves. It is all this concrete help for which we Europeans must pool our efforts in order to fight this battle.  Finally, the fourth very important point is that we must not wait for the epidemic to arrive in neighbouring and cross-border countries to deal with it. We must now prevent the risk of epidemics in these countries. I am thinking, in particular, of Côte d'Ivoire or Mali. This is a war that must be won, it is a war that must be waged and for that Europe will have to live up to this challenge.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: Mr President, Sierra Leone, Liberia, Guinea Conakry and other countries are suffering from an Ebola epidemic. But it's not just this that's destroying thousands of lives. Ebola must be added to poverty. They are suffering the consequences of being poor countries, of being impoverished countries. The European Union, the United States, the West, have turned their backs on Ebola outbreaks in Africa for years and only when they have seen that the virus could reach Europe and that our high walls and that our fences at the borders could not stop it, only then have they reacted. Not to save the citizens of these African countries, but to save themselves. And it seems that all lives don't have the same value. Large pharmaceutical companies are not interested in the diseases of the poor. They don't give them benefits. And this voracity of economic elites is as lethal as Ebola. And I think it is important to highlight - and the European Parliament should be congratulated on this - Cuba's announcement to send staff. It is the most massive announcement of aid in the form of staff to fight Ebola: one hundred and sixty-five people, among medical and nursing personnel. Cuba, again, demonstrates its international solidarity.

name: Maria HEUBUCH
text: Mr. President! I would like to get rid of another appeal here. We have now heard a great deal about Ebola, about the impact and also about the needs that we must now send to these states. Because the aid agencies on the ground and the national governments there are completely overwhelmed and are totally overburdened. This is not just an act of solidarity. There is much more at stake here. It is simply our duty to really provide everything we have at our disposal. As Mr Goerens has already mentioned, we also have military equipment, we have military personnel which, under the Oslo guidelines, we can make available here to the United Nations or under the command of the United Nations there. This is personnel who can also work there in a good hierarchy, in a good command structure and who is very well trained. We need to get that now. We must not wait any longer here if we want to put a stop to this and if we do not want to allow this humanitarian disaster to be extended any further or if we want to give it this space in the first place. It is really my appeal to all the Member States of the European Union to take action here now. We can no longer discuss it. We know the effects if we cannot contain Ebola. Eir know that it is much more than a health problem. I do not want to repeat this here. But I would like to get rid of this urgent appeal once again. For we can also show these people on the ground that we are connected not only by our thoughts with them, but also with the deeds and with our really consistent actions.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: Mr President, the seriousness of the Ebola epidemic must finally provoke an indispensable reflection on the pandemic risk in Europe.  The analysis reveals serious European foresight. Health and social foresight in the use of aid to sub-Saharan Africa for fifty years, with colossal financial masses dissolved in corruption and opacity of objectives. Foresight in the training of local caregivers. The result is three months of delay in diagnosing the epidemic. And above all, the consequences of South-North imbalances and large intercontinental migration movements without control. The recent outbreaks of SARS or H5N1 are forcet Europe to finally take responsibility because a deadly pandemic is not only predictable, it is inevitable. It's just a matter of time.  Therefore, beyond the measures taken, it must be said, more than six months late by this House, we must finally act, with real health cooperation between the developing countries and the European Union with inseparable assistance in the creation of their own social protection system. European migration policy needs to be revised, by re-establishing health control at Europe's borders, but also at the borders established between member countries, with medical quarantine sites. Like it or not, it is the advice of our greatest infectious diseases.  Last but not only, a grand plan must be carried out to create specific multidisciplinary care structures in Europe itself. This request is made by our infectious scientists. They have the lucidity that has failed some politicians mired in their inconsequentical angelism and third worldism. Only at this price will Europe be able to say tomorrow that it has taken responsibility.

name: Peter LIESE
text: Mr. President, dear colleagues! I myself worked as a doctor in a developing country for a while. That is why I can guess how the colleagues who are now fighting Ebola feel and how patients feel. I have great respect for all those who are now helping on the ground.  I find it indecent that some Members of this House are taking advantage of this difficult situation in terms of party politics. What we have just heard about Cuba and so on, I find intolerable in the face of the hardship that people have. We should not be rumpoliticising! (Applause) It is not the case that the people of Europe have to be afraid that they themselves will be infected. It is good that we are taking in people who have helped and that we are giving them the assurance that they will be treated well even then. People in Europe can feel safe about infection – at human discretion, which I can judge as a doctor. Nevertheless, it is not only a requirement of humanitarian aid that we help in West Africa, but above all it is also in our long-term interest. This is because several states are imploding. These are dramatic crises that are taking place there, and god knows we have enough crises in the world. That is why it is also in our interest to support these countries and to do everything we can. That is why it is good that the Commission, Commissioner, and many others have helped us to increase the resources. However, I would also like to point out that we have a problem with our budget. I have heard several times in recent days from the Member States, including from the one I come from: we must do more in Ukraine, we must do more in Iraq, and of course we must do more in West Africa, Palestine, etc.  Giovanni La Via, our budget rapporteur – he is sitting here – And Reimer Böge and others have always said that our budget is not intended for crises. We really need to talk to the Council now that we are becoming more flexible so that we can respond appropriately to such crises.

name: Maria ARENA
text: Mr President, for my part I am outraged, not for the reference to Cuba, but outraged at the problem of migration - some have used the Ebola virus to talk about this migration.  Since March, Doctors Without Borders has been alerting us to the danger of the virus, but also that of the epidemic. It is now September, six months later, and the virus is moving forward. The contagion is exponential and doubles the number of people infected every fortnight. So there's a real urgency to be able to act. We can indeed regret the fact that we were not fast enough. Today, we must focus on what we need to do to stop it. I would almost say it is simple and Doctors Without Borders has told us in concrete terms what needs to be done. We need a coordinated approach. We have to bring equipment. We need isolation cells, field hospitals, laboratories, air bridges. Well, all of this is available to the Member States. Whether it is from a civilian point of view but also - and I am opposed to what was said earlier - from a military point of view as well, because when we talk about the armies, I would like to see humanitarian armies coming to support people in distress.  So let's not be fine-mouthed, all means will be interesting ways to fight this virus, to fight this epidemic. Therefore, we call on the Council but also on the Commission to make these resources available to the people as soon as possible.

name: Frédérique RIES
text: Mr President, my colleagues have already, and largely, reported on the seriousness of the situation. Therefore, I will not go back to those numbers. They are known and by the way largely underestimated, according to experts. It is this emergency and the slowness of our response that concerns me. We have heard this widely shared observation. President Obama, you, Commissioner Georgieva, WHO, we all have the same speech here. The strategies that have been talked about, the roadmap, prevention, research as well - we have heard it - all this is going to take time and we know it. In the meantime, our countries - and Belgium, for example, with B-FAST - have these civilian and military rapid response capabilities that are planned for this type of medical and humanitarian crisis. Structures, including MSF, and all experts on the ground are calling for coordination at European level.  Mr President, I have heard you talk, and very much, about this coordination. We hear it and we know it. But they, there, on the spot - and Mrs. Rivasi said it with her children on the front line - do not hear it, do not see it. They want more, they want better, they want it right away and they want it quickly.  In fact, I think we have no choice if we still hope to prevent this virus from spreading in Africa and at home.  For them and for us too, solidarity today is not an option, it is a duty.

name: Françoise GROSSETÊTE
text: Mr President, Commissioner, of course this has already been said by many of us, we now know that WHO's forecasts for the course of this Ebola epidemic are particularly pessimistic. Make no mistake, this is not just a West African issue.  Given the scale of this epidemic, we are all concerned and it is really time for mobilization, extreme mobilization because we have already wasted a lot of time. It would be so easy to discard our responsibilities by saying that this disease does not directly affect our continent. In reality, this is a real global crisis. The values that we Europeans in the world up to these values of solidarity, dignity and respect for human rights make our support for the countries concerned a moral obligation. I really want to highlight the efforts that are being made by the medical teams there, there on the ground, by the NGOs.  It is really important to give our full support, but beyond the values I have just mentioned, it is also a question of protecting our citizens from the indirect consequences that this health crisis of an unprecedented magnitude could have. There are, of course, health risks that could extend to Europe, but above all there is the risk of destabilisation of an entire region in social, economic and humanitarian terms. Europe cannot and must not remain passive in the face of such a tragedy, for it must also be Europe for our fellow citizens: a Europe that takes its place on the international stage and assumes its responsibilities.  But, we can really question ourselves. The Ebola virus was discovered in 1976 and so far there is no known treatment! That must be of concern to us. I see it as proof that we need to encourage research and innovation in the medical field more than ever. It's absolutely essential.  Scientific progress, innovation, Europe's place, European solidarity, the Ebola epidemic challenges us beyond the health crisis. The European Union has a duty to respond strongly to the affected countries and to itself.

name: Gilles PARGNEAUX
text: Mr President, Commissioner, yes, there is an urgency, as has been said before me. 20,000 people are potential victims by the end of the year, but let's keep in mind, one million Africans are now quarantined as part of this pandemic. There is an urgency and I welcome the European Commission's effort with the release of EUR 152 million. But we must now say concretely what this sum will be used for. First, it must aim to increase the number and capacity of treatment centres with isolation services, to deploy qualified personnel, to install more mobile laboratories, to establish air bridges, to create a regional network of treatment centres. That is what we could do usefully in a hurry. I was rapporteur of the decision on serious cross-border health threats that we adopted here in July 2013, which was implemented on 6 November 2013. There is - and I consider him as rapporteur - urgent for the Member States to hold an extraordinary meeting of European health ministers very quickly to discuss this pandemic.  As specified in the decision on serious cross-border threats to health, the European Union must, as soon as possible, first carry out an inventory of sanitary facilities that can accommodate patients, activate the network of European laboratories on the detection of highly infectious pathogens and above all be in close contact with the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control. That, Commissioner, is the urgency we have before us.

name: Catherine BEARDER
text: Mr President, Ebola is not a distant threat. With Ebola cases doubling every three weeks, there could soon be an emergency here as it spirals out of control. The EU has already started to mobilise but we need to do more, and urgently. We need to prevent future outbreaks. We must boost efforts to develop treatments for Ebola and other deadly diseases. Too often these diseases are ignored by pharmaceutical companies. They cannot make money from them. That is why we must invest public money. The Jenner Institute in Oxford, working on a malaria vaccine funded by the EU, is ideally placed to work on Ebola. Today they have launched human clinical trials. This was only possible because they have the expertise through EU-supported research. Funding for this kind of research is vital. Global epidemics need to be contained quickly. We can only learn to do that through research. Training scientists and building expertise now will mean that lives will be saved next time a new disease rears its ugly head.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, Undersecretary, allow me to begin my speech by thinking of the thousands of victims of this epidemic and, of course, my sincere thanks, which I believe should be from the whole House to all the people who, as doctors, nurses and volunteers, are cooperating to try to control this very bad epidemic, in the interests of all European countries too. I am concerned about one issue, which is the resources we allocate. We are well aware that, in order to act quickly and to have a strong response, we need resources which will then serve to mobilise people and resources to help the people affected. Unfortunately, there are few resources in Europe's budget today, and they are few because we do not have sufficient room for flexibility in the multiannual financial framework. Well, this should prompt us in the budgetary negotiations that we are making to focus on those necessary resources, even at the expense of some other programme which is perhaps not as high priority as this intervention. On the other hand, allow me to say that, on behalf of this Parliament, as chairman of the Committee on Health and Social Affairs, at the informal Council on Monday 22 December in Milan, I will point out the need for an extraordinary effort by all twenty-eight countries to ensure that there is coordinated, strong and immediate action, because an epidemic such as this, even if it does not directly affect us today, certainly needs a time-free intervention in order to be able to prevent, of course, the problems that we may have in our own country. Continent.

name: Kathleen VAN BREMPT
text: In this short period of time, I would just like to emphasise one thing, which has already been mentioned by other Members but is essential, namely coordination. I quote Dr David Nabarro, the United Nations' chief coordinator for Ebola: "Coordination saves lives". This coordination is, of course, about an interplay of medical assistance, other assistance, everything that has to do with logistics, sometimes also real protection that we need. In this respect, it has hurt me and many of us when you and your people in the Commission have almost begged the Member States not only to get going, but also to do so. At that point in August, there was little response. Fortunately, that has changed this week. Meanwhile, the epidemic has taken on dramatic forms. But let it also be a lesson. The Council has said what initiatives have been taken. That is good and I know that all this has been done with the best of intentions, but in the future we will recognise the Commission much more quickly as the body to act in a coordinated way in these kinds of humanitarian crises. On this point, you will find a strong defender in Parliament, including in the new Commission. Because that is what Europe must stand for: to ensure that it acts in the world and to bring together the expertise we have in all the Member States so that such a humanitarian crisis in a continent like Africa, with weak medical care, is quickly addressed.

name: Teresa JIMÉNEZ-BECERRIL BARRIO
text: Mr President, my first words can only support the victims of Ebola, and I want to transfer this support to all those who work on the ground, risking their lives to save those living in countries without the minimum health structures to ensure the response this epidemic needs. One of them was the Spanish priest Miguel Pajares, who died after spreading in Liberia while helping those most in need, in this case Ebola sufferers, who are currently repudiated by their community even after healing. According to the World Health Organization, Ebola is a public health emergency that requires a coordinated international response. In this race we have to be faster than this silent enemy that has already claimed two thousand and three hundred lives. The situation, ladies and gentlemen, is deteriorating rapidly and Ebola is affecting the region's weak economies and, consequently, public order. Humanitarian needs are increasing and, if not met, it will be much more difficult to combat this disease. The number of patients grows much faster than our ability to manage it. We know that the Commission has increased humanitarian aid, but it also needs to increase the support of experts in the region. All countries need to be involved in research, not forgetting the measures to ensure that this epidemic does not spread, without condemning these already severely punished countries to lose all hope of becoming out of poverty as a result of being isolated. And I conclude by reminding those who care for these Ebola sufferers, who deserve all our recognition whether they are Americans, whether European, whether African. They are our heroes, anonymous heroes, and we owe them not only our attention, like the one we are giving here today, but also our action, and fast.

name: Christel SCHALDEMOSE
text: Mr President! The Ebola epidemic is a global challenge. That is why it is also very good to see that both the European Commission and the EU Member States have finally begun to take this seriously, have started to act. It was time. But I have two appeals. They apply both to the Commission and to the Member States. The first is: now resolve the problem of being able to evacuate health workers back to Europe, because that is the only way to send more health workers and help. The second is: I hope that we will jointly agree that the money we are sending away will not be taken from traditional development aid - that is, that is, that it is new money that we are spending. We need that, because otherwise we just run the risk that we will not be able to help the countries concerned to build their health systems in the long term. We need to help massively. Help is on the way, but we need to do the right thing. I hope that we can coordinate it together so that we can resolve this serious challenge.

name: Annie SCHREIJER-PIERIK
text: Thousands of victims have been killed in the affected countries in Africa since the Ebola outbreak, and research shows that 70 million people are at risk of infection and one million may be infected. The outbreak of the virus has dealt a huge blow to these countries, affecting both society and the economy. We in Europe must ask ourselves what we could have done better to tackle this virus and what is our answer to that? How well do we coordinate this approach and how well do we work together? Last week, dutch minister Edith Schippers gave permission to buy a vaccine against Ebola, a step in the right direction. But we're a long way from being there. What is Europe going to do to accelerate the development of a vaccine that can enter the market? Are there not enough applications for projects that have much less priority? I call on the Commission to take a closer look at its priorities in the area of research. Because developments in Africa show that a vaccine against the Ebola virus must be our first strong priority in this crisis.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: Mill-bidu tas-sena, il-virus tal-ebola qatel aktar minn 2 000 ruħ u affettwa aktar minn 4 000 persuna fil-Liberja, Sjerra Leone u Ginea – ġew affettwati wkoll in-Niġerja u s-Senegal. name: Cécile Kashetu KYENGE
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, no country should be left alone to deal with an emergency such as ebola. Today, infectious diseases such as Ebola can only be defeated, and this is only done through systematic, internationally coordinated action. Containment is not an option and I believe that we must eradicate the disease immediately. This tragic event presents us with the structural fragility of the health systems of many African countries, and I believe that this also highlights the underdevelopment conditions in many parts of Africa. Only by relaunching the Union's cooperation and development policies will it be possible to avoid tragedies such as this in the future, such as through the fight against poverty, which becomes a priority. New partnerships are needed to support the creation of excellent hospital facilities, the training of health professionals on the ground and in the field of education. It is unthinkable that a country such as Liberia should be forced to quarantine an entire area of its capital because of its lack of adequate health services. This epidemic presents us with our responsibilities. Supporting the well-being of humanity in this globalised world is in the interests of all of us.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: Ebola is something that we can compare so badly to an epidemic, a plague in the Middle Ages. It's something that can destroy the functioning of any country. We know that Liberia, but also Sierra Leone, is on the verge of collapsing as a country. This has been brought in by a number of agencies.  Unfortunately, the number of people infected is increasing exponentially, and you know that we doctors do not yet have any effective antibody or vaccine. It is being worked on, but the EU must certainly make much greater and more concentrated efforts to promote the faster contribution of the sanitary solution, not just preventive and epidemiological measures. We must certainly show more solidarity and we must show that this is a human rights issue and that it is the EU's duty to help our neighbors in Africa.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: Mr President, Ebola has caused the deaths of almost three thousand people, and at least two thousand others have contracted the disease, according to official figures. And the reality is much worse than that: we are talking about three thousand people, we are not talking about three thousand figures. As a member of the Delegation to the ACP-EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly, I would like to convey to you our partners the concern of the spread of this virus, but also my despair at the delayed and low reaction from international partners. We need to understand the gravity of the situation and for the European Union to take a leading role in solving this problem. It is clear and our partners in West Africa say it: locally, there is no effective management capacity for the virus. The Union must therefore assume this role. My question is how can the European Union react to such situations in the future, if the Council has called for a drastic reduction in the European funds granted for development assistance, and I wonder where these funds have been granted in the past. You mentioned the granting of a significant amount for the fight against Ebola and, being in the Committee on Budgets, I ask whether it is a real commitment or money that will be granted to these countries. I want to finally welcome the effort of non-governmental organisations, especially Doctors Without Borders, to fight Ebola.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: Mr President, we are associated with those who consider this epidemic, which threatens to take on the pandemic proportions, as one of the most important health threats in terms of public health. And I speak of health threats because, in reality, and without underpanyrethis worrying phenomenon, the fact is that the imperialist wars, fueled by the military industrial complexes of capitalist powers, associated with austerity policies, continue to represent by far the greatest social and humanitarian scourges of today. The affected countries, namely Sierra Leone, congo, Liberia, Guinea and Nigeria, suffered for years the colonial yoke, followed after the imperialist yoke. These are countries where the IMF, with its neoliberal revenues and ruinous loans... who currently do not have the effective conditions to deal with this epidemic.  The European Union and the United States, in the name of a debt of the past, have a moral obligation to contribute to an effective disease control plan. I end, and I apologize to the most sensitive ears for recording the differences between the United States, which is in charge of the military, and the Socialist Republic of Cuba, which sends doctors who will be working as early as 1 October.

name: Matthias GROOTE
text: Mr. President! We had a hearing of Commissioner Borg in the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Consumer Policy, where we once again made a massive demand for more investment in research. I have to say that I find it extremely regrettable: the Member States have been very reluctant to finance such extraordinary incidents as Ebola, when epidemics break out. All of a clear time is now calling for Europe to be deployed at the site. But if we don't have money ... Better late than never, it must be said to the Council, because there has been movement now. But we must do better in the future.   To make populist speeches here – as a colleague has already told us – is not to help a sick person there in Africa and not one who has helped there, but it must be improved. We need to get faster, we have to prepare ourselves for the fact that such epidemics will be there more often, and Europe must help and not lament for long, but tackle it in order to improve the situation, including with research and development – that has come from a wide range of groups today. We need to think about how we can get better there and do more in the future.

name: Bill ETHERIDGE
text: Mr President, as we have watched this horrifying disease unfold and the problems get worse and worse, I think we can all unite in saying how awful the situation is and how we salute the health workers who are there.  I think it is absolutely crucial that at this time the politicians give direct answers, are honest, straightforward and take effective measures, and that all of us get behind the people who are trying to deal with this terrible problem. I think that more than anything we should all be united in sending our prayers, our best wishes and all our hopes to those who are suffering from this awful thing at this terrible time, and all our hopes are with them that they can come through this. I think that is the main message we can send from here today.

name: Udo VOIGT
text: Commissioner, I would like to thank the Commissioner for her I have a specific question on your third point, which you have mentioned. You said there that the virus must be combated and isolated, not the countries, and have very much welcomed the fact that European airlines continue to fly to these countries. I would like to hear from you whether this is a responsible act on your part or irresponsible. Because the virus doesn't stop. Once it has landed in Brussels or in Berlin or Paris, we will no longer be able to take care of the other countries. Hence my specific question: are these people being investigated? Are there any possibilities for investigation when the machines land? Or is it thought of isolating it until it is established that this disease does not spread? Otherwise, I believe that i believe that this is not suitable for populism with everyone here. Because if we do not act in time now and the virus has landed in Europe, then we will no longer be able to help anyone.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Dear ladies and gentlemen, first of all I would like to thank all those people who are selflessly on the ground today, that is, in the countries where we have a pandemic today, are really doing good to those who are infected and prevent the further spread of the disease.
