But what we have to admit to ourselves is that this pandemic surprised us, and as it surprised us, we can also see problems in the coordination of the fight against this pandemic. And how on our continent, in Europe, in the European Union itself, I would say with other partners in the international community outside the European Union because it is a matter of the whole world, it is not just a matter of Europe or just a matter of West Africa.  So, I am in need of really investing as much as possible in research and really trying to prevent it as soon as possible, and I support all that Ms Commissioner has been saying and I believe that the Commission really has the best intentions.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Mr. President! "We need doctors, disease experts, medicines and soldiers who also shoot if necessary" – this is how a Salesian father from Sierra Leone describes the situation dramatically. After all, the war against the viruses in West Africa cannot be won without outside help. But sending money to crisis countries without clear concepts is of no use. This feeds only corrupt governments in Sierra Leone and Liberia. Therefore, both the UN and the EU must act. This means: mobile hospitals, medicines, doctors and disease experts, who can again train health workers, and a separate UN mandate for the countries and soldiers concerned, who, if necessary, also protect those affected and also the helpers with the weapon in their hands. We must therefore act quickly so that the epidemic does not actually become a pandemic.

name: Anneli JÄÄTTEENMÄKI
text: Mr President, Ebola is currently one of the biggest threats in the world. The EU and other international organisations have not taken this threat seriously. It has been allowed to grow, develop, expand and spread. What is needed now is joint coordination between international organisations, and it is a disgrace that the WHO, the International Health Organisation, for example, does not currently have sufficient resources to tackle this challenge.  I very much hope that the EU, together with international organisations and the World Health Organisation in particular, will work together so that, at least for the lack of financial resources, the fight against this threat does not fall.

name: Giulia MOI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, on behalf of the 5-Star Movement, I would like to express my solidarity with all the families of the people who have dedicated their lives and are dedicating it to the people who are dying and suffering in these places. , which has been used so far and what use will be made of it if more are allocated.  I would also like to ask for the favour, should they be allocated in Italy, to check, as it could be yet another cause of theft and fraud that is always perpetuated in Italy by our current political caste.

name: Kristalina Georgieva
text: Member of the Commission. - Mr President, I would like to thank everybody who has spoken today. Let me first start with the question of whether Europe acted quickly. From the humanitarian side, it did. We were the first to bring financial support and to send our own staff – our own doctors are there risking their lives – to mobilise attention to this epidemic. Since March when it started, we have been repeatedly giving a very straightforward message from the humanitarian side. This is serious. We have to act in a coordinated manner. Already in August, together with the World Health Organisation, we approached our Member States by activating the Civil Protection Mechanism asking for support in kind for the affected communities. Very often we in the humanitarian community are like the canary in the mine. We feel trouble and we sense danger before the rest of the world understands the magnitude of this danger. But it is also true that the international community as a whole has not been quick enough to respond to calls, from the doctors in the field and especially from Médecins Sans Frontières, the organisation that has been right there from day one. It has taken some time for the world to recognise – even the World Health Organisation if I am to be very honest – that this is very serious and requires a massive response. I want to praise our Member States because in the last weeks we have seen a surge in reaction from them: just to give you some examples, Austria with protective equipment, Italy with a field hospital, the United Kingdom and France with new centres to be opened and more beds to be provided, Hungary with assistance in kind, Spain with an emergency unit in the Kenema province in Sierra Leone, etc. Our military staff are also looking into how they can contribute – today and tomorrow – to the critical evacuation capability of which many of you have spoken as a crucial need for the medical professions in the field but also, broadly speaking, for evacuation capacity. So we are now finally seeing mobilisation on a global scale. But we also have to stay focused, because in today’s world we are facing crises competing with each other for attention and for resources. Not including Ebola, we have four level 3 emergencies – this is the highest possible level in humanitarian terms in the world – Iraq, Syria, the Central African Republic and South Sudan. I would like to respond immediately to those of you have said that we have to create more flexibility in the budget in order to direct funds very quickly to where early action will save lives, but also to reduce the cost, the human suffering and the financial cost of response in the future. I hope that we will work sooner rather than later on this flexibility of response in a more fragile world.  I was asked how this virus is spreading. Well, it is through the handling of infected chimpanzees, gorillas, monkeys, porcupines, but at the moment we are not seeing it as a danger for the rest of the world because we are not seeing that kind of movement of products. Also the virus dies, so from the time between a problem arising and its possible arrival in Europe, we do not have a danger. This is what the medical profession is telling us.  And also a very direct question: is the opening up of travel a risk for Europe? Let me first state something you may or may not know: that MSF do not have a single case of their international staff being infected by Ebola, and they are there, they are in the middle of it. In other words, Ebola is controllable. It means washing your hands, making sure that you sanitise before you get on the plane, and of course our airlines are doing that, so I think that we are very strong in our precautionary measures, and therefore we should not worry that keeping this line of communication open is going to be a danger. On the contrary, if we stop this ability to send more medical doctors to these countries and to bring out our nurses and doctors from the most dangerous zones, then the epidemic is going to explode and then the danger to us may – may – become real, because the longer we do not fight, the bigger the risk of this virus mutating. We have been asked about vaccines and using research. At the moment, there is very aggressive deployment of all that has been developed in terms of vaccines and treatment so that we can provide help to people who are infected. But let us be very fair and straight on that: quantities are limited. So can we help everybody who needs help today? The answer is no, and this is why we have to make every effort possible to fight Ebola at origin, now, and do it in the most aggressive way we can. My last point is on coordination. I could not agree more that coordination saves lives. We finally have a very strong coordination mechanism from the United Nations, with Dr Nabarro, who is an exceptional professional, and the deployment of the best WHO staff. But we must also coordinate our own contribution, because if all of us, 28 Member States plus the Commission, try to help individually, we are putting unnecessary pressure on those who are taking life-saving action today. I am proud to say that last year with your support we created an emergency response coordination centre which is providing a platform for Europe to act as one when the need comes, and this is the moment of such need.

name: Benedetto DELLA VEDOVA
text: Mr President- in-Office of the Council. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to assure you that the Council will continue to treat Ebola as one of the top priorities of its forthcoming work, and I would like to thank the Commission and Commissioner Georgieva for the work and also for the clarity with which, also in its reply, it has reaffirmed its commitment and concrete points of action.  At the operational level, the needs on the ground remain substantial and include medical and humanitarian personnel, as well as laboratories, hospitals, etc. Other health needs are becoming an even greater problem due to the collapse of health systems in Liberia and Sierra Leone. There are also shortcomings in food and nutrition, agriculture, governance and security. All these factors can create instability that in turn risks contributing to the spread of Ebola. Further preparatory initiatives must cover all African countries from those most at risk. Next week, on 24 September, on the sidelines of the UN General Assembly, eu foreign ministers together with international partners and the UN will discuss and coordinate the further response to the crisis.  We now have a functioning EU response framework to protect EU citizens against cross-border health threats. The health services of THE EU Member States are fully aware of the possibility of the arrival of Ebola virus patients in Europe and are doing everything possible to prepare for this eventuality, although at the moment the risk of contracting the disease for EU residents and those travelling to the affected countries is considered low. Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: The Ebola epidemic affecting West Africa is increasingly alarming. The relative passivity with which the most developed countries and the European Union have faced this problem has contributed to an accumulation of loss of human life. This is unacceptable and our duty to help is a moral imperative! The African countries affected do not have health systems to respond to this disease without it being catastrophic proportions! The absence of more energetic action increases the risk of spreading the disease and brings increased difficulties in its control, always requiring increasing operational means and containment infrastructures that are scarce. Furthermore, border closures and traffic restrictions to and from affected countries call into question the stability of the entire region, which is based on an already fragile economic structure. I therefore call for the implementation of technical and human resources to be immediate, as well as the articulation with our international partners for closely coordinated intervention.

name: Kaja KALLAS
text: in writing. –  I welcome the EU's serious concern about the Ebola outbreak since the epidemic constitutes a global risk. Over 2.100 people have died from the Ebola virus in countries including Guinea, Liberia, Nigeria and Sierra Leone, not only in rural areas, but in the largest cities as well. However, there are people infected with Ebola outside these countries too. The Estonian Ministry of Foreign Affairs has already provided 50.000 euros to help the World Health Organization (WHO) prevent the deadly viral illness from spreading further in West Africa. We need to coordinate a global response and it is imperative we try to control the outbreak and prevent economic, social and political impacts.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Motions for resolutions to be tabled pursuant to Rule 123(2) of the Rules of Procedure will be announced at a later date. The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday, 18 September 2014.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: I have had the enforcement of the regulation monitored by the services, including with regard to the amendments. Article 192, paragraph 3, of the regulation states: "If the minutes are challenged, Parliament decides, if necessary, on the consideration of the requested amendments. No Member of Parliament can speak on the subject for more than a minute." I asked Mr Gollnisch what amendment he was proposing. I respect you, I am showing respect for you. I postponed the final decision because I wanted to guarantee your work and the role of the member. I checked and I was right. I am asking you if there is an amendment on your part. We cannot propose political amendments, because it is not a political debate. If there are errors in the text, you can propose amendments. Otherwise, I am obliged to reject the amendments, because the text is very clear: 'if necessary'. If there are mistakes, tell me which amendment you would like to propose. If he is eligible, I will put him to a vote. Otherwise, the minutes are approved. I'm listening.

name: Bruno GOLLNISCH
text: Thank you very much, Mr President, for voting. It is true that the regulation is somewhat ambiguous, since paragraph 2 speaks of approval. It could simply be said that Parliament expresses its disapproval on point 6.  You want to proceed by amendments. I therefore propose the following amendment, which is a supplement after the first paragraph of Article 6 of the minutes. Here's what that supplement would be. I repeat the first paragraph: "The time for votes takes place in simultaneous video broadcast with the Verkhovna Rada (Ukrainian Parliament in Kiev), called to vote at the same time as the European Parliament on the EU-Ukraine Association Agreement." My amendment would be to add this sentence: "This unannounced non-regulatory procedure has not been subject to the agreement of MEPs." I repeat: "This unannounced non-regulatory procedure has not been subject to the agreement of MEPs." It is an undeniable fact, I think, and it completes the minutes so that it reflects exactly what this session was.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Mr Gollnisch, I respect your ideas, as always, I respect all Members. Unfortunately your amendment is a political amendment, it is a commentary on what happened. There has been no debate on this subject. Therefore, we cannot comment on that. I cannot accept this amendment.  The minutes are approved. We are continuing the agenda.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: The next item is the debate on the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the situation in Iraq and Syria and the ISIS offensive including the persecution of minorities (2014/2843(SDR)).

name: Benedetto DELLA VEDOVA
text: President-in-Office of the Council (on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission/ High Representative of the European Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy). - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I am speaking today on behalf of the High Representative and Vice-President Catherine Ashton to discuss the recent tragic events in Iraq and Syria. In both countries the situation has changed radically in recent months. The Foreign Affairs Council of 15 August, the Gymnich and the European Council at the end of August addressed these increasingly pressing crises. On 15 September, France organised an international conference on peace and security in Iraq, co-chaired by President François Hollande and Iraqi President Masum. The meeting was attended by foreign ministers from thirty delegations who pledged to support Iraq's efforts to meet an unreserved challenge.   We are dismayed and outraged, like all of you, by the violence, murders and human rights violations perpetrated by ISIL, particularly against religious, ethnic minorities, including helpless women and children. We reaffirm our firm commitment to support the unity, sovereignty and territorial integrity of Iraq.  The European Union has urged Iraqi leaders to establish an inclusive government capable of giving a political response to the crisis. We welcome the formation of the new government led by Al Abadi. ISIL and other armed groups represent a very serious terrorist threat to the entire surrounding region and a direct challenge to the security of the European Union and the entire international community. The intentions of the jihadists are very clear: the goal is to occupy territory that allows them to found what they call the "Islamic State". The terrorist threat itself is nothing new, it is its global reach that is unprecedented. In some ways ISIL poses as a state that controls territory, manages important assets and imposes taxes. It also has access to considerable, smuggled financial resources, such as oil and other raw materials. The European Union is determined to prevent ISIL from having access to oil financing and proceeds. EU ministers condemned ISIL financiers who acted in violation of UN Security Council Resolution 1267 and later. The despicable actions of the jihadists go from the heinous murder of hostages and prisoners, to abuse of children and women, to the persecution of members of religious and ethnic minorities and the vilification of sacred and cultural sites. Violations of human rights are carried out on a large scale and affect freedom of religion or belief, an essential principle, particularly in a multi-ethnic region, which would require being able to live their beliefs freely without fear of acts of intolerance or aggression. The European Union is determined to counter the threat of ISIL and other terrorist groups in Iraq and Syria, as called for in UN Security Council Resolution 2170. The perpetrators of these crimes will be accountable for their actions. We also have a specific responsibility for the large number of European citizens who have sided with other foreign fighters.  The European Union must act urgently on three fronts: security, political and humanitarian. The fight against ISIL and the alarming humanitarian situation are a top priority. The European Union and its Member States individually are engaged on a number of fronts, including the support of some Member States for president Obama's coalition. We are aware that the military and anti-terrorist response alone is not enough. Actions against ISIL must be seen in a broader context of reforms in Iraq and political transition in Syria. The Member States, on an individual basis, are providing military support through the supply of weapons, ammunition and equipment.  Specifically, US airstrikes and military support to Kurdish regional authorities in Iraq have been crucial in containing ISIL's offensive. The European Union as a whole supports these efforts politically. The action is under way and the first results are already being seen. The Iraqi armed forces have regained ground, as have Kurdish forces in the north of the country. The appointment of Al Abadi as prime minister by President Masum and the subsequent formation of an inclusive government are steps forward. The European Council welcomed the efforts of the United States and other partners, including the initiative of an international security conference in Iraq. The involvement and active engagement of partners in the region is essential to this challenge for security and stability. On the humanitarian side, the situation in Iraq is extremely worrying, with 1.8 million internally displaced persons since January 2014. Access to the population in conflict and risk zones in different parts of Iraq remains a priority for the Union. While humanitarian operations are continuing in the north of the country, unstable security conditions are hampering access to other parts of central Iraq, including the Al Anbar Governorate. Despite the budgetary constraints, the European Union has stepped up its efforts by allocating an additional EUR 10 million to combat the crisis. Thanks to this contribution, the eu's total budget for humanitarian actions in Iraq has reached 17 million euros since the beginning of the year. In addition, the Member States have paid another forty million euros in humanitarian aid. The EU Civil Protection Mechanism has also been activated to facilitate humanitarian assistance. The European Union has brought particular assistance to the most vulnerable groups in Syria and Iraq, mobilising more than EUR 2.87 billion in relief and assistance in Syria and its neighbours. Our help is aimed at all people in need without any discrimination. In Syria, ISIL is strengthening its presence in the country and could soon take refuge on the ground for its destabilization activities. The rise of ISIL in Syria is the result of instability caused by the Assad regime's brutal war against its own people. A lasting solution requires a relaxation of tension, an end to violence and a political transition that is led by the Syrians themselves. The European Union fully supports the mission of the UN Special Envoy, Ambassador de Mistura, to return from consultations in Damascus. On a more general level, we are convinced that the rise of ISIL can only be countered by the synergy of prevention, control and sanctions.

name: Arnaud DANJEAN
text: on behalf of the EPP group. Madam President, it took the fall of Mosul, the terrible persecution of Christians and other minorities, the killing of Western hostages, for our States to take the measure of urgency in the face of the destabilization of Iraq and the whole region by a self-proclaimed terrorist group Islamic State. We had pointed out here, a little less than two months ago, that this phenomenon unfortunately did not date back to these tragic events but that it was much more deeply rooted in the bad sectarian governance that prevailed in Iraq in recent years, in the chaos of Syria naturally and in the murky influence games between many regional actors.  The diplomatic and military response of the United States and several European states is welcome. She's to be saluted. Airstrikes and aid to Kurdish fighters have helped stem the Islamist surge.  However, I think that we should not be deluded about the chosen format, as it is currently presented. The display of a broad coalition is undoubtedly an exercise that is necessary diplomatically but suffers from serious limitations. This coalition first covers, behind a common objective in the very short term, a lot of ambiguity on the part of actors with divergent interests. It forgets the key countries we need in this fight - I am thinking in particular of Iran - and also avoids the complexity of our approach to the Syrian conflict. We also know that airstrikes and arms deliveries are necessary but that they will not be enough to defeat this terrorist group. Finally, the focus on this Islamic state is understandable, but it risks forgetting some other groups, some other threats, while provoking the rallying of jihadist groups, hitherh marginal, to this Islamic State. The Islamic State and its expansion into Iraq and Syria are far from the only Islamist threat facing the Middle East and our Western societies. In the face of this multifaceted challenge, enhanced and very pragmatic legal, intelligence, special operations and military operations coordination is needed to provide a lasting solution.  I would particularly like to stress the need to harmonize anti-terrorism legislation between European countries because we see the phenomenon of these European foreign fighters going to train in Syria and Iraq, a phenomenon that is increasing and poses a real threat to our societies.

name: Victor BOŞTINARU
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, my group is extremely concerned by the deterioration in the security and the humanitarian situation in Syria and Iraq. The extreme violence used, the indiscriminate killings, have resulted in a large number of civilian victims of IS, including a large number of women and children, as well as the complete destruction of important Shiite, Yazidi and Christian places and symbols. The cruelty and unacceptable use of violence against large communities is condemned by the international community. We have a duty to act.  I am very shocked by the murder of David Haines, the third Westerner to be killed by IS militants recently. We know that in many cases people from our EU Member States have also been involved in the conflict, the so-called ‘tourist terrorists’, who are now coming back posing an even higher risk to our security. It is essential that our Member States do all they can to prevent this from happening, and to identity these people and render them harmless, which requires coordination among the 28 Member States.  We need to see the problem not as a national one, but as a regional one, and for the regional problem to be addressed we need a regional response. Iraq cannot be seen as a different problem from Syria, and IS must be contained and then defeated, but this can only happen if we can find a suitable and pragmatic solution. We are dealing with an extremist fundamentalist group which is using a harsh interpretation of Sharia law and our first responsibility is to make clear the difference between this violent group and Islam. Islamic State should not be identified with Islam. Baghdad has not been able to address the problem of an inclusive governance but we have an important duty to apply pressure. Let me conclude by mentioning three issues. First, cooperation with the main regional actors including Iran, Saudi Arabia and the Arab League. Second, cutting financial resources from IS, which are so high today, and finally reinforcing the regional and local authorities and communities, including providing arms to the Kurdish population.

name: Anna FOTYGA
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab On 8th September the long-standing, evil, divisive, powerless rule of Prime Minister Nuri al-Maliki ended. Governments that have undoubtedly contributed to the emergence and rise of the self-proclaimed Islamic State, a cruel terrorist organization that has caused incredible suffering to minorities in Iraq and Syria: Yazid communities, Assyrian Christians, Chaldeans, other communities. It resulted in the deaths of countless citizens of both countries and the need to flee, to find refuge in other countries. The establishment of the government of Haidar al-Abadi is a hope, it creates hope and there is no doubt that the free world, the European Union, should do everything it can to help stabilise, to make this government a united, inclusive Kurdish community and Kurdish politicians, ensuring the stability and unity of the country.  Less than a week later, an international conference was held, co-chaired by President Hollande. This conference is certainly a hope, but there has been a relatively small share of high representatives of the countries of my region, Central and Eastern Europe. However, Minister Lavrov, representing the same country that threatened my country with a nuclear attack a few days ago, was present. I hope that the Union will maintain unity, balance in assessing all threats and will not allow concessions to Russia in exchange for its participation in the anti-terrorist coalition. Today is a difficult day – this is 17 September – the anniversary of bad pacts. I would like this time of our mobilisation for Iraq, for Iraq – and I hope this will apply to all the Countries of the European Union – to unequivocally strike out the bad... (The President received the speaker's vote.)

name: Annemie NEYTS-UYTTEBROECK
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, the proverb that it is no use crying over spilt milk has equivalence I believe in most of our languages. Be that as it may, one day we will need to ask ourselves if the current events might have had a different course had we acted differently. That goes for Iraq; that goes for Syria; and I would like to dare to add that it also goes for Ukraine. I hope that one day we will face that question. In the meantime we must meet the many challenges posed by those situations, challenges that are humanitarian, military, political and societal. In the humanitarian field, there are millions of refugees, both internally displaced persons (IDPs) and refugees in neighbouring countries, so there is a need for increased humanitarian assistance and I hope that, at the international donor conferences which are being organised, many Member States and the EU will come up with increased support. There is also the need for better protection of minorities, including religious ones and all vulnerable groups. On the military front, there is the need to fight Islamic State (IS) and other extremist militant groups. My group leader called a long time ago for a military intervention in Syria, and at the time – I honestly recognise it – I thought he was exaggerating a little bit. Unfortunately events have proved him right: had we intervened earlier things might not have taken the bad turn that they did. Now, a coalition is being put together to take military action against IS, but if Afghanistan has taught us anything it is that groups like the Taliban or IS are not easily defeated, so we will also need political answers: political answers and societal answers. Political action means supporting a unified government in Iraq; trying to ensure a transition in Syria if that is not a completely impossible task, and, if it is, imposing one; strengthening the present regimes in Jordan and Lebanon; and demanding stronger actions by Arab countries. We also want to see clearer action by Turkey and Iran and, lastly, action to cut supplies and income to IS, with sanctions against all those who do business with IS.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, putting out the fire with fire, not even firefighters do it regularly. They call it a firefire and it's pretty dangerous. But firefighters don't create fires. The Western countries of belicists, yes. At the very least, they created the Fire of the Middle East, the fire of Iraq, which has already claimed more than 1,400,000 casualties. And that's what they're proposing, putting out their fire with more fire. What are they going to do now? Bomb those who have encouraged in Syria? Those who were the rebellious friends? Those Senator McCain met with? Those who were funded from the Gulf to contain Syria or Iran? Playing with fire isn't good. The fire spread to Iraq and also ignited a plain paid for by the sectarian governments that the West supported. Because if not, who has supported this Constitution based on ethnic or sectarian quotas? Or who supported the sectarian government of al Maliki, which brutally charged Sunni areas in Fallujah, Samarra or Ramadi? This fire does not go out with its bombardment of unmanned aerial vehicles. It doesn't go out with the madness of arming the contenders. It is extinguished at an international conference sponsored by the United Nations and neighbouring countries, with the prominence of all Iraqi diversity, that gives way to a unitary government that ends, at once, these sectarian policies and violence.

name: Barbara LOCHBIHLER
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her We support this resolution on Iraq and Syria, partly because it highlights the need for a coordinated EU policy. The fight against ISIS in Iraq and Syria will take a long time. Many aspects of a strategy are still to be developed, and the resolution identifies the most important ones. This includes preventing hundreds of EU citizens from registering as IS fighters. Combating extremism in Europe means, among other things, seriously tackling social exclusion and lack of prospects among young adults. The crimes of the Islamic State terrorist militia are extremely cruel and heinous. In Iraq .... (microphone failure) Yesterday, THE UN Syria investigator Pinheiro presented his eighth Syria report to the UN Human Rights Council, and he describes some of the crimes committed by ISIS. He says that the jihadists not only publicly executed the two foreign journalists, but that they are killing many Syrians in the same way in public places in the north and east of the country. ISIS systematically exposes children to violence. They are encouraged to take part in executions and are allegedly confronted with crucified in public places.  Women accused of adultery or who are found in public without male accompaniment would be stoned to death. So far the report. However, Pinheiro also stresses that the Syrian government is still responsible for the majority of civilian crimes committed in Syria.  I would like to take this opportunity to reiterate our awareness that there must be no impunity for all these crimes – crimes against humanity and war crimes – that are happening in Syria and Iraq, and I therefore call once again for the International Criminal Court in The Hague to investigate war crimes there. However, some of the demands in the resolution do not agree, namely where it is said that the fight against ISIS should be waged by all means. It may be necessary to use military means on a point-by-point basis, especially when it comes to the protection of civilians. What we strongly oppose, however, including in this resolution, is an uncontrollable, unregulated military action. There must be no carte blanche for military operations, because we do not have to repeat the devastating mistakes of the so-called fight against terror that we have just witnessed.

name: James CARVER
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Madam President, not since the 1930s has mankind been tasked with tackling the perverted mind sets of a completely flawed ideal. Before Britain joined the European Community, our independent foreign policy allowed us to broker alliances for the protection of those who were threatened. However, in the name of communality, we are losing this skill. This is all the more tragic as genuine diplomacy is what is needed at this pivotal moment in history. Your obsession with harmonisation and a belief that you are always right can only be defined as navel-gazing. Britain, not the European Union, needs to take a lead here, not with troops on the ground but with the diplomacy to motivate and galvanise a global community of reasonable people, including moderate Muslims, to put a stop to these murderous fanatics – including EU citizens in their ranks – who are intent on destroying the tolerance and decency which underpins civilised society. The Western world wanted raging change in Libya and Syria, yet our leaders failed to comprehend how tangled the web of Middle East politics really is. Diplomacy is not about the good guys against the bad guys; it is about understanding how competing countries with competing interests can nevertheless find common ground against this global threat. So, this place has to wake up and smell the coffee. If we are serious about tackling IS then just like in 1941 you have to accept Russia and now her ability to reach out to Middle Eastern states which view the West differently. I am no fan of Assad or Putin, but I recognise the old premise that my enemyʼs enemy is my friend. If we are to forge a genuine coalition against IS, then you have to stop provoking Putinʼs Russia as you did so theatrically here in this Chamber yesterday.  (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Bill ETHERIDGE
text: blue-card question. – Does my colleague agree with me that the acts of barbarism committed by British citizens in the name of this twisted ideology of IS are a disgrace, and will he join with me in uniting to put all of our abilities together to make sure these people do not ever return to British shores, or to the EU, to perpetrate more acts of evil barbarism?

name: James CARVER
text: blue-card answer. – My colleague raises a very serious point and, yes, I do agree that this whole issue of EU open borders creates a problem not just for militants who may be British citizens returning to Britain. They may indeed choose to settle in other parts of the European Union and become a threat and take forward this barbarous, monstrous ideal, and this open-door border situation is a serious threat to the safety of all 28 EU Member States. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: blue-card question. – Madam President, in all my years in this Parliament I have never seen the President allow a Member of one national delegation from one party ask a blue card of another in order to get two speeches out of one and play to a domestic gallery for political purposes. It was a clever move, Mr Etheridge, but I do not really think it should be encouraged in this Parliament. I salute your creativity in this respect.  My question to Mr Carver is a political one. He said that the enemy of your enemy is always your friend in foreign policy. Would he not agree that we in fact made a terrible mistake in 1979 in thinking that the mujahidin in Afghanistan, being the enemy of the Soviet Union, were our friend, and in backing them the CIA and the Americans backed these jihadists and we created a huge problem for the whole of the Western world. I hope that UKIP would grow up and realise that ʽthe enemy of your enemy is always your friendʼ is not actually the way we should conduct our foreign policy.

name: Adina-Ioana VĂLEAN
text: Mr Tannock, I think all of us realised the trick in it, but still, Mr Carver ...

name: James CARVER
text: blue-card answer. – Mr Tannock, it is clearly you and and your party which are politically posturing here because we have on many occasions in the previous Parliament seen your party carry out exactly the same tactic. But, with regard to comparing the mujahidin with Putin’s Russia, I feel there is no serious comparison. We have a situation here where we have to look at the wider picture and the influence that Putin does have in parts of the Middle East that Western countries – and indeed this organisation – do not have. So we have to be realistic and, as Mr Farage said yesterday in this Chamber, we have to stop prodding the Russian bear.

name: Mario BORGHEZIO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the proclamations following the triumphant meeting of jihadist unity ring like a death knoll for the West and for Europe, all the more so since Europe is not saying anything about the danger of the warriors of Allah returning to Europe and the West after practising the noble profession of sckering Christians.  On the other hand, the entire intervention of the coalition does not seem to have even an understandable geopolitical strategy and, moreover, does not involve all the powers concerned. The creation of this huge enclave manned by twenty to thirty thousand highly motivated warriors of Allah totally upsets the geopolitical picture of the region. Now ISIS can also count on considerable complicity from local Sunni forces. Drone bombing is not enough, because there is no political action on the ground to hook up and bring together local allies.  In the meantime, the tragedy of the massacre, the death and martyrdom of our Christians in the East continues, to whose organizations today, thanks to French Members of the Front National and Italians of the Northern League, are being awarded the proposal to dedicate the Sakharov Prize. They are martyrs of the West, of Europe and of your values that you do not remember and do not defend.  Europe is also reflecting on the words of the Bishop of Aleppo, who reminds us that there is an international secret plan behind this advance of these united forces. West, Europe wake up. Wake up, Europe!

name: Esteban GONZÁLEZ PONS
text: Madam President, I am a Christian and have seen many crosses. What I never thought of in my life is that I would really see a man crucified. It's on the internet, available to anyone. There are also seven-year-old girls beheaded with knives. There are stoned women who took more than an hour to die. Groups of young men shot en masse for belonging to another race, for belonging to another religion, for belonging to another land. It's there; it's happening. It's called the Caliphate: it's the Caliphate of Terror. We are attending, through the internet and with the use of our own means of communication, an exhibition of indiscriminate, abominable, brutal violence; to an exhibition of violence that we cannot tolerate. They are not Muslims; it's not just terrorism: it's the Middle Ages knocking on our door again. There's no god who can think of what's going on. Terror can spread and minority persecution too; it can extend to Sudan, Nigeria, Mali, Burkina Faso, Europe itself, since on the map of the Caliphate is southern Europe. And, in fact, there are many Europeans fighting in the Caliphate — fighting in Syria, fighting in Iraq - which leads us to wonder what we are doing wrong to be exporting terrorists; Which forces us to ask ourselves when those here, who have gone to commit terrorism there, will return home to kill; which forces us to tell ourselves that we have to pursue them, capture them and make them available to Justice. Europe must support the international coalition, it must support the new Government of Baghdad. Europe must improve the aid we are providing to thousands and thousands of Christians and other refugee minorities, expelled, persecuted. Ladies and gentlemen, Madam President, fanaticism knows no borders, bigotry knows no times, bigotry is another very contagious, very dangerous virus, fanaticism is the plague of intelligence.

name: Richard HOWITT
text: Madam President, I join all colleagues in this House in proposing a resolution which expresses deep revulsion at the brutal killing spree which has been waged in the name of Islamic State and expresses full support for the international coalition to combat it. Events today add to the tragic history of conflict both in Iraq and in Syria, and my group believes that there can be no substitute for the creation of stable, pluralistic democracies in both countries with full respect for minority and human rights and no impunity for all those responsible for violations. As Socialists and Democrats we emphasise that many Muslims, in the Arab world and within our own borders, are appalled by this horrendous violence. Although there are those who would call this an Islamic State, let me state that this is a fight not against Islam, a great religion of peace, but one against terrorism. Our group says that European diplomacy must give priority to a regional solution, one that, despite the difficulties, must include the participation of Iran and of Saudi Arabia. I have to say I am appalled at the evidence given to the Committee on Foreign Affairs that actors within the European Union Member States are purchasing oil which directly finances Islamic State and I hope that the President-in-Office in his response will commit to the urgent investigation of this problem that our resolution demands. Finally let me express deepest sympathy for the death of the aid worker from my own Member State, Great Britain, David Haines. Humanitarian workers go into zones of conflict and of danger in the world motivated only by the wish to help others. Their only protection is the principles of international humanitarian law as enshrined in the Geneva Conventions. Since 2003 the United Nations has said that any attack on a humanitarian aid worker by a belligerent party is itself a crime of war. Humanitarian workers indeed represent the best of humanity, and the killing of David Haines and the threat against other humanitarian workers can only be described as an inhuman act. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Peter van DALEN
text: "blue card" question. Mr Howitt, I greatly appreciate your input and the words you have spoken. I share it, too. What has eluded me in your contribution is the way in which ISIS must be fought. We agree that we are dealing here with a brutal group of murderers. How would you like to tackle ISIS? I didn't hear you talk about that. Can you explain that again?

name: Richard HOWITT
text: blue-card answer. – I am a joint author of the resolution, one which supports military action as well as other measures, including the cutting-off of financing to IS and measures to work with the peaceful and moderate Muslim community to stop radicalisation and to support cooperation amongst European countries in the provision of arms and military assistance, to make sure that there is no duplication and that there is effective cooperation between us to stop terrorists coming back within borders and threatening our own populations too. My group stands full square with the other groups in support of this resolution and I thank him for giving me the chance to say that in more detail.

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: Madam President, the wave of terror inflicted by ISIS across Iraq and Syria continues to pose a major threat to global security. We have just witnessed the barbaric murder of the British aid worker David Haines. In the face of these high-profile acts of evil aimed at intimidating Western governments, we must also not forget the daily acts of barbarity that ISIS inflicts on Shia Muslims, Mandaeans, Turkmen, Yazidis and Christians. A number of NATO states have already been rightly arming the brave Kurdish Peshmerga which, with the US air strikes, has proven an effective way in halting some of the gains made by IS. I welcome yesterday’s announcement in Paris of a wide-ranging coalition made up of both Western and Arab nations against ISIS. Ahead of the Security Council meeting of 24 September we must also now find a way to extend these military actions against IS in Syria, particularly in Raqqa, their capital, as well as in Iraq where operations are currently going on. Lastly, the EU needs to address the issue of more than 1000 EU citizens who are fighting as ISIS jihadis and how we prevent their return to commit terrorist acts in our own countries. This threat unusually posed by ISIS is one rare issue in foreign policy which unites all major powers across the globe, both democratic and authoritarian. The USA, China, Russia, India and EU Member States are all united in absolutely repelling and being revolted by and opposing this awful menace to global security. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Bill ETHERIDGE
text: blue-card question. – In the interests of a grown-up approach to foreign policy, as we have both agreed that we need to have – going back to the mujahidin in Afghanistan and then going through the years even up to recently when Western governments, including, shamefully, our own in the UK, were talking about arming people who we know are actually fighting – do you think it is a good idea to be sending more armaments into this hotbed of fighting? Maybe we should perhaps stop giving these people weapons?

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: blue-card answer. – I fully support the arming of the Kurdish Peshmerga; I was the first in this House to call for that. I was delighted that that was responded to and that a number of Western governments including the British, the Americans and the Germans are indeed doing just that. The Kurdish Regional Government of Northern Iraq has proven to be a stable democratic and secular polity and they are absolutely united with the new Iraqi Government in Baghdad in opposing the ISIS menace. But of course I am totally against the arming of any kind of militia if there was any serious danger of arms leaking to Islamist jihadis.

name: Fernando MAURA BARANDIARÁN
text: Madam President, we cannot forget that, in any conflict — and this is no exception — there are situations that are forgotten, where minority groups suffer attacks of extreme cruelty, as they find the chaos generated by the situation in which they have been involved. These marginalized groups are certainly no less important because of this and deserve and need our attention. In this case, I would like to draw attention to the very serious situation of the nearly three thousand refugees in the Freedom camp. Refugees from the Freedom camp had to flee an oppressive and tyrant regime such as Iranian rule. And despite the support and recognition of the international community, they have suffered ongoing attacks by Iraqi al Maliki forces remote-directed from Tehran. Since their arrival at the camp in August 2012, these Iranian citizens have been enduring very long restrictions, which have intensified to intolerable levels since last August, when Iraqi forces, taking advantage of the chaos generated by the rise of the Islamic State, further tightened the rope around the neck of refugees, by blocking fuel supplies , food and medicine. Medical blockage is probably the most tragic and outrageous. In the past month, patients with cancer and other serious illnesses — in several terminal cases — have been repeatedly denied the necessary treatment and medical care. Before this situation escalates, or even before the massacre of fifty-two Iranian refugees, which took place in September last year in the Ashraf camp at the hands of Iraqi security forces and commandos from Tehran, I would like to call for the rights of these refugees not to be forgotten under the cloak of a serious situation but not to hide equally worrying situations.

name: Michel REIMON
text: Madam President! We are all very much in agreement on the rejection of ISIS. However, the resolution also warns against thinking only in the short term and says that we should address this problem in the longer term. I was in Iraq in August and visited the refugee camps there. Four million people have been driven from their homes and villages in the region. This problem will not be gone if ISIS is defeated. I spoke to a father my age. He has two daughters and said: "I have two little girls here in a refugee camp. If the ten years have to live in this camp, I will try everything to bring them to Europe so that they have a future." As a father, I understand that he behaves like this. We in the European Parliament, where we do not have to make daily policy but can think long-term, must also think about how we can help this region to rebuild over the next ten years. We must work for programmes that make this reconstruction possible. Only then will our neighbourhood be possible in peace with this region. Only then can we actually provide aid.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, humanity often believes that mistakes can be remedied by repeating them. Colleagues, ISIS is a very different threat than we've seen so far. It is not just an international of Islamic extremism, it even proposes the pseudo-rebirth of the caliphate, a perverse model of brutality and fanaticism, dramatically attractive to many frustrated young people.  This bloody nightmare arises from the superficiality of those who felt in the Persian Gulf and elsewhere that it was useful for bringing down Syria. But Assad, with cold political calculation, allowed him to operate for a long time undisturbed in the East and focused on other countries, with the other rebels, with the hope of one day presenting us with the choice: who do you want, us or the terrorists?  The road to fragile Iraq at risk of Balkanisation was cleared. Is it by chance that these fanatics, riding on the resentment of the Sunnis, declare that they want to cancel the Sykes-Picot agreements and the unfortunate partition of that Treaty of Sèvres that ignored tribal cultures, ethnic identities and theological divisions of Islam? Anyone who is under the illusion that this time a solution can be found, hypocritical as it is bloody, with massive bombing and the support of local factions is mistaken. He is wrong because the iraqi army, which is corrupt and now known for leaks and abandonment of weapons and vehicles, will not be enough, and ISIS obviously thanks.  Nor will the Iraqi Kurds be enough if we do not have the courage to recognise that the issue of Kurdistan, of the whole of Kurdistan, is calling for a solution at last. Only the United Nations, even within its limits, has the authority and impartiality to intervene by creating humanitarian corridors and preventing further massacres, but we must accept that new stable borders in the Middle East should be discussed again, allowing its peoples to determine themselves freely, otherwise the same tragic mistake will continue to be repeated indefinitely as those who first armed the Afghan mujahedeen against the Soviet Union and then had to face the birth of Al-Qaeda. Of those who justified wars by claimed the existence of weapons of mass destruction and instead indirectly created armies of destruction of human rights.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: Madam President, the results of the interventions of the European Union, the United States of America and NATO, which have been intervening in Iraq, Libya, Syria for years and leaving behind hundreds of dead, injured and refugees drowning in the Mediterranean, as well as ethnic and religious divisions, are well known. At the same time, monopolies treasure. These forces and their allies, Saudi Arabia and Qatar, which have recruited, financed and reinforced thousands of so-called jihadists, today, as unsolicited saviours, are calling with willing troops, supposedly to confront them. They project these pretences to control energy sources and transport routes. The people of Iraq and the peoples of the region to spoil their plans and, with their own struggle, not to enlist with any part of the bourgeoisie, to become the same owners of the wealth they produce.

name: Tunne KELAM
text: Madam President, we face the challenge of a most serious international crisis with hundreds of thousands driven from their homes, borders between states having ceased to exist, and genocide committed against civilians, religious and ethnic groups. Among these groups are many of the oldest Christian communities in the region who are now treated as foreigners to be killed or ousted. We have to really perceive what is happening. People are being indiscriminately murdered, tortured, sold as slaves and forced to flee in masses. To counter this new level of terrorism and crimes against humanity, declarations do not suffice. We need concrete actions, efficient international coordination, and also the use of force, because terrorists can be contained only by united political will and better arms. The American airstrikes have made a difference but it is not enough. Yesterday eight Christian leaders in Iraq called for the deployment of international troops on the ground, because airstrikes by themselves cannot defeat terrorists who are fighting among the local population. As a minimum, the international community must create safe havens in Iraq and Syria where refugees could have security and minimal assistance. At the moment the main issue is to assist refugees and repel terrorists, but our next commitment and responsibility is to ultimately guarantee the return of Christian communities and all traditional minorities to their place of origin, so that they can resume living there in dignity, equality and safety, freely practising their religion. Finally, it is crucial to strike at the financial supplies of IS. Substantial resources come to them from the illegal sale of oil – it is estimated USD 2 billion a day – from the occupied areas of Iraq and Syria. It is sold below the market price and also reaches EU countries. We call for EU sanctions targeting all intermediaries, beneficiaries and governments, as well as companies involved in the transportation, refinement and selling of oil stolen by IS, parallel with clamping down on illegal financial flows. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Paul RÜBIG
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Mr Kellam, I would like to thank Mr Kellam for his work, My question relates to the Christians who had to flee there and had to leave their houses and belongings behind. Do you see an opportunity that communication and public relations in Iraq could perhaps create an awareness that they do not have to leave their own country, their homeland, in the long term and only have a future as refugees? Do you see an opportunity to perhaps achieve something here with communication work in Iraq?

name: Tunne KELAM
text: blue-card answer. – This is one of the points of my message: that we need to prepare the ground and networks, and how we guarantee the future of these communities. We cannot allow a state of affairs in which we just recognise them as additional refugees who will settle abroad. We need to concentrate our efforts – and that should be international efforts – to help return them to the places where they have been living.

name: Ana GOMES
text: Iraq has serious governance dysfunctions that have facilitated the progression of the so-called Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant, but we cannot overlook the impact of the brutal confrontation between the Syrian people and the murderous regime of Baschar al-Assad on the offensive of this non-State terrorist organization, let alone islam.  The new Iraqi government must be representative of Iraq's political, ethnic and religious diversity and must give priority to eradicating the sectarianism that has paralyzed governance. It was unable to meet the most basic needs of the population, in particular by outline ing and handing over the Sunni minority to the fanatical opportunism of so-called IS.  The European Union - and not just some Member States - must engage in an international coalition that, properly supported by international law, operationalises a counter-terrorism strategy involving military, technical and political support in training Iraqi forces and others in the region determined to combat this threat. It is essential that the States of the Union articulate themselves in a common position demonstrating, on the ground and in the diplomatic arena, that the Union acts in coordination. The threat posed by IS criminals does not only strike Christian and Aziri minorities, Kurds, Assyrians and others, and the Shiite and Sunni populations in Iraq and Syria, it is a threat to civilization and global security. On the political front, the European Union must not fail to seek cooperation with Iran and hold back - from Turkey to the Gulf partners - those who in these countries instigate sectarianism on the basis of isis's bloodthirsty ideology and to it send financial, military, logistical and other support. The fight against IS cannot also serve to further marginalise the Syrian tragedy on the European agenda. The fight against IS is the end of the bloody conflict in Syria.  Finally, the fight against radicalisation within the European Union must be another one of our references. We have a European security strategy, an internal security strategy, an anti-terrorist strategy, but we do not yet effectively face the problem of radicalisation and recruitment. Our unemployed youth, excluded and exposed to recruiters' networks. This is the priority, it's time to act.

name: Bas BELDER
text: It is worth noting clearly here that ISIS threatens Europe as much as religious and ethnic minorities in Syria and Iraq. For it is inconceivable that the thousands of young jihadists from Western countries who are currently sowing death and destruction on the side of ISIS in Syria and Iraq will suddenly cease their terrorist activities upon their return to the countries of origin. In addition, the territory of the Islamic State can serve these Salafist jihadists as a base and refuge at the same time. Such circulation is life-threatening! Council, what joint strategy have the EU Member States concerned developed against ISIS and its European networks? Finally, two points on the countless displaced and persecuted Iraqi displaced Christians. Firstly, they have historically belonged in the Two-Stream Country. Secondly, they are rightly now asking for direct protection on our part. Right away! I spoke to them a few hours ago. It's almost too late! This is our responsibility!

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: Madam President! After the murder of two American journalists and the violent death of the British aid worker David Haines, it has also become clear to everyone in Europe what Yazidis, Aramaeans, Shiites and Christians are going through in the region. The barbaric ideology of the Islamic State, which is forcibly intervening, is despicable, despicable, and it must be combated. I am therefore pleased that progress has been made at the Paris conference, that there is a determination, particularly on the part of the United States and France, with reconnaissance flights, to help with airstrikes in a very practical way. I would like the United Kingdom to be involved. And I would like my own country – i see this differently from colleagues who have spoken here – to do the same, so that Germany also participates, and not just with arms supplies. We have seen in the past that such arms deliveries are often directed against those who make the arms deliveries with the best of intentions. I think that is wrong. I think it is right to support the Iraqi forces, as well as the Iraqi Government, in protecting the integrity of their territory. An attempt must also be made to make the United Nations more accountable. Resolution 2710 was considerably too weak. I do not know what was decisive for this, but the discussions were certainly not enough to achieve a good result and a strong mandate from the United Nations. The emir of Qatar is visiting Berlin today and has said that Qatar does not support the Islamic State financially. I'm happy about that. There is no reason not to believe him. But then I call on the state, the emir of Qatar, also to ensure that other Islamist movements in the Arab world are not funded from Doha. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: James CARVER
text: blue-card question. – Herr Lambsdorff, would you prefer to see military input coming from an EU context, or would you prefer to see it in context of Member States through their NATO obligations?

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Thank you for the question. We are not currently in a position to provide a military response from an EU context. That is the reality. However, I would clearly prefer this. However, as long as this is not the case, the Member States must act in their individual responsibility as members of the United Nations, not as members of NATO.  It is not an attack on NATO territory. In this respect, I see here a responsibility for the protection of the Charter of the United Nations, but not for the protection of the North Atlantic Treaty. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Emmanouil GLEZOS
text: "blue card" question. No one talked about the reason he created it. We are all forgetting the military intervention of the United States, NATO and, unfortunately, the European Union. And you continue to call for armed intervention and for peoples who are oppressed and lose their rights as peoples, and you continue to call for the strangulation of human rights and minorities.

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Mr Glezos, I would like to thank Mr Glezos for his work, It is possible to go back a long way in research into the causes. It is possible to go back to the Sykes-Picot Agreement and the state order in the Middle East. But I think the immediate cause was indeed the little inclusive governance of the last Iraqi prime minister, who systematically favored the Shia over the Sunnis, which has led many Sunni families and clans to join ISIS, which they would certainly not otherwise do. In the current situation, it is now crucial that the political process in Iraq also offers a new perspective for the Sunnis. I believe that the new Prime Minister has taken the first right steps in this regard.

name: Mike HOOKEM
text: Madam President, I would like to start by asking the House to join me in sending our condolences and prayers to the family of David Haines, recently murdered by ISIS, and also our hopes of a speedy return for Alan Henning, the hostage currently threatened by Islamic State. Since its rise in 2012, ISIS has been committing acts of barbarity and inhumanity not seen since Roman times: beheadings, rape, crucifixion, massacres, persecution of minorities and the imposition of a twisted variant of Sharia law typify this brutal terrorist organisation. The simple fact is that now, through government failure to tackle home-grown extremism, Britain is now directly threatened by Islamic State.  In the Middle East the West has long been seen as the ‘bad guys’, mainly due to the actions of Bush Sr, Bush Jr and Blair. However we now have the opportunity to change this by dealing with the threat of ISIS, a group that now presents a bigger risk to world security than any other single actor at this moment.  It is absolutely necessary for us to act with the utmost haste to destroy ISIS on both the national and international level, and no half measures can be taken. I am very pleased to see that the other Arab States are supporting the US-led multinational effort to stop the spread of this cancer in its tracks. It is only through cooperation that we can hope to build lasting friendships in the region, tackle these threats to world security and defeat home-grown extremism. I also call on this Parliament to vote in favour of any amendment condemning persecution by ISIS and to support national governments in their actions to tackle this problem. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: question posed by raising the blue card. - Madam President, I have only a short, brief question. You're talking about destroying ISIS, I'd like to know how you're destroying it, I'm underestepping the destruction, ISIS, you imagine.

name: Mike HOOKEM
text: blue-card answer. – Simply by the Arab nations getting in with the US-led forces, maybe forces on the ground, also bombing. This ISIS is a cancer that must be crushed, and crushed swiftly.

name: Bruno GOLLNISCH
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, many of the men and women who know you are turn out to be ingenuous when these issues of diplomacy and geopolitics come into our public debates because, as the former archbishop of Mosul said yesterday, right here, the so-called Islamic State in Iraq and the Levant is not a spontaneous generation whose where we do not know where. The origins are much deeper, including textual justifications alas drawn from the Koran or hadiths.    In the name of freedom of movement and belief, you have imposed tolerance without borders and refused to talk about the problem of the rise of radical Islamism showing its most heinous face today in the world and even in Europe. We have been asked to support regime overthrows in Iraq, Libya or the attempted Syrian revolt. The military forces of our states have organized or organized arms deliveries and war formations to the militias and terrorist groups that must be fought.  Recognize today that the Islamist organization enjoys financial support, probably from Qatar or Saudi Arabia, which according to the world's richest terrorist organization with more than $2.300 million available.  Today, we seem to be heading towards the revelation in the public square of the purchase by some members of the Union of oil from reserves or drilling controlled by ISIL via Turkish networks. That is what Mr. Howitt was referring to. This scandal must end as soon as possible, the Arab League must take responsibility and these barbarians must be crushed.

name: Michèle ALLIOT-MARIE
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, not to allow the situation in Iraq and Syria to escalate, to act in an effective and coordinated way against ISIS, is a moral requirement for us, but it is also a political necessity.  It is a moral requirement because a group, in the name of religious perversion, pursues from its murderous fanaticism all those who do not share its madness. Christians first, on whom I drew the attention of the President of our Parliament on 22 July and then several times in August, by asking him for an exceptional meeting of our Parliament on this subject. I'm sorry I wasn't heard. But also on moderate Muslims, on foreigners but also on nationals of these countries. And we, in the name of our values, cannot allow this to happen, we must act, not just in words but in a concrete way, by allowing people to also stay at home because it is not a question of having countries that become monoreligious, which could only lead to additional tensions. That is why it is also a political necessity for us to act because this fundamentalism feeds and encourages war between the Western world and the Muslim world. It pushes terrorists to act against our nationals wherever they are in the world and against our countries. I think it should be made clear here that no country is immune from terrorist acts, whether large or small, whether it is in the north or south of Europe, whether it has acted in this or that circumstance or that it has not. No one is safe and that is why everyone should act. A political summit, a sporting meeting, a religious event are, in the eyes of terrorists, the ideal place to act because what they are looking for is probably less to kill than to have media coverage. And they know how to use communication very well. We do need, together, to have the necessary needs. I say "together," which means that some countries, which always rely on others for military action, may also have to understand that they must also make financial efforts.  And then we must fight the Islamic caliphate, not ourselves as Westerners, because we would fit into the will of the terrorists to create this general conflict between the Western world and the Muslim world, but we really have to involve moderate Muslim countries. Not just in words, they must now really intervene in this action. It is up to our diplomacy to convince them.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: Madam President, first of all, the situation in Iraq and Syria today — conflicts, instability and the alarming and terrible emergence of the Islamic State and its expansion — can only be understood after the gradual breakdown of states in the area, a decomposition which is also linked, after the last decade, to the international action that has taken place on Iraq , and that can be remembered. The current situation and the Islamic State not only cause loss of human life, sectarianism and the fight against minorities, but also cause the instability of our mesh of international cooperation and the international order, and insecurity in our territory. The international community must fight the Islamic State, no doubt, in the political, civil and humanitarian spheres of humanitarian aid in the area, but remembering that ending the Islamic State will not achieve our ultimate goal in the area, which is to reconcile an absolutely battered and divided country, such as Iraq, and initiate a peace process in a country in a terrible civil war... (The Chair withdrew the floor to the speaker)

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking It is our duty to defend the Christians killed and all those who die because of religious hatred. But also, as politicians, we should ask why this is happening, because the European Union has supported (this is the truth) those people who are politically responsible for this today. Prime Minister Maliki, who, after all, is responsible for not being able to bring order there, is, in a sense, politically guilty of what is happening at the moment and in Iraq and Syria, and guilty of the deaths of those thousands of people who die there. It is not just about Christians, it is worth mentioning Iranian refugees who are also discriminated against. After all, there are many such cases.  Nevertheless, in the end, I would like to stress very strongly the need to defend Christians. It is our duty as Europeans, as representatives of individual countries derived from the Christian tradition.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Mr. President! Our values are not their values, nor will they be. Do not be under any illusions, ladies and gentlemen. We all, or many of us, know these gruesome images that take us out of this region, where children with their heads are playing football. That is something we cannot allow. An Austrian newspaper has headlined: "ISIS – Austria is a terror hotspot." Austria is a relatively small country, as you know. There are assumptions that we have about 200 fighters in Syria. These are people with Austrian citizenship. We are not only talking about the fighters, but there are also many supporters of ISIS in Austria. And across Europe, of course, these figures are even more dramatic. More than 2,000 fighters are believed to be believed to be fighters. We have imported the problem ourselves with uncontrolled mass immigration. The European IS fighters will come back. Don't be under any illusions. Only green left-wing extremists, such as Reimon, who has now proposed locking FPOe politicians into a basement with these fighters, see this differently. So this is green first-class solution competence, as we see it here. These fighters are the first to be stripped of their citizenship. We must not turn a blind eye to this huge problem that the return of these fighters in Europe, in Austria, will present us with.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Mr. President, at the beginning, I would like to extend my condolences to the family of David Haines, his wife and daughter who are our fellow citizens in Croatia. Footage of his brutal execution is further evidence of ISIS' criminal policy. The criminal organisation is now increasingly referred to only as the Islamic State, suggesting that it does not want to confine itself only to Iraq and Syria, but to have the dream of establishing a caliphate in a wider area that includes some of the Member States of the European Union. Perhaps one of the best answers to this folly was the Mufti of the Islamic Community in Croatia, Aziz Efendija Hasanovic, who said ISIS is a mockery and disgrace to the entire Islamic world. Mufti Hasanovic advocated tolerance, dialogue and co-operation between Christians and Muslims. Unfortunately, however, these calls have no resusses in those areas of Iraq and Syria where Christians are persecuted simply because they are Christians.  To the persecution of Christians, Mr. President, it sometimes seems that some in Europe are indifferent. Indifferent to the thousands of people who are designated Christians, as Nazarenes have this sign that you see here specially marked and that is why they are also a target for ISIS, that is why they have been put before the choice to convert to Islam or they will lose their lives. What are we doing about it in the European Parliament?  Today, colleagues and colleagues had to have a discussion about the situation in Iraq and Syria, but with a particular focus on the persecution of Christians. Why are we ashamed of that? Of course we have to talk about all minorities, about every endangered man, but why are we ashamed to mention in the debate or in the resolution the name of christians? Are we ashamed of Christians in Iraq and Syria? Whether you are a Christian or not, whether you are a believer or not, if you are on the side of man, if you are on the side of humanity today you must be on the side of Christians in Iraq and Syria.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Mr. President! It is very attentive that you are letting me speak.  I have a question of principle. Obviously, it may have escaped your esteemed attention and that of your staff that I signed up with a 'blue card'.  Can you explain to me why it was not possible to actually perceive this 'blue card'? Why did I not get this opportunity to ask a colleague from you? Was it because you didn't see me? Was I too quiet? Was the "blue card" too little blue, or are there other reasons why you couldn't give me the floor while I was pointing out?

name: Olli REHN
text: Thank you for your speech. I'll mark it for information. The President, who chairs the plenary session, will assess whether we are on schedule and how much we are able to give the blue card.

name: Vincent PEILLON
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, to hear our debates, the fight against barbarism, against fanaticism, against terrorism, is for the vast majority of us a necessity and that is why I wholeheartedly support our draft resolution.  But at the same time, and some have already mentioned this, we are obliged to consider today that the fight against terrorism does not make a sufficient foreign and security policy. In recent years, the feeling we have is that we have responded on a case-by-case. Yesterday's friends are today's enemies who will, perhaps, be tomorrow's friends. And we see that the situation - we intervened in Iraq, we intervened in Libya, we are present in Syria - is deteriorating year after year.  If we look at this situation and those who have called for a long-term political solution, then we are forced to ask questions that we have not asked for a number of years. We need to define a strategy for Europe that is both a coherent and comprehensive strategy for the Near and The Middle East. How are we talking to Iran, what are we doing today about Turkey, what is going on with Saudi Arabia? I hope, since a new Commission will be set up, since we are starting the work, that this strategy will now be defined because otherwise we will go from Charybde to Scylla.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Mr. President, I believe we are all shocked by ISIS atrocities whose scope is increasing day by day. But unfortunately, only a few realize that our countries are also part of this crime. I would not take this into previous international interventions in this area that have left behind the situation they left behind, but I want to put emphasis and draw your attention to the fact that our countries have done too little to keep Muslims living in the European Union away from this bloodshed.  Media reports are reporting the death of a 15-year-old girl, an Austrian national originally from Bosnia and Herzegovina, who was taken to Syria without her parents' knowledge from Austria. How is it possible for minors on our soil to be enlisted en masse for the purpose of international terrorism and to go to the other side of the world without the knowledge or entourage of their parents? And what are our countries doing to stop it? These are questions we have to ask ourselves and more importantly, we need to act urgently to put an end to this horror.

name: Monika HOHLMEIER
text: Mr. President, dear colleagues! Not only will we have to deal with the situation in the region of Iraq and the surrounding regions in Syria, etc., but above all we will have to deal with how we deal with the difficult phenomenon of transnational fighters, also known as foreign fighters. First of all, it is necessary to find out what the reasons are, why ordinary young people who have come to us not only through mass immigration – as claimed – but who are partly born here, who grew up with us, are turning to terrorism that brings with it unbelievable brutality.
