For example, we now have a young man who killed himself at the age of twenty, blew himself up and killed 50 other people. Analyzing these backgrounds is necessary to prevent Salafists and ISIS terrorists from gaining further access. It is also necessary to strengthen intelligence. It is necessary to impose bans on the departure of well-known Salafists and terrorism-prone people. It is necessary that we have an exchange of information of the most intensive nature and close cooperation between the security authorities and the constitutional protection of the Member States with European institutions, because we will be faced with thousands of foreign fighters in the near future. We will have to look at how we better protect and protect our citizens in an optimised way.

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: Mr. President! The events in Syria and northern Iraq are not warlike conflicts, as they unfortunately happen again and again. The systematic terror of the Islamic Caliphate is a total break with almost everything we know so far. It is therefore right to take a firm stand against these deliberate breaches of taboos. With its inhumane methods, ISis terror is trying to establish a totalitarian regime and to end the centuries-old coexistence of people of different ethnic and religious backgrounds in the region. Christians and other religious groups are persecuted and expelled, and while we Europeans have just enjoyed our summer holidays, tens of thousands of Yazidis were trapped in the mountains of northern Iraq without water or food. Thousands died and there would almost have been a terrible genocide. The people of this region therefore deserve our attention. In northern Iraq and Syria, the future of our civilisation is at stake, and by that I am not just talking about Europe.

name: Marek JUREK
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking Ladies and about! We must take into account two elementary facts in our policy towards Iraq and Syria. Firstly, that Christians in the region, in all countries, are a minority, they are the only religious group that is of a minority nature in all the countries in which they live. So in practice, they can only count on our help, only on the interest of the Christian world.  The second element is that the priority of all the actions that we will take, no matter what their nature, must always be the humane protection of vulnerable communities and, in particular, Christian communities, which can only count on us. This sign is not a sympathetic smile, it is the letter N, which are marked the houses of those who are deseased for extermination or extermination. For the tormentors, this is a sign indicating sacrifice, but for all of us it is a sign of crying out for our help.

name: Eleni THEOCHAROUS
text: Mr President, the intention and methods of islamic fanatics to create the global caliphate - the state of terror as has typically been said - have been known for a very long time and muslim fanatics are not born but are created through their training in Islamic schools, in priesthoods, through the brainwashing they have endured for a long time. Unfortunately, no deterrent measures were taken. The reactions of the international community were based on very poor and amateurish assessments and an underestimation of the Islamic threat. Without, of course, meaning any rivalry with the millions of good Muslims who are also victims of Islamic terrorism, the caliphate of terror. Classic examples of bad practices are the deadly wars in Afghanistan, Iraq, Libya, which brought neither security, stability nor peace. I do not believe that the equipment of the various groups will be effective if it is not accompanied by other measures. The much-publicd Turkish Islamic model has proved particularly dangerous and the possible role of Turkey and Qatar in funding ISIS has already been revealed - the day before yesterday. ISIS is also directly threatening Europe, and I must tell you that it is not 'very close' to Europe, as Archbishop Babylon recently told us when he came and spoke to the European Parliament, meaning the threat posed by Lebanon. It is within Europe itself, Mr President, because the Muslim population in Cyprus has already increased dramatically. Mr. Erdogan calls on local authorities to allow Muslim immigrants, i.e. settlers, to arrive seamlessly in occupied Cyprus and that Islamic schools, Islamic priesthoods, places are brainwashed by young children.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: Mr President, whilst the causes that led to the birth of ISIS are complex, and responsibility for them may even lie far beyond the Middle East, the threat of ISIS nevertheless remains very serious and substantial. Its murderous onslaught against minorities and sectarian groups, women and children, has been deeply disturbing. ISIS has now warned that Mr Henning, one of my constituents in the North-West, would be next. Mr Henning is a good compassionate man who went to Syria to help those suffering. We cannot allow ISIS to continue with this barbarity. Muslims everywhere are appalled that these crimes are being carried out in the name of their faith. In fact a letter signed by Muslim imams and leaders is going out today asking for the release of Mr Henning. ISIS’s false ideology and narrative must be confronted. It is imperative that a broad coalition including the Arab countries be put in place to tackle the menace of ISIS.

name: Mirosław PIOTROWSKI
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking In the motion for a resolution tabled by the Group of European Conservatives and Reformists on the situation in Iraq and Syria, we are once again turning our attention to persecution, namely the kidnapping and killing of Christians in these countries. The situation of Christians has deteriorated significantly since Islamic terrorists built their state in the region. The United States opposes this militarily, and the European Union should coordinate with them. In the motions for many Resolutions of the European Parliament, Christians are mentioned as one of the exterminated religious groups, and it should be recalled that they are the most persecuted group in the world, and this should resonate in our Parliament's joint resolution.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: Mr President, why should Europe particularly defend the Christians of the East? For historical reasons, first of all, but also because with the Christians of the East, we Europeans share the same soil of civilization. It is not a religious issue, it is a philosophical question, because today it is the jihadists who are the enemies of a certain idea of Europe. A Europe that invented free will, invented freedom of thought, freedom to believe but also - and this is probably a hallmark of Europe - the freedom not to believe. And the jihadists don't want it.  Then, let us say it in this Chamber, if we Europeans do not defend the Christians of the East, who in the world will defend them? What are the solutions? Of course, military. To annihilate the Islamic State militarily and prevent it from harming and, as such, ladies and gentlemen, shame on all those Member States of the Union unable to line up a single plane, a single soldier to defend their values.  Of course, strengthen our humanitarian aid but, at the same time, stop these totally idiotic policies which, under the guise of wanting to protect the Christians of the East, want to move them to Europe or elsewhere. The Christians of the East are at home in Iraq, they are at home in Syria. That's where they have their homes, that's where they have their values. That's where we have to defend them. Of course, give them the means to weigh in on their future when peace returns. And as such, we must have in mind the Lebanese political model, which is certainly imperfect, but which gives each religious group guarantees of political representativeness.  Finally, to those who think that the Christians of the East must fend for themselves in their corner and who have not seen the genocide that is taking place, I mean the following very simple thing: if you do not want to act for the Christians of the East, act for you! Because Europe is at war with the Islamic State, including at home. Look at the number of young Europeans leaving, indoctrinated, going to war.  Ladies and gentlemen, in defending the Christians of the East, we also defend who we are.

name: Kati PIRI
text: The barbarism of the Islamic State knows no bounds. The mass executions, the forced marriages and the public beheadings of journalists disgusted every right-thinking person. This terrorist organisation is diametrically opposed to the values that we value, the core values of Europe, of freedom and democracy. It is absolutely important that ISIS is stopped. The people of Iraq and Syria are suffering enormously from the reign of terror and, moreover, the further advance of this group is also a threat to the security of Europe. In addition to the military strategy, financial flows to this terrorist group must also be cut off. ISIS' main source of income is the occupied oil fields in Syria and Iraq. To my shock, the EU Ambassador to Iraq was in this European Parliament two weeks ago and she said that there are European Member States buying up this oil from Iraq! So please clarify this from the Council and the Commission: which European Member States are funding ISIS in this way and will this be stopped immediately?

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Mr. President! First of all, a question: where is the EU Foreign Minister, Catherine Ashton, in this important debate on the horrors of Iraq and Syria? Last week, the Patriarch of Baghdad said here in Parliament what the minorities there need: they need military protection. We cannot offer them that as a Parliament. But we can do something, and I believe that we must do the same: we must shake up the public. That is why we, as the ECR Group, are proposing to dedicate this year's Sakharov Prize to the persecuted Christians in Iraq. We would like to award the prize to: Professor Mahmoud Al-Asali, a Muslim intellectual. As a Muslim, he put himself before the Christians, and he was murdered by ISIS for it. Let us posthumously award him the prize as a martyr! And to Louis Raphael Sako, the patriarch of Baghdad. He is the face of persecuted Christians in Iraq and thus the voice of persecuted Christians in the Arab world. I would ask colleagues from all political groups to support this proposal. I am pleased that The PPE-DE Group has also tabled this proposal, Mrs Anna Zaborska. As we meet here, people are murdered for their faith. Let's stand up against it, no matter what or whom we believe in.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: What we are seeing in Iraq and Syria is the genocide of Christian communities. Terrorists who call themselves the Islamic State deprive Christians of their fundamental rights, drive them out of their homes, kill, torture, kidnapp, rape women and make them slaves. Christians become refugees because of faith and religious beliefs. The right to freedom of expression and religion is part of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights. However, even deeper in the foundations of European unity, we find Christian values that have shaped morality, social relations and public institutions of all European nations for two millennia. Solidarity with members of christian communities in Iraq is not a gesture of goodwill, it is our duty. Yes, I believe that we have a duty to protect Christians in Iraq and Syria, they only have us. If we don't stop them, no one else will. It is not enough to help them survive the winter, our aim must be for Iraqi and Syrian Christians to be able to return home. If they need defence, protection of peacekeepers, we must provide them with it. I welcome the formation of an international coalition that can take action against them. However, let us also think about the need for reconciliation, because without it it is not possible to establish stability in the region. Only reconciliation can heal relations between Muslims and Christians. And the path to reconciliation leads through inspiring personal examples. Therefore, dear colleagues, I would ask you to support the nomination of Patriarch Sak and Professor al-Asalí for the Sakharov Prize with your signature. Their life stories contain a message of reconciliation and mutual respect that appeals to both Iraqi Christians and Muslims.

name: Demetris PAPADAKIS
text: Mr President, the crisis in Iraq and Syria has reached the fore and we cannot whistle indifferently. Coordinated action is needed to counter the Islamic State – the greatest threat to civilized humanity. We must react effectively and thoughtfully to avoid mistakes of the past taking into account the specificities of the region, and the racial and religious characteristics of the population. Generalized approaches and recipes lead to devastating mistakes, as was done with the so-called Arab Spring. However, there is no effective European response that does not extend to Syria. Initiatives and cooperation should be needed to deal with jihadists. We must immediately redefine our priorities and not rule out, at the out of the out of the day, even temporary tolerance of the Assad regime in order to deal with the major danger, the barbarity of the Islamic State. At the same time, the states that support it must be isolated. Extremists and blind terrorism must be combated as a carcinoma that must be eradicated along with the entire network.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Thank you, Vice President Rehn, Dear Representative of the Italian Presidency, Mr. Della Vedova, Dear Mr. Vimont, today's debate on this extremely difficult political and security crisis in the Middle East that puts at the very heart of our considerations and our resolution the consequences of a terrorist organization, namely the Islamic State, Iraq and Syria, which, with its moves that have not been seen so far, is unprecedented and atrocities committed by minorities. , and in particular over the persecution of Christians, and the overall destabilisation at the global level, has also put us as a European Union in a position of security to respond firmly and strongly.  Therefore, I also join in the great condemnation of all our colleagues of all that we have witnessed in the past few months, and I think it is up to us to support the conclusions of yesterday's conference in Paris, where it is quite clear that the solution to this problem cannot be the only political and diplomatic means. We have seen the brutal murders of two American journalists, unfortunately we have also seen the murder of David Haines, a British humanitarian, also a man who started his family in Croatia, and I send my condolences to his family here. These are all activities that are extremely unacceptable and require great engagement, namely coordinated engagement by the international community, and I believe that the United Nations, in particular the Security Council, must also react and authorise activities in Iraq and Syria.  Therefore, it is up to us in the weeks ahead to make the maximum effort to in place the global danger of ISIS to be addressed. The mistakes that were made in Iraq itself, and at the same time the influence of some other states on the former Government in Iraq, are partly responsible for the radicalization of Sunnis in Iraq and in this case there is a great expectation of a new government that must be much more inclusive and address this issue in a much more careful way.

name: László TŐKÉS
text: As a citizen of Romania, I know from my own experience what the atheist-nationalist policies of the infamous Ceausescu regime meant, which sought to homogenise the population of our multilingual and multi-religious country on the basis of the principle of "one nation, one language, one religion". Islamic fundamentalism, the extremist Sunni terrorist organization Islamic State, persecutes, eradicates and drives ethnic and religious minorities from their homelands like former totalitarian regimes, trying to force the people of the Middle East, Iraq and Syria into the monolithic order of the caliphate. The Islamic State's primary target is Christianity. The mass exodus of Christians in the Middle East as a result of the brutal violence of the scale of religious cleansing and genocide threatens to threaten the Christian community in the Middle East. Let us call the child by its name: in the vast majority of Islamic countries, it is a persecution of Christians at the level of state policy. No "political correctness" justifies minimizing or relativizing the persecution of followers of Christ. Its Christian roots and residual faith, as well as its conscientious and humane values, oblige a united Europe to stand in full solidarity in the defense of its persecuted brothers and sisters. That is what I am asking the President, the European Parliament.

name: Lars ADAKTUSSON
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratul It is important that we now take seriously the religious persecution that has been going on for over ten years. For let us remember: even before the Islamic State's invasion of Mosul, half of Iraq's Christians had been forced to flee the country. What has happened in recent months is that the situation has become acute, and therefore exceptional solutions are needed. One such solution is the realisation of a protected zone for the endangered minorities. With an internationally monitored protection zone, security would be increased – threatened groups could return home.  The organization A Demand for Action, founded in Sweden, has long worked for protected and protected zones. The founder of this organisation, Nori Kino, says: "Assyrians, Chaldeans, Syrians, Jezids and other ethno-religious groups must have a security zone. Not to vote for this is to vote for the rise of terrorism." The proposal for a closed zone is included in the EPP's motion for a resolution today. Unfortunately, it is deleted in the joint resolution. Socialists, Liberals and Greens blocked this proposal. Two points recur in their arguments. Firstly, this would require military action. Secondly, there is too much talk of vulnerable Christians. Against this background, it is relevant to ask social democrats, liberals and greens what their message is to those people who are currently fearing for their lives and who are appealing for our help with security and protection in northern Iraq. Of course, military action is needed to maintain a protected zone. Of course, Christians are in focus, but not just Christians. A protected zone would also provide protection for Yazidis and Shias.  I will vote in favour of the joint resolution, but At the same time I will continue to work towards a protected zone. To give up the fight for people's right to freely practise their religion would be to surrender to the rise of terrorism.

name: Agustín DÍAZ DE MERA GARCÍA CONSUEGRA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I present to you some facts and facts.  On the night of July 10, DAESH takes Mosul: five hundred thousand people—Christians, Muslims, Sunnis, Shia—flee hastily. At the end of July, DAESH, in Mosul, marks the houses of Christians with the letter "N" (Nasrani, "Christian") and those of non-Muslims with the letter "R" (rwafidh, "rejected"). Terrible religious purification begins: either they embrace Islam or they have to pay the jizya—the Islamic tax for Jews and Christians—or they die. Either they leave town or they're killed. On 6 August inhabitants of thirteen Christian cities on the plain of Nineveh flee in the face of the threat of imminent invasion of DAESH without any Kurdish protection, nor from their peshmerga. These are one hundred to one hundred and twenty thousand Christians out in the open. From one hundred to one hundred and twenty thousand Christians to forty degrees of temperature, in public spaces around the churches, desperate. Their women and their girls are, for DAESH, spoils of war, in the way of the Yahiliya, before the Islamic era. Constant violations of human rights are nothing more than a social pathology that derives from a fanatical ideology, from a false political Islam that aims to conquer and impose Islamic sharia as supreme law. It's about creating a caliphate through terror, fear, oppression, systematic purification and weapons. That's what we're up against. Either we stop them, or they'll follow their progress without limits. A breakthrough of terror, domination and death. We stand in solidarity today with so many innocent victims. We are all Christians, Turkmens, Yazidi, Kakais, Chabaquís and Azeri, as are James Foley, Steven Sotloff and David Haines. We hopefully greet Monday's Peace Conference and hope that true Islam and the West together, Mr President, will know and be able to tackle this horror. We defend Iraq's territorial integrity and want the displaced to return to the occupied territories, in conditions of dignity and security. And we want aid to be activated as soon as possible and urgently... (The Chair withdrew the floor to the speaker)

name: Brian HAYES
text: Mr President, I hope that this evening’s debate sends out a strong signal of support to the people of Iraq and Syria. This is about torture, oppression, murder, domination and a systematic attempt to extinguish religious minorities. We are key players in the region. We have a responsibility to work with the new Iraqi Government in all ways possible. Islamic State (ISIS) represents a threat not just to Iraq but also to the entire region. Clearly they will stop at nothing in fomenting their brand of fundamentalism, which is rotten to the core. Defeating ISIS is also about defeating those brainwashed young European citizens who participate as radical fighters in a part of the world that they know nothing about. I believe that a new opportunity exists to forge a better relationship with Iran. Despite obvious past differences between Iran and the European Union, and Iran and the United States, I believe we have a common objective now in attempting to destroy ISIS and in helping the Iraqi Government to rebuild their country. Iran is a key player in the region. The new President of Iran has repeatedly said that he wants to cooperate with the EU in fighting the violence and the extremism of ISIS. Iran’s border with Iraq is more than 1700 km long. Iran has officially welcomed the formation of the new Iraqi Government and backs the principle of Iraqi unity as a means of stabilising security in the region. In short, I believe that a new opportunity for détente exists between Iraq and the West.

name: Emil RADEV
text: After the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan and the weakening of al-Qaeda, we decided that we saw the light of democracy and calm in a region long associated with bloodshed and senselessly given human sacrifices. As a result, however, the international community chose not to notice the growing serious problems, especially in Iraq – the growing ethnic disparities, the corruption that dooms the common man to poverty, napy but unruly religious extremism. The terrorist group Islamic State was born precisely by the combination of these problems and their ignorance by the entire Western world. We only realized the threat when it personally affected us with the relentless execution of two Western journalists. Contrary to expectations, the launched air campaign against Islamic State may temporarily disarm, but not destroy, the organization. Planes and bombs can't change people's thinking, they can't feed them, they can't provide them with a perspective on the future. It is therefore necessary, together with military tactics and humanitarian aid already provided, for EU Member States and the European Commission to initiate a long-term development plan for Iraq developed in close cooperation with the international community and with the active involvement of local populations. Its aim is to create an alternative to Islamic State – through better education and economic prospects with European assistance, but also clear commitments by the Iraqi government for ethnic tolerance and stability. The battle against the Islamic State organization is only just beginning. As long and difficult as it is, it must be won for the sake of ordinary Iraqis.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Mr. President, I would like to point out that just as the Nazis designated the houses of Jews in World War II, and the rebel Serbs house Croats in the Homeland War, so ISIS denotes the houses of Christians in Iraq and Syria, the oldest countries of Christianity. Christians are being driven from their homes and genocide is being carried out against them. Christian girls are sold in markets for $100. Sexual violence, rape and recruitment of children, abductions, executions of Christians, forced convert to Islam have become a recognizable manuscript of ISIS.  After persevering for 2,000 years, Iraqi Christians were today driven into exile because the Islamic State, emerging from Al-Qaeda, had taken control of the territory. Jihadists don't just deal with Christians. They also deal with moderate Muslims. Therefore, it is not enough for the international community to note that the situation is poor. Concrete actions are needed. ISIS is the cruelest terrorist group in human history and is clearly non-negotiable. If we do nothing and our hands will be stained with the blood of Christians in Iraq and Syria. I call for action.

name: Janusz ZEMKE
text: Well, I would like to draw attention with full force to the fact that, unfortunately, our Western world has seen quite late the fact that the jihadists in Iraq and Syria today represent and will increasingly pose an absolutely mortal threat. It turns out that they are extremely ruthless towards different minorities, especially I am thinking of ethnic and religious minorities here. The truth is, however, that this problem cannot be solved in the long term by military action alone. Strong and real support for the local authorities is needed here. Things are simpler in Iraq, because we have a more stable government there today, but it is much more difficult in Syria. I think there is a serious problem here as to whether the fight against both this government and the jihadists should be supported at the same time. Never has a fight on two fronts at the same time failed.

name: Peter van DALEN
text: Today, together with a number of other colleagues, I am wearing a T-shirt that shows solidarity with Christians in the Middle East. On it is the N from the Arabic alphabet, the N of Nazarami, the followers of Jesus of Nazareth. With this symbol, the ISIS killers mark the homes of Christians when those houses and villages are captured. And then the Christians are given the choice to pay a huge tax or convert to Islam, otherwise they will be killed. This is a sign of solidarity with those Christians. Christians are fleeing, but we must continue to support them. This has to stop! Hence this T-shirt as a gesture of solidarity.

name: Diane DODDS
text: Mr President, we have witnessed a terrible evil in recent weeks. The murders of James Foley, David Sotloff and the British aid worker David Haines are truly barbaric. My thoughts and prayers are with their families, as well as with the family of Alan Henning – and Alan Henning himself, who continues to be threatened in the same way. This situation imperils not only the immediate region, but also the whole world. While media attention is focused on these barbaric actions, we must remember and give support to those who have suffered a long campaign of religious and ethnic cleansing, those who have faced the threat ‘convert or die’, and those who have suffered displacement and injury. Today, along with colleagues, I am displaying the translated word for Christian, a symbol used by Islamic State (IS) to mark out Christian homes during their killing rampages. We need action from the international community but the failure of the European Union is evident. It is disappointing that Baroness Ashton has not taken the time to contribute to today’s debate herself.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: Mr President, thank you for being able to say my name very well, and I thank my colleagues for today's debate. This debate was really one of the best I have experienced in my time as a member of this House. I just wanted to say one message at the end. More than 3,000 people, not 1,000, from the European Union, are said to be fighting in Syria or Iraq on the side of criminals who are making wartime genocide. And we should make it clear to them that no amnesty for criminals who kill citizens will simply be here, and that their return, with impunity, to the countries of the European Union is not possible.

name: Gilles PARGNEAUX
text: Mr President, Mr Presidents, yes, there is urgency, chaos is there, we are at war with Da'ech. Urgency to act, yes, but urgent to think - as my colleague Vincent Peillon has indicated - of a European strategy for the Near and Middle East. Urgency, yes, to support the international alliance that has been created. We should also welcome the initiative taken by the President of the French Republic, François Hollande, to organize a conference on security in Iraq last Monday in Paris.  The danger is immense, the threat is deadly, the creation of a Jihadistan in southern Europe is under way if we are not careful. As we know, there are terrorist groups in Egypt, Libya and Syria that have already pledged allegiance to Da'esh. Well, let's unite, let's work in unison to fight these terrorists and make this war relentless.

name: Benedetto DELLA VEDOVA
text: President-in-Office of the Council (on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission/ High Representative of the European Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy). - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to remind the House that Lady Ashton, the High Representative, is in New York for the important nuclear negotiations in Iran, which are due to end on 24 November and which are currently entering a critical phase.  I believe that the serious and important debate that has taken place has taken up and expanded many of the ideas contained in my initial speech, so I will be very brief. Certainly the Presidency joins in paying tribute together with all the victims of this dramatic crisis, to paying tribute to the prisoners who were recently murdered by ISIL and even more recently to the British and European citizen David Haines, who was a humanitarian worker in Syria just to do good and assist those in need. The Union will continue to support iraq's sovereignty and territorial integrity, to work to alleviate the suffering of all those trapped in the fighting in Iraq and Syria, and to assist neighbouring countries, especially Jordan, which are working to help the refugees. In today's debate, too, the European Parliament has strongly reaffirmed its role and its desire to ensure that Iraqis and Syrians, regardless of their religion or ethnicity, are not left to their tragedy. I have grasped the commitment of many of you, the desire for a greater and more direct commitment also in ensuring the defence of Christians in the East. I think that what we too are trying to do, by supporting those who are intervening, is a way of recognising and trying to protect the right to live freely of the Christians of the East who have lived in those regions that have been immemorial for a long time. This is the commitment of the Presidency of the European Union, which also welcomes the commitment of the individual Member States.

name: Olli REHN
text: The debate is closed. The vote is due tomorrow at 12 noon. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. –  Member States know very well the consequences of cleansing of regions for reasons of religion, ethnicity or any other ground. The ill-treatment of persons because they are of different religious beliefs is unacceptable irrespective of the religion they profess. The usurpation of power to persecute civilians is unacceptable. This concerns us all even though we may feel safe within our own countries. We are one world and equal human beings; the persecution of even one human being, irrespective of where and who he/she is and what religion he/she professes or which gender he/she holds, offends each one of us.

name: Eugen FREUND
text: Writing. – Recent events in Iraq and Syria are further evidence that the EU's foreign policy in the Middle East has not played its role accordingly. Much could have been prevented if the EU had intervened in good time. Once again, we must follow events, and although Europe has a closer link with this region, both geographically and historically, the us leadership is taken for granted. If the EU had put timely pressure on the (former) Iraqi government to represent all population groups accordingly, ISIS would not have been able to spread and play its murderous role. Likewise, the EU should not have watched the bloodshed in Syria for years, but should have used its strength and influence to ensure that President Assad could not constantly expand the cruel civil war. My hope now is for the new EU External Representative to identify conflict zones in good time and to bring in the diplomatic weight of the European Union accordingly in the future.

name: György HÖLVÉNYI
text: Writing. - Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank you for your support. Today's worst human tragedy is taking place far away, but still before our eyes in Iraq, as a result of the barbaric expansion of the Islamic State. Europe is also looking for ways to act, but it is finding the way hard. I would like to draw the attention of European leaders to the fact that dealing with the Crisis in Iraq is not a religious or ethical issue. An urgent international and European answer must be given to a question that threatens millions. In short, according to the International Charity, there are now 1.2 million Christian and non-Christian refugees and victims in the region. What they have in common is that they are threatened by the jihadists. These persecuted are looking at us, Europe with hope. We hear their cries for help every day. They cannot be disappointed in Europe today, be they Christians or non-Christians. And Europe cannot argue on religious issues. Life must be saved.  Nevertheless, we must say that christians are suffering the greatest persecution in Iraq today. A 2,000-year-old Christian culture may disappear before our eyes. Not only the Middle East, but the whole world can be poorer with an indigenous community. Once again, the expansion of the Islamic State means the permanent persecution and disappearance of Iraqi Christians today, in the early 21st century. Those fighting the Islamic State trust us. Their message is that they are fighting for us there in Iraq. Let Europe show courage and determination with concrete steps of solidarity. Thank you for your attention.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. ISIS stands for violence, intolerance and crime. In the eyes of ISIS, non-believers are lawless people. Hundreds of thousands are now on the run, including many Christians. And Europe was and is a defender of Christian values. Accordingly, it cannot just be an option for the EU to be more resolute in this regard. Rather, it is our duty to face our own values and roots. Nothing else is needed for the triumph of evil, but for good people to do nothing. But it is not only we who are encouraged to react. I miss the outcry of the Muslim world. If Mohammed is caricatured, their religious leaders call for retribution, but when Christians are executed en masse on the basis of their religion, nothing can be heard. I fear this is seen in some Muslim countries as a gentleman's offence, perhaps even in secret!

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. – In the short term, terrorist financing should be blocked and foreign fighters should be stopped, especially their return from where they came from. Those buying oil from terrorists took part in the murder of David Haines and other hostages.  In the long term, the most necessary is to create a development strategy for Iraq and the surrounding countries. Military victory over dictators is never enough in itself because it is easier to remove the top of the regime than the political, economic and social circumstances in which it was maintained. An almost continuous series of crises and conflicts from Ukraine through the Middle East to Mali is evident.  That is why I am committed to upgrading the existing global security system that was created as early as the middle of the last century, but is clearly not effective in stopping such accidents in dysfunctional states in the early 21st century. For example, analysts note that there are as many as five different wars going on in Syria at this point. The extremists are already very much felt in Libya with a tendency to spread terror all over North Africa from where we can expect even more desperate people to flee towards Europe and their suffering at sea.

name: Olli REHN
text: The next item is the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the situation in Libya (2014/2844(RSP)).

name: Benedetto DELLA VEDOVA
text: President-in-Office of the Council (on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission/ High Representative of the European Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy). - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in addition to the crises in Ukraine and the Middle East, which we discussed until a few minutes ago, the situation in Libya worsened and worsened in July and August. Libya, a country on the southern shore of the Mediterranean, is failing to end hostilities in its main cities, with a government in crisis struggling to fulfil its basic functions. As you know, parliament meets in Tobruk, 1 200 kilometres from the capital, while a parallel government and parliament are installed in Tripoli. The intervention of third countries in support of the two opposing camps aggravates the current division. The situation has reached the point where an increasing number of Libyans are talking about the plausible risk of civil war.  As stated in the conclusions of the European Council of 30 August, the European Union expresses its growing concern at the current violation of human rights and the humanitarian situation in the areas affected by the fighting, such as Benghazi and the Wershefana area. The alleged attacks on the civilian population and civilian targets are unacceptable and must stop immediately. The impact on regional security, including in Europe, is becoming increasingly tangible. The attacks in Algeria and Egypt, the perpetrators of which come from Libyan territory, as well as the unprecedented number of irregular migrants landing on the Italian and Maltese coasts, give a measure of the seriousness of the situation. Terrorism, trafficking in human beings and the proliferation of weapons are expanding against a background of a growing lack of legality. The situation is dramatic. And yet the vast majority of Libyans want an end to violence and a peaceful resolution of conflicts. Families mourn their dead, they don't want the fighting to continue. An increasing number of groups, including prominent tribes in the South, reject a choice of camp and call for a easing of tension. The situation in Libya has not reached an irreversible point, but time is playing against it. The international community has mobilised in support of a peaceful solution to the crisis. A ministerial conference is being held today in Madrid at which Libya's neighbours in Europe and Africa discuss the issues at stake and the possibility of concerted initiatives. Next week, Secretary of State Kerry and UN Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon will host a meeting on Libya on the sidelines of the UN General Assembly. The EU strongly supports the efforts of the UN Support Mission in Libya, led by Bernardino León, to achieve an immediate ceasefire and bring the parties together around the negotiating table to resume the political process. UN Security Council Resolution 2174, adopted on 27 August, broadened the scope of international sanctions on Libya to include those who work against peace, threaten Libya's stability or security or undermine the success of the political transition.  The EU considers that the legitimacy of the House of Representatives comes from the elections last June. At the same time, we stress the need for the House of Representatives to involve all parties in order to achieve an inclusive agreement. Unfortunately, some of the messages sent and the decisions taken by the House of Representatives itself in recent weeks may have exacerbated the directions rather than building a bridge between them.  Today, some Members of this Parliament are boycotting its work. We have a duty to persuade all Members of Parliament to reach an agreement so that they can play their full part.  We therefore strongly emphasise the need to create an inclusive government, representing all Libyans who wish to accept the rule of law and the democratic process, regardless of membership. As soon as the situation permits, an inclusive national dialogue must be organised. We welcome the work of the Constituent Assembly in drafting the Constitution. We very much hope that the spirit of consensus and constructive dialogue prevailing there will reach the entire Libyan population. We fully understand the concerns of Libya's neighbours. It is important to note the hospitality that Tunisia has offered to hundreds of thousands of Libyan refugees. It is essential that our neighbours and other countries in the region support mediation efforts aimed at an immediate cessation of hostilities and a political agreement.  It is also essential that the parties involved at regional level refrain from actions that can current divisions and undermine Libya's democratic transition. UN Security Council Resolution 2174 should also make the arms embargo more effective.

name: Arnaud DANJEAN
text: on behalf of the EPP group. Mr President, we talked about Ukraine, we talked about Syria and Iraq. At the risk of shocking a little, I think that Libya is currently the country in our immediate neighbourhood that probably concentrates the most security and humanitarian challenges for Europe. The structural fragilities of this country were of course awakened by the circumstances of the fall of the Gaddafi regime in 2011. We must not be fooled, however. These structural difficulties, this fragility of Libya do not date from military intervention and it is not a question of speculating endlessly on the merits of what was done, three years ago or not.  The complexity of the crisis we are facing today, the weakness of the Libyan institutions, the multiplicity of actors mean that there is no solution possible in Libya without a minimum of consultation and coherence in the action of neighbouring countries and international organizations. From this point of view, we can regret the too little coordination between all these actors over the last three years.  The framework of the United Nations was, of course, legally indispensable, but it proved to be very weak operationally and everyone had, in fact, carried out their small Libyan policy - including our Member States - in its corner and without any real consultation. This has been the case, in particular, on the key issue of security structures, security institutions and, from this point of view, the United States, Italy, France, the United Kingdom, Qatar, Turkey, NATO and I do not know who else, each has conducted its policy without real consultation and we are now in a situation of total confusion. To the Confusion in Libya, which should not be excused, that should not be exonerated, has responded to the international confusion, and we have not been able to find a lasting solution. This is worth it, and I would like to mention this in conclusion, for the famous European mission that we have undertaken, the EUBAM mission, border management, border management. This is a key issue. This mission has failed, it must be recognized today, and it must probably be redesigned to produce something that is more in tune with the reality of Libyan complexity today.

name: Ana GOMES
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – From my visit to Benghazi in May 2011, in the midst of the popular uprising against the Gaddafi dictatorship, I retain vivid memory of the meeting with Salwa Bouguiguis, one of the heroines of the revolution and the future of freedom, democracy and progress that she and millions of Libyans and Libyans wanted for her country.  Salwa Bouguiguis was cowardly murdered and her husband kidnapped on June 25 after voting in the last Libyan elections. This tragedy illustrates the spiral of violence and sectarianism that has befell the Libyan people in the last year and calls for the solidarity and urgent action of the international community. Violence is compromising the viability of the state in Libya. And this spiral, if it has much to do with internal rivalries, we cannot ignore that it is also instigated from abroad, either by Kadafist strongholds or by terrorist forces with destabilizing agendas in the region. The priority must be to invest in security and national reconciliation. A ceasefire between rival militias is needed and all parties need to be brought into dialogue. The European Union must impose sanctions on those who put themselves on the sidelines of this process and continue to instigate violence and chaos in Libya. At the Madrid Conference today, alongside humanitarian support, it is essential that the international community and the European Union, in particular, decide to support the training of Libyan security forces, police and armed forces on a national central command to provide security in a region where organised crime with trafficking in human beings, arms, drugs and terrorism proliferates. It's our own safety we're talking about here, too. Libya may be on the verge of becoming a failed state, a sanctuary of armed terrorist networks here on our doorstep, at the gates of the European Union. The European Union must not waste any more time and to provide a mission within the framework of the common security and defence policy, which focuses on assistance to disarmament and reform of the security system in Libya. Libyan dysfunction already has a direct impact on the European Union. The human tragedy and the Mediterranean, which every day becomes more acabrunhante as the disaster that before yesterday victimized 500 desperate. When will we put in place a truly European and supportive mechanism to save lives? I end, Mr President, expressing my admiration and asking for the full support of the European Union for the action of a European, Bernadino León, who was recently appointed special representative of the Secretary-General of the United Nations for Libya and who is doing an extraordinary job of exactly seeking to negotiate the ceasefire and initiate an inclusive negotiation process. He deserves our full support.

name: Mirosław PIOTROWSKI
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by The President of the European Parliament, Martin Schulz, reminded us today of the anniversary of the outbreak of World War II and of the tragic consequences of the implementation of disastrous ideologies. These words should also be a warning in the context of the current serious military tensions, both in the Eastern and Southern Neighbourhood of the Union. One such foci of inflammation is Libya. The acts of violence and aggression observed there may become the start of a civil war, as we note in our motion for a resolution. This war can spread quickly. In addition to providing funding and humanitarian aid, there is a need for stronger involvement of the European Union, as well as the Arab League and the African Union, in high-level international mediation to resolve the conflict.

name: Emmanouil GLEZOS
text: Mr President, was the cause not the regime, the really opposite and unpopular, but the Libyan oil? Let's not forget that and let's not ostrich. That's the truth. Libya's oil, who's taking advantage of it today.

name: Marietje SCHAAKE
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, after the people of Libya bravely defeated the dictator Gadaffi who brutally ruled over them for decades, the recent clashes are no reason for optimism. Various militias are actually cause for grave concern, especially as Islamists have taken Tripoli and its airports. The cases of arbitrary detention, abductions, unlawful killings, torture, violence against journalists and officials and human rights defenders are very troubling, and meanwhile there is hardly any government structure to adequately run the country in crisis. We recognise the House of Representatives, but hope that all parties will engage in an inclusive and constructive dialogue to rebuild stability and in fact to rebuild the country. One important step they should take is to ensure that oil which is still flowing is not sold by illegitimate terrorist groups, and in this sense I emphasise EU-based and international companies’ own responsibility to refrain from purchasing such oil. With such threats at our doorsteps, we need the EU to show more leadership. Globally, we now see a chain of Islamist jihadist militias stretching from Nigeria through the Middle East to Pakistan. So we need more EU leadership to fight jihadist militias, to prevent regional spill-overs and to ensure that the people who flee this violence do not suffer a horrible death by drowning in the Mediterranean. We must seek accountability for the perpetrators of violence and end the impunity with which the most horrific crimes are now met.  Additionally, we should put pressure on those who are externally funding Islamist groups and urge them to stop these toxic activities. Sadly, some of these sponsors are our EU allies. It is time we got to grips with the fact that the instability in Libya directly impacts us. The refugee flows are enormous, and suggestions such the one as by the Dutch Prime Minister that this is merely an Italian problem are inappropriate and no solution. We need European leadership and solutions right now.

name: Pablo IGLESIAS
text: GUE/NGL Group. "Mr President, Franklin Roosevelt said of dictator Somoza: "Somoza is a son of a bitch, but he's our son of a bitch." Do you remember, ladies and gentlemen, when Gaddafi was our son of a? It began to be so from 2000, when it privatized its oil companies to start western multinationals. It was the time when Gaddafi was the friend of Europe who collaborated with manu militari migration policy, as dictators do; it was the time when Gaddafi financed Mr Sarkozy's election campaign and gave horses to José María Aznar. Even in 2011, a month before NATO's intervention, the IMF praised Gaddafi's economic reforms. What happened in March? It happened that the United Nations Security Council, in its 1973 resolution, appealed to the responsibility of protecting civilians and began military intervention, the consequences of which we are now discussing. But that, ladies and gentlemen, had nothing to do with protecting civilians: it had to do with the interests of Western oil companies in the face of the possibility that it was Russian, Chinese and Indian companies that exploited Libya's resources. That is why these three countries abstained in the Security Council. I'm not asking you to stop being what you are, but at least don't lie to people. (He agreed to answer a question posed under the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Regulation))

name: Ana GOMES
text: "blue card" question. – Mr. Iglesias, do you ignore the struggle of the Libyan people to free themselves from the murderous dictatorship of Gaddafi? Because this was the determinant of the revolution. With support, it is true, outside, but there was that struggle: I was there and I saw it with my own eyes, on the front: the boys and girls fighting the dictatorship of Gaddafi. Where are you about this? Have you forgotten everything? Does it all serve to attack the forces that, it is true, yes, have taken advantage of Gaddafi, of this dictatorship of Gaddafi?

name: Pablo IGLESIAS
text: "blue card" response. – Thank you very much for the question, Mrs Gomes. You're right. There were many Democrats in Libya who opposed Gaddafi. But those Democrats who opposed Gaddafi never received NATO support, nor did they ever receive support from UNION countries when Sarkozy's campaign was funded or when Gaddafi became the main ally of the European Union's migration policy. We didn't lie. No intervention was made in Libya to secure the rights of civilians. It intervened exclusively in the economic interests of multinationals. Stop teasing people, Mrs. Gomes!

name: Barbara LOCHBIHLER
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, our group fully supports the resolution and supports the EU in increasing its efforts to counter the escalation of violence and armed confrontation in Libya. In particular we call on the EU to spare no efforts to support the United Nations and other non-military initiatives to settle the current crisis in particular and to step up its humanitarian aid to respond to the plight of the Libyan population. As things stand now, we must state that the European Union has failed to develop and implement a comprehensive strategy for assisting in the post-Gadaffi transition. We deplore the persistent lack of coordination between EU Member States’ policies towards Libya. In the field of security the EU has a limited focus on border and migration management which did not address the root causes of insecurity in Libya. We urge the EU to develop a broad concept for the reform of the security sector in Libya with a special focus on parliamentary oversight of the sector, including strong elements of human rights and humanitarian law training. The EU should further assist in the demobilisation, disarmament and reintegration of former combatants and in the collection and destruction of the many irregular weapons in the country. It should make full use of the Instrument for Stability and Peace with regard to mediation. Even in such a difficult situation as the one now in Libya, it is also absolutely necessary that the EU supports the empowerment of civil society organisations, in particular women’s groups, aiming at finding non-violent solutions to the multiple crises in the country. Finally, let me express grave concern at the fate of migrants, asylum seekers and refugees in Libya whose already precarious situations have further deteriorated. We have ongoing reports on horrific detention conditions for thousands of migrants and refugees – including in government-run centres – and we ask the EU to consider withholding financial support in this sector until this has been investigated. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: James CARVER
text: blue-card question. – Do you have a particular view on the military action that was taken jointly by Egypt and the United Arab Emirates back in August when a military attack was launched against ISIS-style militias in Libya? What I find most striking about this was the fact that Washington and the White House did not receive any prior warning that this military action was going to be taken. Do you agree with me that perhaps moderate Muslim countries are now beginning to look at tackling this on their own rather than listening to the Western approach?

name: Barbara LOCHBIHLER
text: blue-card answer. – My response is that regardless of whether they are from the region or from another region, I think military intervention in another country without the consent of the UN Security Council is against international law. For me the biggest problem is not that the US was not consulted, but that those countries could go ahead and this was not the space for debate at the UN itself.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, just over a hundred years ago, the distinguished MEMBER gaetano Salvemini strongly and rightly condemned the Italian colonisation of Libya, which he called a 'sand box'.  Times are changing, and today Libya is rather a Pandora's box from which blood, oil and tears of despair flow. The acute strategy of Operation Odyssey Dawn, strongly desired by former President Sarkozy, had envisaged being able to cultivate democracy in the country simply by dropped bombs in abundance against Gaddafi, until recently welcome guest in tents in Paris, Rome and other European capitals. Today, however – fatality – we have a fierce civil war and it is difficult even to take account of the factions, all of which are ready to get their hands on Africa's largest hydrocarbon reserves. Was it so hard to imagine, in a country with a hundred and forty tribes and coming out of only forty-two years of dictatorship? But the bill, gentlemen, is paid by the citizens of the Mediterranean countries, together with one hundred and forty thousand desperate migrants. Two thousand five hundred dead have already paid for it this year.  Do we want to talk about the vague promises of Frontex+? It more like the name of a sore throat pill, insufficient to cure an increasingly chronic humanitarian drama, while the Italian sailors of Mare Nostrum risk their lives to save thousands of lives every day. I express my esteem and solidarity to them.  Of course, Italian governments have their faults, but what does the EU do? Does it push for un intervention? Does it jointly take responsibility for combating trafficking in human beings, for rescues at sea, for negotiating incisive agreements with the countries of origin? No, not seriously. Instead, he seems to be just waiting at the window to figure out who the prevailing faction will be, and then rush to naturally rescue the winners. But this crisis and its consequences are attributable to all the Member States, none excluded. Europe must truly be united not only in diversity, but above all in these adversities. Let us prove it by the facts.

name: Janusz KORWIN-MIKKE
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking As an intimidated man, I will not talk about Niger bordering Libya, nor, God forbid, about Nigeria, I will talk about parts of Libya. Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking America's policy of building democracy, especially in Arab countries, has ended in disaster. In Egypt, Afghanistan, Iraq, Syria, Libya, there are hundreds of thousands and millions of corpses everywhere. In monarchies, on the other hand, there is peace and people are not murdered.  Well, in Libya, civil war is practically inevitable, while in the eastern part of Libya, in the former Greek colony of Cyrenajka, there is the possibility of creating an emirate. There is a widely respected descendant of the as-Sanusi family, and of course we do not have the wars to establish it there, but the Arabs believe that we must support democracy, they are afraid of making an emirate. If we were to say that we are not so attached to democracy and that hundreds of thousands of people can be saved by establishing an emirate there, that would be a very beneficial action.

name: Francisco José MILLÁN MON
text: Mr President, the very serious situation in Libya is of great international concern: there is a great deal of violence and acute political division, fragmentation and polarisation. An inclusive political dialogue is needed as soon as possible, as requested by Security Council Resolution 2174, adopted at the end of August. The United Nations plays a very important role, including as a mediator in seeking political solutions. Neighbouring countries and those throughout the region must help. It is very necessary for the neighbours to help prevent the arms trade fueling this violence, which is what the Security Council has been insisting on lately, in this resolution which I mentioned earlier. I welcome the preciseity of a ministerial conference in Madrid today, attended not only by European countries, but also by neighbouring Libyan countries and members of Dialogue 5+5, together with representatives of the United Nations, the European Union, the Arab League, the African Union and the Union for the Mediterranean — the Italian Presidency referred to this meeting earlier. This Conference is a sign of the support of the countries of the region for the Libyan people in this very difficult situation. There is a very serious deterioration which is seriously affecting Libyan citizens and also creating serious problems at the economic level and certainly in humanitarian, security, displaced, etc., and which has very negative consequences throughout the Mediterranean region and, of course, also in the Sahel. The greatest possible international coordination and concertation is needed. I hope that the Madrid Conference will contribute to this concertation and to identify measures that allow a ceasefire, as well as to this peaceful, inclusive political dialogue, which leads to consensual solutions and reconciliation, for a country in serious danger of fragmentation that needs peace, stability and unity. I hope that next week, in New York, at the so-called Ministerial Week of the General Assembly, the question of Libya will remain very high on the international agenda and we will be able to continue to study solutions to this very serious problem.

name: Pier Antonio PANZERI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, allow me to say that Libya is an emblematic case for Europe and the West of what should not be done. In essence, after the military intervention, the situation was allowed to resolve itself, without an idea, a plan for libya's future. Anyone who knows the reality of Libya knows that this could only end up like this, and acknowledging the mistakes today would not be a sign of weakness but of foresight. Now we have to take cover to try to deal with the situation, which, as we know, commits us on three fronts. Firstly, the identification of a path that can lead to democratic stabilisation, a parliament and a government that works, recognized. Secondly, on the terrorism side, because the confusion that has been created in the country offers enormous space for jihadist and terrorist forces. I do not believe that we are in a situation like Somalia' s, but the problems that exist, if not addressed, are in danger of widening and widening.  The third issue concerns the issue of immigration. Libya has always been a country of collection and transit, but today conditions have objectively deteriorated. The many people who have died in the Mediterranean Sea are also the result of the extremely complicated situation in Libya. Woe betide us to underestimate this problem. I believe that Europe must understand, be fully aware that today, more than ever, we need a new initiative on these three fronts as quickly as possible. We shall see what comes out of the Madrid meeting, but there is no doubt that action is now needed and words no longer needed.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: Mr President, the situation in Libya is simply unsustainable, although it may get worse. The Libyan state has ceased to exist and what was once the hope of the Arab Spring has led to frustration and reaction. Therefore, the absolute priority is the restoration of security, without which it is impossible for the dialogue that is trying to encourage, at the Madrid Conference, the United Nations special envoy, Bernardino León, formerly sent from the European Union to Libya. The European Union has its responsibilities, but the international community has to support institutional structures in Libya. It is the only way to generate an independent judiciary, security forces in a position to guarantee it, and a constituent assembly that does its job and brings order where, at the moment, there is only chaos and destruction on the part of the warring factions. But the European Union has to learn from the lessons of dirty realism with which governments of the European Union related to Gaddafi. And this means changing your gaze towards the Mediterranean, the southern border and, particularly, the point of immigration. There are hundreds of thousands of people from the Horn of Africa, desperate, who are trying to reach the border of the European Union. And it is necessary to purge the crimes against humanity being committed by mafia organizations that are attacking human rights in Libya.

name: Vincent PEILLON
text: Mr President, Mr Panzeri has said this, and others have said so before. It is true, as I said earlier, that intervening every time without a political strategy and intervening militarily can create more harm than good, even if it can sometimes be used by both people as a surety at some point. I even hear moral speeches at times.  Now we are in a dramatic situation and I would like to draw attention to one point. Of course, the only solution we have today is to support the political process and the Parliament that emerged from the June elections and, of course, to do so by involving all the regional actors, since they are the ones who are now using Libyan territory to confront each other. To think that we are going to police on our own makes no sense, any more here than elsewhere.  But there is an issue that was raised earlier by one of my colleagues, which is very worrying for Europe, who is talking - and we have done so a lot this afternoon - about human rights. There is the question of immigration, there is the question of the Mediterranean which becomes a tomb for thousands of citizens and in particular citizens who today are taken care of by Mare Nostrum but who we know are essentially based on Italy's action. The solidarity of other European states should be exercised and our passion for human rights should be not just a slogan but a reality in the face of these human lives.

name: Goffredo Maria BETTINI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in the motion that we are debating and which I agree with, I would just like to point out that Libya is currently a powder keg in the middle of the Mediterranean and raises the issue of wars that raise dictators around the world and then leave rubble. The struggling armed factions are creating one of the most serious humanitarian emergencys in the world.  Italy, for geographical and historical reasons, naturally has a special relationship with Libya and is the first European border on which all tensions are discharged. In view of this situation, I believe that the international community must do its utmost to find a political and democratic solution in the country and it would be necessary for the whole of Europe, I stress the whole of Europe, to feel responsible for the consequences of the conflict, starting with the fate of the refugees, desperate and left to their own devices.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking I remember the Arab Spring well. We welcomed and supported her. But what did we get instead of democracy and social justice? Chaos, terrorism, murder, firing for political, national, religious reasons. We have millions of refugees – refugees from Libya, Syria, Iraq. We are talking here mainly about political action. I would like us, together with these actions, to also provide humanitarian aid – after all, winter is approaching – and therefore tents, blankets, warm clothing, food, medicines.  Let us note that we have some surplus food after the Russian embargo. Perhaps this is some kind of zoning method. Children and education – let us take a few thousand students from these exiled camps in the European Union, let us give them a chance to get an education. Let them return to their educated countries, let them rebuild their countries. I think the benefit would be obvious.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: Qegħdin nitkellmu dwar sitwazzjoni li qiegħda bieb ma' bieb magħna, bieb ma' bieb magħna, ma' Malta, minn fejn ejejja jien, imma anki mal-Ewr, sitwazzjoni ta' anarkija sħiħa li għal żal żal ħafna insopaewletament. U kif is-sitwazzjoni fl-Ukraine hija problema tal-Ewropa kollha, is-sitwazzjoni fil-Libja hija wkoll problema tal-Ewropa kollha. L-instabilità li għandna fil-Libja illum il-ġurnata qed tgħin lill-kriminali li jittraffikaw in-nies. Ir-riżultat: traġedji li kellna fl-aħħar jiem b'aktar minn 700 persuna rrappurtati nieqsa fil-Mediterran, aktarx mejta u l-pressjoni ħara fuq il-pajjiżi tal-fruntiera, fuq Malta u anki fuq l-Italja. Għalhekk naqbel li din ir-riżoluzzjoni qiegħda torbot is-sitwazzjoni fil-Libja u l-wasla bla pre大edent ta' immigrant irregolari fi xtutna. Ma jistax ikun li l-Istati Membri jibqgħu jirrifjutaw li jikkoordinaw bejniethom. Hemm bżonn li naraw li l-prijoritajiet identifikati fil-Mediterranean Task Force jitwettqu.  Nappella, għalhekk, flower-komunità internazzjonali biex iva, timpenja ruħha favur soluzzjoni li tassigura l-waqfien mill-ġlied u nħeġġeġ flower-Unjoni Ewropea biex taħdem mal-pajjiżi ewlenin fir-reġjun u tikkoopera fuq kollox mal-Ġnus Magħquda li hija l-forum ideali fejn għandha tittieħed azzjoni dwar il-Libja.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Mr. President, I was in Morocco when the Arab Spring began with the events in Cairo and I was warned by my interlocutors in Morocco that of course this was good, but that the question was how it would end. And that's pretty much how it happens, we often know what we're not going to do, we know what we want, but often we don't know how to do it. Today we have complete chaos in Libya and we need to speak about it completely clearly and we have no solution for Libya.  Malta, Italy, the whole of Europe have big problems. First we need to show solidarity and I am absolutely in solidarity, but we need a new kind of policy, as was a good idea of the Union for the Mediterranean, but which has failed, which today practically does not exist and we have to talk about it, we need a proactive policy for the south of the Mediterranean because if not, everything will be reflected again to the south of Europe, and then of course to the whole of Europe.  And I want to express my great condolences and solidarity in the end with all the victims and families of those who died.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: Mr President, I see an epidemic here of selective amnesia. In the People's Group, I am not surprised; in the Social Democrats, something, although some have already become "social-NATO"... It seems that the situation of extreme chaos was the result of a peaceful transition, as if there had been no military intervention, as if NATO, in violation of international law, had not supported one of the parties.  Does NATO have no responsibility to have turned the country into a failed state? What was the reason for rejecting the African Union initiative that Gaddafi even accepted? Maybe it was oil control? They took responsibility for protecting but it was actually a responsibility to protect oil. We are defending a solution in which it is the neighbouring countries, the Arab League and the African Union that promote a process for the immediate end of hostilities and dialogue between the militias in conflict, an initiative promoted by Algeria, which also rejects new NATO intervention.

name: Benedetto DELLA VEDOVA
text: President-in-Office of the Council (on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission/ High Representative of the European Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy). - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I should like to thank the Members who have spoken. The European Union's message is loud and clear: no military solution can bring lasting peace to Libya. The current crisis can and must be tackled through peaceful negotiations paving the way for the political process. The European mission EUBAM – Libya, which aims to help the Libyan authorities manage their borders, remains ready to resume full operation, as soon as security conditions allow and to adapt, if necessary, the current mission to the new reality that will emerge in Libya. We trust that the mediation efforts conducted by the UN support mission in Libya, with the support of the EU and its Member States through the special envoys, will begin to produce results. The reports received following the latest visits indicate the possibility of a change in dynamics and a growing willingness on both sides to reach agreement on the basic principles that will guide the political process in the future. The international community must devote all its energy to supporting these efforts and complement them, for example, by applying the relevant UN Security Council resolutions and refraining from actions that risk exacerbating tensions. We hope for a positive outcome to today's ministerial meeting in Madrid and the one scheduled in New York. These high-level events at close range, along with others, such as today's debate, show that the world is now looking closely at what is happening in Libya.  The international community is strongly committed to supporting the silent majority of Libyans in their battle for a peaceful and prosperous existence.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: Motions for resolutions to be tabled pursuant to Rule 123(2) of the Rules of Procedure will be announced at a later date. The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday, 18 September 2014.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: The next item is the debate on the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on Israel-Palestine following the Gaza conflict and the role of the EU (2014/2845(SDR)).

name: Benedetto DELLA VEDOVA
text: President-in-Office of the Council (on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission/ High Representative of the European Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy). - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the ceasefire of 26 August, which ended 50 days of terrible violence between Israel and Palestinian groups in the Gaza Strip, was welcomed by the European Union and the entire international community. By putting an end to a cycle of violence that has left more than 2 100 Palestinians dead and 71 dead among Israelis, this ceasefire has made it possible to launch a much-needed humanitarian assistance operation which is now facing considerable difficulties. However, the ceasefire agreement did not guarantee that the previous status quo would be exceeded. This is of fundamental importance, and the various conclusions adopted by the Foreign Affairs Council and the European Council in recent weeks clearly underline this.  What is needed is a lasting solution to the Gaza issue, which will decisively address both the problems of the people of Gaza and those of Israel. A broad political agreement is needed, which will frame the Gaza problem within the framework of a peaceful and comprehensive solution to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. There has never been any doubt for the European Union that Gaza should be part of a future Palestinian state. Efforts are continuing to continue the path taken with the ceasefire agreement of 26 August. On 20 September – within the agreed one-month deadline – Egypt is expected to re-invite the parties to Cairo for important negotiations on the key points that remained unresolved in August. These include calls, on the one hand, from the Palestinian side for the opening of a seaport and the reopening of the airport; on the other hand, on the Israeli side, on the security and demilitarisation of the Gaza Strip. At the same time, the members of the UN Security Council are seeking a consensus on the adoption of a resolution establishing an international framework for normalising the situation in Gaza. There is no denying that there is great uncertainty about the outcome of all these negotiations, but one thing is certain: the EU and its Member States spare no effort in trying to achieve a result that is satisfactory to all the parties involved.  The EU is also mobilising to make a concrete and substantial contribution to the reconstruction of Gaza. Of course, the EU's ability to provide practical assistance is closely linked to the political process I have just described. Political stability will be crucial if we are to be able to provide humanitarian assistance and continue to offer stable support. To this end, it will be crucial for the Palestinian Authority to re-establish in Gaza and take back control of security. EU missions already on the ground (EUBAM Rafah and EUPOL COPPS) could provide a good starting point, provided that the parties reach an appropriate agreement and that the situation in Gaza improves from the point of view of conflict and security.  The European Union calls on the Israelis and Palestinians to choose peace and the resolution of the conflict which has been opposing them for too many years. It is time for the leaders of both sides to take bold decisions, which are necessary to end the spiral of violence and resume negotiations. Rest assured, ladies and gentlemen, that the European Union, with your support, will do its greater to contribute to achieving this objective.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, I would first of all like to welcome the truce reached on 26 August and to underline the very important role that Egypt played in achieving this agreement after seven weeks of conflict. I hope that both sides will remain committed to finding a lasting solution and that Egypt will continue to play a positive role in future negotiations on a permanent ceasefire. I deplore, on the other hand, the fact that the recent conflict has once again caused loss of life and suffering to the civilian population. I express my sympathy to the victims and their families. It is important that the responsibilities for these acts are clarified and, from this perspective, I would like to welcome the fact that the Israeli authorities have committed themselves to examining any credible allegations of Tzahal's actions in the recent conflict and have launched five criminal investigations on this subject. I would also like to note that our joint resolution addresses the humanitarian situation in Gaza at length. This remains very concerning. It is clear that Europe needs to do more to meet humanitarian needs on the ground, and this is where not only political will is needed, but also appropriate financial means. I would also like to point out that in the AFET Committee, where we discussed the Union budget for 2015, there was a very broad political consensus on the idea that financial assistance for UNRWA needs to be increased and we have adopted amendments to this effect. I therefore welcome yesterday's agreement on the establishment of a provisional mechanism to speed up, under the supervision of the United Nations, the reconstruction of the Gaza Strip, while ensuring that construction materials will be used for civil purposes. In the run-up to the DonorS' Conference, which will take place on 12 October, I hope that the Union will contribute substantially to the reconstruction process. Finally, a word about the overall role of the Union. I am pleased that, this summer, Europe has reiterated its readiness to contribute to a sustainable and comprehensive solution that enhances the security, well-being and prosperity of Palestinians and Israelis. We must not lose sight of our common objective of achieving a just and lasting peace in the Middle East.

name: Victor BOŞTINARU
