text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, the resolution to be adopted tomorrow is well balanced. It is once again the result of close and serious work by our political groups, which shows Parliament’s commitment to fighting for and working for peace in the Middle East. Without mentioning the numbers – the damages and losses which are part of the daily tragedy we faced in the Gaza Strip – I would like to make the point that Europe was practically absent, and has not been living up to its duty in the Middle East in recent months, during the USA-brokered negotiations or during the ceasefire. This is a fact of life and it is a painful lesson in terms of what we need to do. Regarding what we need to do, I was inspired by the visit we made to Jerusalem and Ramallah. Firstly, implementation of the ceasefire agreement is fundamental and is also a good basis for the negotiations which will soon take place to address the most important topics on the agenda. Secondly, a successful donors’ conference in Cairo will offer an opportunity for starting the reconstruction of Gaza. Thirdly, the national consensus government of Palestine needs to be empowered to take full control over Gaza, for without that the reconstruction will be in jeopardy. And finally, the role of President Mahmoud Abbas, and his moderating authority to negotiate with the Israeli side, must be strengthened. The most important thing is to work for the peace process. Here our Union, together with the United States and with such important regional actors as Egypt, Saudi Arabia and others, should contribute to the success of the talks. I believe that now is the time for Europe to change from a payer to a player. It was a payer but we have to become a player and I am therefore very happy for the newly designated High Representative, Federica Mogherini, to pay so much attention to the Middle East and to the role of our Union in trying to work for peace in the Middle East. This is the only answer for the region at a time of great instability.

name: Bas BELDER
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Exactly one week ago I paid a working visit to the south of Israel, just a few kilometres from the Gaza Strip. With my own eyes I saw timely discovered and dismantled hamas terror tunnels. The local population in the western part of the Negev Desert has been exposed to Palestinian rocket rains for years. And now this debate on the role of the EU after the last round of fighting between Israel and, let us be honest, islamist enemies of death are in Gaza. What role should the EU play in this inevitable conflict? Well, given that Hamas rules Gaza and is on the official EU list of terrorist organisations, it is obvious that the EU supports the Jewish state in its relentless defence against Hamas with words and deeds. In concrete terms, this means that the EU is making a real effort to achieve a real demilitarisation of the Gaza Strip. Does the Council share this European role as essential? What steps does he intend to take in this essential direction towards a decidedly urgent pacification of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict? In any case, it is of great importance that any European aid to the economic reconstruction of Gaza does not contribute at all to the military reconstruction of Hamas. Finally, an influential role for the EU in the Israeli-Palestinian conflict certainly requires good relations with Israel, including the annual meetings of the Association Council. I very much regret that the High Representative is not here, because she has not held the last two association councils. This is extremely bad for relations between the EU and Israel, which I very much regret as chairman of the delegation for relations with Israel. [The speaker responds to a "blue card" question pursuant to Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure.]

name: Gilles PARGNEAUX
text: "blue card" question. A question to our honourable parliamentary colleague. Can you tell me how many women and children have died during those seven weeks of conflict?

name: Bas BELDER
text: "blue card" answer. – You should ask that question to Hamas, which uses human shields in its struggle to maintain its own power, a method that we are also seeing these days in ISIS. [The speaker responds to a "blue card" question pursuant to Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure.]

name: David MARTIN
text: blue-card question. – Two thousand civilians died in the Israeli bombing, 450 of them children. Do you really think that the European Union should be on the side of a country which is prepared to sacrifice innocent civilians for its own political ends?

name: Bas BELDER
text: "blue card" answer. I would like to remind Mr Martin once again that Hamas has a method of fighting in which the civilian population is used to justify the terror. The organisation makes enormous use of social media and I can assure you that there is careful consideration on the Israeli side before any attacks against Hamas aggression are launched. You have to look at this from both sides. [The speaker responds to a "blue card" question pursuant to Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure.]

name: Sofia SAKORAFA
text: "blue card" question. – I would like to ask my colleague if he knows that the terrorist organisation Hamas, as he says, is the legally elected government of the people of Palestine, Gaza. Should we respect or should we not respect the choices of a people?

name: Bas BELDER
text: "blue card" answer. – I myself attended the Palestinian parliamentary elections in 2006. If the majority of the Palestinian population chooses Hamas' rejection of the two-state solution, then through democracy you call out the mischief about yourself. I find that extremely sad.

name: Annemie NEYTS-UYTTEBROECK
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, we have heard from the Chair of the delegation for relations with Israel so we should not be surprised that his sympathies lie mainly with Israel and the politics of its government. One could share in his sympathy for the state of Israel, but not necessarily in that for the politics of the present Israeli Government. That is something different. When I heard the debate on the numbers of victims on either side, this reminded me of a meeting I had with the chief negotiator for the Palestinian side, Saeb Erekat. At the time I was Minister for European Affairs of my country Belgium. He said to me, ‘Madame, we are drowning in our childrenʼs blood. The Israeli’s and ourselves are drowning in our children’s blood’. Now, that was ten years ago and since then, things have not exactly improved. On the contrary they have got worse, it seems to me. And I would try to encourage us to abandon the arithmetic of death and to engage in the difficult path to peace.  I believe it is very important that in this joint resolution before us today we state that in any case the status quo is unsustainable. If a majority, which I expect tomorrow, approves the joint resolution then I believe this is the first time we have said this so clearly. In other words, just returning to the status quo ante, the situation as it was before the ceasefire was – let us say – interrupted, offers no solution and does not offer a solution to a sustainable new situation. I believe that this is an important statement if this Parliament makes it: it means that we support the efforts of the High Representative, of the Commission and of the Council on the path to peace.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, Israel’s attack on Gaza resulted in the killing of 2147 people, 503 of them little children. These were crimes against humanity under international criminal law and international humanitarian law. Recently, 13 MEPs were refused access to Gaza because Israel did not want us to see destruction there that is comparable to World War II. On fact-finding in the West Bank, we MEPs witnessed the South-Africanisation of Palestine with its apartheid roads, walls and buses. Israel’s violations of international law have been well documented – on six occasions, in fact – by the UN Security Council plus the International Court of Justice. The clearest violations are the illegal transfer of 600 000 Israelis to live in illegal settlements in occupied Palestine, where 170 000 acres of Palestinian land have been confiscated since the Oslo Accord – 1000 acres last week alone. International law imposes a duty on all members of the international community, including the EU, not to recognise as lawful or render aid or assistance in maintaining a situation created by a serious breach of international law. Allowing economic relations with Israeli illegal settlements and importing their products into the EU contributes to the prosperity of those settlements and assists in their development, all of which is contrary to obligations under international law.  Those who make the law must uphold it. The EU must not simply discourage business relations with firms established in illegal settlements and only insist on correct labelling of settlement goods, but must also halt all relations with Israel and prohibit imports of its goods. After all, what happened in Gaza over 51 days makes us look at Article 2 of the EU-Israel Association Agreement, which must be implemented. If it is implemented, that means that the Association Agreement must be suspended.

name: Tamás MESZERICS
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, as a seasoned diplomat told me the other day in relation to the Gaza war: once hostilities stop, the incentives for politicians and other actors to engage in serious diplomacy quickly fade. We have a very small window of opportunity. The title of this joint resolution indicated that the EU, including the European Parliament, was willing to take a bold step towards becoming a serious player in the Middle East peace process. Unfortunately, the resolution does not deliver on its title. I wish I could say it did, but we are unfortunately unable to co-sign it, basically because, unless the forthcoming negotiations in Cairo are broadened to include much more than simply the ceasefire agreement between Israel and the Gaza authorities, there is no hope for any meaningful peace process to be started. Mr Della Vedova said that the EU would leave no stone unturned. I hope he is right about that, but this resolution may be more notable for what is missing from it than for what it says. This is, in fact, a resolution full of unturned stones. My colleague has already mentioned a number of them: I will add two. Accountability for all violations of international humanitarian law by all sides is a minimum requirement for a meaningful peace process. Endorsing the request by the United Nations Relief and Works Agency (UNRWA) for these accountability measures and for humanitarian aid to go unimpeded into Gaza is a minimum requirement, but it did not find its way into the joint resolution. Nor did a minimum request for an ad hoc delegation by this very Parliament to see the facts on the ground. At the end of the day, unfortunately, we cannot support this text, and the window of opportunity is closing very quickly.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, after a war, the victims are counted, we cry, but they do not weigh. Israelis: five hundred and thirty wounded, sixty-nine dead, one child. Palestinians: more than eleven thousand injured, two thousand and four dead, four hundred and ninety-five were children. In the last decade, every conflict has been bloodier and more devastating than the previous one. How long can our consciences tolerate this carnage? Will we remain powerless to the point of no return? No, we can't and shouldn't. If Israel wants to legitimately guarantee its security, as Europeans we must help it to understand that the only way to defeat terrorism and extremism in the Gaza Strip is to guarantee the Palestinian people human rights and social justice. Ladies and gentlemen, we must finally lift the embargo, push for the creation of a port and the reopening of the airport. Let us take responsibility, as the Union, for helping to monitor them by extending EUBAM's action to prevent any illegal arms trafficking. We have an opportunity thanks to egypt's truce, an opportunity for lasting peace. It could be the last one. It will be the last if, as the European Union, we do our duty in these negotiations for two states, for two peoples. (The speaker agreed to answer a blue card question, Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure.)

name: Bas BELDER
text: "blue card" question. – I have a simple question for Mr Castaldo: what do you think about Hamas having executed more than 20 collaborators – as they see it – in public? What kind of movement is this? Isn't this a terror group, and you're silent about it? Are you bothered by your conscience, or not? Israel, and the Palestinian people, stand up to such an opponent!

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Answer to a blue card question. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, thank you for your question, Mr Belder.  I think I have already replied to you during my speech, when I told you that in my personal opinion the cause of terrorism and extremism in Gaza is that there is no social justice. It is a people reduced to poverty, to poverty, to an embargo. Let us solve this problem and it will be the Palestinian people themselves who will put aside extremism and push for a solution, because as one of my colleagues said earlier, they have been washing themselves in their children's blood for years, it is time to put an end to it.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: Mr President, the ceasefire will not stop the aggression of Israel and its allies against the Palestinians. Those who bombed, those who supported the bombings and in an unacceptable way equate the perpetrator 'Israel' with the victim 'Palestinian people', including the European Union, must apologise for the new shipwreck outside Malta with most of the victims being refugees from Gaza. The same forces, in fact, are now self-trying to rebuild the debris left by the Israeli army in Gaza. We denounce the new settlements of Israel, as well as the upgraded political, economic and military relations between the Greek Government and the European Union and Israel. The peoples of the region need to be vigilant and strengthen the fight for solidarity in the Palestinian people's struggle for an independent Palestinian state on the 1967 border with East Jerusalem as the capital, for the immediate withdrawal of the Israeli army and settlers from the occupied Palestinian territories.

name: Michèle ALLIOT-MARIE
text: Mr President, in modern wars it is always the civilian population that suffers the greatest human and material damage.  The conflict between Israel and Palestine has been dragging on for decades causing unnecessary suffering to civilian populations on both sides. And yet, many on both sides, in Gaza and Israel, recall how they once holidaysededes each other's religious holidays. When we talk to these populations, as I did a few years ago, there is a real expectation of progress.  Let us not forget, too, that it is also on the basis of this conflict that terrorism and the pretexts that are put forward by fundamentalists flourish.  The European Union, unfortunately, has been too absent from the solutions to this conflict for several years. It is essential that, beyond our great and pitying statements, we provide concrete and rapid solutions, which is not always the case, to the needs of the civilian population, but also that we carry out genuine diplomatic action to help build the necessary confidence.  On both sides, the most pragmatic are very close to the solutions, which we all know, on the two states and on the guarantee of Israel's security. It lacks the element of trust. Some countries, such as Egypt, are involved, and we also have a role to play. Time is against the civilian population and against us. It's time for us to act.

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: Mr President, a child who is now six years old and living in Gaza has lived three wars in his life. What future, what social or human construction can fit in a situation like that? We have recently returned from Jerusalem and Ramallam. What I have seen this time is the fed-up Palestinian leaders; I have seen a fed-up in people who have been trying for many years to peace, in experienced people, in fighting people; I've seen a fed-up like I've never seen in his eyes. Every day without a solution is an intolerable setback. There are no manicheanisms here, but there are no balances, because it is the balances that are completely unbalance the relationship.  I will reply to Mr Belder: you know that there is an occupying force and a occupied land, and you know that the occupiers have a responsibility to the occupied population, and that the occupied have always had the right to defend themselves. It is the first time in history that the occupiers are those who must defend themselves. A solution must be sought, and the first is reconstruction in the face of destruction; the second is dialogue in the face of bombs; and the third is political momentum. The European Union is completely absent from the solution, that is the truth, and that is why Mrs Mogherini's words must be welcomed in recent days. The European Union is absent and it is also our responsibility to find a solution for the Middle East. And security must be one of the priorities, but security for the citizens of Israel and security for Palestinian citizens, for Deputies of the Palestinian Parliament who are detained and imprisoned without trial and by military courts. Safety for Israeli children, yes; and also safety for Palestinian and Palestinian children. Balance is making the imbalance: what needs to be done is justice and peace.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Mr. President, the recent escalation of violence in the Gaza Strip began as an act of retaliation for civilian casualties, and further inflaming the conflict has claimed many more innocent lives. I therefore consider that our priority must be to protect civilians who are the target of indiscriminate and misunderstanding of the armed actions of both sides in this conflict.  Hamas' military doctrine involves hiding behind the civilian population and deliberately exposing it to a counterattack by Israeli forces. Such tactics are anticivilizing, but unfortunately it is proving successful when it comes to the West's sympathy for the Palestinian issue, so I do not expect the use of civilians for propaganda purposes to stop any time soon. But this does not amnesty the Israeli government, which also allows itself the luxury of neglecting the safety of civilians in this conflict. There's no excuse for killing civilians, an innocent victim is an innocent victim and it doesn't matter which side he's on.  For years, we've been hearing and talking about israeli-Palestinian conflicts, and we can't seem to move toward a solution. It's time to finally put lives, especially children's, above politics.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: When I visited Gaza in the past term, much like a concentration camp, I walked along the beach where a group of children who played football had recently died under gunfire. In the wake of the Gaza tragedy, the resolution we are talking about is a particularly belated expression of our discomfort and helplessness. We are in favour of a lasting settlement of the dispute on the basis of mutual recognition and respect within the two sovereign states within the borders of '67. The aggressive settlement of Palestinian premises is increasingly moving away from this goal. Until Israel and the Palestinians agree on how to live as neighbours, we will accept similar documents and agree on the status quo. This means new casualties on both sides and the destruction of what the European Union and the international community helped to put on their feet after the bombing. The Israeli-Palestinian conflict cannot be resolved with weapons, but with respect for international law and through peace talks without delay.

name: Sofia SAKORAFA
text: Mr President, Israel's latest crime has forced the international community to chant the only viable solution, namely: an independent Palestinian state on the 1967 border, the capital of East Jerusalem, the repatriation of refugees. At this juncture, however, the majority proposes a resolution that is timid, lacking and unspeakable. No mention of settlements, refugees, occupation and resistance. But also distortion of reality. There is no involvement of two sides, there is a conqueror and a resistor. There is no operation "protective ends", but war purges of the occupying army. There are no hostilities in Gaza, there is hard apartheid. Let's at least protect the truth. This is the only way to protect the Israeli people from the legitimacy of their government's crimes.  Ladies and gentlemen, the German people's atonement for the crimes of the Nazis came when they looked the black page of their history in the eye. Let us not allow history to mention Israel's atrocities in terms and words that incubate their repetition. The snake's egg is already among us.

name: Keith TAYLOR
text: Mr President, the Green Group will not be supporting this joint resolution as it fails to properly address either the causes or the solutions to the conflict between Israel and Palestine. Our alternative resolution highlights the gross disproportionality in the violence and the casualties of the Gaza war and holds both sides to account. It stresses the positive roles for both the EU and the new Palestinian unity government as brokers for peace and calls for the lifting of the illegal blockade of Gaza, extension of the permitted fishing zones and opening of the border crossing. Finally, we recognise the danger that Israel’s recent and largest land grab in 30 years represents to the Palestinian interests and to the delivery of the two-state solution. Overall, the joint resolution fails to call for any of those things. It is weak, it is biased, it is factually incorrect and it offers no sense of a Parliament role for the EU’s future role in the aftermath of this vicious war.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the conflict between Israel and Palestine is probably an emblem of stupidity, senselessness, the inability of the human being, as well as the impotence of international institutions and bodies of all kinds and origins.  Ever since I was a child, since I remember, the message that was constantly coming from that part of the world to me was one-way: bombing, destruction, dead civilians, madness, war. An endless war, a war that like any damned war knows and will never know neither winners nor losers, but only and exclusively victims and defeated.  What changes for palestinian or Israeli civilians who have been orphaned, mutilated, homeless, with their lives in tatters and the desert around them, when they learn that the bombs came from the right or the left, from the West or from the East? So many, too many speeches spent in the institutions, beautiful speeches, tear-jerkers, and still many resolutions from the European Union, from the United Nations, but still, at the same time, too many weapons sold to those who use them unconsciously, improperly, insanely. There are thousands of civilian prisoners, many of them held in Israeli prisons, without due process. These include Palestinian ministers and parliamentarians who must be freed. I will conclude by saying that the Union represents the states that have made the history of the world. It has the diplomatic strength to put an end to the conflict and it must necessarily do more to ensure that the most basic international conventions and the principle of peoples' self-determination are respected.

name: Marcel de GRAAFF
text: Despite the ceasefire, Hamas fired another rocket at Israel yesterday. Hamas, ISIS, Al-Shabaab, Boko Haram, they are teeth and claws of a monster called Islam. These teeth and claws need to be ripped out. Hamas must be totally destroyed. The Palestinian Authority has failed to curb Hamas' violence. It has done nothing to allow its citizens to recognise Israel and to coexist peacefully with it. The EU's financial support has not been used to build an infrastructure, but for attack tunnels and benefits to murderers. The EU must no longer be complicit in hamas massacres and human rights violations. The EU should not provide any financial support to the Palestinian Authority, but rather exert maximum pressure to completely defuse Hamas and allow its inhabitants to recognise Israel.

name: Richard HOWITT
text: Mr President, this is our first opportunity to react to the temporary ceasefire in Gaza and, perhaps even more importantly, our last chance to comment, eight days before the deadline to secure a permanent ceasefire and ensure there is no more violence. Today our Parliament must support the EU representative in insisting that there must be no return to the pre-war status quo in Gaza. The humanitarian crisis started not with the 50 days of Operation Protective Edge but with the 2500 days of the blockade which preceded it. The EU must contribute humanitarian assistance, but it must now act politically too, so that we are not trapped inside the seemingly endless cycle of destruction and reconstruction. I encourage and welcome diplomatic engagement with other regional players, further efforts to build Palestinian reconciliation and renewed discussion about a new role for the EU Border Assistance Mission. However, after the failure to follow up on the Goldstone Commission, I hope the inclusion in the new UN investigation commission on war crimes of a lawyer due to be married to George Clooney means that its work will have more substance than the Hollywood dream factory. Five hundred children died in the Gaza conflict and 63 000 people were forced to shelter in just 29 UN schools. The attacks on those schools were called ‘criminal’ by the UN Secretary General and ‘a war crime’ by Human Rights Watch. A child of six in Gaza has now lived through three wars. We should uphold the Palestinian Authority and support it when it says it wants to see in Gaza ‘one authority, one gun, one law’. But, most of all, we should work with both Israel and the Palestinians towards the day when not even one gun is needed to preserve peace and security for all.

name: Jan ZAHRADIL
text: Mr President, Israel has faced and faced attacks in recent weeks on its territorial integrity and on the very essence of its existence. And it is because we have two currents in Palestine, one that wants to agree and is willing to seek a peaceful solution, and the other that does not want to agree and whose sole objective is to destroy the state of Israel, and that is Hamas. Since the European Union is sending quite a lot of funds to Gaza, I believe that it is time to ask the European institutions, the Council and the Commission, for an impact study, whether or not these funds, the humanitarian and development aid we are sending there, have any positive impact on the peace process or not, and whether or not even these funds are being misused by those who then attack the State of Israel with missiles. Because if that were the case, it would be scandalous. The European Union can only support those who really want a peaceful solution, not those who want to continue the war.

name: Teresa RODRIGUEZ-RUBIO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, a lot of data has been put on the table, but one is missing. Do you know how many Israeli civilian casualties there have been in these seven weeks of supposed war? Four. Four! What has happened in Gaza is not a war. What has happened in Gaza is the systematic bombardment of territory isolated by land, sea and air. An Israeli informant, on our last visit, said that a similar precedent was the Warsaw Ghetto. A bombardment in an area without a rear, in an area where there was no safe place. This conflict is a colonial conflict. We saw him in the West Bank. An ethnic cleansing already reported by Israeli historians, such as Ilan Pappé. A colonial regime never leaves its territories if it is not forced. We saw him in South Africa. That is why we are asking for a rigorous international investigation into what happened in Gaza; suspension of the Agreement with Israel—what needs to happen for us to question this Agreement and non-compliance with the human rights clause?; the military embargo—how can we be so hypocritical of crying for the victims and continuing to sell weapons to the State of Israel? banning products from illegal settlements — how are we going to label illegal products? Illegal products are prohibited.

name: Ernest MARAGALL
text: Mr President, tomorrow we will vote again on a motion for a resolution on the situation in Gaza and we will once again see that the European Union, and this Parliament in particular, play a declaratory, secondary role of very serious real influence.  Let me quote four lines of action which should instead define Europe's active, urgent and effective presence in this conflict. Firstly, the sending to Gaza, I would almost say the permanent establishment, of a plural delegation of this Parliament, with the specific mission of entering into dialogue between the two sides, in particular for the lifting of the blockade on Gaza. Second, the urgent reconstruction of all that has been destroyed, something that is part of the obvious responsibilities that the State of Israel must fully assume. Thirdly, all actions contrary to human rights must be transferred , and Europe must intervene – to the International Criminal Court in The Hague. Not to impunity protected by our silence! Yes to accountability and to address the clarification of responsibilities! In the meantime, the existing Association Agreement between the European Union and Israel must be frozen. In any case, any supply of weapons must be banned altogether. Fourthly, decisions such as those of the new settlements envisaged by the State of Israel, which take away the possibility of two states and fatally bring us closer to a new armed conflict, must be avoided at all costs, and Europe must intervene.

name: Udo VOIGT
text: Mr. President! I wonder what else needs to be done to ensure that double standards are not applied here in this Parliament? So if we look at what we heard yesterday about Russia, Ukraine and violations of international law: imagine Russian bombers bombing Kiev or another Ukrainian city, attacking 244 schools, attacking 500 children, hundreds of women and families. What would happen in this Parliament then?  And the same thing that would have happened in this Parliament should actually happen now, when it comes to Israel, so that calm can finally return. It cannot be the case that a power always escapes with impunity and with impunity only with explanations. If you already believe that sanctions make sense, then they should also be carried out against Israel. It is so beautifully stated in the title of the resolution: 'Israel and Palestine after the Gaza conflict and the role of the EU'. It should be correct: 'Israel and Palestine after the Israeli massacres in Gaza'. Then measures would have to be taken, not just declarations.

name: Vincent PEILLON
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, is there still hope for peace when we meet the Israelis when we meet the Palestinians - I was there twice again this year? This is doubtful, especially among the younger generations. Is it up to us, through speeches that are taking sides for one or the other, to spoil what could be, after this tragedy, an expectation of negotiation? I do not believe that and I do not believe that our resolution on two extremely concrete points should be underestimated today.  Fatah's president, President Abbas, cannot travel to Gaza. So, there is still a question for the negotiation: who are the interlocutors? We must succeed in the reconciliation of the Palestinians, it is not done. And the first thing we can do to help - there is the problem of the salaries of civil servants rather than going into big speeches - is to determine how we, the European Union, can first bring a solution, in the coming days, to Palestinian reconciliation. Because in Gaza, even the Palestinian Democrats cannot enter today. Secondly, and this is in our resolution, the European Union is available to ensure border control and to say that security is guaranteed. Here we have the condition of trust, which was earlier proposed by our colleague, which would, of course, allow us to return to the settlements and the embargo. But until we move forward, very concretely, on these two points, namely the interlocutor in Palestinian reconciliation and border control - some of them boast of rebuilding the tunnels already - there will be no peace solution. Let's focus on the peace solution.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: The Palestinian conflict in Gaza has already cost many lives, and I want to condemn this unequivocally. However, we must clearly name the cause of the escalation of tensions and condemn the attacks on the State of Israel. Hamas does not warn the population of attacks, on the contrary, it urges them to stay at home and even put them on the front lines. Hamas hides rockets in schools and hospitals, "forcing" Israel to attack these civilian buildings, in which women and children are present.  One renowned Czech psychiatrist characterized this as israel protecting its people with rockets and Hamas protecting its missiles. The response must also be appropriate on the part of Israel, but we must take into account the overall context, although I think that Israel has also exaggerated this in this war.  The European Security Strategy 2030 clearly declares: the strategic priority for Europe is the resolution of the Arab-Israeli conflict. Without it, there is little chance that other problems in the Middle East will be solved. Resolving this conflict is a key prerequisite for facing the threat of terrorism. I therefore call on the EU to make peace efforts to stop the violence in Gaza. But I am aware that civilian casualties are also significantly damaging to Israel's image in the world.  At the same time, however, I am terrified by the dentling anti-Semitism in Europe. Hatred of Israel is openly transformed into hatred of Jews. Angela Merkel said there was not a single Jewish institution left in Germany that would not have applied for police protection lately. We all have a duty to stand up against anti-Semitism and not allow it to spread. (The speaker agreed to answer the blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure).)

name: Teresa RODRIGUEZ-RUBIO
text: "blue card" question. – Your Honour, you said that Hamas does not warn the people of Gaza before the bombings and that is why so many civilian casualties have been caused. Do you know that the Israeli newspaper Haaretz has recently published its own telephone communications with the citizens of Gaza, notifying them five minutes in advance that they had to leave their homes? Do you know that it was they themselves who watched the citizens of Gaza as they entered and left their homes and gave them five minutes to vacate entire buildings?

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: answer to the question posed by raising the blue card – Colleague, do you think that 5 minutes is enough to escape from a rocket coming out of nowhere? I said that Hamas does not warn its population of attacks either and, on the contrary, hides them in schools and hospitals, where rockets are also placed. That's what I said. And I think Israel is warning the civilian population. So Hamas is provoking conflict.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: Mr President, it is important to remember, by the way, that the Palestinian conflict has lasted since 1947 and therefore to put Hamas at the root of the problem is to omit history itself.  We were, together with several comrades, in Palestine at the beginning of the month, and we were able to witness the oppression of a people by the Israeli authorities. We have been able to observe the complete disproportion of means that lays down any theory of a supposed war between two parties that harm each other.  The Palestinian people, and ourselves, and all those who believe in this peace process are firmly convinced that this solution can only come out of the deadlock with the end of political, military and financial support from the United States and the European Union to Israel. We call on the European Union to respect the commitments signed on the peace process and to apply the clauses of the association agreement with Israel which oblige both sides to respect human rights.  The Palestinians have been waiting too long. Let us recognize once and for all and work to recognize the State of Palestine according to the borders of 66 and with the capital in East Jerusalem. (The speaker agrees to answer a question under the "blue card" procedure in accordance with Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". The general problem is not only between Israel and Gaza, but the problem lies throughout the Middle East. We had been sitting together before, and the subject of the Middle East was also discussed. What do you think of us simply taking responsibility for ourselves? Because the Palestine you are talking about also includes Jordan, including other parts. We have refugee camps in Jordan and Syria. Hundreds of children have died of starvation in Syria. I have not seen this statistic in you yet. These are UN camps where we can take responsibility. What do you think of us acting through the UN, taking responsibility there and creating better conditions for the Palestinian refugees there?

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: Response according to the "blue card" procedure. " I fully agree. The right of palestinian people to return to the occupied territories is one of the issues that has to be at the heart of the negotiation, and this has been mentioned several times in the meetings we have had with organisations.  Now, let's not mix it up, let's not complicate it, and then everything is the same. Let us just acknowledge what is written, apply what is in the Treaties, and make the European Union condemn Israel, because we have an Association Treaty that is not being respected, because Article 2 is not being respected because of Israel's human rights violations.  They're concrete things, they're boycotts, no more selling arms to Israel... They're very simple things. Weapons that were used to kill children... We have to recognize this and take concrete measures, while considering the complexity of the problem, but without paralyzing our action.

name: Margrete AUKEN
text: Mr President! I think this debate and this resolution are one of the most disheartening things we have had.  After the terrible war, we might actually have hoped that Europe - the European Union - would now come together to try to play a role and use the forces we actually have. After all, it was gratifying that the Council said that we could not return to the status quo.  What happens next? Nothing! We get almost nothing. We will have a resolution that is nothing. The status quo is that we cannot return to the status quo in Gaza as if it were just a matter of alleviating a little on the siege. I really believe that this is the chance we have to be able to talk forward with some credibility about a two-state solution. I have done it for all the years and I have fought for it, but now I do not see how I can speak with some honesty to my partners in Palestine and in Israel, the peace wings in Israel, and say anything that sounds credible when they can see that, even in this appalling situation where the United States has given up - the United States has clearly given up - the cards are left on the cards. , shrugs, keeps paying - we are payers not players - we're not here to do anything.  I think we need now to change the language and speak clearly and honestly and say: Okay, there is no possibility of a two-state solution. Now we must fight for a democratic one-state solution, but I fear that it will be a disastrous situation.

name: Boris ZALA
text: As has already been mentioned here, the EU is present in dozens and dozens of different activities with regard to Israel, Palestine and the resolution of the situation in the Middle East, but we have already stated this here by many. It's not enough. What the EU is doing is still little. The EU is not a sufficient or powerful player in shaping the whole of the Middle East.  I think that the EU as a whole, and not its individual states, must use with full commitment all the levers at its disposal to deal with this situation. It has to be said that we are shouting, shouting, adopting resolutions, but in reality we have not been able to curb terrorist activities, be it Hamas or Hezbollah, and we have also failed to stop the Israeli Government from building illegal facilities.  Realistically, we're unsuccessful, let's be clear. This is a huge challenge, particularly for the Office of the High Commissioner of the European Union, the Office – perhaps even for the new line-up that will come in order to draw up a real European action plan for peace in the Middle East. I stress the European state, not the individual nation states.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: Mr President, in the face of the violence of the facts, the war crimes committed in Gaza, the ends of what the occupied, colonized Palestinian people are enduring, denied in their most basic rights, there is no need - I think I should add to this by the violence of words.  But our responsibility still requires us to say that the international community and Europe have no excuse. You see, in other times, it was possible to say "we didn't know", but here we knew and we let it happen. We know what is happening in Gaza now and we continue to turn a blind eye.  However, during our trip to Jerusalem and Ramallah, we saw among the Palestinians that there is always a expectation of Europe, because, it is true, it is from Europe that a new impetus can come today provided we believe in our diplomacy. And I will end with one word: provided that we finally stop making the Palestinians the hostages of a european bad conscience on which Europe's barbaric history is atone.

name: David MARTIN
text: Mr President, for the third time in a decade we will contribute to the rebuilding of Gaza after a conflict. The chronic cycle of violence and violent deterrence has to end, we are all agreed on that, but I have to say that the words we heard from the High Representative’s representative and the resolution that we are going to pass tomorrow will make not the slightest difference to the situation in Gaza. Like many others who have spoken, I believe the only solution is a two-state solution, but the combination of illegal Israeli settlements in occupied East Jerusalem and the West Bank and the closure of the Gaza Strip makes it near impossible to achieve this. In fact, every day, every action by the Israelis takes us further and further away from a two-state solution and from a peaceful settlement. I agree with other colleagues who have spoken – Ms Anderson said it first I think, but others too have mentioned Article 2 of the EU-Israel Association Agreement – in saying that, until Israel shows it is clearly determined to move down a path of peace, we have to suspend that Association Agreement. We have to ensure that the guidelines on EU money going into projects in the Occupied Territories are fully implemented. We have to make sure that goods from the Occupied Territories do not enter the European Union. Until Israel gets the message that the EU is prepared to act it will not listen to our words.

name: Marisa MATIAS
text: Mr President, more than 2000 people have died because they are Palestinian, more than 10 000 have been injured by the mere fact that they are Palestinian, because there is an occupation, an occupation where crimes against humanity have been committed. Crimes against humanity have to be tried here and anywhere in the world.  There was a colleague who said in the room that they would be investigated by the Government of Israel. Are you serious? Israel is the defendant! Israel has to sit in the dock! No court works with the defendant as a judge! That's unthinkable.  But this debate, this debate is about the role of the European Union. The European Union has been able to do for a long time. The European Union must no longer be an accomplice. You cannot write on paper that you do not recognize the occupied territories and do not suspend the association agreement and do nothing to counter that and keep Israel in the state of exception.  The European Union cannot be cynical. Every month in this Plenary we hold debates on the urgencies of crimes against human rights and against humanity. Every month in this plenary we cry tears for human rights crimes. This is the most visible of all, the greatest shame of the international community. Let's stop being cynical, let's stop being part of the problem.

name: Maria ARENA
text: Mr President, the situation of the people and Palestinians in Gaza is indeed dramatic and has been said on several occasions. In general, the situation of Palestinians in Palestine has been dramatic for years. The violence inflicted on them by the Israeli government in recent months has put them in a situation that is no longer dramatic, but in a serious humanitarian situation.  And in the face of this serious humanitarian situation, the Union must respond. It must, of course, respond urgently to the humanitarian needs of the people of Gaza. But it must also and above all - and I am glad to see that the situation of the status quo cannot be the starting point of the discussion - to favour the substantive agreement, this agreement of two peoples, two States, which has suffered many failures and for which Europe has often been sidelined from the negotiations.  Europe must therefore, for me, resume this part of diplomacy. It must, of course, in this agreement guarantee Israel's security, but who is putting this at stake? But today, we don't talk so much about the situation of Israel's security, we talk more about the security situation of the Palestinians. For these Palestinians, of course, there is something important: it is the human rapprochement between the Palestinians in Gaza and the Palestinians in the West Bank. That is what we need to work on as well.

name: Anne-Marie MINEUR
text: Today I received an answer to my question on Gaza on 27 July. You are not going to do anything about the permanent destruction of Gaza, except by expressing your commitment to human rights. Boy, that'll help. What are you going to do? Wearing t-shirts with "I love human rights"? According to Reuters, the latest war has resulted in a loss of EUR 6 billion, two and a half times Gaza's gross domestic product. The country is in ruins, one in ten inhabitants has been killed, injured or on the run. Everyone is waiting for the next war. That is unacceptable and it requires much more than just an aneaves. Israel must apply international law, in particular the fourth Geneva Convention, which deals with human rights in occupied territories. Applying international law is a duty, not a political choice. We need to step up the pressure. Suspending the Association Agreement is the strongest means.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: Mr President, the loss of human life and damage to properties in this conflict has been shocking. What is even more shocking is how little influence we in the EU have been able to yield. Despite the fact that we are Israel’s largest trading partner and Palestine’s largest aid donor, we have been virtually absent from the Palestinian conflict.  We can – and need to – do more to find a permanent solution in this long and ongoing conflict. We should not tolerate the collective punishment of Palestinians. We should therefore demand that Israel open Gaza’s borders. Israel must halt and withdraw from all illegal settlements, which are currently undermining the two-stage solution. We must also support the investigation of war crimes. Failing this, we should suspend relations under the human rights clause in the EU-Israel Association Agreement and we should stop pretending that Israel follows international norms. If we need to, we should consider imposing sanctions against Israel. That includes military sanctions as we have done against Russia.

name: Gilles PARGNEAUX
text: Mr President, I have been the last of this debate in this Chamber for an hour now. I must say, being the last one, that the debate we have been having since earlier really gives me a bitter taste. A bitterness because I heard from prosecutors on both sides, I heard going to war on both sides as well. And I have heard few messengers of peace in this debate. However, I believe that we are a large majority in the European Parliament who want peace and show that there is indeed a balanced voice to say stop to what we experienced during this week when more than two thousand children, women, especially on the Palestinian side, were massacred.  We also know that at the gates of this region we have jihadist terrorists, whether it is Da'esh in Iraq, we talked about it earlier, but also al-Nusra in Syria, but also in Egypt with the supporters of Jerusalem.  We see that the only solution is reconciliation, it is to find the voices of peace, to finally find a credible voice, a credible diplomatic policy of the European Union and I, that is what I am asking for. Let us return to Europe's initiative, to the Oslo Accords, because there is a possible basis both vis-à-vis Israel and Palestine.  My colleague Vincent Peillon has put on the table a number of proposals. Well, I hope that not only will we vote overwhelmingly on this resolution, but that finally a large majority in this Chamber will be able to find the way to peace.

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: Every few years, the state of Israel kills and injures 10,000 Palestinians and destroys Gaza to the ground. Why? Because you can. It seems to him that there are no consequences. I ask the Representative of the European Council here about the following. Question one: what is the European Union doing to make war criminals criminally liable? Question two: what is the European Union doing to make Israel liable for damages and not for the EU taxpayer to rebuild what Israel is destroying over and over again? Third question: it is quite clear that Israel regularly and continuously violates, in particular, its second paragraph, the Second Article of the Association Treaty between Israel and the European Union. When will this contract finally be suspended?

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: Mr President, yesterday, during the debate on the Agreement with Ukraine, we heard in this House words, the truth, very bombastic on the part of both the Commissioners and the honourable Members or President Schulz himself, such as: 'We are laying the foundations of the law' or 'Could we have imagined that the right of the strongest was supremacy over that of the weakest?' Well, here's what's going on.  And this afternoon, in relation to the situation in Iraq and Syria, we heard the same thing again. I ask myself a question, ladies and gentlemen: why does the European Union practice this double standard, this hypocrisy, with Israel? The Government of this country does not respect international law in the least, nor the judgments of the Hague Tribunal, nor human rights, nor the treaties or agreements it signs, not even borders. He commits crimes against humanity, steals his lands and houses from the Palestinians. Kill, stop and imprison with total impunity. Meanwhile, the European Union looks the other way or at other interests that are not so legitimate and rather spurous. In Gaza, now, there has been genocide, and it is an open-air prison. No one can get in or out, according to the United Nations Agency itself. They don't even allow humanitarian aid. Thirty-three deputies are administratively detained. You know what that means.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: Mr President, 'passivity', 'complex', 'paralysis', 'fear', 'slowness', 'absence' are words which describe, once again, our Union's attitude to the massacre in Gaza this summer. I do not deny that rockets from the Strip are an act of violence, but I do dispute that the way to deal with this phenomenon is to bomb schools, murder children and cynically call so much suffering "collateral damage". Between 12 and 16 October 2006, in the midst of the Blockade of the Strip, I visited the Ramallaa headquarters of the Palestinian Parliament and spent a week walking through that wound that bleeds three hours by plane from Strasbourg. I understood that without an outside umpire worthy of such a name, things could not go on but worsening. Yes to the solutions to achieve peace! but, out of humanity, out of solidarity, it is required that we demand from Israel the same respect for basic human rights as we demand from other countries with fewer godparents. It's a question of dignity, credibility and justice.

name: Benedetto DELLA VEDOVA
text: President-in-Office of the Council (on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission/ High Representative of the European Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy). - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, thank you to the members who have spoken. The European Union supports peace and democracy throughout the Middle East region and makes a firm contribution to ending the Israeli-Palestinian conflict which, as long as it remains unresolved, will continue to undermine peace and security throughout the Middle East and along the Union's southern borders.  The recent outbreak of violence in Israel and the Gaza Strip cruelly reminds us of the urgent need to do so. Events show that there will be no definitive cessation of violence, no lasting peace, until the aspirations of the Palestinians to have their own sovereign state and the aspirations of the Israelis for security are fulfilled, through a comprehensive, negotiated peace based on the coexistence of two states. Together with its partners in the international community and the region, the European Union will continue to call on Prime Minister Netanyahu and President Abbas to engage in genuine negotiations in good faith and work together to achieve a lasting solution to the conflict. The EU is called upon to play an important role in this context and intends to continue to do so in the critical weeks and months ahead.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: Motions for resolutions to be tabled pursuant to Rule 123(2) of the Rules of Procedure will be announced at a later date. The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday, 18 September 2014.
